Review title: A must see film... Brilliant Sci-Fi drama
Review_body: My review and slightly spoiler-ish... So, you've been warned.The premise: In 2027, as humankind faces the likelihood of its own extinction, a disillusioned government agent agrees to help transport and protect a miraculously pregnant woman to a sanctuary at sea where her child's birth may help scientists to save the future of mankind.The premise was enough to peak my interest, for a simple reason: I enjoy seeing peoples fantasy of what the future brings and it usually poses a lot of what if questions, which make for great discussion. However, when I saw a commercial that said, "Blade Runner for the 21st Century", I knew I needed to see this immediately. Blade Runner is one of my all time favorite films and, really, watching Daryl Hannah run around in skimpy clothing fighting Harrison Ford should be on a list of things you should see before you die. Not to mention that its one of two movies Rutger Hauer was in that you should actually care about (The other is The Hitcher).Director Alfonso Cuaron is responsible for a few other films you might of heard of, such as Great Expectations (A films whose fault lies in having very proper dialogue in a modern setting, but otherwise a good watch), Y tu mama tambien (Which is a good watch) and Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (My favorite one visually). He does a great job with direction on this film and chose his shots very carefully (The cinematography really takes center stage in this film, but Ill get very carefully). Not to mention, he really got A+ acting out of all of his actors. Its very rare to see a director do that. I cannot point out one actor who consistently was not directed and did not act well.Clive Owen was really great in this role is probably his best instance of acting. along with Closer. Secretly, I was wishing the Converse would come out and he would get into a gunfight, but it didn't happen. His character in this film is very alone and just drifting through life in the beginning of the film (Apathetic). However, as the film progresses, his out-view on life changed and he becomes very concerned and very compassionate (Something he was the exact opposite of in the beginning of the film). Also, hes not an action hero in the film (I happened to think the trailer made out to be in a round about way). He has no fighting skills, no guns, no bombs, not even a plan (The guy tries to jump-start a gearshift car while being given chase).He accomplishes a much greater goal by doing small, insignificant things that at the end, are really part a plan he came up with on the spot.Claire-Hope Ashitey as the pregnant women in question, Kee, fit her role very well and hopefully, well be seeing her in more films. Michael Caine was great Jasper, a pot smoking hippie type. The only character I didn't like in the whole film was the white guy with the dreads (I cant remember his name). He was just a douche. But, at least he was meant to be one.The cinematography of the film really is the centerpiece. The atmosphere created by the director and the photography is second to none. The Apocalypse-like future never looked so desolate and depressing. The long shots presented at the end of the film were an amazing feat to accomplish, both in driving the films climax and as a technical achievement. The amount of choreography and rehearsal put into making these scenes is mind-boggling.After I have basically given this film the equivalent of a rim job in this review, I have some minor qualms with the film. First off, Julianne Moore did a good job in the film, but her skin color. I mean, perhaps she was so pale because she meant to symbolize martyrdom (Because of her white like qualities=innocence), but everyone else in the film seems to have so much color and she looks like a sock puppet with red hair. It just urked me. In the grand scheme of the film, not a big deal but it just bothered me. The thing that did urk me and is a more valid complaint is against one of the long shots at the end of the film. I felt that the first long shot of Theo outside of a apartment building was meant to be the first in a series of long shots that were put in place to make you feel like you were watching a army newsreel. Fair enough. But, when someone gets shot, the lens gets sprayed with blood and it stays there, streaking down the lens for the rest of the first long shot. It was just out of place. The idea of shooting it like this was a good idea, but not just for a sequence, it should have been done like this the whole movie. It interrupted my suspension of disbelief for the film and just took me out of the universe the film had set up for me.Overall, I give this film a 9.5/10. I highly recommend it, it truly is a great sci-fi drama.

Review title: Boring, stupid and the list goes on
Review_body: Please, everybody rating on IMDb stop having a field day with any movie slightly "original". I could make an original movie about a dog with two heads that eats children and excretes goblins but that by no means would make a good movie. My point being, the premise of Children of Men is promising, and indeed if directed and written differently could have made for a very interesting, original film. Unfortunately, Children of Men fails to do this in any regard. I will list just a few of the infuriating mistakes made throughout this film:1) Children of Men, despite being made in 2006, assumes that the United Kingdom (and other parts of the world) are not civilised developed societies. For example instead of assuming that in such a catastrophic situation the world would turn to science, new ways of creating life, cloning, improving in vitro fertilisation etc etc etc, the film of course creates a world of chaos in which the educated population turn to a fascist regime. Granted, jobs would be lost amongst teachers and there would be less business because of a loss of demand but no way would the world come to a hault, and even worse, become a warzone within the first 18 years. Science. Unlike most other futuristic films, this film entirely lacks science. Explanation. Discovery. Nothing.2) Why didn't they make the baby public? Considering the adoration for the youngest person alive, despite being described as a "wanker" by Jasper, you would surely think that they would cherish new life in the same respect (which is demonstrated in the penultimate scene as the soldiers stand back and make way for the child).3) Why would the soldiers not take in the child and create a safe place for it?4) Why was the UK the only place that had "survived"? Although in my frank opinion, it had not. Despite being set in the future it was drab, there had clearly been no developments in technology, for example the bus which was a standard ARRIVA 2002 (most likely).5) No character development, don't become attached to any of the characters, lack luster performances6) No explanation for why women can't have children in the first place?7) THERE IS NO PLOT. It's basically a chase from near beginning to end of a man and pregnant woman in tow, with everyone involved being killed at some stage along the way, and yet miraculously she survives through gun-shot central! It is never eluded to that the baby is going to bring hope to humankind, never suggested that scientists are going to be able to collate research from the "miracle".8) Worst ending to a film ever. Well, with the exception of the Wicker Man. That film left me reeling at the end. But this ending does not even provide a solution! There is no equilibrium! IT JUST ENDS AND YOU DON'T EVEN KNOW IF HE IS DEAD OR IF THE HUMAN RACE IS GOING TO BENEFIT OR WHAT THE ORGANISATION IS. IT'S. JUST. SO. MADENNING. IT. MAKES. THE. WHOLE. FILM. POINTLESS.WHAT A WASTE OF MY TIME.

Review title: Horrifc visionary of the future of mankind
Review_body: Children's laughter, children's cries. These have all vanished as Alfonso Cuarón tells us a story of the possibility of women being infertile by using a gritty, war torn backdrop with an unlikely saviour. I completely took this movie word-for-word as I watched it; I couldn't sit back and not pay attention because I was immersed into the fallen nation of a post apocalyptic 2027 because of the solid acting of Owen, Caine and Moore. The cinetography played an important role in the film as well, it played you. It played the man watching Owens character struggle through London's brilliantly remastered city to the shanty towns of the English coast because of the natural progression of the cameras movement, it was so natural. I really thought Cuarón paid close attention on Britain's society, it was so plausible, it brought a new definition of a British stereotype when he made the sub characters to be so diverse, it could almost bring fourth a possibility for this likelihood to actually happen. I always thought the achievement of capturing the heart of a viewer was so hard to master, the expression given on the first child born in over 18 years was simply remarkable, I gave heart in hand as I witnessed the scene of two opposing forces to stop their conflict and bow down to a newborn child. The film was executed perfectly bringing both a scary crisis of the future and an epic struggle to solve it. 9/10

Though the plot sounds a little bit gimmicky, as many 'in the not-too-distant-future' films can be, Alfonso Cuarón's Children of Men is one of the best films I've seen for a long time. The central idea revolves around a future where, for the last 18 or so years, no babies have been born; all women seemingly, are unable to conceive. Clive Owen plays Theodore, a quiet sombre man who is going through the motions, and seemingly has little to say about the sad state of the world around him, a world riddled with terrorism and run by a Government with a hard-line on immigrants. Theodore is snapped out his reverie by Julian (Julianne Moore), ex-wife and member of guerrilla like resistance group who incredibly, have with them a young pregnant woman Kee. The discovery of the pregnant Kee by the resistance group doesn't necessarily mean all is suddenly well in the world, some in the resistance group see the pregnant woman Kee as a political tool, a means to bring credibility to their cause, rather than savior of the human race. On the other hand Kee mustn't fall into the hands of the Government, the plan being to get her safely to something called 'The Human Project'. The idea of the entire human population being infertile, though central to the plot, is not exactly what I would say the film is about. Infertility seems to serve as the catalyst for a world gone crazy, and also compounds the pain held in Theodore's past. The portrayal of an over zealous Government intent on rounding up every immigrant is more loaded than the problem of infertility, and quite frightening too. At one stage Theodore finds himself inside a detention zone for immigrants, which has an eerie resemblance to the detention of Jews in a section of Warsaw during WWII. (Not to mention the current state of immigration detention in my own country of Australia).Visually the film is quite stunning; there are some impossibly long takes that would have taken ages to set-up again if any of the actors were to stuff up. I read another users comment that it reminded them of Half-Life 2, and there are scenes which make you feel like you're in a first person shooter. Wisely, Cuarón doesn't try to explore the reasons or science behind the infertility, choosing instead to set up the plot and steam ahead rather than get caught up in an explanation. This way you seem to forget that the plot might possibly be absurd. The depiction of technologies in 'not-too-distant-future' is also quite realistic though not overstated to the point that they become distracting from the plot. Performances are fantastic all round, Michael Caine is memorable as the ageing hippie Jasper, Clive Owen too has really grown on me as an actor, Julianne Moore as always is in fine form, and the underrated Chiwetel Ejiofor whom I keep seeing in a heap in films lately, continually impresses as an actor, providing a solid performance as Luke, one of the resistance fighters. It's hard to categorise this film but I think that's why it's so entertaining, taking aspects of Sci-Fi, action, drama, even war and mixing into a stunning film.

There's nothing I like better than a good dystopic and this pic has its dystopia down pat. Set in a near future that has seen the death of the world's children and a pandemic of infertility the film moves deliberately forward to the inevitable great hope, about which I'll say no more, across a sad grayscape of loss and despair and survivor's guilt and survivor's humor.I was so happy to see Michael Caine's jolly little performance here because, while he's always an asset (except in movies such as Bewitched which appear to render assets an impossibility), I was beginning to wonder if he still had any life, any vibrancy left in him after seeing him in some of his recent, more quiet roles.I was also extremely impressed (and relieved -- because I always want very much to like the movie I'm watching, after all) by the fact that this film, while out of necessity relying on certain conventions of the action and science fiction genres manages, when some of its protagonists are "on the run" to avoid devolving into the usual chase/fight/wisecrack scenes as too many potentially good films do (The Island, for example, which peaked early and went south fast.), but instead shifts gears during the fugitve segment to resolve the pursuit by way of a (correctly) dreary sequence of urban combat on a near-documentary level of reality suffused with the sense of a clumsy, desperately stumbling struggle to live and maybe live better.I'd like to tell you why I liked the ending, but I don't like spoilers when they can be avoided, but I will say that I like both types endings to pictures with dystopian settings. I like a hopeful dystopia if it's accomplished correctly, without hypersentimentality because such a work causes me to think: Yes, that's us, it's bad, but somehow we'll always make it because of the potential that's inside each and every one of us. And I like a hopeless dystopia, if it's accomplished correctly and without excessive heavy-handedness because such a work makes me think: Yep. That's us. We've screwed things up to the point where everything we do to try to make things better can only screw them up more and sooner or later we'll be the death of us.Anyway, I liked this film because it made me think: That's us.

Excellent movie. There are very few bad things I can say about this movie.Brief Summary on the movie.*POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD (minor if any)* Children of Men is set in a bleak post-apocalyptic world where women can no longer procreate. This movie takes place in London, which has become a sort of fascist ruled state, having a strict no immigration policy. All immigrants are treated quite harshly and given little or not rights. A terrorist group known as the Fishes (which fight for equal human rights for immigrants) are attempting to transport the pregnant woman, Kii, to the Human Project.*END (potential) SPOILERS* The casting is excellent. Clive Owen gives an outstanding performance as a former activist soon to become deeply involved in aiding the first pregnant woman in 18 years. With other supporting actresses/actors such as Julian Moore and Michael Caine, you already know that whatever you end up thinking of the movie, the acting is still top notch. Music is well done and/or well chosen, with several songs that help suit the mood. The atmosphere of this movie was extremely well done (as in my opinion, it seems quite the task to create such a bleak world, and have actors convey a convincing disillusioned state at the fact that humans can no longer procreate).Children of Men offers a high tension, high suspense thrill ride coupled with immensely engrossing and well done action scenes that could be described for lack of better words as "meaningful". This movie steps above the bar set by typical action movies (involving often pointless action scenes with underdeveloped characters) and keeps you wanting more. Characters are easy to attach to (or easy to hate, depending), allowing you to almost feel what they feel in a sense. A highly recommendable film, as long as you don't mind movies of a bleak nature.Also! This movie could easily be compared to the popular computer game Half-Life 2, in my opinion.Enjoy the movie! Well worth the admission fee. :) 8/10
