Review title: If you read the book and liked it, don't watch the movie!
Review_body: I made the grave mistake of watching the movie after having read the book. I liked the book very much, because it explored the undertones of a world without children, the subtle ways in which it changes people. The book showed how different persons had different coping mechanisms and what that did to society as a whole. It also showed so many different facets of the same person, not just a tired nobody, like the movie made Faron out to be.So I went into the movie having certain expectations which were never met. Characters were changed or added or subtracted. The relationships between characters were greatly modified. The main character had nothing but the name in common with the character in the book. The mother is not the same in the book. The Fishes are not anarchists, they're just a group of people who haven't stopped caring, like the rest of the world. The group leader is someone else. Jasper was not an old hippie who grew weed and lived in a hyperbolic world. Everything was messed up and backwards. The action was totally different from what happens in the book. So I would repeat my warning: if you read the book and liked it, don't watch the movie, you will be utterly disappointed!I don't know if it was the bitter taste that made me watch this with very critical eyes, but I also found the acting pretty bad. Faron had no depth, his cousin had no credibility, Julian only seemed to be in it for the kicks, and don't get me started on Miriam, worst of all. I appreciated they hired a Romanian speaking actor to do the Romanian bit, it does taste authentic, though I did not like it that they felt the need for the gypsy in there in the first place. I did not like the shaky camera either, made me feel like I was watching a poorly budgeted documentary. The crying baby scene... dragged out and milked for everything it didn't have.This might be the last time I watch a movie after having read the book, especially if I liked it.

I have to mark this movie for science fiction. No matter how bad the world situation is, societies do not collapse because of illegal immigration. Come on-the world's youngest person is beaten to death? When Kee has her baby in that filthy room, and they go on the run again, everybody who hears the baby cry acts like it's music to their ears, then they go right on fighting as soon as they are past. There's no reverence for life. I thought it was a bit scary to find white supremacists directly in charge of caged immigrants. Or crazed evangelicals loaded down with assault weapons. No wonder the society broke down. Those people rendered the government troops mostly ineffective. When a country can no longer provide security and basic services, the stage is set for anarchy. The movie reminded me of 1984. Regardless of the quality acting, the plot was sketchy and the story line was uneven. Even the chaos of war has a certain amount of organization to it.

The concept of the world population suddenly becoming sterile is unique. However, the movie's take on what would happen is totally unbelievable.On top of that, the movies plot was pointless. It essentially involves getting humanity's last hope, the first pregnant woman in 18 years, from one area to the next to some mysterious entity called "The Human Project." The purpose was never explained.Acting was average and the movie features a few novel cinematographic tweaks, which saves it from being totally bereft of watchability. The action kept up and to be honest I was never fully bored, but it ended and I found myself wondering why I wasted 110 minutes on these empty, unexplained visuals and hollow characters.This movie is for cinema students and art snobs - not the general public.

i really don't get why everybody in this forum thinks this is a great movie. it clearly isn't. most of the acting is people babbling in a foreign language, the plot makes no sense and the film is too confusing. the sci-fi is poor: 1) cars are barely better than today (2007), 20 years on. 2) guns are barely better than today 3) tvs are barely better than todayif you gonna do sci-fi, get a decent budget to do a good job.simply horrible. i have to admit that when i saw the trailer I was very curious to see the movie, and it couldn't have been worse. i wonder whether the reviewers giving this movie 10 stars were on the strawberry cough that is shown through the movie?

Am I the only one who found this movie pretentious, annoying and unnecessarily violent? Granted, being more familiar with the previous string of post-apocalyptic stuff from the 70's and early 80's, I might be biased (Soylent Green, Logan's Run, Omega Man, ZPG, Blade Runner, etc...). Whenever the political climate is negative and depressing, filmmakers feel the need to comment on the culture, usually with unsatisfying results. Generally, these films fail to withstand the test of time as the culture shifts to something a little sunnier and less humorless. This film seemed dark for the sake of being dark, with the frequent use of heavy-handed allegory (the Human Project ship is called "Tomorrow"). I prefer my social commentary with a little more subtlety.

The best movie I've seen in a long while and I've seen a few. It really does tick all the boxes and invents some new ones of its own.It has the look and feel of some classic films namely Clockwork Orange and Full Metal Jacket. A Fantastic premise and plot and is entirely unflinching in it's brutal yet responsible portrayal of some of the best screen action scenes of the last ten years (think Saving Private Ryan). I am not a fan of 'pornographic' violence namely the swathe of rubbish like the saw and hostel films which frankly portray images I don't want to see and which is why i haven't. However, real film making like Children of Men make you feel every punch or kick thrown, and certainly every explosion and bullet wound. Someone being horrifically injured or fatally wounded should shock us if we are being confronted with mature thoughtful film-making.I'm in danger of turning this review into a one-sided debate about screen violence so I'll just stop there.Personally I think this is the best dystopian future movie to arrive since Blade Runner and I include the Matrix in that.See this movie while you can on the big screen and buy it on DVD. See this movie.I would love it if this was considered for the Oscars, certainly for it's cinematography which was simply breath-taking.

Review title: At least I didn't waste my money in the theater...
Review_body: I wasted my money by renting the DVD. This movie was a mess. I have never read the book, so I can't comment on the discrepancies. I was just unfortunate enough to believe the movie reviewers that unanimously agreed that the movie was a masterpiece. This couldn't be farther from the truth.The movie begins and ends with no explanation as to why children are not being conceived. In fact, I'm still a little puzzled as to what the movie was "about". The very little dialogue that was in the film didn't help explain. I guess the viewer was just supposed to know the general facts and not ask questions.The character development was poor. I felt absolutely no connection to any of the characters in the movie. As they began to encounter dangerous situations, I found myself thinking "Who cares?". There was little, if any, back story on any of them, so it was hard to feel any emotion for them.The movie itself was gray and dark. I'm supposing that was to create a somber, ominous mood. All that achieved was creating a depressing atmosphere reminiscent of a movie about World War II.Don't waste your money.

Review title: What if there will be no children?
Review_body: What will it be when there is no children, no future, when the whole world is in chaos filled with smoke and fire and cries of refugee? What will it be when women stop having babies but the grow-old-and-die part still remains? Is that some kind of punishment and do we deserve it? However, there's hope left, and that slightest hope is all we get.It is a decent story, filmed with astonishing cinematography which is so well managed that it won't distract you. I have to admit I thought it was a little bit boring in the first half an hour, but it grabbed me when the miracle came out(which i wont spoil) and Theo(Clive Owen) found his mission. Great scene in which Theo and Kee walked out of the building-in-war and all of a sudden everybody stopped firing, alone with the music added in the background, I actually cried. It was so emotional, so moving. When there is hope in the deepest abyss and you happened to see it, all you can do is to hold back, whatever you're doing, even if you're gonna resume the fight, even if the fate of humanity is kinda doomed, that moment, that moment when hope came out, is holy. Lot of people are arguing about the ending. I like it, generally, semi-Hollywood ending.Love that poster with "THE LAST ONE TO DIE PLEASE TURN OUT THE LIGHT". Loved it even before I saw the movie. So cool.Personal favorite of the year.P.S. another director from Mexico worth to be noticed. he actually put PinkFloyd into this movie

Theater of the Absurd. It is as if the director is telling his audience, "But wait, there is a hidden meaning, look closely, please look harder, it is there if you just look close enough, oh, please can't you see it, isn't it wonderful?" This movie tries so hard to convey meaning through meaninglessness. It fails on every level imaginable. Did I tell you that I hated this movie? Awful! A complete waste of two hours of my life. In a world without truth, anything will stand as a truth.

Review title: Good idea, solid crew, great scenes...
Review_body: It's interesting when someone gets an idea of what will our not so distant future look like and puts it on screen. I think there is really no point in debating how 'good' or 'precise' the future is displayed in Children of Men, because if nothing else, we really can't judge on that. If the time travel machine has been invented while I was asleep, please let me know :-) If not, let's rather concentrate on more important things.The idea itself is very intriguing. I also think that the actors played their rolls well, especially Clive Owen. I'm not a fan of Michael Cain, so I wouldn't comment on his performance. What impressed me the most were the action scenes in last 30 minutes of the movie.Children of Men is in many ways beyond the usual futuristic schemes, it isn't filled with countless special effects or computer animations and I would definitely recommend it.

Wow what can i say about this amazing film, just when i was starting to get bored of all the clichéd movies of the average todays cinema, and then it comes this movie with such an interesting story, and the best of all, the way it was done, technically perfect, amazing cinematography, brilliant performances, especially from Clive Owen and Michael Caine, great effects, and also the long shots were impressive.This is a slow paced kind of chasing movie, with very stressful moments and tense music, and its developed in a way that can be sometimes a little confusing, because the story starts an no one explains nothing at first, you have to put a lot of attention on some parts that doesn't look to be so important but they are, anyway at the end its still one of the best movies of the year.Definitely we have to keep an eye on Alfonso Cuaron next movies because he has demonstrated to be one of the best directors of this times.

"Children of Men" is a deep movie, which is at the same time futuristic and realistic. It presents a savage picture of human world, 18 years after the last time a woman has born a baby. It is really heavy and somehow different stuff. A point of view that nobody has presented so well in a movie.Director Alfonso Cuarón did great job creating a society who still looks familiar but also somehow changed and alienated. His vision is marvelous and the atmosphere he creates is absolutely influential.The actors did their best  especially Michael Caine. Everyone created a character that won't leave you indifferent to his emotions.Despite the almost flawless presentation in the mentioned categories, one technical aspect would leave you entirely speechless. The cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki is fully TREMENDOUS and INCREDIBLE. There are sometimes up to ten minutes, which also include marvelous action sequences, shot with a single camera without any interruption. I don't know if you imagine how difficult and time-consuming it is. If I could, I would give Emmanuel Lubezki an Oscar for his well-done job.Finally, I would that this movie is not for everyone, for it is hard, dark and as I said  different. But I am completely sure that every real movie fan would enjoy it very much.

Dull, dull, dull. Where's all the intrigue? Maybe it was lost in the 20-year gap between today and when this film is supposed to be taking place. A nod to the cinematography - I'll give it that. But that's just not enough to let this film stay ranked as high as it is! Not even close. 2/10 is more like it. Acting kinda blows too.Kind of reminded me of how bored I was watching '28 Days Later' back in 2002. 'Children' is like '28 Days' ugly cousin of dull doomsday films from the UK.The attempts to create interesting and likable characters just fell flat. M. Caine almost comes close to being a likable character - I wanted to want to laugh and some of his almost funny scenes, but just couldn't.I just cannot believe it's high rating. What, did I watch an early version with all the good scenes removed? Oh well.

Review title: Somehow it doesn't feel as futuristic as it should...
Review_body: I mean, it is a sci-fi film, but to me it feels eerily and painfully close to our present world. Like a snapshot of our not-so-distant future. I hope I'm wrong about this. I think Cuarón is one of the most powerful directors we have today. I love the way he handles actors and scenes, making it all seem very realistic, spontaneous, far from contrived, unlike most present-day Hollywood films. The action scenes are breathtaking, but not just because of the masterful way in which they are filmed (with very few cuts or no cuts at all), but because of what we know is at stake for the characters, whom we learn to care for. This may sound clichéd, but in many scenes you actually get the feeling of being there with them. Apart from a scene near the end which quite shattered my suspension of disbelief for a minute, I think this is an excellent work, with great performances (Michael Caine is brilliant and moving, as usual) and a message about the terrible future (and no,I'm not talking about infertility) that possibly awaits us just around the corner.

Not only is this movie a superb piece of work--superior acting, writing, directing--but its message is timeless. Everyone should see it, particularly at this dubious moment in history. I'm ashamed to say that I haven't read the book, and I have avoided it because I love the movie so much, and the book versions, the original articles, are *always* better, I find. Though the movie has a political hue, above all else, it's about humanity, individual acts of kindness and sacrifice for something greater than oneself and for that which cannot be seen in the present moment. Hope, faith in others, and faith in oneself that what seem like the smallest contributions can have a huge impact down the road.

Dark, dystopian, well acted and beautifully shot. Lots of reviews on here that clearly didn't like it but it's exactly what it should be (read the book and you'll see the central premise is the same). 
Sombre and all too likely. Great Sunday evening viewing. Take a punt on this as iit's beautiful to watch.

Almost everything in this film was brilliantly executed. From the acting to the sets, to the story. I have read the book and it is no where near the movie. Alphonso Cuaron needs to consider bringing in more novels to the big screen. Because he knows exactly how to do it. I want to be a film maker when I'm older (I'm 17 now) and this guy is an amazing directer (other than David Fincher and Danny Boyle) and I can say he is an influence on me. The only problem I had was that some of the characters felt a little underdeveloped,but other than that, this movie is flawless. A must-see for....well everyone. I've heard that it is boring, but it is one of the most exciting experiences around in modern film.

OK i am a straight man who loves Clive Owen in pretty much everything-i watched this movie twice to confirm it was really as bad as it is -and yep it sucked-granted with all going on it would have to be a 12 hour movie for it to make sense but from the beginning i felt like i had missed pieces of it and this concept just continued throughout no semblance of order,it was depressing that the rolls Royce was current to 2007 and the black hawk helicopters were old as well-I am not that into movies or the making of them but this was just BAD-i think they wanted to invoke a feeling of drama but it was just poorly done-i wish i could explain how disappointed i was

...to stop seeing movies that critics like. I had the unfortunate experience of viewing this "film" one evening. A friend was in from out of town so my family decided we'd buy a movie for the evening's entertainment. I was instructed to buy this critically acclaimed movie that had just come out titled, Children of Men. I remembered the previews, such an interesting premise. Why was humanity no longer bearing children? What sort of message would the film put across? Clive Owen was supposed to have been lucky to miss out on playing Bond for this role, so I was excited.Wow, was I wrong. Wrong, wrong, wrong, wrong.We watched. Slowly, our suspicions that the reviewers had duped us (misery loves company as they say...) were panning out. Now, normally I dislike when I see overly negative reviews on the IMDb. "Just don't watch it," I think, "please don't drag the rating down." But, when I saw this was in the top 150, beating out such classics as Yojimbo, Annie Hall, The Princess Bride, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, The General, and even Gone With the Wind, I couldn't take it lying down. What I will do is outline, briefly, the many problems I see with this film.1. An obvious agenda with which the makers feel they must bludgeon the audience. Michael Caine's character is a pot growing ex-reporter hippie who lives with his disabled wife (whom he helps commit suicide halfway through the film). He has various stickers in his home that are common these days, rather brainless political stickers with slogans like, "No more Bush," "War is Bad." I'm paraphrasing, but you get the idea. Kinda funny that even though the film takes place in the year 2027, this guy would still have anti-Bush stickers. Any message you're trying to get across, producers? Also, there is a constant "big brother" idea running throughout the film, any democratic government is pretty darn oppressive and evil. Also, the Greenpeace... I'm sorry, I mean a boat called the Tomorrow shows up at the end of the film to save the day. The people who own the Tomorrow are part of the never defined Human Project. The audience has little clue as to the identity of the people in charge of the Human Project and the movie sure as heck isn't going to tell anybody.2. Constant uncomfortableness. In movies where the characters are running from someone, the audience needs occasional reprieves. The characters need to get to a place of safety, even if it's momentary. Otherwise, the audience begins to squirm. Children of Men, however, wants to make sure that you feel as though your television were chaffing you. This is indicative of a movie-making philosophy that is steeped in the literal rather than the metaphoric, and is indicative of lazy writing. Yes, the characters are uncomfortable, and that is necessary to portray, but once the audience is made to feel uncomfortable, the movie has lost focus. The main characters are always running, always being double crossed, always watching loved ones die, always getting in gun battles. They rarely get a chance for dialog, and when they do, it's out of place because their talking in the middle of a skirmish.3. Neverending gore, shooting, violence, and gallons upon gallons of blood. For some reason, modern filmmakers have decided that their audiences want to see what it's like when a person gets shot, stabbed, blown apart, disemboweled, etc. The reason these things weren't shown much in the films of yore was not just that they didn't have the technology to accurately replicate the human anatomy, it's that graphic violence is a cheap way to toy with the emotions of the audience. It's why people look down on slasher flicks; they're gratuitous and unnecessarily gory. It's more artistic to see the facial reaction of the person who's doing the shooting rather than seeing the blood spray from the wound of the person getting shot (see Lawrence of Arabia, this was actually a plot point). In this movie, they show anything they can. Limbs are torn off (in the first five minutes, actually), people get holes put in their heads, blood pours everywhere. In the scene where Micheal Caine gets shot, it takes about five minutes and twenty bullets for him to die. I don't want to watch that. And I question the sanity of people that do.4. Bland performance after bland performance. Everyone seems bored, high, or full of caffeine. Clive Owen's character is a typical indie film anti-hero in a movie that desperately needed a hero. I never felt a connection with him because the movie never presented a reason for me to like him. Owen's character is dissatisfied with everything, rarely showed any emotion other than squirming fear, and never makes a concrete decision that wasn't already made for him. The character of Kee, played by Claire-Hope Ashitey, never allows the audience to find anything likable about her. She smokes some pot while still pregnant with her child, she swears constantly, she admits that she has no idea who the father is, and instead of telling Clive Owen she's pregnant she decides to strip for him. I thought the "Code" in the 1930's, banning pretty much everything we plop into movies now regarding drugs, sexuality, and violence went too far. If the "Code" were still in effect, we would not have films like The Godfather, Braveheart, or The Matrix. But, I'd rather watch nothing but "Code" films if it means Children of Men is the crap that's going to get pushed on us.So, if you like this film, please feel free to explain why. I don't mind the discourse, really. But please, put this movie in its place. Don't rate it higher than The Conversation, It Happened One Night, The African Queen, Duck Soup, and Groundhog Day.

Warning, some elements of this comment might give you some hints on the plot.A big disappointment... The plot looked interesting at first, no more babies born, dark set with governments and activist fighting hard against each other. Questions are raised like why is the World in this state, etc. Some good ingredients for a nice film. However, after watching it whole, a taste of superficiality linger... Where are the explanation of why activist are fighting so hard against governments? Why is there no more baby or almost none? In the end, we only have a feeling of having seen lots of actions, fight, run, escape, etc. But where is the meaning of all that?Hopefully, there will be a following to this film and this could make it a great series, or if it isn't, it is only a big waste...

Review title: Certainly the best British film in years, and one of the best ever!
Review_body: Children of Men is a truly fantastic film, which has ingredients for everyone - action, romance, gore, tension, wit and political meaning. All given enough space to satisfy, but also enough breadth that they can be ignored if you're not into it. As a piece of cinema it is a well shot, reasonably well directed movie, with a few scenes that are outstanding enough to merit awards in themselves. The acting wasn't anything to shout about, but neither was it anything to complain about either. The story, coupled together with fantastic political symbolism and many many influences from other films and news footage paints a scary, depressing and stark warning about the future we are being forced towards. Don't believe the holocaust could happen again? Watch this film! I was really disappointed to read other reviews on IMDb, which said that it didn't explain everything (god forbid a film leaves something for us to ponder on our own!) and even more disappointed to see the review that said that the key actors were killed off early...this film is so not about actors. Some complained the film was depressing - but it is so nice to see a film that doesn't have the Hollywood happy ending. My only explanation for these reviews is a misunderstanding, perpetuated by the person sitting behind me in the cinema who said to their friend: "What exactly is a fascist anyway?" . I hope a lot of young people go and see this film and feel motivated to make a change...I'd hate for any part of this wonderful and amazing fiction to become a reality!

Review title: Don't Trust IMDBs reviews or ratings
Review_body: I watched this movie last night after reading the first page of reviews and seeing the overall rating on the film at 7.9. In a word, this movie sucked!!! I could not believe how bad it was and so, after watching it, I decided to go back to these very reviews and "dig deeper". Here's what I found: All of the "great" reviews came from September 2006 to January 2007 and the reviews were not in order but peppered in strategically so they would blend in with the "real" reviews. This is deceiving and I can only wonder if IMDb didn't get paid by the executives that created this film. I have watched 1000s and 1000s of film from virtually every genre and this ranks as one of the worst films I have ever seen, particularly in regards to script. The cinematography however, was very good.

Why did I give this film a 2? I'll tell you why. Because this film boasts two of the most annoying characters since Jar Jar Binks: Kee's new-age babysitter and the jibba-jabba landlord lady toward the end. These characters made me want to kill. And then there's the fact that the movie didn't make any damn sense. "Little-bitty babies are just so precious" is a terrible plot device, and was not adequate to rescue this horrible story. The story put a big question in front of the audience that never successfully addressed, the central theme that was screaming at me was "where did this fertility crisis come from?" Their treatment of that question was superficial, cursory and completely unsatisfying. This could have been a great film if they'd found a good way to answer that question. But they didn't even try. If "precious little babies" make your eyes glaze over in ecstasy, if you require no more plot exposition than "goo-goo-ga-ga", then you and this film deserve each other. I give it 2 stars because I actually like babies a little. And Michael Caine's aged hippy character is such a shallow stereotype that it cheapens his participation.

Review title: Not my cup of infertile tea
Review_body: Nah, I don't like this one. I hate the way it's shot and the acting, the plot and everything. It's just boring

Review title: Two contradictory visions of the future packed into one film
Review_body: The film depicts a not too distant dark future in which natural resources like drinking water have apparently become so scarce that most societies have fallen apart among fights over their distribution and instead turmoil and chaos are ruling. Britain has kept its status as a nation at the price of becoming a brutal police state that doesn't respect human rights any longer in its fight against rebels and refugees from other parts of the world. (The latter of whom are kept and treated like animals while getting deported into refugee camps.) The other vision which the film presents is that of the infertility of mankind for unknown reasons so that 18 years have passed already since the last birth of a human being.This is the background on which the story is developed. However, the problem I have with this is that both of these visions don't fit together very well. Many of the environmental problems we are facing today and will be facing in the future are more difficult to solve due to over-population and would rather be relieved if mankind would diminish every day. Also the fights over natural resources should decrease and not increase if all humans knew that the days of mankind are counted and that day by day there are fewer people among whom they have to be shared. So for me the different aspects of the film simply don't add up to a plausible whole.The story which evolves on that background is not very plausible either. There are different sorts of rebels ("fishes", "fugees") fighting against the government and also having their own inner fights. A young refugee woman has become pregnant against all odds and for some reason is now trying to get to some mysterious "Human Project" with the help of some untrustworthy rebels who apparently have their own hidden agenda.Since from today's perspective the worsening of the environmental problems is by far more likely than global human infertility, the film would have made a good comment on our problems without the latter point. Perhaps the authors were just uncomfortable with the message that would have come across then: Namely that less humans would actually be a good thing and not something to be dreaded. With the combination of those aspects the message is mixed if not to say contradictory: Humans can not peacefully coexist with limited natural resources and yet their diminishing would be a catastrophe.The film deserves some credit however for its strong and impressive imagery.

Review title: A Fine Journey Through the Tunnel of Dystopia
Review_body:
'Children of Men' is a dystopian drama where men are fighting their biggest enemy, themselves. There are two ideals pitted against each other. An inhumane, totalitarian regime, behaving in their obscured manners, and people who rebel against the discrimination, for the honor of humanity. But in all this game of war and cease, the cries of children are lost. Women have become infertile; men only live to satisfy their hunger. But amongst this dark, glooming misery, plays with the gleaming glimpse of hope, a girl, a pregnant girl, a miracle.In his known fashion, Alfonso Cuaron delivers another delicate piece of art, filled with symbolism and sentiment. The film references many biblical symbols, as far as making the coming child, an image of Christ himself. But the visionary director makes it even more heart-touching, he reimagines the image of Christ as a girl. But also at times, some of the imageries were becoming too obvious. Which cuts down from the value of the message it's trying to convey.
It is undoubtedly beautiful in its cinematography. It follows the actions and emotions of the characters very precariously but, with much dexterity that always maintains an attachment between the audience and the film, it sets us inside the gritty and horrid paths of this dystopia.
Some of the featured songs elevate and emphasize the rhythm of the scenes and make the impact more heartfelt.
But to its criticism, the sound editing was a bit off at some scenes. And although the screenplay is not something I can complain about, it seems a bit animated at moments.
Maybe it is the execution or maybe; it's because of the slightly rushed pace of the first two-thirds of the film.
But it steals the show in its third act. One of the most heart-wrenching and intense third act, I have witnessed in this movie. A man, who tries to strand himself from the rest of the world, finds once again the means and joys of becoming or at least filling the given duties, the role a father portrays. Now, I think anything else would roll into spoilers.In the end, it is not a perfect movie. I'd even go to say that It contains a serious amount of plot-holes. But that shouldn't retract the credit this film deserves. This movie is about reminding us of what we can be at the worst of times and how we can still serve humanity justice by being humans again. To love, to teach each other to love, we can get a grasp of the peace in a relentlessly striding, crazy world.

Review title: One of the best movies of all time in my opinion.
Review_body: For me this was such an amazing experience. I can't recommend it enough.I know this review is not helpful, I don't care. Give this movie a watch tho', you might like it.

Alfonso Cuaron hammers out a totally believable distopian vision based upon P.D. James' novel, "Children of Men". A film about a future in which the human race is on the verge of extinction due to the sudden and inexplicable infertility of all women, where the last surviving shred of civilization is the police state of England where euthanasia is advertised on television, illegal immigrants are hunted down like animals and 'deported' (many never get that far), and Clive Owen is the only hope the first pregnant mother in over 18 years.Clive's character, Theo, drifts through his character development sequence as a lazy and stoic antihero. Our story begins on the day that the youngest man alive dies, killed by an angry mob after refusing an autograph request. Theo hears the news in a café that explodes shortly upon his leaving it. He then heads to work as if it never happened, only to discover that, as evidenced by the weeping ladies in the cubicles surrounding him, "Baby Diego's" death is so traumatic for the women of London that he'll be unable to get any work done. He takes the day off and calls his old friend Jasper played by the illustrious Michael Caine, who lives hidden just off the highway and is our comic relief.Upon returning to London he is kidnapped by his wanted ex-wife (Julianne Moore) , who asks for his help in procuring traveling documents from his rich cousin. After some establishing events that I won't bring into focus, as you'll enjoy the surprises, Theo becomes the sole protector for Kee, played by the lovely Claire-Hope Ashitey (who I sincerely hope we'll be seeing more of). Kee is the aforementioned mother. His mission: escort key to the coast, where she'll be delivered into the hands of 'The Human Project', an enigmatic group trying to save humanity whose existence is only rumored, via their ship, the aptly named 'Tomorrow'. Theo sheds his antihero status at this point and we see the uncompromising 'activist' he used to be. Given this purpose, he understands that this mission is more important than anything he's ever done, and subsequently takes us on a journey through the film, showing us concentration camps, bleak countrysides, and senseless human conflict, featuring an edge-of-your-seat urban combat sequence that rivals the beach landing in 'Saving Private Ryan'.But here's the thing. None of that is what this film is about.The infertility problem is never explained, and Kee's story ends as abruptly as the film began because they are simply the plot device that allows Cuaron to take us on a trip through this apocalyptic world. They are just plain unimportant. Make no mistake, 'Children of Men' is not about hope. And if you think it is, you're quite the optimist. The tag-line says it all: "No children. No future. No hope." No joke.In the end, 'C.O.M.' is a despairing look at what a wretched species the human race is, so wrapped up in our politics and religious differences that nothing distracts us (for more than 90 seconds) from the wholesale destruction of ourselves. The fact that this future world is so believable shows this to be true. Cuaron seems to be saying, "We aren't headed here for sure, but it's a possibility, isn't it?". It forms parallels to current events without hammering any specific political ideology home, just the horror of what we're doing to ourselves and where we could be headed as Earthlings. The closest thing to hope that we are offered is that this cycle will, indeed, continue.

This movie seems depressing at first, and its view of the future is very bleak, but ultimately good triumphs. Yet the story is not sappy at all. They took a big risk by setting the film in the near future, 2027, but it pays off. Highly recommended. Great acting, plot moves right along, plausible. Clive Olwen and Julianne Moore play convincing, warts and all characters, and I had no idea a certain prominent character was played by Michael Caine until I read the credits. If you know any old lefties personally, the characters in the film will seem familiar to you. The bad guys are a little too bad, but as no one can be trusted for long, the movie can't be said to be propaganda. It is violent but not gratuitously so. I haven't read the book so can't comment on the relationship between the book and the movie.

A very disappointing show. With several very favorable reviews as a base guideline, I went to this show with high hopes and left feeling very disappointed. It may be an artsy favorite but it missed the mark with me. I love sci-fi but this was weak in many areas--initial story, suspense, and ending. At the conclusion of the show, several people in the theater exclaimed at the same time--"You have got to be kidding!" That is exactly how I felt. There were many holes in the story which went unexplained and left the viewer perplexed. There were allusions and inferences of religion which strayed from any real impact. A nice concept but poorly delivered. Others may have liked the show but this could have easily been better if done in a Twilight Zone or Outer Limits mode.

Review title: Children of Men: A movie that aged phenomenally well in the most terrible of ways.
Review_body: From the utopian worlds of Star Trek to the cold brutalism in Dredd (2012), good world-building immerses the audience into the media without the audience even realizing it. And certainly, the cast and crew of Children of Men immerse the audience incredibly well.Filmed in a documentary-adjacent style, Children of Men portrays characters moving through a dystopian world in which women can no longer become pregnant due to an unknown malady. Moving through the world, the viewer is introduced to an immense class divide, a protracted war, pollution, jingoism, and in all of that, people just trying to get by.What makes Children of Men so poignant is how the characters interact with the world and each other. There are moments of love and brutality that, even as I write this, months after seeing the film, make me tear up.The true sadness of Children of Men is that the world it conveyed in 2006 feels far more familiar in 2021. The director, Alfonso Cuarón mentioned that he wanted to create a film that felt like a near future documentary, and unfortunately he might be right.If I could give this movie a rating higher than a 10, I would. This movie is easily one of the top 5 sci-fi films of the last 20 years. If you haven't seen it yet, schedule some time to watch it, and then another hour or two to decompress.

after i watched this movie, it made me move emotionally because the film takes you through the eyes of a hero like Theo. i thought the start was not very well introduced into the storyline, because it made me think everyones lives were going great until all of a sudden only human has to survive, but when it comes to brilliant acting from Clive Owen, it made me think more about his brave and strong character. in fact this film reminded me of Saving Private Ryan where captain John Miller died after a heroic mission success in saving James Ryan. Children of Men shows exactly that only this time it was a hungry baby Theo was saving. I'm very sad to admit this but i thought the ending was quite poor. overall, its a great movie, for anyone to watch

Sorry to disappoint but having read a few highly rated comments on IMDb, I expected quite a lot more from this film. But alas, I wish I hadn't bothered. Personally, I found the film overly bleak and the plot so outrageously implausible that it was hard to become 'immersed' in it. For me, it was one of those films leaving me feeling I wasted my time (and money). My wife and I sat through it purely because we'd paid to go and see it. Otherwise, had I been watching it for free on TV, I'd have probably switched channels long before the end. I'm now convinced that I'll have to exercise more caution in considering the ratings on IMDb. In this case, I doubt they are a truly representative sample.

Review title: A Boost in Cinema in the 2000's
Review_body: This movie IS the best movie of 2006. It was touching, hopeful, funny, suspenseful. It had action, Michael Caine, great acting, and a great plot line. Clive Owen wasn't just the guy who went along, Caine was more than a hippie, and Alfonso Cuaron had made another great film. But most of all, there was hope. The movie was dark, and depressing, some even said it was filled with propaganda, but the whole movie had hope in it. Since the beginning of this century, a lot of the movies that came out were good, but they had no hope at the end. What I mean is, the characters weren't redeemed from their actions, or that what they did justified their cause/reason. The endings tend to be nasty and vile, with no reason, except for the fact that the makers can get away with. Which is why I loved this movie, it is full of hope, a chance for survival and human decency. And the ending is the best ending that happened. It didn't answer everything, and a few pieces were missing for interpretation (in movies and books, less is more).Overall, CHILDREN OF MEN IS THE BEST MOVIE OF 2006

Review title: Goodbye Ruby Tuesday, Hello Hope of Tomorrow
Review_body: This cinematic version of P.D. James' bleak yet beautiful tale of an infertile future stands alone in its greatness. From the beginning scene in the coffee shop where it is announced the youngest child on earth had died at the age of 18, you are set in a world of no hope. The first part of the movies concept being, what is there to live for when there is no one living tomorrow? The second concept being, die trying so those tomorrow have at least a chance to try. Theodore Faron (Clive Owen) is the central character who has chosen to risk life and limb to bring Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey) to The Human Project. The Human Project headquarters if you will is a boat adrift at sea, that is a symbol of a new start for civilization. This movie has so much symbolism going on its mind-blowing. From Jasper (Michael Caine) to Clive Owens,'s shoes it makes you watch and examine what the meaning of the film is truly about. The meaning of the film mostly being the concept of winning the fight's over your trial and tribulations. Human survival, government oppression, racism, infertility; the idea that humans can and will outlast any problem that comes there way. I think the strongest point of this though is used through a song, "Ruby Tuesday." So many lines referencing the current state of things in London and throughout the world. The clearest being "Yesterday doesn't matter if it's gone." In other words goodbye Ruby Tuesday, hello hope of tomorrow and save the children of men.
I don't like this movie. It is neither a realistic, nor a scifi story. Most of the tine spent with gun fire. Very boaring movie. Why the rating of the movie is high I don't know.

I wasn't going to write a review until I read some of the negative reviews for this movie. What the hell Strawberry Cough are you fools smoking that think this movie is bad? In an era where 90% of movies are watered down tripe designed to satisfy the 10 second attention span populace that normally goes to movies, this is a bright star in a dark galaxy.Cinematography is great. I could see how some people could quibble with hand held cameras, but I like it here. The concept is great. I think the small touches throughout the movie are fabulous like the signs, and billboards and whatnot.Rarely are movies done about the future where I say to myself "you know, I could see the future being like that". It's a complex and difficult thing to predict the future in a movie. Will it be completely technologically advanced, will there still be combustion engines, what about weapons, etc. This movie seems to get all of those aspects right.The end of the movie is really what shines the brightest though. The beginning and middle are certainly solid, but the end is just magnificent. If you watch this movie and you don't at least have some emotion towards the end you are a soulless scum sucking waste. I'm a hardened movie vet and I had to check myself because I think I got something in my eye at the end of the movie (if you get my drift). Watch this movie with your lady and she will be bawling and happy at the end. A rare combination.Can you somewhat predict the end once you put together the pieces about 1/3 of the way through the movie? Yes. But you know what, it still doesn't matter. The execution of the final scene is incredible.As another reviewer said, go see this film, support intelligent cinema, there isn't much left anymore.

The solemn feeling throughout this movie is clearly there as soon as the title appears on the screen. The bland, white on black line 'Children of Men' really sets the mood for this epic drama/thriller from the get go. Moving on to the actual movie and what a movie it is. The fact it is set about 20 years from now really strikes a chord for watchers as it could, and could being a key word, happen with some of the policies and 'agenders' set about by politicians in 2006. Clive Owen plays a superb lead and gently pursues an English accent-not flamboyant and cockney but surprisingly realistic. The actors filling in the tidy amount of other roles are also up with Owen in believability and just make the world seem so much more real. The film is jumpy, at points, as it is witty and breathtaking. The music and set pieces are excellent if not slightly clichéd at points. Characters are believable and you fell even for the bad guys and even a small tear jerker appears unexpectedly at the end. The ending, however, is not as expected but the build up towards it is mesmerising. If only certain facts were told somehow at the end, the film would feel completed, but questions like What happens to her/him? still linger in the mind. And linger is what this film will do. You will think about it a day or so after viewing and the message will still be there whether that be about the future or what will happen with immigration. The film tackles both with flare and the whole base of infertility becomes side tracked but still there and still important, as shown by the expression and reaction when a baby does appear...

I'll keep this short and spoiler free. I cannot find a thing wrong with this film - it is an absolutely stunning piece of work. The attention to detail in realising a near future world - the richness of it rendered without a single line of obvious exposition. Brilliant performances from all concerned. The long takes and the stunning set pieces are just beautiful - echoes of Brazil crossed with Channel 4 news. It makes it's political and social points cleanly and succinctly. The best British film since 28 Days Later - and it took a Mexican director to do it - I liked his take on Harry Potter, but this portends so much more, I will be keeping a close eye on any future films directed by Cuaron. Simply brilliant.

I never thought I would be moved watching this film, but I did. You have to see it, and it doesn't matter if you don't like Sci-fi, because it resemble somewhat of our real world today. I love films, like most of us does, but recently films have been letting me down, but this film exceeded my expectation. The year 2027 and no children our born, no baby laugh or crying, all they had were pets to replace children. The suicide rate increase, whats the point of living when it's all going to end soon in 50 years. Clive Owen plays Theo (great acting on his part) a ex-activist drunk, who gets pulled into this situation that will change humankind exist. They're better plot description then me so i'll tell you my personal views. The cinematography is top-notch, ti's gritty and make you feel that you are there. When a bomb goes off you hear screaming,crying, and little tiny rocks falling from the background. It also has the best opening scene, when Theo walks into a coffee shop, and a bomb goes off, it grabs you in and you there for the rest of the movie. See it and it will change your view on life and possible the world were it's heading too.

Review title: Blade Runner meets Schindler's List: The most unsung and underrated film of the 21st century
Review_body: I recently saw this film after seeing a very interesting trailer of it over the summer. Judging from the trailer, I was expecting this film to be pretty amazing, and with all honesty, this movie was so much better than I expected. It is shot so well, with its ever longing track shots that gives the film a eerily realistic dimension to it. It is a very graphic yet powerful film, and doesn't show the future in a nerdy cleaned up future. It shows London in 2027, and only a few not-too-overdone futuristic modifications are made. The movie is extreme, and I envy anyone going to see it for the first time. Clive Owen Rules.

Children of Men portrays a grim future in a classic science fiction tale where the veneer of civilization is peeled back and raw humanity is exposed. The film is unsentimental and true to its premise. Clive Owen was especially effective in his role as an "everyman" caught up in events. Michael Cain played a great supporting role. And the music was a blast from the past. This being a near future context, the dates seemed a little off, appearing to place the targeted release date of the movie more at about 2003 than 2007. This is, of course, a problem for all sci-fi stories set in the near future. There were times where I thought the editing could have been tighter, but overall I think this is the next great classic sci-fi offering in movies.

This is a very good film... not as good as the reviews would lead one to believe, but nevertheless, much better than a great deal of major studio releases and far better then most major studio science-fiction offerings. The attack in the woods, the escape from the farmhouse and the battle scene at the end have got to be three of the best film scenes of the year, by far. My major qualm however is with the CGI atrocity the filmmakers have decided to use in lieu of an actual human baby. I understand the difficulties (and possible illegalities) of using a baby during violent action scenes with squibs and pyrotechnics flying. I also understand the scene where the baby is born could not be shown as is with a live baby. But there are plenty of other ways around these problems without resorting to a grotesque abomination masquerading as a child. Whenever the infant was on screen, I found myself mesmerized in a sort of repulsed and nauseated trance. And when the old "foogie" lady at the end is reaching for it's foot... *ugh*, the baby's foot looks like a stillborn baby Hobbit foot, gray, and lumpily malformed...

Review title: Politiccal BS pretending to be science fiction
Review_body: I love science fiction. I loved Blade Runner, 12 Monkeys and Dark City. They all had believable scientific explanations for the plot, but this movie makes no attempt to explain the science behind the infertility or the poverty. After setting through the gloominess, depressing poverty and brutality I was hoping for some coherent explanation of what caused it all. So I watched all the bonus material on the DVD and found the most ridiculous explanations of what had caused the deterioration of the human race. It seems that globalization, capitalism and global warming (caused by capitalism) are the culprits. If you look at the countries with the least poverty, highest standard of living, best human rights records and the least pollution they are all democracies with capitalistic economies. This movie even blamed tsunamis on global warming! What a joke. There is a lot of fiction here but not much science. I really hate movies with such an obvious political agenda.

Review title: One of the worst movies I have ever watched.
Review_body: I am astonished with the overall rating for this movie. I am still at half of it and with the expectation that something will eventually improve. I do not know where to start. The acting in general is poor and the actor's performance is very unrealistic. I do feel some sympathy for Clive Owen but I do not think he is a good actor. In every movie with him I have the same feeling, that he has a strong presence until he speaks, then everything falls apart. Another very annoying aspect about this movie is the technique used to shoot it, the cameraman is running after the characters and in fact participating in the action. Result: you become dizzy and in my opinion it simply does not fit! I also have the impression that the soundtrack is inexistent, therefore taking away any emotional atmosphere a movie with such a plot would need. Don't know where the English movie industry lost it but this work of poor quality falls very much into the same category of many other English movies, series and comedies of the last decade. Unfortunately...

Review title: refreshingly NOT filled with icons of America
Review_body: This is the best filmed "end of mankind" movie I've ever seen. Usually these set-in-the-future, apocalyptic kind of films end up being clichéd and filled with overused crumbling Manhattan landmarks like they're the only buildings in the world that matter. And then invariably some nobody at the end has to (successfully) by "fluke" dodge 10,000 rounds of ammunition and rise to a challenge of running up the colors in true American heroism that ruins so many could-have-been good movies. I loved how this film had NONE of that. It was set in Britain in 2027 but it definitely took some political stabs at the whole "Homeland Security" stuff going on in the US right now. All that aside however, it was a film that took you right into the action. Many times it was all hand held, 1st person perspective filming like Saving Private Ryan meets The Bourne Identity kind of thing. I had seen the previews and I wasn't thrilled about seeing it but some friends dragged me along last night. I surprised even myself as I came out immediately raving about it.

Review title: Children of Men - Clive Owen's great but...
Review_body: ...not even the fantastic Clive Owen and superb Michael Caine can make this movie work to the level that I'm guessing the Producers initially envisioned. The concept and storyline is great but - the finished movie does not work - it lacks "flow". I know this sounds harsh but my sense is that the director did not give the actors sufficient attention and was probably more preoccupied with technical aspects of explosions and logistics. The "extras" in the crowd scenes were all "over-emoting and over-acting" and in the face of having to work with poorly directed actors, I don't know how Clive Owen kept a straight face at times. The movie suffers as a result as although I am a huge fan of the main actors, I was very disappointed with this movie. The choice of music throughout (except for the rock music which was great) was completely wrong for this film - it did not connect with the visuals at all. Normally I NEVER talk through a movie and save my comments for afterward with friends, but we were all fidgeting and muttering comments throughout because there were parts which just did not even fit together. Poor direction and perhaps poor editing, not sure, as an editor can only edit what's there. And the key scenes are all very unconvincing. The locations were pretty good and captured the cold, wet English environment. Don't want to be more specific as it will spoil the action etc. Good news: for me it was worth sitting through it just to see another incredible performance by Clive Owen and an equally amazing performance by Michael Caine.

Review title: Like a film made by students.
Review_body: Within the first 5 minutes of watching this film my spirits sank and I knew we should have stayed in and watched television instead. It was like a film made by students who had been lent a camera (albeit with a biggish budget!). The storyline was so ridiculous that if holes were picked in it one by one we'd be here all night. Basicially we are asked to believe that the birth of a single baby girl will enable civilisation to recover from world-wide sterility. The battle between the rebels and the government soldiers towards the end was quite well done as a set piece and whoever set that up should have a go at the battle of Stalingrad..but on the whole I'm sorry, it is one of the worst films I've seen at a cinema(seen worse on TV of course.

OK, I only got through the first 3 pages of comments but let me add my own. 1) Fantastic cinematography. Some like hand-held, some don't. It certainly worked very well here. 2) Related to (1), very long shots. There is one scene where the camera lens has blood splats on it for quite a few minutes. Hollywood would get rid of it, but for this movie it adds amazingly to the atmosphere that is being created. 3) Like "Code46" the technology is in the background. Just the way it should be, allowing us to focus on the story. 4) Theo as the central character NEVER picks up a gun, despite them being all over the place and easily available. As a viewer you are almost willing him to do so, to manage some of his challenges - but very deliberately the character does not. 5) I've read separately that yes this is a comment on current society. Being an Australian, with our controversial immigration laws and practices, that rings true. 6) Similar to (5), using the term "Homeland Security" in the movie is an obvious reference. 7) The revolutionaries/terrorists/fishes are shown to be just as political and militant as the government they oppose.There are more, but that is enough. Overall a wonderful movie which leaves me thinking for a long time, which is all I ask.Cheers!Anton.

I have just returned from seeing Children of Men sometime after its release in the UK. It is by far one of the greatest films I have ever seen, I have already mentioned to a few friends that it may be the best film that I have in fact ever seen! You may think this statement is a little over-stated. Let me briefly explain why I left feeling so strongly. The beginning of the film is possibly run-of-the mill, but as the story develops, so does the action. Children of Men is at times slightly depressing, but so relevant to current affairs, that at other times the boundaries between reality are blurred. London looks much like it does today and despite being set almost 20 years in the future, many of the political and social problems are quite believable.Michael Caine and a bungling police man add a sense of humour and light-heartedness at moments when you may feel like there is nothing else to do but to jump under a passing lorry. This film is bleak, but I find plenty of under-lying messages. It is also excellently directed and has several great moments of filming.Without saying much about the actual plot, the end of the film fills one with a relieving sense of hope and faith. Sometimes things do take place beyond our control, however much we would like to believe otherwise. Yet Children of Men seems to remind us of the value of life and the seriousness of many of today's issues. It is the sort of film that has the potential to change you for a very long time.
Not a movie, but a complete depression. The mood is ruined. dislike

Review title: Truly truly abysmal - WORST film I have EVER seen!!!
Review_body: I am utterly speechless at the amount of high points other voters are giving this film...Having watched this the other day I was shocked at just how awful it was....I mean there's bad films and there's BAD films...this is now my all time worst film taking over from the appalling SESSION 9 The storyline is a complete shambles, the acting is terrible all round and the film itself disjointed and highly unbelievable....the amount of flaws I found were amazing...plus its BORING...just plain BORING!!! 8.1 out of 10 this got....HOW ON EARTH??? PLEASE tell me there are others who agree with me???!!!

Review title: it was alright... could have been better
Review_body: I had seen the movie and did not pay for the ticket. I am glad I did not. I liked the action. I liked the story line, but is really depressing. When saw it, some characters had died. The movie did have some nice and cheesy moments. I did not like the ending. If felt that it was real, which is nice, but in a way scary. The screenplay was well written from what I saw in the movie. The characters had their own personalities, that was well done. They all have their own story, which ties into the story. The sound was well done, but at times (to me) were a little over the top. There were some things I was not expecting, which always adds a little curiosity Overall, I was expecting more than I got.

Review title: A boring and very violent film with no discernible message
Review_body: I just saw this film and found it rather boring. The plot seems to make no sense at all, we are never told why the hero is embarking on this rather futile journey, and the film is full of pointless moralising about the horrors of the futuristic society it depicts. There are numerous heavy-handed didactic visual references to contemporary political issues - the Iraq war, refugees, police brutality, Guantanamo bay, Abu Ghraib that have nothing to do with the plot and are rather irritating. The characters seem totally unbelievable - one-dimensional cut-out figures with no plausible personality. The film is also full of the kind of senseless and gory blow-them-away violence that characterises so many empty-headed American action films nowadays, except it is even more objectionable here as this film obviously has pretensions to be a serious product. I haven't read the original book, so I am unable to determine if these flaws are in the book, or are the result of the highly didactic objectives of the director. Either way, this must be one of the worst films I have seen for the past several years - boring, irritating and entirely vacuous.

This film reminded me of my days in film school in London. There were a great majority of wealthy background students who were overambitious and inaccurate with their projects. Children of Men is like one of those projects. The idea for the film is excellent, but only truly obtainable on a big budget. Children of Men fails to convince on a number of counts. While the filming is polished, the sound is well mixed and there are C list actors, the budget just hasn't stretched far enough to pay for a realistic backdrop. Using Michael Caine instead of paying for realism wont sell the film to me. The main big fault is the fact that the cars are present day models, with added bits of plastic to make them look "futuristic". While this may fool the average American who hasn't seen these models of vehicles day to day, the average British person isn't so easily fooled. Imagine a Buick or a Chevrolet with a plastic elongated bonnet but the same standard features left elsewhere, and you get the picture. This brings the feel of the film right down to low budget level. Children of Men reminded me of that Australian (with fake U.S accents) TV programme - The Tribe. Watch it and see for yourselves.

Review title: Hope for Man, Hope For Film
Review_body: Britain, 2027. Women are infertile. Society is collapsing. No more children are being born and the end of the world is nigh ("the last one to die, please turn out the light"). Theo (Clive Owen) joins a resistance group who have discovered that one of their members is pregnant. He now must go on a dangerous journey to the coast, so that the mother and the unborn child that hold the only hope for mankind can escape to a secret colony, dedicated to preserving the future of humanity.With such an intriguing premise, this film at the very least cannot fail to be morally interesting. Although it never fully explains why women have become infertile, it is evident that it is the result of large-scale ecological factors, such as global warming and pollution of the rain forests. Although not a fast-paced film, the narrative holds together extremely well and rarely leaves time for boredom. It is also often very violent but always remains true to the realism of a British dystopia. I think this is predominantly due to Cuarón's outstandingly claustrophobic direction that makes the viewer utterly emphasise with Theo and follow his journey almost through his eyes. The acting is incredible from all parties, particularly a fun loving, yet serious portrayal from the great Michael Caine.This film is superbly acted and displays an absorbing and extremely thought-provoking plot. This, coupled with the top-notch direction, makes this film a must-see for all serious film-goers. Although often an uncomfortable viewing, its bittersweet ending round things off to a tee and leaves the viewer with a poignant but thoroughly satisfied feeling.

Children of men is very near, or perhaps is on the top of my favorites list. This movie completely blew me away. I had no idea what it was when I rented it but I am so very glad that I did. Reminiscent of Blade Runner, Alfonso Cuaron has constructed his own vision of the not-so-distant dystopian future and has presented it in a shockingly real, vibrant way. This film is truly magnificent. Acting on all accounts is solid, Clive Owen giving a surprisingly good run as Theo and Michael Caine giving one of his usual top notch performances. The story is well thought out and captivating, revolving around keeping one of the only known pregnant women alive on earth. For some reason, most of the human race is unable to conceive children. Not this one. Cinematography is among the most fresh and original I've ever seen. There is one sequence of an in-car chase that will blow you away. It was perhaps 2 minutes long and they didn't cut ONCE. Really superb camera work. I could go on in my fragmented thoughts about this movie but really, you should stop reading this right now and just rent it. Buy it even! You won't regret it - Children of Men will be remembered in the same sentence as Blade Runner and 2001: A Space Odyssey 50 years from now.

Review title: I wasn't expecting the film to affect me so much
Review_body: I usually do not respond intensely to films of future dystopia, so I was not expecting much when I went to Children of Men. But my heart was racing while watching this movie, and my mind is still reeling with its images and depictions of Britain as a war zone of refugee camps, random violence, omnipresent police, religious sects and the disillusion of humans who for a generation haven't heard a newborn baby's cry. I'm sure my strong reaction to the film comes in part from the breathtaking camera-work, including several exceptionally long takes during action sequences which must have been incredibly difficult to shoot. Yes, there are plenty of explosions, stray bullets and blood, but the technical effects entailed are not what draws one's attention.To avoid being a spoiler, I can't share all the various images and features of the action that add up to one of the most unsettling, apocalyptic visions I've ever seen. But I will say that part of their effectiveness comes from these being presented as a given, not something to be laboriously explained. Clive Owen gives an excellent, understated performance as a once-idealistic bureaucrat propelled into a battle. This film would be pretty awful if some sort of hammy Hollywood actor like Tom Cruise were in the lead. But such an actor was not chosen because this film has far more intelligence in the making than most.

Review title: The details are so spectacular that they are actually hard to miss.
Review_body: It's a difficult thing, defining a masterpiece, especially when the term is thrown about all too casually. And I wouldn't want to call this film 'important' either, because I don't believe it is a word that should ever be used when defining ANY work of art. A film (or anything at all for that matter) is only as important as you're willing to make it. I sometimes wish people wouldn't be so shallow as to pour so much of their time and energy considering such superficial things as a series of moving images projected onto a large white screen, no matter its contents. Yet here I am, like many of you, spending both my time and energy typing away about this film (even if I do so implicitly). And so, I find that I am left with two possibilities; either that I am another shallow rambler wasting away in contemplation of foolish things, or Children Of Men is truly important to me. In reality, both of these are true...and in a nutshell, this is what Children Of Men is all about. It's about most us, those of us who are 'aware' yet not bothered enough to transcend their mere 'awareness' of the problem. That is, until something comes along and lights a fire under their asses. For me, it may be this mere film, Children Of Men.

Review title: Without out a doubt the best movie of 2006!
Review_body: When I went to see this film I had an idea of what it would be like, a typical action film, and I have to confess that I was totally wrong about "Children of Men". My expectations were destroyed as it broke all the archetypal stereotypes that are present in an action film. The action in the film (which there are many scenes) has some point to it and it does literally have you on the edge of your seat. However what I found far more mesmerising was the emotional journey that the characters go on, none more so that Clive Owen. He was the reluctant hero that I found most appealing. I saw this film with every intent of taking my younger brother with me even though he is not 15 (which is the certificate the film was given in the UK) as we are pretty lax at what he sees. However having seen this film, I am glad we didn't because it had a brutality of it that I had never quite seen before. I suppose that it affected me so much, because I had been to many of the places shown in the film; it looked more like the Middle East than England. For two hours this film hypnotises you. It is one of the rare films that afterwards you kind of wish you never saw it, just because you can watch it again for the first time with no idea of what will happen. I recommend everyone to see this film as you will not be disappointed.

There is nothing really redeeming about this film, and i fail to see why it gets high ratings from viewers. To be positive, the cinematography was fairly decent-although i'm not much for the 'handheld' camera work. Unfortunately this is the only good thing i can say about it. How can one take a wonderful cast like this and make such a crappy movie? There is no story set-up and no explanation of anything that happens. It would be nice to know who some of the people are and how they are connected. The hippie mentality that enjoys this (ahem) 'film' might be the thing that drives the publicity. There is liberal propaganda galore and, naturally, anything that remotely seems right is horrible. I often wonder why the libs only see the future as grey, smoke-filled, and horrible. Is there nothing that makes these people happy? Save your ten bucks and go watch a cloud drift across the sky. You'll get more out of it!

Review title: The Lasting Message - Wrote this for my English class
Review_body: It is the year 2027. Women have been infertile for a generation, and the world has fallen into chaos. Britain, the only remotely stable country remaining, is plagued by terrorist attacks and internal strife. Enter Theo, a former political activist who has given up his rebellious ways for a dismal, bureaucratic job. He is coerced by his former lover into helping a refugee, Kee, escape the country. Kee would otherwise be forced into a labor camp  reminiscent of those used by Nazis  like all other refugees. But Kee must be saved from imprisonment, because she has a secret. She is pregnant.This is Children of Men, a film utterly depressing in its view of things to come. The sky is almost perpetually grey and human rights are crushed under government oppression. The film is shot with Theo in every frame, giving the audience an intimate view of the decaying world and how it affects him. This perspective particularly reveals that in such misery, there is still a ray of hope for mankind, and it lies in Kee's womb.The central theme of Children of Men is debatable. Is it a political film criticizing current world affairs, likening modern government philosophy to Orwellian totalitarianism, or is it a story of humanity? The political viewer finds support for his opinion in the very first scene. Theo ducks behind a newspaper stand as the coffee shop he just left explodes. It is easily mistakable for the many bombings that occur on civilian targets in the Middle East. The political undertone of the situation: the government planted the bomb in the coffee shop.To defend a political interpretation, one might recall a television ad Theo sees. It hails Britain as the last bastion of freedom in the world and orders all loyal citizens to report refugees so they may be sent to labor camps; the ad bears an uncanny resemblance to the nationalist, pro-war bulletins broadcast on American news networks. One might notice the powerful symbolism evident as Theo walks into the entrance of the labor camp under the sign "Homeland Security." One might remark that the rebels marching through the ruined streets of the labor camp firing guns into the air parallels the current situation in the Middle East, where men calling for change also take to decrepit streets with revolution on their minds and weapons in their hands. Theo's friend and confidante, with whom he shares his most secret thoughts, is a former political cartoonist whose every comment insinuates dislike of the government. And, in perhaps the least veiled criticism of all, the government and those with political aspirations are the antagonists.However, there is something to be said for the fact that the most memorable images in Children of Men are not of political symbolism, but of simple displays of humanity. Audiences are speechless with wonder as they watch Theo deliver Kee's baby in a crumbling apartment. The shouts echoing from the streets disappear, there is a deep silence, and then Kee's baby begins to cry. Such a simple human thing, the first breath of a child, is magical in this film.Later, Theo and Kee are separated in a standoff between militants and British soldiers. As Theo runs through the tenement looking for Kee and her child, artillery shells destroy the building around him. Refugees fall to the ground as they are hit by bullets streaming through broken walls, yet Theo sees none of this; he hears none of this; he is oblivious to the death surrounding him. All he hears is the sound of Kee's baby crying.In what is the most emotional moment of the entire film, Theo and Kee emerge from the tenement. They are unarmed, and Kee carries the baby as they face hundreds of armed soldiers. Yet these men, ruthless and trained to kill, are rendered speechless by the noise they hear: the cry of an infant. They lower their weapons in disbelief. Some fall to their knees and pray. It is a scene both terrible and beautiful  on a battlefield where so many have died, everything is silenced by Kee's baby.Yes, it can be argued that Children of Men is political, however it would be an insult to the film to brand its legacy with something as transient as politics. It has a timeless message, one that transcends any political situation. This is especially clear when Theo and Kee emerge from the tenement. Soldier and refugee forget their differences. They are the same under the spell of the infant's cry  they are human. This, if anything, reveals the film's ultimate point: humanity conquers all differences.

Review title: This is a movie that won't be a waste of your time
Review_body: I came to see this movie and I must say it is a lot better than I thought it was going to be. The movie is very well directed, because the graphics and the imagery is very disturbing yet so real like, that it even made most of the audience that I was in cry. The acting is also excellent by most of the actors, especially the performance by Micheal Caine. As for the story itself, it is an interesting concept and very good. The story sets place in England, in the year of 2027. A man named Theodore lives in a world that is in total chaos because women can no longer get pregnant. He soon discovers that a woman is pregnant, but the organization that is keeping her safe is actually wanting the baby for different purposes. Theodore goes on nightmarish adventure in a desperate attempt to get her to an organization called"The human project". The reason why I gave it eight stars though is because there was some parts of the story that was not explained, such as the part where you see soldiers treating the illegal immigrants like they are in the holocaust. Other than that, it is a movie that is worth seeing.

I took a date to this movie(bad choice) and was expecting to see a good flick. I had heard a good review for it earlier in the day and so that's where we went. First off, the cinematography reminds me of 28 Days Later not to mention the whole British thing to begin with. In the end, the story line stank, the acting was mediocre, and the ending straight up sucked. One of the biggest wastes of $17 (2 people) I've ever seen. If you really think you need to see it, wait for the DVD and rent it or Netflix it. This was supposed to be a serious, sad movie that made you think and get you involved but my date spent half the time laughing and was starting to wish we had gone to see Happy Feet..... Now Pursuit of Happiness, that looks like a good movie, that has been seen by a few of my friends and they said it was good. If you're looking for a good movie, I'd guess you should go see that one. I know that's where I'll be next time......

I had first heard about the show in a very, very short preview on TV only 4-5 days before it showed up at the theaters in our large city. I was IMMEDIATELY impressed with the power and impact that this movie had even with the very limited amount of media coverage on it. Let me tell you, I was NOT disappointed by the incredible surge of energy that "Children of Men" delivered. It was both powerful and intelligent as well as disturbing and yet moving with both humor and dread finding a way on to the screen. Our Earth is heading to h*ll in a hand basket and this show brings it all to a very vivid, amazing and tumultuous conclusion. The realism in every frame of the film was exceptional and I found myself with a racing heart, adrenalin pumping through my veins and knuckles clenched in excitement near the end of the film. It was like I could hear my own heart beat in my ears and nothing else. There were many times in the film where I found myself so immersed in the action and emotion that I almost forgot that I was actually WATCHING a film and not simply in the middle of a situation that was going horribly wrong. This really was one of the most interesting films I can remember watching.
