It made my heart THUMP but not because of fear... it was shear adrenalin that was making it pound and the emotional roller-coaster was part of that adrenalin rush. I truly think that this will be THE film to watch in 2007 and will go on to become one of greater, yet less hyped films of recent times.

The Premise of this movie was excellent, the fact that there had been no births in the world for 18 years. The movie starts out encouragingly enough with news that the worlds youngest person, Diego who was a celebrity at 18, is dead.****SPOLIER**** The plot falls away from there. There was no tension or deliberation when Theo decides to help Julian, which he knows will alter his life dramatically. Heck, he doesn't even know Kee is pregnant at that point. The movie seemed to gloss over that point.The second thing that bothered me was the locking up of illegal aliens. OK, no babies born for 18 years, and the "big" focus of the government is keeping people out of the UK? First, don't you think that they would be focused on bigger things....like REPRODUCING! Also, if the population is dwindling, wouldn't you want as many people as possible in your country, considering that in 50 years no one will be left! It just didn't make sense.****SPOILER**** Third, there was no clear reason as to why Luke and his gang wanted to kill Theo. I know it was necessary for the story to go forward, but they could have given a plausible reason for it.Most importantly, the fact that no baby has been born in 18 years is so interesting, so chilling, that it should have been used more in the script...almost like a character unto itself. What happened to all the school teachers? What was society's plans for the next 50 years...when we would become extinct? What would happen to armies and sports teams in 20 years? Run by 50 year-old's? Even Theo's "London 2012" Olympic shirt could have been used by saying organizers of the Olympic games say 2040 is the last year of the games. Also, the reason why there was this mass infertility could have and should have been explored more. Miriam's character did touch on it in the school room, and it was reverting, but it left me with a feeling of wanting more.****SPOILER**** Finally, this movie did have its moments, one dramatic one is the baby crying as all fighting stops. Soldiers fall to their knees as the sight of the first baby in 18 years. But as pleasing as that scene was, the end of the scene was as bizarre. How do hundreds of soldiers witness an infant for the first time in 18 years and then COMPLETELY IGNORE her when the fighting starts back up, leading to the final escape? All in all, the premise almost carries this movie...but I would be hard pressed to give it a thumbs up?

Wow a movie this side of the century that is a political stunt?! No way...I'm note sure I've ever seen such a novel idea! Lets just add this to the list of movies that try to make a point about the war in Iraq. And to think I was going to the theater to see a movie with a plot that seems reasonable and entertaining and yet I was so very disappointed in the fact it took a well casted, well written and well thought out storyline and made it take a turn for the crapper when it was all about a government-spawned war to keep people under thumb. I was either terribly misinformed about the movie or it was drastically ill-advertised. Two thumbs down for lack of creativity in a time where everyone's political standpoint is plastered on the silver screen and this one deserves nothing less than to be lost in the static just like the rest of them. But don't worry MTV generation by reading this you shouldn't be losing cool points by listening to someone else's opinion, losing those ever-so substantial points only happens when what they are saying makes sense and can be applicable to your life. whoops.

Praise aplenty for Children of Men, yet even after a second viewing I still totally fail to see why.The movie starts out well with depicting a world in chaos due to humanity seemingly being punished by being unable to procreate and no signs of handling this predicament well. England seems to cope relatively amply with the situation but is plagued by revolt against the fascist way the government maintains some form of order. Think refugee. This background should be enough for a compelling story to develop.But between the uninspired dialog, which is basically plot driven, and the poor character development there is also very little story- and or plot development. With an overly use of the hand-held camera style the movie quickly turns into a chase the rabbit style of film with a lot of muddled action sequences which reminded me of first person-shoot-m-up's. Scattered throughout the bleak set pieces there are less than subtle comments on the world we live in today, presented to the viewer in a blunt tabloid style. They make absolutely no sense as to being in this chase/action movie.This film simply lacks a heart and consistency in what it was meant to be. As a social drama it lacks character depth and a less obvious script. As a science fiction movie, it lacks science fiction. As a thriller it plods too much and again some character depth would have been nice for I truly couldn't care less for any of the characters.I can only recommend this movie for some impressive editing of some of the action sequences near the end and parts of the cinematography. Beyond this, I'm still baffled at the praise this poorly scripted movie with its shallow messages, dramatic clichés and average acting has received.

Our last Hope, but who cares? This film has had rave reviews. Athinking man's action movie, It appears that the majority of reviewers have nothing but praise for it. Despite a very good cast and director this movie failed to move me, which was the least I was expecting from it. The baby is mankind's last hope, but I felt no emotional interest in its fate or the fate of any of the characters in the movie. Yes technically the acting and directing were excellent, especially the scenes of urban warfare, but its failure to draw the viewer in emotionally was a major flaw. Perhaps I have become too cynical to watch this type of movie and others will care about the characters. But for me its inability to do this ultimately ruined what could have been a great movie.

I really don't understand the hype about this film. It was terrible - gratuitously violent and confusing - from beginning to end. I went to see it with misgivings (and got two friends to go along - they hated it as much as I did!) because I loved the book even though a review in the Chicago Tribune led me to believe some major changes were made to the story line. No kidding! The movie missed the book's point and philosophy completely. They made up half the characters and those that were actually in the book were completely different in the movie, and not changed for the better! Luke was barely recognizable (I only knew it was him because of his name), Rolf was nonexistent, and they created new characters (such as Kee - ridiculous character, racist premise) for no good reason that I could fathom.The plot bore little resemblance to the book. I would be interested to know why those who made this movie felt compelled to make these changes - the story P.D. James wrote was excellent the way it was - and what the author herself thinks of this film. The book had religious overtones, and the violence in the book is as much the fear of violence as the violence itself. Also, the characters are well-developed and believable. Theo is a character who goes through a complete transformation as he deals with the people he meets (such as Julian, whose role in the book is central to the plot and she certainly is not a terrorist, but instead the first woman to bear a child in 25 years). He is also forced to deal with the issues he has ignored up to now. His cousin, the Warden of England, is reduced in the film to one confusing scene that doesn't add anything to our understanding of the story. The only character I sort of liked and who was even remotely (I do mean remotely!)like the original was Michael Caine's character, Theo's friend Jasper.And the Quietus - what was with all the advertisements? They never tell you what it really is. In the book it is a crucial incident which leads Theo to join the rebels in the first place. In the movie, it's reduced to almost a footnote - "suicide in a box".I could continue with this rant, but my real disappointment and anger is that an awful movie based on a wonderful book by a great author will not attract new readers. If I had seen this movie before reading the book, I would never have read the book.

Review title: Powerful. Emotional. Private Ryan like Action.
Review_body: I've read a lot of the reviews on this movie and know there are more detailed explanations of all the parts of the movie out there (the actor's performances, the music, the screenplay, the plot, etc). What has stuck with me though, and the reason I'm writing at all, is because of how amazing this movie was able to capture certain intense moments. This movie is unbelievable, unparalleled in a lot of ways in it's ability to impact its viewers.Michael Cane is first off incredible as the old hippie Jasper, an absolute delight to watch perform. Clive, Julianne, and the rest are merely along for the ride of the unfolding of the plot, which just so happens to take us along for the ride too.I was not so excited about seeing this movie to tell you the truth and during the first few scenes in the beginning I was thinking about leaving. It wasn't that the movie was bad at all really, I just have a rich taste for human dynamics and wasn't confident this movie would deliver. I was very wrong. Any intense scene, which involved the actual display of that world (future England), was so well shot it was experienced not just witnessed. I felt like that was actually happening and I was in the horror and realness of that world. I did not feel like I was watching a movie, it seemed like reality caught on film. Quite a feat for an entirely fictional piece of art. Director Alfonso Cuarón is a genius, or at least got very lucky when throwing this thing together, all the action scenes are like the landing on Normandy Beach in Saving Private Ryan. In fact this movie seems just as real as that film. Now that's saying something, didn't Saving Private Ryan win best picture? This movie had to be created from someone's imagination, private Ryan was based on something that actually happened, I am so blown away at how good the action of this film is captured. The only reason I didn't give it perfect marks is because the story isn't as incredible, although it's very good and fairly original. Go see this movie on the big screen, when I saw it everybody in the theater was weeping during the last war scene (including me) I believe it was because of the dynamic that was captured involving the baby, (I won't spoil it for you). Up there with the most powerful scene I've ever enjoyed during a movie, and I watch a lot of movies. Go see it even just to get that scene. Incredible.I can highly recommend Children of Men to anyone who isn't afraid to feel our collective humanness. Children of Men will make clear to you, in the best kind of way. We're all one baby, we're in this together.

I am surprised at the amount of nice reviews for this movie. It's such a waste of time! May be some people really enjoy looking at suffering, poverty, garbage and blood, I can't help but pity them.The whole movie you are looking at burning garbage, depressing dark colors, crying people and murders. The people who enjoy such movies should be isolated from the rest of the society, because there is something wrong with their perception of the world.And the lack of logic in the movie is just stupendous. Starting with their "silent" escape from the farm, when they were opening and closing car doors and trunks with enormous noise 5 meters from their captors, and ending the lost of attention to the only child in the world once soldiers started shooting in the refugee camp. Let aside the unreasonably hopeful mood of the ending, despite absolute uselessness of having one accidental baby for the restoration of the world. Just look at the war in Iraq  even the fact that they can have babies can't save this country from the suffering and war.Overall  stupid, depressing and hopefully useless movie (may be except couple of nice findings and tricks in the filming practices).

Review title: A movie for those who look closer
Review_body: Children of men is a fantastic movie and I fail to realize why so many people on this website have posted comments about how bad the movie is. Their are many people who have ridiculed the plot by questioning the secrecy of the human project or the meaning behind Kee's pregnancy. Why must so many people need everything explained to them? For those who looked a little deeper the symbolism in the movie was overpowering and present throughout the films duration. The greater meaning behind Kee's display of her pregnancy in the barn, the presence of the Pink Floyd pig outside the apartment Clive Owen visits in the beginning, etc. It was excellent. I have read statements from people who question the whole issues of infertility and the immigrants. Infertility does not need to be explained, the reality behind infertility and governmental control (as symbolized in the Pink Floyd pig) is veiled for a reason, it is meant to show the audience the confusion and despair inherent in the imagined society and to allow the audience to draw their own conclusions regarding it.The immigrants head to England for a reason, it is the one country that soldiers on. Many people question why individuals would bother to risk their lives when civilization was crumbling anyway. If you are still alive and you believe that their might be a shred of hope for you and your loved ones in another land, it is only human that you will do everything in your power to survive. The mass immigrations are explained both through basic human instinct and the presence of newspaper clippings throughout the movie.The lighting is beautiful, the acting is above average and the camera work is nothing short of spectacular. The use of entire sequences consisting of only one camera shot is simply incredible. The camera work was incredibly innovative and I have never felt so embroiled in a movie as when the camera was splattered with blood and then, in one shot, the blood was digitally removed. All technical aspects of this film were mind-blowing.In the beginning of the film there is a group of activists who say that "infertility is God's curse". The simple presence of those protesters put a debate in my mind as to who the blame should be placed on. At another point the radio station announces "let's take you back to 2003 when the world didn't believe in living for the future". The issue of infertility is simply a metaphor for our disregard for our environment. Only through the proliferation of catastrophe will the world be willing to alter their lifestyle. This movie is a fantastic representation of that. People who want everything explained to them in a movie need not apply here because your impatience will only breed your ignorance as to the quality of this film.

Children of Men was highly rated in 2006 and, as I write this, it's in the IMDb top-250. I saw it yesterday and I was slightly disappointed.Children of Men is based on a novel by P.D. James (which I haven't read, by the way). The movie depicts the UK in the year 2027. Women can't have children anymore and the whole world is in chaos. In the UK illegal immigrants are put into refugee camps. Theo Faron, a former activist, gets located by his ex Julian and discovers that a woman named Kee, an illegal immigrant, is pregnant.That's pretty much the whole story and there are problems with it.First of all, it's incredibly shallow. No real explanation is given to the question "Why are women not capable of having children". Some thought should have been put into it. It's one of the central themes in the movie. Second, characters lack depth, especially the main character Theo. I think he is a lame excuse for a main character. Even though he's had a tragic past, I just couldn't sympathize with him at all. Clive Owen's mediocre performance didn't help, either. However, Michael Caine made a great performance as Jasper, the weed-loving cartoonist.Although the story itself is flat as a pancake, the other elements of the movie work well. The dark tone of the movie is excellent, the camera work has been done in a beautiful but grotesque way, especially in the later scenes of the movie and the chaos is portrayed well. Those are the factors that tighten the grip of the movie.But these elements can't completely save Children of Men. I think it's one of director Cuaron's worst movies because of the lack of a decent story and the emptiness of the characters. I think that at a length of 2+ hours this would have been a much better film. Now it's too compact for its own good.

You have heard of utopia. Well this is dystopia, and I might add, at it's best, or should I say worst. This is in my opinion the by far best dystopia film ever. Really a mind-blowing experience. Not the regular kind of movie, which makes it even more worth seeing. Excellent filming puts you in the mood, and leaves you thinking in the end. An extreme comment to where we could be heading, extrapolating the trends, and compressing the time-line. And, I might add, not adding any optimism an hope to the future. Reminding very much of George Orwell's 1984 or Aldous Huxley's Brave New World. A new genre in film is invented, film dystopia

I watched it on TV last week encouraged by the the very positive review it was given by my TV guide.It was hopeless dreary nonsense from the beginning and I only watched it to the end partly to see if it could get any worse - it did - and because I thought that it must some redeeming feature to have been described as "superb" by the reviewer - it didn't. The script is abominable, packed with clichés and unnatural monologues. The plot is pathetic and deteriorates. The acting isn't good and one actor is staggeringly wooden. The music is awful and the attempt at "future music" is like the logic my step-father once used in buying me a tie as a present when I was a teenager: "I thought this tie was awful, so I thought you'd like it". The cars are particularly annoying. In a feeble attempt to copy Gattaca's stylish and subtle use of old Citroens as cars of the future, it uses some of the odder looking modern cars with bits of stuff crudely stuck on them. Clive Owen manages to push start one of them, pushing it uphill single-handedly.It is like a drawn out episode of Dr Who with all the silliness but none of the self-awareness. The ending has to be sen to be believed - it could have been written by a ten-year-old. I've made better films on my mobile phone by pressing the record button by accident. How it can have been nominated for any Oscars, I cannot imagine.

Review title: Long Action Sequences make this movie Original and Awesome
Review_body: Alfonso Cuaron, took a risk in doing an action sequence in one take, IN A CAR! i mean you're in the car looking out at the chaos going on, and you feel as if you're in the car with them. It was an amazing scene and it was an amazing movie. Toward the end of the movie he does another long take, this time, with tanks and bullets flying everywhere, i mean it took me awhile to realize that the scene had not been edited yet and that it was all one take! He is without a doubt the new Spielberg. The birthing scene was so real i thought they had a real baby, is swear it looked so flippin real. Everything about this movie was great. Another thing i liked was how he opened the film with an explosion and then with the sudden title, "CHILDREN OF MEN" and ending in the exact same way with the sudden title. and of course to top it off, he used John Lennon's "Bring On The Lucie (Freda Peeple) at the end. This movie was great Even though Clint Eastwood is my favorite director, i feel that Alfonso Cuaron should have received an Oscar nomination for Best Director for Children Of Men. I mean the story was interesting and the acting was incredible, so why not?

Fantastic movie!!! Children Of Men has a distinct atmosphere that some may find gives the pacing of the movie a slower feel-- this is only necessary as at most points (the slower points) the pace perfectly mirrors the atmosphere we have found ourselves in while in this dying world. The cinematography rivals oft-cited top film Apocalypse Now, and succeeds in creating a world that is both sadly disturbing and eerily beautiful. It has memorable characters, and surprising moments of touching emotion and sly humor. If not perfectly airtight, it still has an excellent and entertaining plot. One must admire the reminders of the small beauties of life, the beauty and ugliness of humanity that persists no matter the circumstances. Also, there is symbolism planted throughout this movie, both in superficial ways and underneath layers. This I consider this one of the best movies I have ever seen. The theater I was in gave a standing ovation, and I was just overwhelmed by what a well put together film this is in acting, production, and especially setting. It is a modern classic. I recommend this film to anybody!

Review title: The whole is much smaller than some of its parts.
Review_body: There is some cinematography worth mentioning in this movie, but apart from that, it is quite a trial to sit through.The premise of the movie does conjure up some interesting questions but director/writer Alfonso Quaron makes it a point in this movie to avoid them all. How will the people in this society cope with being unable to fulfill their primary biological function? How is the scientific community trying to battle the sudden infertility loss of people across the globe? Or even a nice sappy drawn out conspiracy theory explaining the onset of it all, is left entirely to the viewer to insert into this story.In stead, the viewer is served a ridiculous chase story with characters devoid of any qualities one can sympathize with and groups of people which' motivations for doing the things they do, is totally left unclear. Add to this a very weak script that was rather patronizing in its attempts to inform the viewer about what was going on and a superabundance of situations that simply didn't make any sense at all and which were highly annoying as they demolished any chance of this movie becoming an enjoyable watch.Like so many mediocre films these days (Slumdog millionaire and Gran Torino to name but a few), Children of men scores big time on this website and in the eyes of the people formerly known as professional movie critics. It is simply a farce to think that this film reaches anywhere near the level one would expect from a film with a 8+ rating, so shame on all who have helped to destroy the credibility of the highly rated movie and the critics who should be able to do a critical analysis without being flamed for it. After all, this is their job. One they sorely forgot to do when this movie came to pass.**/5

Children Of MenCatchy title eh? Acting is absolutely brilliant, the actors have obviously studied their roles really good. Jasper, played by Micheal Caine was absolutely the best character in that movie.. Although i never found out what his relation to Theo or role in the film was.The plot, was really confusing as the movie took some serious jumps, and it was hard to get into the mood of London in 2027. The movie starts out too fast, but after a minute or 10 you get the hang of it and you follow through..The fact that the hero Theo doesn't touch a gun or weapon through out the film is excellent! A new Hollywood action film twist.A little to many missing limbs and legs according to me, but i guess thats what wars like.I might only be thirteen years old but having watched as many movies as i think this was one of the weird ones..Absolutely worth watching. Lousy ending though..

I seriously don't know why so many people have given this film such rave reviews. The story was dull and uninspired, the near future world that it was set in was cliché and the action, if you can call it that, was pathetic.Clive Owens performance was good, but even a talented actor like him could not save this film.The only reasonable explanation for all these rave reviews is that these people want to sound like high brow critics praising a crap-fest like this for its "fine cinematography ".Don't waste your time with this film.

It is hard to believe that the movie we saw tonight is the same as the one praised here on this website. Where is the intrigue? Where is the view of a world that is tormented with the knowledge of being barren? Where are the deep insights into a 'very possible future'? All I saw was a simple chase movie that was obviously done differently compared to what we are usually dished by the likes of Hollywood but also one that not for second convinced me. Worse yet, I can't remember the last time I saw a movie this fake and contrived. Apart from the fact that no reasonable explanation is given for the whole ordeal of getting the child through the violence to a ghostlike organization other than that it provided some sort of subterfuge for shooting the battle-scenes, no credible reasons are ever given for Anything that happened on the screen. The same goes for the motivations of most of the characters in the movie.Sure, most mainstream productions hit us over the head with exposition making such productions not very challenging to watch, but to simply reverse it and unaffectedly explain nothing is just the opposite side of the coin and equally insipid even if it was shot from a first person perspective. The fact that the audience has to dig with shovels to find a plausible story somewhere is what makes this a masterpiece? By God, I think not.I think I speak for the four of us who saw this movie tonight that we were all totally underwhelmed considering the acclaim and current ranking of Children of Men. The acting felt labored, especially by Caine whom we adore, the script embarrassingly poor in places, nothing really profound or philosophical to sink your teeth in and the ending, if one could call it that, was unimaginative and completely devoid of any intelligence to it. But frankly, so was the whole movie, so ten stars for coherence.We remain dumbfounded considering the praise of this clearly overbudgeted but all the same cheap effort and feel totally hoodwinked by the glorifying reviews.Ann, Kate, Deirdre and Cathy

Well, there is a lot that can be said about this film. I have read some of the negative reviews.. and it has to be said.. the amount that the 'reality' of the film was being criticised made me laugh out loud. That's the whole point.. it's *not* real. It's fiction. Not everything has to make sense. Use your imaginations! Just let go, *accept* the plot. Don't think about why the world went infertile, just go with it! Only then will you be fully able to enjoy a film like this. Sometimes you need to not think logically. I think the cinematography was simply excellent - hand-held really worked for this. The tension was portrayed extremely effectively. I was squealing at the screen. I can't compare it to the book because I haven't read it, unfortunately. But a shocking, phenomenal and sometimes unbearably emotional movie. I felt very involved. I can see some of the plot holes. But every film has some.. and like I said before, you just gotta forget them.

Review title: Regret the time loss watching this
Review_body: I don't recall regretting watching a movie as much as I did this one. I kept thinking about the high ranking and continued hoping it would get better. It never did and my time was lost forever. This was just bad. The only interesting thing came away with is it shows how the human mind is so vastly different, because so many people on here raved about it. It's boring, low tech, not futuristic looking, hard to follow. It doesn't take the time to explain key aspects of the story. I'm having a hard time expressing my disappointment! The only good thing I can say is there is one scene where they are trying to jump start a car that is suspenseful.

Had much hope for this film and Clive Owen is the shining light. Sadly, it tries too hard to be a dystopian epic and includes too many cliches to be believable or enjoyable. A bit of a poor mans handmaids tale... which itself isn't perfect but is much better than this.

I did not expect too much when I was about to see this movie, hadn't heard anything about it really. I didn't even know it was based on a book by P.D. James, an author I like but I didn't read this book (yet). Well, I was surprised - it is an excellent movie, really. There are good actors, quite a few of them are totally unknown to me but I consider that more of an advantage. Seems a bit strange this movie hasn't received more PR - its not a low budget SF movie. The story is good and you really don't need to focus on what it was that made the world go unfertile, if you do that you kinda miss out the point of this movie. For me personally it was a totally convincing picture of how wrong things could go... if you take in the aspect of what humans are willing to do against other humans. The only reason I don't give the movie a higher rating is the ending. Sure it might get you thinking about things but I'd like to have known what happened to the girl and her baby...

This movie has to be one of the best movies in the last 20 years. the imagery and cinematography has to be the best nearly ever.the character development is one of the best in cinema when theo does not care about anything but then go to caring enough to give his life for what he believed in. the "long takes" can be breathtaking at times and i have not seen better shots since Andrei tarkovsky's stalker. The "shaky cam" or "handycam" sequences are 10x better than Cloverfield or Bourne Ultimatum. this movie is hands down my favorite film besides Stalker. I highly recommend this movie. This movie is compared to V for vendetta in subject matter alone but i find that children of men is a better film in terms of cinmatagraphy writing and acting. Children of men is also more realistic of a film. V for vendetta is more cartoony and a guilty pleasure. in terms of a better movie Children of men is the better i Cant state how awesome this movie is in both Subject matter and Cinematography. 10/105 stars

This movie is difficult for me because I can't quite figure out how to articulate exactly how this film falls short, but I'm going to give it a try and see what happens. First, I'll say that overall the movie, for what it was, was done OK. I was in the moment the majority of the time, sort of. But distraction doesn't equal real reward. Actually, this is usually my biggest gripe about anything purporting itself to be "artistic" or real cinema, that it is simply a distraction: "I'd like to forget I'm alive for the next two hours so I can get lost in something.. but nothing more please!" Or maybe it isn't trying to be anything but a distraction, who am I to say? But either way, the foundation of this movie is gimmick. Gimmick gimmick gimmick. You'll see what I mean. I'll start with the more minor points, to make some points, and also to second the opinions of many others..Blood on the camera: gimmick. What does that add to the movie? Or is it more "real", bringing me back to the fact that I'm looking at a film frame made on a Hollywood set? The hand-held thing, especially in the woods, if anything made me feel like I was a wolf waiting to attack our characters. Either way, I don't know what kind of message I am supposed to be getting about a pulsating camera holder, especially in scenes with no one even in the frame.. Gimmick. Then there is the military seeing the first baby born in years, then like a tank of goldfish completely forgetting, going on to fight some more. Not only was that absurd, but it was also almost unclear WHY they happened to be attacking that building with tanks and everything, just at that moment, when the Only Baby On Earth was inside.. And this film also features the most noisy "smooth" exodus from a compound of guys standing around with guns 5 feet away. And the car door taking the same guy out, twice? First, Really?? Second, Gimmick.In addition. There was hardly any character development. Now, granted, everyone is shooting half the time so it isn't like they are going to be sitting around debating Nietzsche or something. But, these characters are stoic, monk-like. They hardly seem invested at all, except when they are about to die or think they are about to die. Otherwise the carnage around them apparently doesn't bother them too much, unless it's way too close. In the building at the end of the movie, Clive continues to nonchalantly walk in front of open windows while the whole British army is knocking people off all around him from outside. And let's not forget how at the very end the air force decides to start air bombing the hell out of a city with their troops scattered throughout. Or how old Clive managed to paddle what appears to be miles with a bullet in his stomach. And, I hardly cared that he died. He was THAT developed. Wait, I forgot that the miracle baby was delivered in perhaps the quickest and most pain free birth in the history of man. Just a few minutes of screaming and POP.But let me get to the real problem. All that other stuff would just be good humor in the face of an OK movie. At least worth 6 stars, right? No. No! No! Because the whole GD movie was a big gimmick. This movie is the definition of gimmick. Gimmicky characters walking around a gimmicky world with gimmicky TV's and gimmicky military and gimmicky everything. I'll do my best to articulate what I'm complaining about. This whole movie runs on one thing, the last woman on earth that has a baby. But that's it. This is our justification, our only justification, for everything else that happens. It's cheap, plain and simple. A gimmick. This is the only "thought-provoking" part of the whole movie. I'd rather they would have just left it out and left the whole thing ambiguous. That would have been a lot more fun for me, just the experience of society falling apart for some reason. But no. The apocalypse will come because of.. infertility? Governments collapse from not having babies? Really? So THAT is what will cause the breakdown in government. Not foreign relations, scarcity of oil, food, water, etc etc. But infertility. The word "orwellian" will soon be replaced when we see how insightful this film is in time.. and every other justification is just as gimmicky. OK OK, I'll stop talking S and get to the point: Just because the film REFERENCES something doesn't mean it CONSIDERS it. This film just name-drops subject matter, a small series of really bad excuses for a long chase scene. This film is like if I came over to your house, spattered a few post-it notes with words like "homeland security", or "just imagine being on a bus and feeling like you are going to a concentration camp", and you go, twitter, facebook, and myspace the hell out of the internet, about how GD thought-provoking I am and how great I am to have as a friend.A good movie, in my opinion, is more than distraction. It's about giving me an Experience. Reflecting back towards me. Maybe even giving me an insight or two about life. This didn't have these things. It was a 90 minute chase scene thriller. I don't need everything explained to me to enjoy it, but don't treat me like an idiot by "explaining" the movie in a cheap way.. I'd rather they just skipped the pretensions. Enjoy it for a not-so-hot chase scene, but don't go talking about thought-provoking. Clear out the spider webs of your mind, there is a lot more thought-provoking out there, in any medium, than this film.

I remember watching Alfonso Cuarón's Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban which was for me the first movie I saw by him. Great film well executed, but there's not much to add to a movie thats got its whole story and visual style laid out about.So to see Children of Men, I came into the movie with very little knowledge about everything about this movie and I have to say the story was spectacular and provocative but once the movie started going, the whole story kinda too a back seat to what was really happening in the movie which was very simply an action-movie about one character guiding around the pregnant girl all movie. I feel like I didn't get enough time to tune in and feel anything about the immigrants, if they were even spose to be part of the main story or much else that was going on outside the main journey involving Faron and Kee. Cinematically, it was absolutely breath-taking, and all the shots were just so well executed and performed. But beyond that I think it lost some of what it first brought to the dinner table.

Review title: One of the best action films ever
Review_body: This movie is a pleasant surprise not for the plot but for the sheer execution. There are a more than 3 scenes where it's a continuous sequence, action sequence. I have never seen such thing in a Hollywood movie. Any Hollywood movie has a big bang sound even when you fire a very low calibre pistol and rapid movement of camera.I just hate that camera movement which actually distracts more than entertain. I don't know why it's so prevalent in today's movies. But this one is very different. I just love this. The shooting is more real than any other Hollywood flick. It's more true to the action genre than many others - even Bourn series has some extra sounds. However the plot doesn't explain the current situation that they are in and doesn't even attempt it.

Review title: my point of view..like it or not..i think it is the true one
Review_body: men do depend a lot on women's mood during their relationship, and women's influence them with their attitudes and emotions..on the other hand women's are influenced by the love for their children, and when they come to miss the first once feel enormous pain..the same thing happens to a woman that can't have a child but want's it badly..with loneliness in their soul, they become distant in the eyes of their partner, they start to refuse him and in one way or another they make him feel insecure..insecurity is the key word..men's if insecure are capable of doing really bad things just because they loose their point of reference(Oedipus's complex)..here we come to the point where we can explain the apocalyptic consequences of not having children that this movie tries to present to us..parents fight for their kids, if they don't do bad things is because of them, if they go to war it is because of them, if they want peace it is because of them and if they want a better world it is because they want their children to have their own little paradise in which the can't feel the harsh hand of our society system..without kids and procreation, all this things unforgettably come to miss and sh**t happens...

Review title: This movie is NOT that good (although not specific spoilers)
Review_body: Without spoilers: 1. Stereotyped ancillary characters. 2. Open ending which does not explain important questions. 3. Unrealistic random attacks (burning cars anyone?)The motivations of the government, the rebellion, and people in the warzones don't fit with what would really happen. The reactions around the baby are very unrealistic. Pain mitigation, enemy psychosis...you name it, this movie screws it up.The plot beyond the overall premise is very weak.Matt

Review title: Entertaining but ultimately a let down and very thin.
Review_body: This is my kind of genre and I love Owen and many of the other actors in this movie, so to watch them read poor dialogue like this and act un-actable scenes was painful. It's really that distracting.Fortunately a bleak and interesting future makes for some face saving action scenes that are very tense. It must be warned however what passes for the future here is a mishmash of current affairs issues taken to the extreme. There is no insight, no real imagination here either, it's all as if they grabbed someone of the street and asked them what they thought the future would be like.If you can get past the hammy acting, dialogue and concentrate on the more interesting scary aspects of this future world, I'd like to say you'll find a great story. But you won't. I don't ask for messages in my films, but there was no insight into anything here. Not the characters, not the idea behind it, no story metaphor (although plenty of heavy handed visual metaphor).As for a thinking persons action movie, sort of an insult to thinking people really. I know a lot of popcorn movie goers who'd be just as happy to see this, though it is a fair bit more interesting than your average Saturday night flick.To sum up, it should have been a thinking persons movie, and if the dialogue was better it would help. Even so, the story is so flawed, it's like you know something good is there but, it's been in such a horrendous car wreck you barely make it out. What a real pity, but thank god for the cinematographer!

Review title: The year is 2027 and our future is a thing of the past
Review_body: Humanity can no longer conceive, and the world has fallen into dirt, disorder and chaos. Only Britain holds a semblance of civility, and thus, hope for the endless tide of immigrant refugees or "fugees". One fugee is Kee, who happens to be eight months pregnant, and must be delivered to the possibly mythical Human Project by the jaded Theo (Clive Owen).Children of Men is quite simply breathtakingly stunning. Alfonso Cuaron handles the gritty action like a war correspondent's report - with *12 minute* takes and seamlessly realistic violence. With the startling attention to detail - visible in newspaper clippings, sides of buses, propaganda, adverts, television broadcasts, packaging... - it does not feel as if you are watching a film, it feels as if you should be running for you life along with the cast.This film does not preach. It does not tell you why suddenly, no one can have children, it simply drags you along on a post-apocalyptic, but surprisingly funny, journey with perhaps a glimmer of hope at the end. Utterly compelling in every way.

Review title: My good lord - what a well directed film
Review_body: Just got out of the theater, and I just have to say, quite briefly, that this is an exquisitely directed film.I don't know why the heck the studio isn't putting any advertising push behind this movie, but - really - it is an extraordinary, powerful, human, and very moving piece. Full of action and pathos. It should be getting more attention, and hopefully the word of mouth will carry this movie enough to attract a strong audience. Won't spoil anything here. But for any intelligent movie goer who enjoys beautifully shot action sequences, intelligent cinema, and the best portrayal of a squalid future dystopia since "Brazil," this movie is definitely for you.

The pace of the movie felt very rushed. Neither the characters nor the setting were developed well, in my opinion. It's an interesting future, but nothing was really done to bring that out in the movie. There were some scenes that were like parts in the book, but they weren't nice made significant. I liked Michael Caine's performance, but it didn't add much to the story. Effects and scenery seemed ok, but they didn't add much since everything else was lacking. I didn't enjoy the movie. I give it 4/10
One of the best post-apocalyptic movies ever. A must watch.

Review title: Gripping and moving piece of cinema.
Review_body: I went to see this at the local multiplex last night and must say that is one of the most satisfying cinema experiences i have had in a long time. I went in with high expectations, firstly as a unashamed sci-fi fan and in particular of dystopian visions (although the daily mail may see this film as more of a utopia) such as Brazil which i consider to be a sort of companion piece to this film, secondly as a cuaron fan who made a Harry Potter film that even i could enjoy and thirdly as someone from England who is tired of the same old genres that we appear to have in this country ie. corny gangster films, kitchen sink dramas and historical adaptations I have to say that this film lived up to all my expectations and then some. Without going into the plot too much it concerns England in 20 years time, with the human race infertile and the outlawing of immigrants leading to a fascist style government. Sound a bit like v for vendetta? well i assure that comparison couldn't be further from the truth because the future displayed in this film felt so grounded in reality and so possible that it made my stomach turn. The performances in the film were almost uniformly excellent with Clive Owen clearly playing the kind of role he was born for and Michael Caine giving a fantastic performance which could so easily could have been ridiculous in the hands of a lesser actor or lesser director.However the thing that impressed me most about the film was the visual style the hand-held camera and documentary style gives the film a gritty feeling yet also allows for beautiful shots that appear natural and not as forced as in other large productions, *MINOR SPOILER* Towards the end of the film is a major set piece set in a war torn refugee camp that is simply stunning with explosions and gunfire that had me gripped and close to falling off my chair as the world falls apart around the films protagonists. I must stress that this film has to be seen in a cinema with surround sound for full effect as a normal DVD set up will not do it any kind of justice.A few minor criticisms of the film for me are that some of the lesser characters don't feel very fleshed out and a couple of supporting performances didn't ring true for me (slight overacting). With that out the way i feel the need to stress once more that this piece of cinema needs to be seen in a cinema. Lets just hope we can look back on it in 20 years and laugh at how wrong was.

Review title: Ten Years Later, This Movie Makes Much More Sense
Review_body: When you realize that Children of Men is not actually a obscure sci-fi movie, but a war thriller it is too late to not get involved. Cuaron has a perfect hand to conduct this 2 hour movie that never gets less exciting. We follow the journey of Theo Faron through the decadent England, but from time to time, Cuaron focus on random people suffer. It's this technique that feeds the environment around Theo and makes us notice that we're just seeing a tiny pixel of a huge picture. Today, Children of Men could be compared to the real life situation on Europe immigration rate.Great movie. You should definitely check it out.

I have just seen the film and I'm not disappointed. I wanted to see this film because of A.C. After watching the third Harry Potter film I thought that the director was the best and I decided to find and watch one of his films. And then... I have forgot it. But now I saw the poster of 'Children of men' and that makes me remember. As I have said I was not disappointed. This man is crazy but a genius.And I loved the story too. Miriam... I will be just a bit younger than her in 2027. Weird. Those spots of blood and the moving camera make you to be a part of the film. Brilliant! The end was a bit strange for me... I had the feeling that something is wrong. Oh, I don't know! I really don't know. But the film is horrible and also beautiful, and worth watching it! I'm not really sure that see it once time is enough.(Sorry for the grammar.)

Review title: this film made me hate baby's
Review_body: this is a really stupid movie, it describes a world which i as a viewer found unbelievable, the script has lots of loose ends but still remain very predictable, and by the way there us about 4 minutes of constant waining of a black baby that look like a a small rat... i found no empathy for the characters , and it just seems like some crap disguised as artistic, Micheal Kaine as a n old hippie just doesn't work,and everything in the movie is so lame... the friend tells the hero that he will talk himself out of the bad guys dealing with him and guess what happens? they kill him.. hem who didn't see this one coming a mile away, do not go see this movie!!

Review title: The 35% that rated this movie a 1 must be left-wing fanatics!
Review_body: This movie was absolutely horrible! Most of the action was seen io the previews. You never find out why children aren't being born. And you never find out where they are taking the pregnant girl. Which is really ridiculous, because if the entire human race was going extinct, I thing the duh-heads would want to take the girl to scientists, so they could examine her and the baby. This movie was obviously made by left-wing anti-government ideologues. Michael Cane played a neo "60's acid causality'. The anti-war propaganda was quite evident, replete with references to "Bush". The left-wing propaganda notwithstanding, the movie was slow paced, lacked plot depth, and was painfully slow moving. I couldn't wait until it was over.

Review title: What is all the fuss about?
Review_body: I had waited a long while to catch this movie on DVD hoping that the hype surrounding it would die down enough for me to enjoy it. However I was constantly bombarded with comments from friends and even the video store clerk, that this movie was 'greaaaatt'. OK I said I'll see for myself.Firstly the acting is absolutely awful and isn't really helped by a poor script with shoddy, cringe-worthy dialogue 'ohhhhh I forgot how beautiful babies were'...oh please. Clive Owen looks lost, he's got his next movie on his mind, either that or he's thinking about a holiday on the Med. I never related to one single character in the movie and couldn't care less whether they lived or died. That said there were numerous pointless deaths.The dystopian future that is created is so hackneyed it's laughable. Kids throwing rocks at the train, that stuff already happens where I'm from, it's not particularly frightening. Graffiti, jackbooted thugs, small fires, people speaking in foreign tongues, sorry have I not seen all this before somewhere.The plot or lack of it is probably the most fundamental problem. We drift from one scene to another with not much happening, we are given no credible back-story to get us interested. When Cuaron realizes he has a kipper on his hands he ups the pace a bit in the final few scenes, but unfortunately he goes too far and it ends up almost like a video game.Finally numerous colleague's commented on how well it looks, mainly in reference to the cinematography. Sorry people, have ye been locked away in a closet for the last ten years. Lubezki is just trotting out the 'style de jour', there is nothing original in any of the cinematography. I have seen this style handled better by the likes of Kaminski in Private Ryan and Idziak in Black Hawk Down. In both these movies the DPs had to tackle the style on a grand scale, there is nothing like this in Children of Men. The scenes in the farmhouse are particularly weak and look out of place with the rest of the film. Too much reliance on practical sources made this overall quite a flat film, a muddy grey sludge of a palette, where there is no depth separation.

I really enjoyed this film - it works well as a piece of entertainment and something with a bit more bight. Like a lot of dystopia-future type films, it says a lot about the present, particularly the tabloid hysteria over immigration (interestingly there's quite a few Polish people in this film, something of a bugbear for the gutter press at the moment)and the footage we see everyday of Iraq. I think this film would sit nicely alongside Brazil, Dark City, or even Three Kings. Technically it's superb - it looks brilliant, and was nicely sombre and gritty, which worked fantastically with the special effects. The battle scenes were truly breathtaking, as were the sudden, almost off-hand explosions. It ends nicely as well, avoiding the temptation to 'over-tell' the story beyond its natural ending as far too many films have done recently. The actors all give good performances here, especially Clive Owen who makes a natural hero without resorting to absurd posturing, and Michael Caine is brilliant as ever, at once familiar yet completely different, even making 'pull my finger' fit into this movie somehow! All in all, this is really a film worth seeing. I just hope we can look back in 20 years and laugh at how wrong this prediction was...

The long shots add to the tension of the story. Clive Owen and Michael Caine cushion our anxiety throughout a film of lightly controlled chaos. We see what looks like present day landmarks: Nelson's column out the window of Clive's cousin's house, plus the ubiquitous red double-decker bus. The street where Clive gets his coffee could be Tottenham Court Road. We see a separateness between Julianne Moore's character and Clive's character. Clive himself delivers a 21st century kind of guy, nice but apathetic,just getting by in life. How futuristic is that? He does get ignited and it is a movie about hope. The message is personified in these characters, but Alfonso Cuaron lets it sink in, doesn't hit us in the face with it.This writer saw an early release on December 20. I haven't stopped thinking about how that movie relates to our world and neither will you. It captures you when you see it, but then you keep on trying to evaluate it here it is, three weeks later! That speaks volumes.

Review title: Children of Men creates a brilliant contradiction: it's dark, but it's illuminating
Review_body: I saw "Children of Men" in the first weekend of its commercial run, at a packed house in Century City. It's a dark film about despair and hope, but its great virtue (at least this is MY hope) is that it illustrates the logical extensions of many strands of current public policy. If we keep allowing brutalism and mischief to multiply abroad, what will it look like when it festers and seeps in under our doors? What would life be like if you had a certain amount of wealth or privilege and you built a bubble of normality around you? What would happen as the "cost" for maintaining this bubble became more and more prohibitive and more of your friends couldn't keep up? In this film, there are lots of different coping mechanisms on display. Some characters turn to a resistance movement, which ultimately is as ruthless as the forces it opposes. Another character tries to get by on his wits (and his ganja) and is steamrolled by the urgent business at hand. Another relies on a religion that seems to be an off-shoot of New Age idealism that looks at danger as something of an inconvenient attitude problem. Another character, one that has assembled considerable power and treasure is asked how he copes with the chaos just outside the door and he replies, "I don't pay attention to it."But worse, what would life be like if you didn't have sufficient wealth to maintain your freedom? In this exercise (in this movie), civil liberties are shattered. "Illegal immigrants" are collected like Pol Pot-era Cambodian outlaws, put in cages and taken to camps. Some are displayed in poses from Abu Graeb, others... who knows? We the viewers of the film, move on to other vital business.So, bravo to P.D. James and the five other credited writers: Alfonso Cuarón, Timothy Sexton, David Arata, Mark Fergus and Hawk Ostby. And of course, bravo to Alfonso Cuarón, who held this all together as an organic, nuanced vision.Bravo.

I first saw a trailer for this several months ago and was immediately intrigued. I expected a lot of current political and social themes, and this movie definitely gives them en force. There have been many reviews criticizing the unanswered questions about the siege of Seattle, why everyone wants to go to England, why women are infertile, and more. However, the answers are certainly in our imaginations living in the world we do today. The plot could certainly have been fleshed out more to include these answers, but the movie would have had to be three hours long instead of an hour and 45 minutes. I was left feeling very hopeful with this film. This says a lot considering the entire film is about as full of despair as any film could be. I preferred not having every little detail explained and the gritty way it was filmed. The more I think about this movie (which has been near constant since I watched it last night) the more I loved it. I can't wait to read the book.

In just his fourth movie directed abroad, Children of Men (USA-UK, 2006), Alfonso Cuarón establishes his great skills to take advantage of the huge technical resources and special effects of the majors, in order to use them along with an interesting and uncommon story. Although set in a futuristic scenario (seen several times before): a fascist and Orwellian society, paranoiac, xenophobic and repressive, the result is an impressive and entertaining film, formed by a great production and a superb cast.In one of the most sublimes and outstanding scenes (adaptation of the P.D. James?s novel) Theo (remarkable Clive Owen), after surviving a rain of bullets and bombs in a tumbledown city (not far away from the modern Irak war images), he's holding while walking between soldiers and illegal immigrants the first baby girl born after 18 years without any new born child. A miraculous and hopeful image, announcing a promising future for mankind.Cuarón is aware about the great and efficient cast he has in hands. Michael Caine (evidently he had fun performing his character) is just great as a sort of hippie of the 21th century and pacifist who fought against the war in Irak back in the 1990's and 2000's. Besides, Cuarón is able to direct with ability the action scenes and persecutions, creating outstanding digital scenarios as well (i.e. that of a huge balloon pig-shaped, taken from the cover of Pink Floyd record "Animals"). The photography is a master-work of the Mexican cinematographer Emmanuel "Chivo" Lubezki, filming the entire movie with a shaky-cam style. His work is simply impressive, especially the last scenes where he imitates the style of a camera-man in a kind of battle field, following Clive Owen to every corner in the destroyed city.

Very depressing movie when you think about it. And it only gets more depressing as it goes, with each character getting killed off as the movie progresses. The theme was a good one, but i think it could have been done a little better, Alfonso Cuarón is not a good director. There's a particular first-personish part that happens near the end, and it gets confusing for a moment how he transitions to first person, you don't know if you're the gypsy girl, or just following Theo around, and for a good 5 minutes, dust/blood gets on the camera lenses, and makes it rather annoying to me.The ending was very abrupt, and that really hurts the already iffy movie in my opinion. All in all, it was a decent movie, but, i don't think it's worth your $10, wait for video, or, if you're really anxious, get an early showing somewhere.

Review title: WOW!!! Words can't describe how this movie made me feel....
Review_body: And, therefore, this will be a rather short review.... Watching this movie reminded me of the opening scene of "Saving Private Ryan," where you felt like you are right there in the middle of it. It provokes an emotion that you didn't even know existed. You feel the sorrow, pain, anxiousness, fear, and ultimately the hope.I won't go into the plot or my opinion concerning the ending. You can find a hundred other reviews for that. I have been reading reviews from this website for years, but after watching this movie, I felt the need to express how incredible I thought it was.It is absolute insanity that this was not nominated for a best picture award...but oh well, the Oscars tick me off anyway. They hardly ever get it right....

Clive Owen and Michael Caine were excellent in this finely crafted and articulately shot movie. Shot in a "Saving Private Ryan" style, hand-held, with continuous, unflinching shots, some several minutes in length, the cinematographer should be a shoe-in for an Academy Award nod.Michael Caine steals every scene he is in as the aging hippie "Jasper". Clive Owen, already a fine actor, has outdone himself, playing the part of the reluctant hero and Saviour (He must have it written into his contract that every movie he's in he gets to wear a slightly rumpled but very stylish trench-coat). This movie pulls the audience from the opening scene and builds momentum and anticipation throughout until the final 20 minutes which are quite possibly the best shot, most riveting and anxiety driven scenes of this entire film or any film of 2006.Children of Men is both a thought provoking and well thought out film.Not too long, not too short, this is a must see for all movie lovers which will leave them thinking, is it too late? for hours, if not days.Perry

This could have really been a good movie, decent plot, interesting start.. really got our attention UNTIL THE MIDDLE. Nothing happens after that point, enjoy your popcorn and just relax.Then the director just rushed to the end with no point being made. No story, nothing changed in the movie. Momentous plot introduction and it didn't change anything, characters still carried on even though this was supposed to be amazing climax.. there was none, zip.Watch only if you are bored! This will definitely leave you confused. We expected much more from this line of potentially strong actors.

Review title: A Sci-FI cult classic in the making!
Review_body: a movie about the UK some 20 years in the future, Fantastic! A Sci-Fi movie in the caliber of Blade Runner! The title of this movie: Children of Men.Great effects, and a fine cast, paints a dismal view of the future of mankind....with such detailed scenes of the future in just one generation. Makes today seem like paradise! This movie has certainly changed my views on children and birth, I never before thought much about the miracle of child birth, I suppose I took it for granted, especially in this over populated World. In fact, This movie has changed my views of child birth, I can actually say, seeing this movie has changed me! And that is art! I believe art should cause an emotional reaction, this movie has! I also have to say, I think Clive Owen has replaced Nicholas Cage as my FAV male actor!

Review title: That rarest of things...a film better than the book
Review_body: I avoided this film initially because the religious overtones of the book really put me off what was otherwise a great idea. Thankfully these aspects are played down. Although the terrorists are called FISHES and they are expecting the second coming in the shape of a miracle birth. The film chooses to focus on telling a story of hope out of hopelessness. Everything is unrelentingly grim,grey and all the better for it. Rarely have I seen such a vivid dystopia of a possible future,and it works so well. The sci-fi elements are played down so that they become just a part of the story(in the same way as say,Gattaca,for example). Best of all,Clive Owen finally has a vehicle where he can show that he is a good actor. Sir Micheal Caine has never been funnier on screen in ages and almost steals the film as Owens' pot smoking friend.Julianna Moore makes the most of her part and limited screen time (and looks stunning)her hair, a rare glimpse of colour in an otherwise grey world. The ending may be a bit trite, but the film wins overall because it focuses on contemporary issues making this future even more plausible.

In a world, where could be our very future just around the corner, no one can have any new children. No one knows why nor how it started. In result, the world turns on each other making only England as the only strong nation left that's not in rumble. This now makes immigration even more of a problem as people of all cultures try to sneak into the country, only to be hunted down like dogs and sent to refugee camps around the UK. Now this is where Clive Owens comes in as he is a selfish, rough man who sees the world as a crumbling cookie getting crushed under our feet as he sees no purpose in the decline of babies or how F***ed up the world as he used to know it is. He then gets offered something that is way bigger than anything that mankind will face s he will serve a protector to a young girl with a world changing secret. This movie captures a realism of how the world could easily end up if we don't see the evil in our actions or the consequences that will follow as the stoppage of babies is somewhat of a sign from God and his anger with the world and how it looks like he gave up all hope in mankind and left them to kill and tear each other apart instead of bringing the end of the world. The sci-fi traits are there but they are the focus nor even included into the story as the movie mixes future and current day life. The performances sell the intense "OMG" moments and believe me there are a lot and they keep you invested into the movie and almost bring you to your knees and have to pray that they survive through the broken world. Overall without giving anything away, I would like to say I was one who thought this wasn't all that but ended up surprising me like the film's director, who also did my next favorite movie "Gravity", is very good at and makes stay with him till the film goes to black and the credits start rolling up. This will be a classic for many years to come for how real and yet not so real atmosphere it creates. Its worth checking out and buying to own forever as part of anyone's movie collection.

Review title: By far one of the BEST!
Review_body: Let me preface by saying that even with movies that I believe are classic, I tend to still only give them a 9. However, this movie moved me and struck me in such a way that I had to go ahead and give it a perfect 10.First the acting: While some may argue that Clive Owen's acting may be a bit dry at times, he actually fits the part perfectly. Considering the setting for this movie, one cannot expect right off the bat extremely moving and deep acting. It's set during a time of pure despair and loss of hope. And by midway through the movie, you see him transform and see a side that you normally do not see from Clive Owen in his movies (particularly because of this type of movie and the producing of it). Julianne Moore still has that wonderful persona about her of being professional enough to fit her character and come across as a bit of a hard-ass yet still perfectly capable of pure emotions. Michael Cane's character(while his fate is unfortunate) cracked me up and was perfect.Secondly, the plot, story, directing, cinematography, etc: The story, while it has been speculated, and I believe been produced in possibly a few other movies, is so raw and radical yet can be seen as so realistic! The directing and cinematography could not have been done any better for this movie. The scenes were superbly set up in terms of what needed to be "seen" during them. The key scenes that struck me in particular were the following from off the top of my head(Spoilers):1)In the beginning scene after Clive Owen comes out of the coffee shop and a bomb is detonated in that same shop after he walks about 30 feet from it (this is when i had a feeling i would in no way be disappointed by this movie).2)The entire time from when Julianne Moore and Clive Owen's characters are riding the car playing the game with the ping pong ball to when she is killed. CRUCIAL to the film in terms of raw emotion and completely sudden occurrences.3-?) There are so many more to be listed but I'd prefer not to spoil any more of the movie and let you watch it.The cinematography was excellent especially in showing the complete and utter devastation and chaos that has come over the world in just the twenty years.In a way I felt as if I were watching a George Orwell or Aldous Huxley novel being put to film. It was SUPERB. I will leave the rest of you to go see it for yourself!

Excellent special effects, effective story telling, and terrific performances from Julianne Moore, Michael Caine, and Clive Owen.What went wrong? Well, there's the thinly veiled political message that homeland security is turning western society into a police state. And beyond that, what is the story? Not much. Do we know why human reproduction has stopped? No. Do we know why they government is attempting to deport illegal aliens? No. Do we know why "the human project" is something better? No.We pretty much don't know anything, except that homeland security is bad, and the government is abusing illegal immigrants. If that is the point of the movie, you can keep it. I would like to have a story. And something that is politically neutral.

Besides some amazing cinematography, and other technical merits, this movie has little to offer. Poor character development, painful exposition. This movie consists of a beginning and a middle, no proper ending anywhere to be found. As it is an adaptation of a novel, it is hard to fault them for staying true to the source material, but this movie has the same problems translating to the screen as The Da Vinci Code. The audience is expected to care about characters who are given less than 5 minutes of screen time before they are thrown into peril. Supporting characters are given annoying catch phrases or quirks in lieu of proper personalities. Look elsewhere for the next big thing in sci-fi. This is clearly out of the Stephen Spielberg school of film-making. If this film wasn't so hyped up I wouldn't feel the need to comment, but there has to be a voice of reason midst all the hysteria.

When I first saw the trailer for this film and subsequently heard the title, I didn't get the "have to see this" reaction initially. It seemed interesting enough, something I could wait to see on DVD, but after hearing initial reviews I thought I'd give it a go. Thankfully I chose the latter - because I was blown away by this film.The best way I can describe it is "Eraserhead" meets "Blade Runner" meets "1984". It is undoubtedly a bleak look at a future world mired in violence and hopelessness. Each scene is beautifully framed by Cuaron; who illustrates a world that only a visionary could create.There are two scenes which clearly stick out in my mind and will most certainly be long remembered, which I won't go into detail on. I will say one scene contains one of, if not THE most incredible tracking shots I've ever seen. Some of the hand-held shots are done in such a way that you get absolutely lost in the action. The camera angles and perspectives Cuaron chooses aren't truly innovative but somehow they feel as though they are. The film has some truly poetic moments which contrast the beauty of new life against the gritty, tough and violent backdrop.Clive Owen proves yet again he is one of the most gifted modern actors. He balances the action sequences with the quieter, more dramatic moments in a seamless fashion; his performance is powerful to say the least. Owen is surrounded by an ensemble cast of unique characters headed by an interesting portrayal by Michael Caine, his ex-wife/activist leader Julianne Moore and a nice performance by Claire Hope Ashity, who plays "Kee", the one light in a world of hopelessness.Unfortunately there will be those that lump this into the "leftist propaganda" mess, political jargon, blah, blah, blah. You can't deny the statements that the film makes but this movie is so much more than a simple political statement. It is a work that will be looked at years down the line as one of the more amazing and noteworthy accomplishments of the last several years.Do yourself a favor and go check this film out.

Review title: probably only those people like it, who read the book
Review_body: Clive Owen... a cardboard box has more emotion in it's acting. I wonder if anyone tried to give him any directions on the character or they just let him go wild.Julianne Moore?? Yeah, she was in this film,I can't remember her character's name. I assumed from the sad music I was supposed to feel sad that she died but couldn't care less. I've read other reviews and people who liked this movie often say that important information is shown here and there for example one piece of newspaper (out of a few dozen) next to Clive Owen in the interrogation room, that we see for a few second, mentions nuclear fallout in Africa. That's either lousy production design because why would I read THAT particular newspaper on the wall or a lousy attempt to explain the lack of information in the movie.The problem with this film is that it thinks it's very clever with it's secrecy and aura of mystery but it's just stupid. A clever film gives us small pieces of a bigger picture which by the end I can put together in my head (an even better film surprises me by putting together the same pieces in a way I didn't think of), but here the pieces don't make a bigger picture, they don't make sense together. There are a lot of information that isn't given (or "cleverly" hidden) but would be important, a lot that is useless and they're mostly told instead of shown. For example Julianne Moore's character get's way more screen time and build-up for a character that dies 15 minutes after appearing.I didn't know enough about ANYTHING to connect emotionally. Not to mention Clive Owens robot acting.This film was too long for so much nothing to happen.(The cinematography was nice and Micheal Caine - compared to the rest - was good in his horribly written character.)

There is a contract between the audience and the creators of any artistic endeavor. Simply put, the creator agrees to make something believable and the audience agrees to suspend disbelief.This was taught to me by my acting prof in university and has held true for all exhibitions of artistic talent I have had the privilege to experience.This film fulfilled that contract without even a murmur of doubt. The individuals portrayed seem like people we all know. Their actions in any given situation are realistic and the situations they find themselves in are believable.Details have been considered from how a person falls when hit by a stray bullet to natural dialog between old friends.I highly recommend it!

Review title: I've been 10 rounds with Mike Tyson
Review_body: Fantastic and moving film. I wasn't sure where this film was heading but in the end, it didn't disappoint.The start instantly hits you. Then build up of the story, until the shocking revelation. Then the final scenes, are all put together magnificently. Some of the fight scenes are so well done, with no expense spared. I loved the way the Terrorists where turned into Freedom Fighters and the goodies became baddies. Great twists and turns in the script without getting stupid.I will wait a few months and watch this one again.A MUST SEE! Tony

Review title: Amazing cinema, let down by poor story.
Review_body: Children of Men (COM, as I will now refer to it as) is not a movie you recommend to your friends. Yes, it's violent but who doesn't enjoy a good dose of violence. What COM lacks is substance and without it, the film feels slightly weak.Alfonso Cauron set out to accomplish something other than entertain his audiences with COM. You could argue that he is making a point about present day issues regarding racial profiling and fear mongering. But then, what film these days isn't trying to deliver a message.After viewing COM I have a lot of respect for Mr. Caurons eye as a director but I feel that the message he was trying to express have ultimately been sullied by the films lack of back story and information. Not to give away any of the plot it's suffice to say this movie lacks the padding it needed to make it truly acceptable to audiences expecting 'more'.This however should not deter people who can look past such misdemeanors and go and see a film that is incredibly engaging and extremely well shot. Even without the information you so dearly crave as the credits roll any lover of cinema will be able to sit back and appreciate the creative prowess so apparent in this film. Not since Kubrick have I been so stunned by such rock steady camera work.The opinions expressed in this film can be interpreted as many different things, depending on your own opinions about standard of living and racial acceptance. The closing 45 minutes of COM illustrate a world we so often view many miles away through the lens of a CNN or FOX camera, devoid of any true emotion. COM makes you walk the path of the deprived and forces you to accept what you see.Whilst not a moving picture in my opinion, Children of Men is an important film due solely to the fact that Mr. Cauron set out to shoot the film HE wanted to shoot. It is reassuring to know that there still remain film makers daring enough to pursue their own ends and not bow down to others. Perhaps the scariest idea to take away with you after viewing is that often in this world the truest face of evil in this world is the most familiar.A sterling effort by Clive Owen, who I believe held the film together with his down but not out performance of a man fighting to make a difference. Michael Caine injected some much needed comic relief which helped keep the film fresh in the viewer's heads. I want to give COM an 8, but due to the many questions left unanswered it slides to 7.5 out of 10. Once again, this films main attraction is its simply amazing cinematography, the best in recent films.

Review title: I can't see what the excitement is about ...
Review_body: Let me start by saying I am a huge SciFi fan and will watch anything of the genre. I went to see Children of Man because I heard somewhere that it was the Bladerunner for this decade or something like that. Well I don't know what the fuss is all about. This movie was certainly not up to Bladerunner. Sure it has a life message for humanity as Bladerunner did, but not much substance. There were so many holes in the film. We are never really satisfactorily told why there are no more babies. We are never told why there are mounds of burning animals and stuff all over the fields of England. We are never given any reason why they are rounding up foreigners. One would think with the human race dying off already we would not need to round up immigrants and kill them thus accelerating the problem. Plus there was nothing really techno in the movie at all. We are never told what the 'Human Project' is trying to do. We are never given a clue what is going on in other parts of the world other than they are evidently worse of than England. I think the movie fails as a SciFi movie, I think it fails as an action movie and some of the acting just fails. Hello Clive! Show some range will you. He does get better as the movie goes along.I think the movie was simply a plea to our humanity to live in peace or face the consequences of the end of that humanity mixed with a little 'children are our future ... let them lead the way ...". That message is clear. There is also definitely more than a tinge of anti-totalitarianism and anti-terrorism in the film, so that works as part of the overall message as well. Maybe that is what amazes so many critics, but I left feeling a little cheated.

Stunning? Oh I was stunned alright.
