You sit in that cushion seat in the theater with all the other yuppies who were brainwashed with the trailer, previews and reviews, and you think your going to watch a real master piece. More along the lines of a piece of *&^%. Indeed. So let me get this straight! The world goes mad when it becomes news that a new child will be brought into the world and that reproduction may continue, but they have no problem kill each other constantly? Do they or do they no appreciate human life in general? Jeez. Bad acting, cinematography, storyline (lack there of I should say). I sentence Clive Owen back to playing more interesting characters such as in 'Closer' instead of associating himself with this cheap remake of '1984' meets 'The Handmaids Tale' without the substance! boo.

Review title: Wow I did not expect to love this movie
Review_body: I had heard bits and pieces of Children of Men being great but the general look of it never really interested me. I recently found it on demand and decided to give it a try, and boy am I happy I did. What seems like it may be a boring drama is truly an immensely well shot, intriguing and overall fantastic piece of great science fiction. First off, the acting is phenomenal, Clive Owen is perfect in his leading role and the supporting cast around him including Julianne Moore, Chiwetel Ejiofor, and Michael Caine all put in stellar efforts. Where this movie really makes its mark however is the directing and cinematography. The film is filled with beautifully shot, long drawn out one take shots that pack in more action, suspense, and drama then some films manage to do as a whole. At times the camera movements feel almost found footage but it is done in a way that makes you feel like part of what is going on without the nausea some people feel from the form of film-making. The cinematography also perfectly encapsulates the ruined dystopian future these characters are a part of. The plot and story telling is the only area that I fault this movie. The premise is very interesting but many things are not explained as well as they could such as where they are going, how the infertility came to be, and the uprising. That being said, the way the story is told more than makes up for that. Overall, Children of Men was a huge surprise to me and I am more than happy to watch it again. Children of Men gets an A

After reading some good reviews of this movie, I decided to finally watch it although the whole concept of the story didn't really appeal to me.I wish I could get those two hours of my life back. It was extremely boring, the story was very confusing, I was just sitting and waiting for something to happen and some kind of explanation of what the story was actually about. They were going to catch some ship to get to some people you never really hear anything about? The story is basically this: They are running away from someone. They are hiding somewhere. People are getting killed and they move to another location. Repeat.Some of the cinematography was good, but that is really the only thing that in my eyes can juuust pull this up to a 2-star rating.

Children of Men is quite possibly one of the best films ever made. There is so much to admire about the film, and way too much to notice in just one watch. One of my absolute favorite things in any given movie is its ability to craft an entire world before your eyes, and no movie quite does this as well as Children of Men. From the very start we're hearing news stories about the death of important figures, and seeing the state of things in the world around us. There's just so much to see. Alfonso Cuaron takes the audience on an amusement park ride by moving the camera into locations we wouldn't normally go just to get an extra glimpse at the state of the world. We never learn the story of a mother grieving over her dead son, nor do we dive deep into the British propaganda we see scattered in the streets, but that's the beauty of it, all of these things help to create a believable world that's never been done so effectively.The story we actually follow about Theo Faron trying to transport the first pregnant girl in 18 years to the safety of the fabled Human Project is just as fantastic as the world it takes place in. Theo leaves his boring lifestyle to do something good for the world and as a consequence we see various figures in his life get ripped out of existence. The things we see people do for the hope of seeing just a single newborn person again is beautiful and heartbreaking. Best of all, the story is told through the actions the characters take, the movie includes almost no expositional dialogue and rather we learn about the situation through the character's actions, and through the details in the world around us.I haven't even mentioned the massively impressive long shots. In the end, Children of Men is challenged by very view in its world building abilities and uses its universe to deliver a story about the good of the entire human race's future. It's compelling, and it look and feels beautiful. 10/10.

I went to see this film last night and I found it at times shocking, moving, exciting and funny. The storyline is a little thin with many things (such as the Human Project) not fully explained. However, for me this added to the total effect of the film. Instead of an old fashioned chase film where your concentration rests on the next obstacle/explosion I found myself resting on the fact that Britain could turnout like this. It is, in my opinion, the most realistic portrayal of what the near future may be like. Immigration is already a political hot potato and illegal immigrant probably would be locked up in cages if everyone was trying to get into the UK. Anyway, I am clearly getting off topic.The acting is first rate, notably Caine as an ageing hippy who grows his own weed! Owen does a good job as well but he always seems to play the emotionally torn role in almost everything he does.It is very well directed, at times Blade Runner-esquire, and at times comparable to Saving Private Ryan, (in an excellent battle sequence).All in all, I give this film 8 out of 10, could have been better, but not by much.

There is nothing worth saying about this movie except don't watch it. If you are looking for a somewhat political sci-fi movie set in the future rent Brazil. Brazil is a GREAT movie. Children of Men is a TERRIBLE movie. Hope that comparison helps somehow.Maybe I'm being a bit hard on this film. I mean it would have been good if they had just included things like a plot, the slightest bit of cleverness/irony/thought in their political references, or even just something a little bit more entertaining than an old hippie hooked on strawberry cough weed. They should have just thrown in a good knock knock joke somewhere so we could of at least had a giggle, although I suppose coming up with a knock knock joke would have required 3 to 4 times the amount of thought that went in to making this entire film.No, I'm not being hard on it. The movie sucked.

Review title: A classic that will not grow old for a very long time (ironic in some respects)
Review_body: This film truly is a dark horse. It hits you with a swing from the side when you're expecting an uppercut. I hadn't tracked progress of this production and so only came across it when the trailer was released. Immediately the plot caught my attention and my girlfriend and myself both agreed it was a must see (through interest of how they would progress the story) and we were not in anyway disappointed. Unlike many recent films of a grim near future the story doesn't require an obvious twist to justify two hours of simple plot, it sticks with what it says on the tin and delivers perfectly. Its truly beautiful. Tear jerking in fact.Please please rent or buy this film. Support a truly amazing British movie production and understand for yourself why this is my number one film of 2006.

Review title: Not worth it, bunch of famous actors won't make a good movie of this one. Sorry for them, pathetic move in their careers.
Review_body:

Review title: Honestly confused to how anyone can give this film a bad review?
Review_body: I found this film after looking up best recent British films, maybe that's the issue, maybe there wasn't enough nudity and aliens for Hollywood "big screen" fans. Maybe I'm bias but the film I just watched had me far more gripped than any big Hollywood film of recent.Felt tense and thrown in to the suspense, as well as being touched by the plot line and trying to imagine how horrific the events in the film would be if they were to happen. There were parts in which this was very potent, especially near the end, no spoilers intended.Michael Caine played a role I could never see him suiting and he played it well. The two lead roles also pulled me further into the suspense, especially like how, again, Hollywood poison seemed so distant from this film in the respect that the lead role didn't even need to fire a single shot in this quite action packed film.I read a review on here before watching that claimed that this film left things unexplained, and having just seen another current film in the cinema recently, I salute the makers of this film. It's like people have lost the use of their imagination and need to be spoon fed what to think, also don't take that as in this film leaves stones unturned, they are silly little things that lazy people can't be bothered to think about.Great filmWorth watching.

Although released in 2006, Children of Men is more relevant today (2016) than ever. The film explores the crisis of an end of the world scenario where fertility had all together become nonexistent. The feeling of depression, terror, and down right chaos prevail all over the fictional world. Fictional as it may be, the world of Children of Men explores the same fear and terror plastered on the news we see today. Dir. Cuaron and his team, most notably cinematographer Lubezki, amazingly depict a future that is no far from ours today. Pictures of caged immigrants; the dismantle of strong and sane leadership; riot police and garbage plaguing the deteriorating world all reflect what may occur in our future. Today, anti-immigration aggression; riots against authority (namely against police brutality); and a dictatorial, racist presidential candidate evoke the same omnipresent fear felt in the world of Children of Men.In an addition to the gut-reaching pictures of chaos, the film has been stylized in a way that could only be due to the genius minds of, long time collaborators, Cuaron and Lubezki. Filled with loads of cultural references and incredible use of the camera to submerge the audience even further, surpass the vision of the main character but to make the audience its own subject, this film is just a beautiful, chaotic piece of art that deserves to be dissected and analyzed. It's a glimpse of the past, present and future. Maaaan, I sure wish I had a crystal ball... and know how to use it.

Review title: It's definitely overrated. Good dark, depressive movie, but nothing more.
Review_body: Sci-Fi ?! - not even in a bit. Why this film even have this tag?Thriller?? - doubtfully, yupp there is violence, but there is no "trill" it doesn't keeps you in a tension.If you want to see some depressive film - that maybe your choice. You will be allowed to smile, or feel some warm feelings only several times that may be counted with fingers on the one hand.I'm analyze this film from the point of view of the mere watcher. When I want to watch movie, I may pursue several things: relax, joy, maybe it gives me an non ordinary thought or insight, or at least will resonate with my own views. So of course no relax or joy, because it's really dark film, so thoughts and compatibility of views left? As for me none of original thoughts. All ideas are swallow, even psychological aspects weak and not consistent (real people will not act in the way heroes does), the only way it may resonate with your feelings is if you know with your own eyes troubles of the refugees. In that case it'll only amplify your aggression and(or) despair (more like the second). It have great pictures, great atmosphere (in decadent sense, of course), but does it worth it, if only resolve of acquired experience is to commit suicide?

The most impressive element of this movie is the world building! every frame illuminates a new detail of the world in which the characters live and how it contrasts to our own.Every member of the cast performs very well. conveying the drastic situation. this movie is commended often for its one take sequences of action but one super fascinating aspect of these scenes is watching Clive Owens character find new objectives and accomplish them throughout these scenes without the need for cutaway shots or explanatory dialogue. it is partly due to his constant awareness in these scenes that the audience can follow the action.the premise is unique and extremely well executed. shocking and disturbing in the same way as bird box or the myst. the violence in this movie can be triggering because of its sudden and immediate nature. which is perhaps different from the cartoonish violence of other action movies.

Review title: Average Movie with Poor Storyline yet Good Action Scenes.
Review_body: I have just arrived from the cinema and have this movie fresh in my mind. The movie is set in the year 2027, during a time when all women (for a reason left unmentioned)are infertile. The youngest person on Earth is 18 years of age.To cut it short, and avoid too many spoilers; the movie can be slightly confusing at times. Whilst the main goal during the movie is quite clear, the reasons why are not. I do not believe it had a very good story line but do believe that its intense action and suspense at times throughout partly made up for that.I think what the film lacked was conveying the audience into its world, leaving the viewer with the feeling at all times of, "This is just another movie."**SPOLIER BELOW**I am quite unhappy with the ending of the story, as it cuts short too soon. The death of Theo (Clive Owen) at the climax of the film was not particularly favourable because it was seemingly left unregarded and unimportant.In conclusion, I believe this film deserves an average rating of 6/10.

This is not a mainstream movie, but surely a masterpiece, for many reasons:

-It is very well produced and translates the absurdity of many modern age problems very well,

Fans of end-of-times movies, great news - this is the best one yet.It's the near future. Women are infertile. There are no more children, and no prospects for procreation. The youngest people on the planet are 18. Schools lay fallow in disrepair. Nations are collapsing. Britain still operates as a police state, and has closed its borders to all immigrants - only British citizens are allowed to live there. Illegals are rounded up and sent who-knows-where; they are badly treated. Radicals violently protest this injustice, and terrorism is a daily fact of life. You risk your life simply getting a cup of coffee. The end is nigh, the end is nigh! Against this backdrop, we get both a superb action plot and a high-impact human drama, that rarest of motion pictures. I shall reveal no more and leave the pleasures of the intricate story to the viewer. It's expertly directed by Alfonso Cuaron ("Harry Potter/Prisoner of Azkaban", "Y Tu Mama Tambien"), who also co-wrote a brilliant screenplay. The genius of the movie is in the pacing - it starts out fairly sedate with an interesting examination of the world as it exists at that time, and gradually ratchets up the tension until by the end we can hardly stand it any more. The characters are deep and memorable, the dialogue is rich and natural, and the machinations of the plot are unpredictable and pack a great payoff. The acting (Clive Owen, Julianne Moore, Michael Caine among many others) is nothing short of immersive. Our "hero" is no Superman, and he spends most of the movie just doing the best he can, which makes him very appealing. The effects are utterly seamless. They're so well integrated you can't even tell what's an effect and what's not. This is no Hollywood picture; there is no melodrama and the camera doesn't flinch from anything, nor does the script ever resort to cliché or convention. In fact, quite early on, it clearly signals that anything goes. The cinematography is top-notch, easily the best I've ever seen in this genre. The soundtrack is suitably downbeat and never gets in the way.Like I said, best "world apocalypse" movie yet. Better than "28 Days Later", better than "Dawn of the Dead", way better than "Night of the Comet". The whole production is triple-A, and a major artistic achievement for Cuaron and his crew. 4 stars out of 4.

Review title: Excellent film if you can go watch.
Review_body: I can say that this is one of the most believable films i have seen in a long long time. The setting is realistic you can actually believe that what is going on the screen could happen.Its a mirror of what might happen if humanity doesn't change its ways, how persecution and fear can be manipulated to control a country. How people you might think of as civilised when hope is taken from them will resort to extremism.The director of the film has done such an excellent job at setting the scene with just the right amount of action vs story. the whole thing flows from the beginning to the end you feel as though you are there.yes there is blood and yes there are scenes that will make you cringe but that is probably one of the darker sides of human nature that the director has managed to portray.If you can get to a cinema watch this film, i don't think it will translate well to the small screen as it needs to be IN your face to make its impact.

First off, I hadn't heard much about this movie before going to see it; I went mainly on a whim and at the request of a friend. Overall, it was fairly entertaining, but that was about it.The thing that bothered me the most about this movie is that the message that the movie makers were trying to get out seemed to take precedence over making a good movie. The cinematography is decent, not overwhelmingly bad, but not very great either. The plot is intriguing, but moves quickly with little explanation. Perhaps given more time and development, the plot and characters could have really added something to the movie, as it was, they seemed to mainly be drivers for the message of the movie as opposed to part of the movie itself.The battle scenes were very well done. As was the explosion at the coffee shop in the beginning. They were chaotic, loud, and very convincing.However, other than that, the movie seemed to lack quality. I simply feel that they could have done much better. Overall, a good movie, I'd watch it if it came on TV, but I wouldn't spend money to see it again.

Review title: The Most Artistic Film I've Seen In a While
Review_body: Alfonso (CoM Director) has astonished me with a great film. Expecting a techno thriller, I was treated with great camera shots, very fast paced and yet an emotionally balanced action/drama. That said, the music was well placed, the story line was set and followed consistently, and perfectly casted. Every aspect of drama and action were perfectly placed to make a more than decent sci/fi drama. If movies were made like this from now on, critics would have a whole lot less to complain about. I can't wait to add this to my movie collection and ranks high with others in the genre. I recommend to all who love a good conversation afterward.

Review title: Notes from interview with Alfonso Cuaron
Review_body: I saw this movie last night and after the screening Cuaron was there for a question and answer session.First of all, this is a science fiction movie, set in a fictional future. He did not want to make a science fiction movie, but he grudgingly admitted that this is one. He also said it was a chase film, one big long chase scene. The scene in the car with the motorcycle I believe is one of the most gripping, shocking and best made car chase scenes ever. It looks like one take, but he admitted that that was pretty much impossible given 5 people in a moving car and the camera turning 360 degrees.What Cuaron kept stressing was that he was making a 'theme driven' movie, not a plot driven or character driven film. In the movie, he didn't even try to explain why women had become infertile, to him it didn't matter. To explain the 'why' would have made the focus of the movie the infertility. His theme was 'Hope'. He said, and I kind of agree, that the movie showed how he sees the world right now. There were some eerily real images on screen at the illegal detention center, scenes straight out of Abu Ghraib and Guatanamo, images of what America had become out of fear and lost hope. Even though this film is set in Britain, the Abu Ghraib images and the 'Homeland Security' references will hit thinking Americans hard.The long shot, where Theo has been separated from Kee and is trying to find her in the middle of an all out battle, was one shot eight minutes long. They had roughly 16 days to block and rehearse, and it wasn't until the 15th day that he actually rolled off the first take. They got about 3 minutes in when the D.P. slipped. Since it would take about four hours to reset everything, they had to try again in the morning, on the last day. That went about 4 minutes, when somebody missed a major cue. Late in the afternoon of the last day, with the Sun beginning to set, they tried it again. Something went wrong in the bus, and blood ended up on the camera lens. Cuaron yelled 'cut' just as an explosion was set off, so nobody heard him. Owen just kept going, and so did the camera. He claims that was how they got the take. I felt the blood on the lens just made this whole grisly, shockingly violent scene seem that much more real.Cuaron said that they had initially planned to digitally splash blood on the lens in post-production for the car chase scene when Jullianne Moore was shot, but left it in this other scene instead.There are some people who aren't going to like this movie, but I was mesmerized by the work. It is a fantastic achievement, one that assaults both your senses and your soul.This movie is still 5 weeks from being released (at least in the U.S., I'm going to assume it has already been released in Europe) and has already garnered nearly 6,000 votes on IMDb giving it a rating of 8 out of 10, not to mention hundreds of posts on here. That is simply amazing. This is sure to be one of the most talked about movies in years. I thought this was one of the most brilliantly made films I've ever seen.

I had to get out of the house. I pull up the movie listings and read a few quick summaries and picked the one that was starting in 15 mins. It turned out to be Children of Men.I have never watched a movie and said out loud, 'Wow. This is an awesome movie!', but I said it twice during this one. There are several single shot scenes that last almost 10 minutes and they are enthralling. One immediately wonders how they pulled it off. I started to look for cgi effects or wires, but they mastered total immersion with this one. This movie is captivating. The action is immediate, the plot evolves at a nice rate, and the characters are diverse and developed enough to make their behavior credible and consistent.And that says nothing about its theme and its relevance to current times.Go see this movie!

Review title: A lot of good pieces that never seemed to make a good whole.
Review_body: I was taken with the premise of the movie, a chaotic, xenophobic and doomed future world where women can no longer conceive, and the plot, the attempt to rescue the single pregnant woman on the planet. The acting was good, particularly relative newcomer Claire-Hope Ashitey in the role of the pregnant Kee. The scenery was gritty and convincing. And there were a lot of pieces in the lives of the characters that should have made be believe these people cared about each other and made me care about them. But it never quite got there. Part of the problem I felt was the lack of connectivity with the background. I kept asking how the chaos in the streets and cruel xenophobia connected with failure of humanity to procreate? It was never explained. It was just there. An interesting disappointment, but a disappointment just the same.

Review title: I know most people like it, but...
Review_body: I found the movie disturbing, not necessarily for the violence or the bleak scenery, but rather for the dismal view it gave of the capabilities of mankind. Set twenty years in the future, _Childen of Men_ gives a view of a sterile Earth, a world where no children have been born in over 18 years. Supposedly, scientists have no idea why this has happened and are powerless to stop it.The two biggest problems I have with this premise are: 1) There are three billion examples of each human gender on Earth. The scriptwriters would like us to believe that every single one of the females has suffered exactly the same fate from, one would suppose, exactly the same reason. This would have to assume that every female on earth is equally susceptible to one particular pathogen, a supposition which, scientifically, is so unlikely as to be almost impossible.2) Science is an ever changing and ever improving series of disciplines. We are in an age where we wield an almost unimaginable power over our own existence. Yet, the movie would want us to believe that scientists have essentially given up on trying to solve what is arguably the worst possible catastrophe that mankind could possibly endure. With IVF births being practically commonplace these days, we are supposed to believe that in two years, scientists will suddenly become impotent (no pun intended) to solve a fertility problem? To me, that's an almost absurd supposition.Admittedly, these are seemingly picky reasons for objecting to this movie. Still, these and other implausibilities made it impossible for me to suspend my disbelief long enough to enjoy this movie. I can toss aside belief when the premise of the movie is sheer fun (as in _Men in Black_), but in a movie which is trying to send a message, these kinds of inconsistencies serve to make the message laughable, not laudable.

Review title: Fantastic visuals, excellent story, it has a sense of realism.
Review_body: This story had some striking visual scenes that remained in my mind for hours after the movie was over. I thought the plot was excellent, and that is realistically showed how people behave in very unnatural setting. This movie had some very deep and emotional moments. It seems to me that a lot of reviewers are focusing on some parts of the movie to really nit- pick, this isn't an action film, this movies point it to convey an overall feeling of being in a time and place and that is what it does very well. You can see tiny little details all over the set and references placed throughout the film that instead of being vague and confusing are enlightening or at the very least add an intensity I haven't seen in a long time. One of the few movies that made me want to cry at one point. Definitely one of the better movies so far in the 21st century. If I had a child I would want to take them to this movie. One thing I loved about this movie was that it didn't try to explain what happened like often happens in sci-fi movies, this is very plot driven, they just show you the landscape and tell you the situation and move on. I also liked that on the extremes of either side of the political landscape in this movie they where more or less the same, just on side had power and the other none. I thought that was very true about most of life, with the people in the middle just kinda caught up in it all. I highly recommend this as a beautiful piece of film, go see it with a friend or spouse or family member, even alone if you have to.

For apocalyptic stories, this is one draws you into an amazing flowing cinematic adventure. First part is a little slow, but then the reveal and the pace and intensity increases to the end, Granted you have to buy into the situation of the world. Given that, the events are about as gripping and realistic as any film I've seen. There are long uncut scenes with high levels of coordinated action that are well worth watching. Situationally realistic is an understatement.

Review title: Full of original action, emotions, by no means a classical movie story
Review_body: This film was a very big surprise, as I never heard of it before seeing it. And the title was not promising for me.It was one of the few movies that made me drop a tear while watching it with other people. First, in the car, Theo and Julian start to play, they catch a ball with their mouths, their heads coming closer and closer. There was a feeling that their love will be revived as soon as they meet, and, as the action goes, this feeling is stronger. Only that a few seconds after the ball game Julian dies. Love won't resurrect.Second, there is an incredible scene where all the fights stop as the soldiers hear a baby crying. It caused emotions just like a real world event seen with one's own eyes. This moment ends very soon, too soon I guess. The action will continue to have nearly impossible situations, each one solved with a little luck and some divine protection. By no means a classical happy-end story, there is no strong promise that the world will be better, almost everyone dies, the love story is killed early (though the ones carrying the most of hope survive) and though people survive, their condition and perspectives worsen every day. I don't know what still holds me from giving it a ten, maybe the genius scene when the peace lasts only for 10 seconds.

Review title: The greatest movie I have seen in a long time
Review_body: Not quite science-fiction as much as a hypothetical view of what the world might turn into under extreme circumstances, Alfonso Cuarón's grim, stark vision of the future is one of the most amazing and original films of its kind.The origins of "Children of Men" lie in P.D. James' novel of the same name, but it's clearly Alfonso Cuarón's vision of the future, a hyper-exaggerated view of today's world, transposed onto a grim world where humanity's last generation is on the verge of extinction due to their inability to procreate. . It's not the shiny future with flying cars we've seen so many times, instead being a grimier version of England today that falls somewhere between Stanley Kubrick and Terry Gilliam's "12 Monkeys," humanity having given up hope on evolution or technological advances at this point.This movie gives off a eerie effect of that this is the future in store for mankind. I recommend this to anyone.
All around amazing movie that I can't describe in a few works. The last scene with Michael Kane is absolutely heart breaking. What would you do to save humanity ?

Review title: A scary thought provoking vision. Who cares about the logic holes!!!
Review_body: OK so some things aren't explained but you know what..... it really does not matter. I for one am sick of being spoon fed by film makers. I liked the sense of not knowing what was going to happen and why. Clive Owen is an amazing actor that previously I had relegated to pretty TV actor (OK so I was wrong) He has an understated quality and some fabulous lines that will alternatively have you laughing out loud and then blubbing like a baby. Children of Men is poignant, it is thought provoking but above all I hope it will change the way our world is going. Cuaron is a director to watch out for. He has really got a refreshing style. Be warned this is a film that leaves the dead to die and suffer with no fanfare. Watch it!

Review title: Children of Men" is a thrilling, visually stunning adventure with a strong lead role and a thought provoking plot that progresses at a refreshing pace.
Review_body: Judging from the trailer, Alfonso Cuaron's "Children of Men" looked to be a thrilling but relatively formulaic action film with moral issues tacked on. After seeing the whole film, I can confirm this is far from true. "Children of Men" is a brilliantly paced and stunningly directed film with some beautiful dystopian backdrops and a competent plot to boot.The film begins with a disillusioned and cynical bureaucrat, played brilliantly by Clive Owen, being kidnapped by his revolutionary ex-wife and forced to transport an unexplainably impregnated women to a mysterious haven, away from the political violence of dystopian London.While this concept is hardly worth seeing the film for, the sets and cinematography are, as is the acting, particularly from Caine and Owen. The gritty portrayal of the war torn environments are hugely realistic and enthralling, showing a post apocalyptic world that is as believable as it unreal.. This original and resourceful direction alone is a reason to see this film on the big screen, as is the hard hitting conflict and aggressive sound effects balanced with a fitting soundtrack The film excels because of this attention to detail and inventiveness but also because of its breathtaking pace. The film moves from hostility to calm at a pace that is fast enough to keep the film fresh and exciting but not so abruptly that plot details and character interaction is left untouched. While the movie moves along at a swift pace, it manages to cover many political, environmental and human issues in a subtle, arcane manner that adds to the emotion of Owen's character without detracting from the overall experience.****

I saw the poster advertising the DVD. Something about how women can't have babies anymore and the world is on the edge of destruction as result... Ho hum I thought - sounds really contrived. Another end of the world story with a dreadful sounding plot.A few months later on holiday, I saw the film on a crummy TV and missed the first 10 minutes.I was fairly interested and the movie seemed to be moving along nicely - the dystopian Brittan, the collection of art relics, the pregnant girl, the constant pets, the mysterious Human Project, the relationship between the rebel leader and Theo. Good low key acting - hey some people face the end of the world differently! Then BAM! The car chase scene. So unexpected. My eyes pretty much popped out of my head, my expectations of the movie shattered and I was so brutally, viscously dragged into the world of Children of Men.I've never experienced that with a movie before. It's like I had been watching a human interest news item about a bad place and then suddenly that world was crashing though my door. From that moment on, I was there, it's world was mine: the pain Theo felt, the desperation, the drive in him to achieve a small amount of good against a crumbling vicious word, to achieve a victory in his small, pathetic life.The picture quality was terrible, the sound poor. I didn't understand what was going on, but I was there with Theo. The people that love this film were there with Theo! And the film making emphasized that feeling perfectly - the final battle scene was unforgettably memorable.A few weeks later I bought the DVD. I saw the start. I understood what was going on. The evil plots and plans. I watched it again. And again.I have been waiting a long time for this film.I now have a new favorite film.

Review title: 2027?? I saw nothing that was more modern than 2006
Review_body: The idea of men can't have children could be worked out into a good movie i think. But the makers of Children of men failed to do this. The whole world is in chaos and the film doesn't explain how this point of chaos is reached. There are Muslims marching in London, a old German woman appears a few times babbling something that sounded like German. A gypsy also babbling in her own invented language. The hippie Jasper listened in 2027 to exact the same music as old hippies in 2006. there is also a resistant but the movie doesn't explain where against they resist. there is also a human project?? what this is i don't know.I saw this week also Buddha's lost Children and Pan's labyrinth both great movies. This one i disliked very much.

Review title: One of the Top Films of 2006-2007
Review_body: Clive Owen delivers a very impressive performance as the disaffected activist of yore. He has seemingly given in to the " one person can't really make a difference" philosophy. Micheal Caine is scarily believable as the reclusive hippie who hasn't let his idealism wane over the years though the government has become increasingly oppressive. Claire-Hope Ashitey delivers as a dumbfounded new mother, unsure of what fate has in store for her. The only issue of cast I have is with the choice of Julianne Moore. She plays her part well as the activist muse who was once central in Owen's life, but seems slightly out of water. The movie has a certain noir that is reminiscent to me of " Blare Runner"All in all, this is a complete work from director on down. Do yourself a favor and see a film that has both a message and appeal.

I saw "Children of men" yesterday and it was a big disappointment for me. I heard several of my friends say, that it is a great movie and i should definitely see it.I always liked Clive Owen, and i still think he is a great actor, but in " Children of men" he s really bad like all the other actors. They are fake, and you don t believe them.Then I liked the idea of a "post-apocaliptic" future although thats nothing new nowadays, it seems to be quite modern. Review title: Brilliant film that falters in its second half
Review_body: In a world with no future for mankind, what's the point? Of working, of peace, of living out your days? Even the audience cannot help but be gripped by this fundamental dilemma, so skillful is the manner in which movie-goers are drawn into the world of 2027.In fact, the extraordinarily three-dimensional and relevant setting is the film's greatest strength. Down to the details, each piece of the environment displays a moribund hopelessness which immediately draws the audience into its bleak atmosphere. The audience members know they are, of course, the very people living in this miserable London of the near future. This is our world, when we are just a few years older. The crushing closeness of the setting to our own reality makes this film a breathlessly intense ride.Brilliant cinematography (there are more than a few shots that resemble perfectly-composed photographs) and fantastic casting choices (Michael Caine makes the ideal fatherly hippie) makes this a wonderfully well-crafted film. And while there are clearly metaphorical overtones throughout, the director is careful not to overdo it, or to impart too much information that is not truly relevant to the story.This film would have been able to hold its own against literary classics like 1984 or Brave New World if only the second half of the movie had been as strong in plot as the first half. Unfortunately, the end of the movie degenerates into an irritatingly generic battle-zone escape sequence, as if a shortage of plot development was filled in with a gluttony of guns. The only moderately satisfying ending does nothing to save the latter half of the movie.As a whole, this is a movie to see and perhaps to continue musing on for several days afterwards. It would certainly not be appropriate for anyone too young for 'Saving Private Ryan or Schindler's list. But for an adult looking for a film that will expertly seize your breath as well as giving you something to talk about on the way home, Children of Men is highly recommended.

I'm very surprised this movie got as many starts as it has. I am a big fan of sci-fi movies but thought this was awful. It's quite dark and depressing and I don't feel there was ever much hope shown.If you like watching rampant killings, close-ups of people having their brains blown out, and tons of senseless violence, then you'll love this movie.Otherwise, I didn't see any redeeming qualities and would not recommend it to anyone. It's a shame to see such acting talent go to waste on this type of file. With a little time spent to improve the story line and remove the excessive violence, it could have been a good movie. Instead of bringing me into the story, I felt like I was constantly on the outside looking in and feeling appalled at what I was seeing.I disliked the movie so much that I seriously considered getting up and leaving after the first hour.

Some simply extraordinary scenes. Cinematography of pure excellence. The birth of "Danny" is was such a mesmerizing moment, he just sprung to life in his hands. The laugh withheld for twenty years through pain and suffering. Kee and Theo's decent down the building being fired upon by the army. The yell's for "cease-fire' as the cry of the first baby in nineteen years fill their faces, thoughts and actions with hope. With an apocalyptic belief filling the air with dismay and decay, the feeling of hope really fill's the viewer, making it a must see movie. Furthermore are the roles of each character filled perfectly by the talents of Julianne Morre, Micheal Caine, Clive Owen and Claire-Hope Ashitey. Their roles were complete, and filled me with warmth. The music, "Eternity's Sunrise" was such an example of the mood of this movie. The gradual steadying of the camera. It was simply superb.

Review title: Children of Men, Subtitile: Why Bother
Review_body: I am a major "Blade Runner" fan and I heard this movie advertised as "Blade Runner for the 21st Century." Unfortunately it wasn't even close and it wasn't sci-fi. This movie takes place only 20 years in the future and is clearly tied to our present. For some unknown reason, society has fallen apart throughout the entire world. Apparently wars are going on and there was an epidemic (bird flu?) in 2007 and people are generally vicious and uncaring about what goes on around them. The only plot you can glean from the movie is that for some reason (maybe the epidemic) women can't get pregnant so everyone goes crazy and attacks each other, and people from all over the world want to sneak into England (illegal aliens). The illegals are treated harshly in England, by being rounded up and put into tiny cages before being transported to a walled up (part of) old city (i.e., the Nazis in Poland, or Escape from New York).Then "hero" of the story, Theo (played by Clive Owen - big fan) surprisingly appears to be living a fairly normal life (going to work, coming home every day, trying to pay his bills) in the midst of this chaos. Suddenly, he finds himself asked to do a favor for a radical political group called the Fishes, lead by is ex-wife. He and his ex were members of the Fishes in their youth. He left, she stayed and the Fishes committed some terrorist acts (after Theo left), but his ex assures him that, that isn't what they do anymore. She asks him to get travel papers for a young woman without giving him much info, he says no initially but decides he needs the money she offered. Do you think he'll get the papers when pigs fly? Look what's floating in the background when he arrives to ask for the papers, a flying (well actually floating) pig. It was so distracting in the scene that I could only look at that giant ping and wonder, "does the director think the audience so dumb they won't get the symbolism unless he slaps them in the face with it." Anyway the savior of mankind is a baby being carried by the young women that, unfortunately for Theo, he only finds about the baby after he is under the control of the Fishes. Shortly afterward he finds out the Fishes staged a coup by killing his ex, and they will kill him in the morning and keep the baby (did I say savior of mankind) for themselves. For some reason the radicals believe the baby will incite an uprising against the current government, and I assume they will need to rule until the Savior, uh I mean baby is old enough. Unfortunately for Theo (and Clive) his heroism never comes out, by the time he finds out what is going on, he is already stuck, with escape his only way out. He seems to hang on to the girl and baby more as a security blanket then any attempt to rescue them. Near the end of the movie when there is everything from handguns to tanks firing all around him and the baby, he never once attempts to pick up a weapon to protect the baby. What I found most offensive was a scene that clearly was intended to depict a group of Middle Eastern radicals (terrorists) parading down the streets of the walled-in and secure (?) ghetto, carrying banners and AK-47s. Why Middle Easterners and where did they get all the AK-47s in the middle of a walled-in ghetto (prison camp) in England? The good: Alfonso Cuarón produced some great cinematography. If you are interested in becoming a camera operator and or directory of photography, this is a great movie to watch. The visuals seem to be right out of the war in Iraq but with even greater intensity. Surreal gritty realism at its best. It is clear that Alfonso Cuarón wanted to create a movie with such stunning visuals that you would forced to consider mankind's future. His movie does this, but unfortunately all you see is hate, pain, and cruelty, from the point of view of a few, who seem only to want to be left alone. If Alfonso Cuarón believes this is where mankind is headed, then why care at all.Final: Blade Runner was about the hope that men and women have (even if artificially created) and that life no matter how it turns out, is worth fighting for, even if it isn't perfect. In Children of Men most everyone wants something at the expense of others, except Theo who just wants to survive. The only hope we are left with at the end of the film, is that maybe this baby will enable the continuation of the savagery and pain we saw throughout the film. Why?

Review title: Massive migration problems vs. lack of children
Review_body: I think that movie was quite good, especially first half hour of it. But then it more and more tries to convince us that there are too many people world-wide, despite the fact that there were no new kids in 18 years. If we look at the Sierra Leone for example, half of the population consists of children aged up to 14 years. We can imagine what would happen if there were no natality for so long. There were also many other activities such as discriminatory emigration policy, terrorist groups in GB, but the reasons for that were never told. They for sure cannot be consequence of lack of children and common misery because of it. Immigrants are surely not the only reason (if at all) for the world to collapse into chaos. I think that many important themes were too much simplified in order to present one problem. However, violence, riots and civil disobedience which led to unrest were shown very well and realistic, but reasons for them were not defined.

Review title: Very powerful, effective and realistic....... apocalyptic chaos brought to life.....
Review_body: This is a great movie, truly, a very powerful and emotive movie. the acting was top class (including an underused Julianne Moore), it could have been over acted but wasn't, could have been tacky and sensationalist but the cast and director maintain a very level headed, dramatic, yet believably. Thats the charm....and power of this movie....its incredibly realistic. This doomsday scenario is made believably....and thats pretty hard hitting. Unfortunately, there is a draw back, they went too far to make it look gritty, the shaky camera technique, apparently "documentary style". the sets, locations and effects are all superb, therefore in my opinion the gritty look is completely unnecessary. its realistic enough and doesn't add at all to the action. All in all, its a great realistic, and challenging movie... definitely worth a look.....

Review title: Beautiful film about our ugly world
Review_body: With Children of Men Alfonso Cuarón continues his skill at making films that are beautiful to watch, layered with political commentary, and leave the audience with enough ambiguity to interpret the film for themselves.The backdrop is a not-too-distant future where problems like war and ecological destruction have reached a breaking point causing both mass migration and infertility. A single woman, Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey), becomes pregnant and must navigate through an oppressive nationalist England as well as revolutionary groups concerned only with their own agendas. Kee gets help from the jaded alcoholic Theo (Clive Owen) on their way to a secret project that aims to undo infertility.The film is beautifully dark with each set packed full of information about this strangely familiar world. There are piles of burning cattle carcasses, ever-present advertisements for drugs, and immigrants being rounded up and hooded. Long "single-shot" action sequences that incorporated digital splicing help move the story along. Cuarón straps us into each car chase scene making them feel almost like amusement rides. In Y Tu Mama Tambien, Cuarón used an erotic teen adventure to tell the tale of contemporary politics in Mexico. In Children of Men, he uses the escape plot line to tell the story of an issue that is hardly action-oriented: infertility.Children of Men refuses to give us any simple answers. The government labels a sympathetic Julian (Julianne Moore) as England's number one terrorist. The revolutionary group "The Fishes" cannot be trusted. There is no named cause for the mass infertility. There is no single cause for the global collapse that seems to have happened outside of England. The ending is ambiguous. Theo comments early in the film that he is not sure how much new babies would help since the world was already a messed up place. In our contemporary world we have wars, authoritarian governments, climate change, collapsed fisheries, refugee crises, toxic pollution, infertility, disease and water shortages, any or all of which can lead to the world of Children of Men. There is also a quiet acceptance in our modern society that we have crossed a threshold that we can never return through. We might not get a happy ending. Children of Men unnervingly represents this lack of hope.When Kee is in the barn, she makes an aside about how the "cut the titties" of dairy cows because the machines can only fit 4 nipples. Only in a world based on masculine values would such a barbaric act be perpetrated in the name of production. Ultimately, we are all children of men and world we have created is the child of men. We have been raised to value violence, material production, authority and ecological destruction. Issues like fertility and compassion for our fellow humans fall to the wayside to oil wars and deporting immigrants. The children of men very well may spend their dying days oppressing immigrants and pointing guns as they march violently into the hell of their own creation.If this interpretation is true, this would make Children of Men the only contemporary ecofeminist film to my knowledge. In the end we are left to wonder, "If children of men have destroyed this world, can the children of women heal it?"

Review title: Stop viewing this movie through a political lens
Review_body: One of the best I've seen in a while, but I can't stand reading these posts about how the movie is any kind of a warning or political commentary---it is not---it is a story. Having said that, I took the movie as a fascinating look into the ability of childbirth to make us feel just a little bit immortal, perhaps just enough. In the world today, we are all going to die, just like the world in the movie, the only difference in the movie is that these people cannot pass life along, but just as they are witnessing an end to their species, we're witnessing the end of every living person on Earth, the only difference is that in this world dead people are replaced with other people, who will eventually die. Sorry if this seems bleak, try not to discount it as despressing. As far as leftist/Georg Bush-ist views on the film, can't we learn more about ourselves by REMOVING a story from our own world? and its biases and spins? I'm not saying relevance is bad, its very important for our understanding ... but please leave your politics at the door of the theater.Also to answer the ridiculously distracted post about the black baby... do you really think that woman and child were going to have thousands of kids and repopulate England alone? First of all, if babies were born again, perhaps the world could be rebuilt as a result of increased morale, so it would not be any kind of Black England, as scary as some you bigots may find that; second of all, the girl was not going to have the world's population come out of her belly, the scientists were going to find out how she was different biologically from all of those who were infertile, and hopefully allow others to have children.One question, why exactly were the those people pelting the trains with rocks? I'm assuming it was a microcosm of the impotent frustration of society over the condition of the world. (sorry about the pun) I'm out like jean short, Hayes

The idea was great the execution weeeeeeeeeeell not so much :-( Between now and 2026 there's such short period of time that it is very unlikely that anything even close to what is depicted in the movie would happen. Also not much has been said on how the situation evolved into being a war between immigrants and .... who is on the other side British citizens or the government? Who is the leader, is there still democracy or - human rights hardly exist. What is that? Is is Britain or Guantanamo? Infertility affecting all, Hmmm that is interesting but how is that gonna happen. I also lol'ed at the German immigrants in the caged areas. Is it a shout out to Germany in any way? For me the movie was too shallow tapping on certain issues (immigration, racism, Muslim -Christian conflict) without providing the audience with some depth and a glimpse of the multilayered problems - and points of views - that are behind. Ultimately it came down to good guys and bad guys (even if you could argue that the bad guys meant good). Cliwe Owen looks good but there's nothing else in it. My all time favourite actor Michael Caine is sadly not given anything to show. I hope that when he receives his lifetime achievement awards here and there the Pull my finger line (it wasn't even funny)will not be included in the short movie summing up his highs.

Review title: My review that a lot might not like...
Review_body: To all of the people who read this and loved this movie; I'm sorry: The only reason why I'm giving this 4 stars is because of the screenplay and direction style, the action sequences, the feel of realism, especially, when your watching, acting, and other small things were great. If not for some details with making the movie it would be close to 1 star. This movie was set up to be great. It had a great story idea that it could build on, but it ended up giving us a big piece of crap ending with no idea of the what we, or maybe just I and the other I saw this with, really wanted to know in the movie...and that is, "What is The Human Project?"...They give us interesting information about getting to a boat to go to The Human Project. But we never get to see it or find out any details of the science side of things. It lacked having some kind of "layers" to it, but instead the story is just said to be, right at the beginning, "...get this pregnant girl to the coast." The main reason why I wanted to see this movie so badly is 1. I wanted to see what the world would possibly be like if there were no babies being born. 2. Why are those babies not being born? They give us #1, but we get nothing close to #2. They had everything going right with the movie, but if they just made it like 40 minutes longer to get us to #2 then this is one of the best movies of the year. Someone's review said, "The ending seems a little abrupt, and leaves something to be desired." That is a perfect way to describe it, but a lot of people say that the ending is holding it back from 10 stars. And then they give it 9. For myself, on the other hand, I want a good ending to tie the movie all together, and this ending just did not cut it for me. This movie could have been monumental and could have ended 2006 with a BIG bang if they just kept giving more to the story. To me, this is one of the biggest disappointment of 2006.

I just saw this movie last night with my wife, sister and niece and we all walked out with way more questions then answers. I love sci-fi just as much as the next guy, but this movie was just done wrong!They did not explain anything at all!! It was very frustrating not knowing what was happening or why things were happening. I looked around the theatre after it was over and everyone seemed as lost and confused as we did. I really wanted to ask for my money back, but knew the request would fall on deaf ears. Spoilers possible..... 1) Why are their no pregnancies in the future? 2) Why is the world in chaos? 3) How did this woman get pregnant? 4) What happens at the end!!! 5) Who are these people? 6) What is the human project? Anyone have the answers??? I doubt it.

What frightened me the most in this movie, is that the way the year 2027 is pictured, seems so realistic close to how we live today. Except of the infertility theme, and some smaller high-tech improvements to objects we use today, the way people dress, the bars, the TV journal ... its is all so similar... very well done, and it's a fantastic trick to make you think it could all really happen in a few years from now. The plot is well build, good suspense, although towards the end the film looses somewhat of its tension, especially after the scene with the cease-fire of the soldiers in the last 10 minutes or so. That scene is extremely strong, but the continuation is somewhat of a strange curve I thought. How the "fugees" are set in scene and the link to the the refugees we see today, is particular interesting. What stays somewhat unclear is why the human race is infertile, and why the particular girl isn't, but OK: I guess you can make up something yourself... Great movie!!!

Review title: Innovative, thought provoking, and brilliantly entertaining.
Review_body: There is no story giveaway here, just short description of a shot.This film is incredibly well made and innovative. The whole action sequence filmed in the car is awe-inspiring from a film-making point of view - that is never before seen choreography and blending of acting, camera movement, stunts and special effects. The special effects are flawless throughout. The music and sound effects are pure quality. Only a few criticisms: 1) Some acting is pretty bad (but not the main characters, Clive Owen and Michael Caine are brilliant). 2) I felt the small blood splatter on the camera wasn't effective, it detracted the attention. 3) It was too short; it needs a sequel to build on more of the story. Ratings: Acting: 7.5/10 (Some 10/10, some 3/10)Directing: 9/10Cinematography: 8.5/10 Sound/music: 9/10 Plot/story: 8.5/10 Overall: 8.5/10

I've seen this film and let me tell everyone that it was one of the most pleasurable surprises I've ever had with a film. I hadn't heard about it before and it totally took me by surprise. It blew me away and left me speechless. The acting is excellent by most of the actors, but Michael Caine deserves to receive a special mention for his amazing portrait of the old hippie Jasper. His performance is fantastic and he totally stole the show in the scenes he was in. Claire Hope is also fantastic in the role of Kee. Her performance is quite impressive, especially considering this is one of her first films. Clive Owen is also great as the reluctant hero who sees his life turned upside down and is given a huge responsibility. I've seen him in some other films and he's at his best here. A very good performance, you could feel what he was going through. In the technical aspects the film was brilliant, particularly Alfonso Cuarón's strong and consistent direction that is one of the best things in the film, and contributes a lot to its quality. Also director of photography Emmanuel Lubezki does wonders with images and there are some extremely beautiful shots all done in a naturalistic way, natural lighting, etc. It's an extremely well crafted film that makes you go through the emotional struggle the characters go through and makes you feel that you're in the middle of it all. Besides, it's also an extremely touching story that certainly touched my heart. One of the best films I've ever seen without any doubt.

This was a very good movie. The theater was packed and I haven't seen a lot of advertising on it. It must be word of mouth. It's fast paced and kept me engrossed every minute. I really liked the fact they had scenes where the camera is obviously being carried by a camera man. It gave certain scenes a gritty realism that was kewl. Michael Cain is amusing right to the end. It will probably be good on DVD . I'd say waiting for this to hit commercial TV would ruin it for you. This film has good momentum and advertising would probably render it unwatchable. What is up with minimum lines? Can't someone just come on with a brief take on a film?

Last night was probably my fourth viewing of this film, and as expected with every watch its message and mentality becomes more and more clear. When I first watched the film ten years ago I wrote it off as too bleak and depressing. But as I have grown older, and with the world of the last four years of Political unrest, western cynicism and anti-immigrant rhetoric, the film seems more tonally perfect than I think Cuarón could have ever guessed it would be (which could be seen as worrying as we move towards 2027 - the film's setting).Besides the quality of the work in the context of the world, CHILDREN OF MEN is also simply a visual masterpiece, the set design creating a dystopia so clear we needn't see one more caged up London bus to understand the world we are in. The masterful tracking shots, lasting for minutes on end give the film a flow and heartbeat which makes it feel more like the events of a few hours than those of a few days. Daring, unpredictable soundtracking as well does a huge amount of work to add to the theme of cynicism vs. hope.Clive Owen, who I don't always rate, delivers an on brand unflappable protagonist (which works perfectly for the pessimistic former activist Theo Faron) alongside a cracking debut lead performance by Clare-Hope Ashitey, who invokes so much sympathy and support from the audience, all the way forward from the scene in the barn. These central stories are enhanced gorgeously by the ensemble cast, a cast which also helps to bring the feeling of familiarity to this cinematic universe.Overall, this film works perfectly both as a self-contained story of a world with a future of maximum 100 years, and the anarchy that would come about as a result. And it has such power as a representation of how we are moving in the west, knowing that we are killing our planet and how we have a true lack of sympathy for those on a different path to our own.

Review title: and brilliantly filmed in hard, flat, crisp
Review_body: PD James's future-nightmare novel of a world without children has been turned into an explosively violent and chillingly real movie, probably the best film in the Venice festival competition so far. It is directed by Alfonso Cuarón and brilliantly filmed in hard, flat, crisp detail by his cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki. The digitally realised vision of a reactionary, Orwellian Britain in 2027, with its seedy streetscapes periodically smashed by terrorist bombs, is eerily convincing, and the spectacular sequences of all-out urban warfare are electrifying and very scary.There are great cameos, chiefly one from Michael Caine as an ageing hippy who grows ganja in a secret woodland hideout and hooks Theo up with a counter-cultural support network.Peter Mullan puts in a bravura appearance as Syd, a border guard and one of Caine's weed clientele, who is able to smuggle them away from both the authorities and the terrorists. It's a smart and funny performance from the multi-talented Mullan, and it would incidentally be good to see him direct another film, as his last one, The Magdalene Sisters, won the Golden Lion here at Venice in 2002.Apart from everything else, this is a great action film, with thrilling and nail-biting moments that are all the more gripping for taking place in a ruined future world, which looks all too plausible. Added to this is Cuarón's subtle dimension of metaphor and parable: it is humankind's spiritual sterility and vanity which has made possible their catastrophic despoiling of the planet. This is quite an achievement for Cuarón, who must surely be a contender for the big prize.

When I invest two hours of my life into a movie I'd like some kind of satisfying resolution. Even David Lynch with his abstract, dreamy stream of consciousness filmaking leaves the viewer satisfied on some level. That is not the case here."Children of Men" thrusts the viewer into a future where men and women are sterile and faced with certain death. Our hero, Clive Owen drags himself through this world, jaded and sluggish - averting the eyes and pleas of non-British citizens, foreigners and immigrants violently imprisoned behind barbed wire in public places. The "resistance" discovers the only pregnant woman in Britain and recruits Clive to transport her to safety - to the mysterious group known as the "human project". How any of this pandemic and social collapse came to be is never explained.As the story unfolds we meet the "resistance" - kind of a Mad Max Population meets Hip Hop meets Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition meets Greenpeace Boat Sailors. The wise man who counsels Owen in his desperate, meaningless and doomed existence is his own dad! But this a special dad - it's Michael Caine dressed up to look exactly like John Lennon married to a woman in a Yoko Ono costume. In this flick, Mr. Lennon's seventy and tenderly caring for a mute staring Yoko, I mean Mrs. Caine who'd been tortured into an autistic existence by the British government for some unexplained reason (just like everything else that goes on here). Mr. Lennon aka Caine, is still the merry mop top prankster, smoking dope and daring Clive to pull his finger after which he lets rip a disgusting fart! Ha!Ha! The stirring background music to this loving family is a Rolling Stones soundtrack featuring an achingly sung version of Ruby Tuesday.At this point I should have said "Hello Goodbye". But I continued to plow on, like my reluctant, but consciousness awakened hero Clive. Even after the liberal, brave hearted, resistance leader - the determined and beautiful Julianne Moore is gunned down by what we and Clive discover are her own followers. It gets even more ridiculous. Every time the pregnant black woman is revealed to the world, the stunned observer cries out "Jesus Christ"! There's a Monty Pyhonesque fellow who rescues and later shoots our hero! Lots and lots of random shooting by who knows who! Trying to glean some explanation I even watched this DVD's making of featurettes. I knew I was on the road to enlightenment, when they interviewed several talking heads who made bold comments about global warming as water rushed between icebergs. Maybe I need Barak Obama and Al Gore to explain this flick to me!

This year I attended for the first time the Venice Film Festival in Italy. I was of course quite excited and bought tickets to some screenings of a few different films I found interesting. Initially Children of Men wasn't in my plans but I was convinced by a friend who was very enthusiastic about it. Now I say I'm glad I bought the tickets! What an amazing film this is. The science fiction genre is just a coat to project into the future the horrors and problems of our current days and many films attempt that ending up, in most cases, failing. This one however succeeds. Succeeds indeed but not only in this... The film blew away nearly everyone in the audience as one of the best action movies we have seen lately, with extremely exciting and brutal chases, gun fights, etc. Don't be put off by this though, the film is as good as it is not because of the action sequences but its amazingly emotional and touching story. The performances of the cast is impressive especially Clive Owen and the newcomer Claire Hope Ashitey who throughout the film develop the relationship between their characters and it's such a joy to see the development. I'm not very good at writing reviews so I think I'll stop know, but I had at least to transmit something to everyone who might be interested in watching this film. Don't pass this one, you won't regret it. In my view one of the few excellent films released this year.

Review title: unbelievable number of religious esp. catholic symbols and motives, close to scorsese
Review_body: I saw the movie children of men yesterday evening and I was amazed of "Spoilers" its way of foreshadowing and symbolic language. such a mass is only to be seen at scorsese's work. The wounds on Hands (Michael Cain) and feet (Owen) The child bringing life back to mankind, the miracle of it's birth - a story of escape and torture.And again, like in scorsese's work - a hero who doesn't want to be a hero...great work, one of the strongest movies I've seen this year and certainly one to collect to your other DVD's

This film watches like a party political broadcast. The idea that gangs of white terrorists would form so that illegal immigrants could come into the country is ludicrous. What would be their motivation? The film is summed up best by the scene where Michael Caine asks the main character to pull his finger so he can flatuate. That is around the intellectual barometer reading for this movie.This is a good example of how not to make a science fiction movie. There is a train of though that says science fiction says more about the time we live in now rather than the future. In this film it is blindingly obvious we are dealing with the present with a highly improbable storyline tacked on. Encounters with highly unpleasant characters in a grim boring looking world form it's core. To be honest I could only sit through the first half hour. This is a film that should not have been committed to celluloid. A big budget, all-star disaster which was notably only nominated at the BAFTA's for it's cinematography.

Review title: Interesting plot, too bad the movie wasn't very good.
Review_body: While basic plot of the movie seemed very interesting to me, I have to say that Children of Men was a bad adaptation of a great idea. While I am not a fan of putting art into a movie for art's sake, this movie could have used something other than dark, dreary settings and two faced people. The points that the writer(s) were trying to make may have come across a little easier if I was so depressed. The characters were supposed to be living in desperate times, this we know, but to have a movie plot with no hope and then make settings that add to the hopelessness makes the movie a little hard to stomach. This movie was the worst one I have seen since Girl with a Pearl Earring....and that, if you have seen it, is saying a lot.

Review title: my opinion on a few things in the movie!
Review_body: This is my first post, so please be gentle! i've mentioned a few things from the movie, so don't read this if you haven't seen it (though you probably won't know what i'm talking about anyway!) I saw this film last night on a whim - to be honest, there's not really any movies out at the moment i want to see! I'm so glad i saw this! I've read a few reviews of this movie in magazines, and they all said it was a sci-fi flick, but in my opinion, it's more of a 'futuristic' film - i think sci-fi, i think movies like star-trek. but this film showed a future that is quite possible. it really made me feel uneasy! everything about this 'future' was familiar, and there wasn't anything so out of place that it was jarring like in some other movies where it all seems possible and then someone gets in their flying car! the most disturbing was 'quietus', the at home suicide kit - even the advertising for it was sickening - and the fact that the kits were free and handed out by the government? creepy! i've read a few posts by others and there was one that commented about the fact that the infertility plot line didn't seem to make sense. i have to say that my initial reaction was the same, and i couldn't understand why Britain wasn't letting in any 'fugees'i the population was declining, and then i remember a comment by one of the characters - 'the whole world was going to s**t before the infertility issue - it just made it worse' (or something like that!) the infertility was like the straw that broke the camels back. i loved at the end when they were coming through the building and the sight of a baby brought everyone back to one level - it was like it united everyone, they forgot about what was happening, this little ray of hope was in their presence. but like most things, people quickly forget and the fighting starts again.i also loved the fact that there wasn't a 'good guy' in this movie. Theo was originally in it for the money, the 'terrorists' planted a bomb that killed innocent people, the government (supposedly) did the same and was keeping fugees in cages on the street, even the people who were trying to save Ke and her baby had ulterior motives. it was realistic and kept you on edge - i never knew who they should trust (i swore that Miriam was in on it too, especially when he came into the room to tell them they had to leave because they were in danger - i was yelling in my head, no! don't trust her!) in fact, the whole audience was tense, the funniest moment in the theater was when they were running away from Sid and Theo smashed him in the face with the box, the whole audience screamed! at the end i just sat in my chair and was just blown away - you didn't realise how on the edge of your seat you were! i can't say i 'loved' this movie as it's not the kind of movie that you buy on DVD and watch over and over again on a Sunday afternoon - it's too depressing! but it definitely made an impact on me. the best movie i've seen this year! (actually, equal first - i loved Confetti!)

Incredible film.brilliantly put together, and if you can ignore a few very obvious mistakes, then this might just be film of the year so far. There is a whole 15 minute section thats all one shot and it just defies belief. Its so well made. Tricky subject matter and a storyline thats nowhere near believable (because science will eventually fix everything if we can just survive long enough) but the film is so engaging and interesting that it just hooks you in and keeps you immersed in this world. I was really surprised that i liked this film so much because to be honest, everything id heard about it before just sounded like the desperate graspings of Hollywood minds. But in this case I'm well and truly proved wrong

"The Children of Men" by P.D. James (1992) is a good book. It is not very good nor is it medium. It is good.The "Children of Men" is a movie directed by Alfonso Cuarón (2006) inspired by the just mentioned book. As a movie, it is neither very good or medium, it is good. There are plenty of alternatives to this movie but seeing it is not a waste of time.Now, there is not much in common between the book and the movie. Character names are the same but not the characters themselves. Actually, I wonder why they used the same names for essentially different characters.The basic story is the same, its background is more or less the same.The book has a political appeal but it is not that political; it is more "human" (feelings, instincts and affections are of course also part of politics). P.D. James would probably not like to accept this, but as the book reaches its end, it communicates more and more directly to our instinct the fact that it was written by... a woman. (A man could of course describe this and that, it is not in the descriptions themselves, it is in the underlying "how to"). The book, even though absolutely bookish, has a deliberate vocation for a movie script.The film is an action, political and war movie. Not much "human". Indeed, not much well defined. Interesting that the suffering and miserable illegal immigrants in England are German (and also French). Interesting that the English authorities behave as German authorities did during the 3rd Reich. There is even a ghetto. Contrarily to the book, all important cities of the world, including our city, fell into anarchy and or destruction. London was the exception. Is this also interesting? The movie could go without this assumptions. Yes, they seem assumptions to me; whose assumptions are these?ricemagic.blogspot.com

Review title: Terrifying how realistic this Sci-Fi is..
Review_body: I saw this movie last night, knowing the plot summary and reading the buzz on the internet, but was still expecting just another "end of the world" movie. Children of Men is unlike any sci-fi movie I've ever seen. At times, as silly as it sounds, you feel like you are on the journey with Kee. There is plenty of adventure, drama, dry humor, and mystery to entertain all. While watching it, I was overwhelmed by the non-stop terrifying journey they go through in order to save Kee, and the chaotic world that has been created by the government....which terrifying enough, is referred to as "Homeland Security." Excellent acting, terrific script, and amazing cinematography. I recommend this movie to everyone, it will leave you thinking.

Seeing this at the cinema. Being dragged along not expecting much of a movie. But then suddenly the movie took pace from the start the acting was good and this didn't look like what i had imagined it to be. No NO instead instead i am greeted with a wonderfully gritty tone, some in your face violence and tense scenes. The basic plot of Children of men is simple.*Warning Spoilers* Its 2027 and Humanity has gone into chaos because women around the world have a infertility defect (they can't become pregnant). The only country that seems to have law left is Britain which is now hunting down immigrants and putting them in camps. At the very start the worlds youngest person has died at the age of 18. The news says he was stabbed because he never gave a fan an autograph. In comes Clive Owen (Theodore)who is watching the news in a bar. He walks out, a bomb explodes, from there on in he is thrust into humanity's last hope. To protect the worlds only pregnant woman. The goal: to get the pregnant woman to a boat for an activist group that will take care of her and find a cure for the infertile woman. Out of the movie i think the best area was the immigrants camp which looked very gritty, harsh and terrifying. It also is an obvious reference for the Jewish Ghettos in WW2. Except the only difference is people of every nationality apart from Britain that were fleeing the chaos have been crammed in this area.All in all its a very worthwhile movie to see. I thoroughly enjoyed it and will definitely be buying it on DVD when it releases on it.

The acting was awful, and the characters were just short of repulsive. Clive Owen was dreary and unconvincing, and that sums up the whole film. I have nothing good to say about it. Please don't take any notice of the amazing reviews which made us go and watch it. Save yourself a tenner and 2 hours of your life.
