If it was not for my girlfriend I would have walked out which on second thoughts I should have done. Probably the worst movie I have ever seen that had a lot of glowing reviews... what a let down...makes me wonder if they were written by the producers/directors or studios family. Hope this one goes some way to balancing them out. You have been warned.

OK lets get straight to the point, this is the easily the best action movie I've seen for several years - a gripping story, believable character acting combined with taught direction and thankfully sans cringe-making dialogue and Hollywood sentimentality.Whether the plot line bears any resemblance to the novel is frankly irrelevant - the screenplay successfully creates a recognisable (near) future world without relying on hover cars and camp Space 1999 type fashions.The extended scene following Clive Owens character as he battles through the immigrant compound betters in intensity and realism any movie battle scene I can think of (yep including the beach landing in Private Ryan) - it looks like its been shot in one continuous take. That being the case I'm still trying to work out how Cuarón managed to stage such a frantic, exciting and bloody scene.Sadly, the local Odeon where I watched the film had only about a dozen or so in the audience - pretty rubbish for a first night, especially considering the quality of the movie.Children of men works on several levels; as a thriller it betters recent Hollywood action flicks; as an example of virtuoso film making (stunning cinematography) and on another level it offers a damning indictment on the increasingly right wing political morality currently prevalent in UK and US government (but you don't have to read that into it to enjoy the movie).And as its sort of a British movie, you should go see it.

Just back from seeing the film 24/sept I can hardly recall a jot of the dialogue, but cannot get the themes, the cinematography, the action or the mood out of my head. This is a gritty film, and even the inclusion of the twee balloon (pigs might fly) outside the window in the Battersea scene and the mawkish Hollywood-esquire sentimentality of the soldiers' pause in fighting later in the film serve the purpose of enabling the director to roughly drag the viewer back to his 'reality'.Michael Caine's ageing hippie, cheerfully devoted to his invalid partner and ruthlessly executed by the self-styled liberators is in stark contrast to the pragmatically loveless society portrayed. Images recalling Guantanamo, Abu Graib, contemporary conflict between western power and Islamic determination, detention and abuse of migrants, 20th century images of the Warsaw ghetto, the Hungarian Uprising and the fragility of redemption are interwoven as Clive Owen struggles to make sense of what is going on. He becomes an unlikely hero whilst Bexhill becomes Beirut. There are no 'bad guys' or 'good guys', just a bleak expression of how ordinary people respond to extraordinary circumstances according to their own perspectives, but the innocent suffer more than the guilty,- chillingly real.A thought-provoking cinematographic experience with excellent soundtrack, brilliantly understated acting and stunning, visuals.I will certainly buy this one when the DVD is released. I also hope no-one will ever attempt a sequel, which would destroy the enigmatic impact of the film. Hollywood, keep your hands off!

Being somewhat of sceptic of any movie coming from Hollywood, I find myself pleasantly surprised with this movie. Alfonso Cuarón paints a picture of society set in a not so distant future, a society where class divide, discrimination and brutal repression have become integral polices of the British Government. The movie uses contemporary social issues affecting the U.K and in general the Western Hemisphere to highlight the main theme of social injustice and despair. I feel the story of women being unable to procreate is merely a sideline, the true message focuses on what the world has become, drawing on the example migrant resentment and hate, the film also outlines that Islamophobia and discrimination of Muslims has become common place in a not so distant Britain. The film uses a Neo-Marxist approach to understand the society, where the ruling class government will boycott minorities (migrants), use fear and manipulation to create a totalitarian and authoritarian state. Evidence of this is subtly put when Micheal Caine sates that when there is political scandal of sort a bomb goes off, deflecting the attention of the masses away from the government. The vivid imagery and violence adds a true sense of realism to this film, this of course is visible most of all in the end battle scene or "Uprising" as mentioned in the movie and is the pinnacle of the movie, what must be noted that if you looked closely when the refugee camp scene starts you will spot the words Intifada(uprising) written in Arabic on one of the walls. The refugee camp scene draws many parallels with Guantanamo Bay(camp x-ray) and in Iraq the Abu Ghraib Prison used by the American army to dehumanise Iraqis not to mention conjuring up memories of the holocaust. The most important parallel of the movie is the end battle scene one cannot help bridging the refugee camp and Uprising (Intifada) and tanks rolling in and bombing the city to bits an echo of the Palestinian West bank refugee camps being destroy by Israeli army incursions. The end scene is without a doubt the most gripping and powerful of the movie. Clive Owen, Micheal Caine and Julianne Moore give a excellent performance in this eye opener of a film.

Review title: Never felt so Dispondant and depressed
Review_body: This film had the wrong rating on it for starters and it makes 28 Days later look like a Disney film. I left the cinema felling depressed, with a very bleak outlook on the future. Don't look for the silver lining folks, because it hasn't got one..........The film had every opportunity to be a great movie, and that is by no means discrediting the acting. The acting in this was second to none, and could have been portrayed differently, and still managing to get the message across. However, the content of the movie is with such violent gorge that one would think Tarantino had a hand in the making. I am sorry movie goers but I would miss this one like the plague unless you are prepared for the worst.

Review title: near future state of t he nation and human state
Review_body: Went to see this yesterday....................at one stage I was in tears....................strange and very different film with Michael Caine playing a very different supporting role to his normal parts.Not for everyone this film, shot in Britain - British actors - quite a dark one and scary in some ways but not a horror at all ................what is scary is the subject matter and the fact that some of the scenes we see played out in other parts of the world now and the feeling that it could happen here all too soon Based in the future well not that far 2027 we have stopped having babies with the youngest person being 18 yrs 9 months - the world is in turmoil, shot with a hand held camera adds to the feel of the film.........go and see this with an open mind as I did not knowing really what to expect.Left me feeling disturbed, concerned and more as the events though fictional are not that far beyond belief..Elizabeth

Review title: A very realistic dystopian vision that just 'clicks' if you've lived in London for a while.
Review_body: A very realistic dystopian vision that just 'clicks' if you've lived in London for a while.While a pessimistic vision of the future is presented here, the movie plays for entertainment... It plays on themes prevalent in our post 9-11, post Iraq world, and it pushes the correct buttons to take intelligent england-based (specifically London centric) movie goers for a ride with enough precient themes and details to entice involvement.The background scenario is cleverly bereft of overly-simplified expliantion - rare in the Hollywood model.The cinematography is raw, convincing and seemed to me to be highly accomplished.I'm not a film critic, but I thought the acting was great and the set pieces harrowing and realistic.brilliant movie.

First off, watch this film - i don't usually enjoy helping to fill the coffers of Universal, but in this case we can let it slide because Children of Men is the kind of film that doesn't come along too often - a 'silver screen jobby' not a 'wait until it comes out on DVD' film.it has all the elements of distopian sci fi at its best, and whilst not quite on the epic scale of blade runner, it pitches to us the idea of a future we can visualise - a future in Britain thats a present in much of the world. you can take this film on face value as a high paced action flick with a story line (remeber those Hollywood - come on, dig deep) or you can look at the myriad of little asides to the plot that help paint a vivid picture of the world in which its set. references to the war in Iraq, the abuse of prisoners in abu ghrabe prison camp and the refugee camps in the UK that could have been taken right out of Lebanon.its a powerful film that shows us a Britain we can imagine, a future that is pieced together from images we see daily no the news and which almost seems to be the real message of the film.

Review title: Rubbish! worst film i have ever seen in my life (boo)!
Review_body: This film underminds the good name of bad.It did not explain many parts of the film such as who the characters were and how the world became infertile however the only reason that i did not nod off was the orthentisity of this film such as the shooting and the resemblance of concentration camp's.The story line of the film was most certainly adequate however was not portrayed successfully.Clive Owen did not particually add any individuality to the role of Theodore Fardon.The ending of the film was extremely disappointing and i don't want to ruin it for any one who has not seen the film,But it was more than ridiculous.I would definitely not advise this film to any one although if you do see it try and stay awake he he!

Review title: "Will the last one to die please turn the lights off?"
Review_body: I had seen the trailer of Children of Men some time before it came out and heard some good reviews about the movie so I was hoping I would not be disappointed.And I must say I wasn't. Overall, I found the film to be very moving and enjoyable(as much as a dystopian movie can be). Think Clive Oven's acting could be better but it was certainly intolerable. I just think he went too over the top with the "hopeless, uncaring and broken man" acting. Michael Caine was just perfect and the scenes he is in are easily the most enjoyable and positive scenes. Julianne Moore was also good although I did not expect her to be killed off so early in the movie.I have not read the book(except a short summary) but I knew the story in the film would be different than the one in the book. Come on. There is little possibility to make a successful movie appealing without adding or changing some things. Overall, I liked how the story and bits of information were told. You will not be seeing clichéd news or billboards that poke the reality to the viewers face all the time. The fact that no children are born is a reality of life and even if its rarely mentioned very openly, you know it is there. Its in the air. And you can feel it all the way through the movie. Thats another thing I liked. In almost every scene of the movie, there is a sight that reminds you that things are falling apart despite the best attempts to hold it together. You can sense the hopelessness whether its in the form of a cracked window, a distant gunfire, the dirt and grime in the cities or the detention cages that illegal immigrants are put to. And all those images and the atmosphere, put together, make Children of Men one of the most emotional movies I watched.However, the movie is not flawless. The first half of the movie felt somewhat slow and condensed. Something that I have experienced in other movies of Cuaron (such as Harry Potter and The Prisoner of Azkaban). During the first half, I got a feeling that the movie was just skimming through the story and hurrying up to reach the second half. I could swear that some scenes were cut or shortened just before the movie was released. However, the movie does shine in the second half that starts roughly from the sequence where the main characters leave Jasper to meet Sid (who is, by the way, a greatly written character on itself) and the whole Bexhill sequence. The scene where Kee gives birth and Theo has to act of midwife and the following sequences of the street battle and the "Fish" holdout in a tower block filled with civilians is one of the most violent, yet moving scenes that shows the ravages of war and the ruthlessness of its combatants all too well. I loved the shot where Luke keeps going between a state of war frenzy and a state of compassion for the newborn is, to me, a scene that reminds me of the things humanity lost in its fear of extinction and death. But the high point of the movie is the shot just few minutes later, when the whole world seems to stop for a moment upon the sight of the baby. I mentioned emotions and how Children on Men was a movie packed with it. That scene is the prime example and one of the most moving scenes I have watched.The movie ends somewhat abruptly. The question whether humanity is saved or not is not answered. But I don't think its such a bad thing. An ending that humanity got saved would be a cliché and unfitting with the grimness and bleak perspective of the movie. An ending that humanity did go extinct, however, would be a bleakness that was too forced and would have made the story pointless. Thats why, it ended just in the right place.Children of Men is a very bleak and depressing movie and I left the theatre feeling that way. But I don't find that as a bad thing. Shows that the movie was capable of invoke feelings. Also, as a lover of dystopian movies and books, I would have expected no other way. As a movie, it has its low points and it has its (very) high points. Thats why I did not regret seeing this movie at all and recommend it, but only if you're a lower of the genre. If you expect people cooperating each other for a better future and all that nonsense, pass this movie. It is one that shows the best and worst of humanity without cringing.

Review title: A very poor film apart from a good performance by Mr Caine!
Review_body: We went to see the film on opening night after seeing the trailers and reading some positive early reviews. The subject is of great interest to us and we expected a well researched and cohesive storyline at least on par with a typical TV drama. This film was nowhere near as good as the dramas shown on television and less exciting and thought out than a typical Spooks episode. The storyline of the film lacked credibility and was disjointed often leaving me with a sense of frustration. The lead up to the essence of the film - the extinction of mankind through infertility - was not dealt with at all. There were scenes in the film which were ridiculous ... 30 seconds shot of a pair of sandals being put on etc etc. A number of scenes weren't credible at all and we generally felt little connection with the characters. We left the theatre with a sense of being conned by the postings of the early critics but now find reviews from 'real' people who appear to share our disappointment. Feel free to watch the film, perhaps on DVD, but it really isn't worth the money or your time to make a trip to the cinema!!

Having read many RAVE reviews i have to say this film was a real disappointment.The story itself is a really good idea and as a book i can see how brilliant it must read,but as i hadn't read the book the film was incredibly distorted and not very explanatory.I would have liked to learn more about the lead characters,their history,and the history of what brought the world to this standstill and the women infertility.Being a fan of both Clive Owen and Julianne Moore i felt that these roles were undervaluing their acting abilities.All Clive's character seemed to do was run and hide and make the odd joke,and we barley had time to get to know julianne's character other than the fact that they had obviously been an item and had had a child together.

The entire premise of the movie is literally to discredit the native population, that is in this case, the native Britons in favour of mass uncontrolled immigration that will lead into demographic replacement. So quite literally speaking, the only way to fix this infertility apocalypse is by importing millions of non-Europeans....

First the positives. Clive Owen has established himself as a class act and continues to deliver. Michael Caine is superb as Jasper and Claire Hope is excellent as Kee. Chiwetel Ejiofor continues to give varied and excellent performances and shines as the zealot Luke. Unfortunately, Pam Ferris, as Miriam, gave an atrocious performance as though the dreadlocks were a stapled on attitude. She reminded me of Neil from the Young Ones in her comical pronouncements.Some of the imagery and cinematography was good but was also one of the downfalls of the picture for me. The Pink Pig over Battersea may bring a smile but really was too much.The car driving down the country road past the unrecognisable creature next to the effluent drain with a horizon of smoke belching chimneys really summed up this film in that it rammed home a right on message. It often tried too hard.Many have commented on the realistic and believable nature of this near future. It just made me shake my head.This was a premise film (what would a world that was sterile be like?) and it had no convincing story to carry this premise. In fact, quite ironically, the world we discover is not sterile. There are no explanations as to why the world went sterile in the first place, beyond a curse from God, and we find that it is in fact not sterile as Kee is having a baby. What sets her apart? Nothing it seems. So we must conclude that all over the world there are other Kees.There are a host of other issues force fed to us: environmentalism, nationalism, treatment of illegal immigrants - but it is all in your face and tabloid. This film tries too hard to be right on without have a narrative to speak of, beyond the single journey of woman with a baby and a reluctant hero to end up is a dinghy being picked up by some enigmatic last hope organisation.So to conclude. Some great acting, some good set pieces and camera work but a dire script and poorly conceived shovel fed moralistic stance.

Review title: Great Title! Great Plot! Great Action!
Review_body: 'Children of Men' is one of those rare films which seem to pop up ever so infrequently these days, putting your faith back in cinema. With it's fresh approach to cinematographic and superb locations, you get a real sense of how scary and feasible the plot could be. It's good to see a film of this calibre shot on British soil and makes you question why we don't get to see more UK based films, as apposed to the same Hollywood drivel we get time and again! 'Children of Men' has that grittiness about it in a similar way to Danny Boyle's 2002 Sci-fi '28 Days Later', in that you feel very much a part of the story and are taken on a journey with the characters not knowing what could be round the next corner. Clive Owen who plays Theo portrays a guy who is obviously fed up with how the world has become a hell on earth, and we get to see how he battles his own demons with the hope he has found in Kee one of the main characters, both played very convincingly, as with all the cast. One of the best Sci-fi movies of the year for me, action from beginning to end, the time just flew by...a must watch!

Children of men is philosophical, Intelligent and frightening realistic. Thumbs up for the small futuristic indications in music and technological gadgets throughout. A surprisingly good performance by Clive Owen for a change. Outstanding one-take camera-work. You must love the dirt on the lens. Excellent cinematography and editing. A technological masterpiece. You really wonder if it is really cgi. I couldn't have asked for a better ending. Totally cult already. This film has been in my mind ever since I went to see it. Children of men is intensely confrontational and from beginning to ending catching and exciting. This film must be in the running for several Oscars. Alfonso Cuarón, I think I love you.

I recently watched this film and I have to say it blew me away. I'm not usually a fan of Clive Owen, but I think his role in this film was spot on. Micheal Kane plays a successful futuristic type of hippie, again a spot on performance. The Director didn't stick to standard camera views and managed to keep the audience on the edge of their seats throughout the whole film.The story itself is intriguing, although could possibly do with a bit more explaining, and it shows quite a vivid future for the united Kingdom. Director uses some powerful images to emphasize the scene and the story, but still manages to keep it within a reasonable limit. The message is quite subtle throughout the film and I believe it shows a unique view of what the future holds for us.Absolutely worth a watch.

This movie must be viewed in the cinemas and for 2 reasons only: 1, Its a damn good yarn. 2, The SOUND FX WILL BLOW YOU AWAY !!!Oh how shallow, I hear you say. Yes thats right I am shallow. Should you get this out on DVD, make sure it is played on a surround sound system with DTS and a decent sized sub. This does not replicate the sound in a modern cinema, but it does demonstrate the pure genius of the sound crew.Oh yes, did I mention this was one the best films I have seen for many a time. Clive Owen, wry intonation at its best. Michael Caine, a joyous, mischievous return to the big screen. I won't bore you with a rambling review, just behold the film for all of its greatness.

Review title: Britain faces the end of the world
Review_body: The thing that most impressed me about this futuristic drama was the cultural accuracy in the depiction of London and England. Set 20 years in the future, you can clearly see the present day cultural influences in the characters facing the destruction of the human race. Unlike most sci-fi, which concentrates on the technological, the concept of cultural progression is central to the characterisation - how might present day hippies, new-age travellers, city hedonists, left-wing activists, terrorists, governments; - develop under the threat of destruction? The accuracy in the depictions of the different strands that make up British society, gives the feeling that the film always has an angle on you. You can see who these people were before this tragedy took hold and distorted them. This is a future that you could belong to.The background of Armageddon, reveals the superficiality of these cultural pretences, and leaves you with the raw humanity of the characters. Showing, as sci-fi can so ably do, the temporality of our present day cultural identities.The film has plenty to say politically too. The future government maintains power and tries to hold society together by creating a common enemy, immigrants and terrorists. The references to nationalistic propaganda are very well done and hit all the right prejudices. It serves as a necessary reminder of how close we are right now to George Orwell's prediction of constant war with an unseen, unquantifiable enemy.What makes this a great film in my opinion is that it does all this and it also manages to entertain in an edge of your seat fashion from start to finish. The photography and special effects are superb, especially the use of cgi - which is pretty much undetectable and used not as a flashy spectacle but as a highly effective tool, similar to "Saving Private Ryan" or the fire-truck chase scene in "Terminator 3". The story constantly takes you by surprise and ably conveys an atmosphere of chaos and confusion, as we are shown a self terminating society. Life is cheap when humanity is doomed, and a sense of meaninglessness pervades the film. The last third is very action heavy and creates incredible tension as the protagonists stumble through a series of encounters and situations that are highly unpredictable and chaotic.Feels very fresh and a great mix of genres, sci-fi at its best.

This movie has absolutely nothing to do with film art. Actors drier than a piece of wood (except M. Caine!), story completely implausible (and I know science fiction). Some nice effects though, and I actually had to smile one or two times, but that isn't enough to call a movie "art" or even "good". I particularly didn't like the part where the ex-girlfriend (ex/wife, whatever) gets shot in the middle of nowhere, and they are able to organize a new car out of the blue.What can one expect from a movie based upon a book by P.D. James? It is a movie that'll make two hours go over (if you are waiting for a train, or a dentist's appointment...), but that's all. One of the worst movies I ever saw... two hours of my life I won't get back!

Review title: Heard so much about, was really disappointed...
Review_body:
It's not worth to write more about it directly and I wish I could get the time back to look at paint dry instead. It sucked.
Get a 3 because of the actors, and could possibly have been a good movie.

Review title: a plausible attack on the senses
Review_body: Children of men. Going in "blind" to see this I was expecting a happy sci-fi yarn. what I got was a fantastically gritty thriller, set 20 years into the future,and once you have got past the premise that every women on the planet is infertile, you can enjoy this film. The immigrant issue is a visually disturbing possible future truth, it has an attention to detail that impressed as does the whole film. The violence also has the power to shock in a way you don't get,even with most shoot em up films. Michael Caine as chirpy as ever, lightens the frankly heavy storyline, Clive Owen is no "action Jackson", however is very credible as a reluctant hero. This film stands its ground and maybe needs a second viewing as some scenes are run at a fast pace.

Review title: Good story, Great acting, Very Good Directing, and oh amazing cinematography!!!
Review_body: First of all, the movie was very good and had its amazing moments!!! It gives you this feeling in your gut that nothing lasts forever, "even us"!!! Second of all I can't understand people who are saying "what is the reason women are infertile?" The answer is that no one knows!!! GET IT NO ONE KNOWS!!! If people knew why women were infertile there would be no story or novel or movie!!! Because if you found the problem it will be clear to see if there is hope or not!!! That's why Kee is the only hope!!!

Those who have read and appreciated P. D. James' novel, on which this film is supposedly based, will be disappointed. The book and film coincide at a few junctures, but the film basically presents a new story -- sometimes illogical, and inferior to P. D. James' original. Retained is the future, childless world, a world in which humanity is doomed because of its mysterious loss of fertility (other animals can procreate), a world of ever-increasing chaos, and the names of the characters. Almost everything else is changed; the story is mostly new and the characters bear little resemblance to their namesakes in the book. As it stands, the film is fair, but go read the book.

What a waste of a terrific opportunity. Infertility provides grounds for a brilliant apocalyptic vision but the logic of this film is so wrong it destroys any credibility the concept gave it. Here are my problems...1. Why is the Human Project a mysterious entity? Given the resources spent on infectious diseases today, every government, every biotech and pharmaceutical company would be doing NOTHING ELSE but trying to solve this problem. What is wrong with these people?2. Why do they believe that because KEY is an immigrant, the fact that she may hold the answer to saving humanity would be ignored? Why doesn't Theodore (Clive Owen) just take KEY to his rich and powerful cousin that gave him the transit papers? It's retarded.3. If they need to get to this buoy to find The Human Project why don't they just get a boat and go there? Why do they need to go through the detention centre? Sure it's a little closer but it's also a war zone. Why not get a decent boat, row a little further and avoid being shot? People this stupid deserve to die out.4. Films need to be thematically tight. The themes of immigration/humanity just don't fit with the theme of infertility. It's trying to be two films in one and this never works.So really, with so many writers credited with the screenplay you'd think someone would have picked up on some basic elements of logic - but then maybe that's the problem.

I had high hopes for this film before seeing it, however after about 15 minutes I knew we were on a downhill slide.The background of the story (the idea that humankind has become infertile) was always a bit far-fetched. There were other overtones, such as Bush's influence (which seems improbable considering that the film is set a number of years into the future), which made the whole endeavour look silly.One thing I will highly commend this film on is the scenery, a well-done fusion of Britain with a pre-1990 Eastern Bloc influence. The attention to detail in the portrayal of the destruction, decay and rot that visited British society was simply superb. Broken lifts, windows falling out, people living in scrapped buses - very well done indeed.On the whole I found the film monotonous and boring. I felt little personal empathy with any of the characters, in fact it was hard to decide who was even good or bad. None of the characters made any substantial development from the first few minutes of the film - we knew little if anything about any of them that we didn't already know at the beginning. Many of the confrontational scenes went on too long, we were none the wiser for seeing them for 5 minutes instead of one.I found this film tedious and could not wait for it to be over.
Has one of the most moving and powerful scenes in cinema that I've ever come across, simply outstanding movie.

Children of men is an epic tale based in a world where humans cannot reproduce. Over all the movie was great. Great plot. Some humor, a lot of violence. SPOILER: There is a sly (well placed) scene in this movie. When Faron goes to his cousin to get the papers for transport, he enters a converted factory-home. Now when Faron and his cousin are talking over dinner, in the background behind Faron's cousin, is a floating pig. It took me a few seconds to realize what I was looking at. The smokestacks gave it away. It's the inside view of the factory on the cover of the "Pink Floyd" album "Animals"! On the cover there is a factory with several smokestacks, between two is a floating pig. Very clever. Here is a picture link: http://www.kulichki.com/cddisk/pinkfloy/animals.jpg Just copy and paste!Michael Caine did a great performance also. Excellent movie, a must see.

Review title: Children of Men Does Not Disappoint
Review_body: Powerful, gripping, intense, moving; all of these words describe "Children of Men." I was extremely excited for this movie when I saw the preview, so I decided to read the book before the movie came out. I read the book, and really enjoyed it. This movie was better than the book. So rarely do I say that, but "Children of Men" is one of the best films I have seen in a long time. The director creates an atmosphere that pulls you in and never lets you out. This beautifully crafted atmosphere sets a stage for some spectacular performances by Michael Caine and Clive Owen. All of the acting is great in this movie, but Caine and Owen steal the show. Do yourself a favor, and see this movie. It's one of the year's best.

Review title: As a story, it is a promise unfulfilled...abridged review
Review_body: As a movie, director Alfonso Cuarón's Children of Men is state-of-the-art. It has incredible action, sound and visual effects. The acting is believable and compelling. However, as a story, it is a promise unfulfilled. It starts with a premise pregnant with questions, implications and possibilities. They are left unasked and unanswered.The story revolves around Theo ( Clive Owen) who is contacted by his ex wife and former fellow activist, Julian (Julianne Moore). As a leader of Fish, a terrorist organization, she has a special project for him- to smuggle the only pregnant woman in England, a black immigrant named Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey) to the coast. They must take a perilous trek across the countryside, avoiding the police and the terrorists. It is a trip which gives the audience a slice of this dark land and era, purportedly the best the world presently has to offer.Upon reaching the coast, Kee will be picked up by a clandestine ship sponsored by a mythical organization called the Human Project. It appears that all of humanity's hopes lie with this child. The Human Project, about which no one appears to know the truth- even of its very existence- becomes the Holy Grail for the few honest brokers in this morass. When it appears that they are safe (mother and child are the only ones to get there), the movie ends with the promise fulfilled.For some inexplicable reason, only humans became infertile. There was no plague, no nuclear explosion, no increase in the ozone- it just happened. This is an event of Biblical proportions, like the Death of the First Born. How can science explain a disease or event that singles out only humans, and all over the world simultaneously, not spreading to reveal some epidemiological source? It doesn't occur in animals or plants. The world's food supply appears to be intact. In fact everything appears to be intact except this single, and singular, event. Yet there is no peep of wonderment about this gargantuan, universal, and still personal, catastrophe. The only response offered comes out of a B.F. Skinner laboratory. The stimulus is infertility- the reaction is despair, aggression and rage. The egocentricity of this society reeks. Everyone is feeling sorry for himself for not seeing a future in progeny. In this self pity, they destroy their personal future and well-being. It is no surprise that this self-indulgent society's favorite drug is a suicide pill.Are these truly the only possible human responses to a severe crisis? Does Cuarón really believe there is no nobility in humankind, that the sum of his miseries point to governments, militias and events beyond his control? Are peoples' resources really exhausted when science fails to come up with a solution? Is there nothing an individual can do to elevate himself? This appears to be more a reflection of the director's own cynicism than the reality I live in. If the viewer accepts this premise, to what extent has he limited himself? Whatever the cause of the disaster, the response to it is adolescent. Peoples' willingness to allow themselves to be further subjugated in order to maintain the comforts they have condemns them further. Cuarón would have you believe that dignity was wrested from them, but they removed their own dignity.If anything, this is a deep condemnation of our modern world which promises fulfillment with things, removal of distress with drugs, relationships without commitment, and its concomitant decreasing demographic. If the movie is any reflection of an outcome to our present circumstances, it is to show how detached we are our from feelings and actions, and how irresponsible we have become as a result.But Cuarón painted a monochromatic picture. There are people who live with meaning. Some genuinely believe in a Creator who is intimate with the world and who deliberately placed us as stewards of the earth. They will say that there are no coincidences and no accidents. They see themselves as responsible for their actions and that they do affect the world around them, even when they do not know precisely how. In response to the catastrophe, some may pray for forgiveness for themselves and all mankind in the belief that redirecting thought and vision does manifest in the concrete. And they know that thought precedes action. Some may accept personal responsibility for not having done enough to ease the suffering of their fellow humans and redouble their efforts to reach out. And they are not for themselves alone. Some may work to find those in despair and offer personal comfort and support, not the anonymous chemical soporifics which offer only unconsciousness and death. And they are the ones who would burst Joy's grape, knowing full well that its companion is melancholy; so would empathize with the despairing.As to the future, there is an unbearable focus on a single baby being the salvation of the world. The Christ-like image oozes like a sour sauce from old meat hoping to be made fresh by removing traces of spirit. People fighting and killing each other pause in their killing at the sound of an infant's cries, momentarily fascinated by their vaunted hope. Clearly it is only a passing fancy, for the baby barely moves beyond the perilous domain when the shooting resumes. If their aggression and despair was for lack of progeny, it would seem that the presence of a baby would attract more than a passing interest.For the full review see http://orderfrochaos.blogspot.com/

I don't understand all the hype about this film! For anyone who's seen the trailers, you know it was Clive Owen's goal to get a pregnant young woman to safety so she could have her baby; the first baby after over 25 years of none. Well, guess what... That's exactly what the movie was about, no more, no less. I couldn't have cared less about any of the characters in the film. No one was particularly likable or good. Just like you'd expect in a film like this everyone's got their own hidden agenda, people aren't who they appear to be and no one's to be trusted. Lots of darkness and evil. Too bad they didn't make this into a Mad Max film, it would have been more entertaining. Instead it was mediocre and tedious. I was glad when it ended.Anyone else agree?

"Children of Men" is one of those movies that kept me thinking for days afterward. There are a number of truly amazing scenes from a directing point of view, I still can't figure out how exactly they filmed the "escape car" scene! There are also very moving scenes that had me welling up with tears, the guy down the row from me was openly crying during the "walking out of the building and through the soldiers" scene. The actors were all well cast, notably Clive Owen, Claire-Hope Ashitey, Michael Caine and Peter Mullan. When you go to a Saturday afternoon matinée in my town on a sunny, gorgeous day you don't expect to see a full theater, but that's what happened for "Children of Men". Believe the word of mouth, this is a really good movie.

Review title: Children of Men-a waste of time
Review_body: It's a waste of time and money. Not the CHF15.- for the ticket, no! Waste of the millions invested in this depressing and ridiculous movie. I do not understand the ratings, I do not understand the aim of making such a movie.I just can imagine that the aim of the movie is to warn the audience. But it is just a sinister and morose way to portray the future. The best way to bring the best out of men is not shock-therapy but by bringing hope. It is pretty simple, it is just a discomforting and disturbing movie. When someone makes a movie filled with so much violence, it is just a cheap shot to capture the attention of the audience.In couple words: just another bad movie!!!!!!!!!

what an astoundingly gritty film. Amazing co ordination must've been used for the extremely long tracking sequences. my mind is blown. Anyone read the book 1984 by george Orwell? similar theme of unchecked immigration and paranoia. anyone know why Britain is usually the scene of dictatorships and oppression, similar to in V for vendetta? But god,what realism(in Children of men)! I even saw it twice!obviously much better the first time, though. Anyone know what the dead cows symbolise?or the ones in the barn?or the myriad of dogs involved in almost all the scenes? i am glad that somethings were left unsaid though. Leaves the viewer guessing.Some one said that Cuaron should try his hand at directing a war movie,I agree. That would be amazing. Another element is the detail in the scenes. The ending wasn't that strong. were those french jet planes coming across the channel to bomb the town? But why?

This movie is certainly a hit or miss. I will say the movie was WONDERFULLY shot. However, I feel that something was lost while trying to convey the story. If you want to just go out to see a movie without knowing which to see...I would not recommend this movie. If you are familiar with the story and what to see a beautifully shot movie then it is good. All in all I feel like I wasted my money and my time seeing this movie. I wished I was better prepared or had possibly understood the story a little better. Some of the back story was very vague at best and possibly not explained at all. That all being said, the acting was decent and I felt connected at parts.

Review title: I hope it will open a few more eyes to the future we are creating
Review_body: I liked this movie very much, I hope it will act as an eye opener for people to see what kind of future we could be creating for ourselves if we aren't careful and do something about it before it's too late. This vision of the future is very scary for the fact we can see a lot of this happening now. Much of the imagery is taken directly from what can already be seen in the news. All we need is some kind of catalyst. In the movie it's a species survival crisis, in reality it's not inconceivable to think that the eventual lack of and high cost of oil could make enough of us think we are having a species crisis.

Review title: interesting story, but poorly presented and bad directing
Review_body: The movie strongly reminded me of my own first movie course, where we produced a 2min movie in half a day. The plot develops linear in a boring manor and every step is known before it is shown. It seemed like an American movie, where usually only America is able to survive the end of the world, only that this was a production from "great Britain" and this time only Britain is able to battle on.... The scenes are too long, so you are bored in almost each scene. I was deeply disappointed as i was not surprised a single time, even the ending was a disappointment. Clearly this movie is not only a waste of time, but also of money.

Well - as you can see I am a Romanian. It seems that in all movies we appear we are shown as being "gipsy" or some inheritans of Dracula (a character who never exist in reality). All these things proves me that the people who wrote the screenplays has no knowledges about history (Universal History) and geography and more than this they don't even come in our country to see the difference between us and what we are calling "Rromas" (gipsies). For others info, "Rroma" can be meet in many European countries under different local names and their roots are in India from where they start to migrate arround 1050 and arrived in this regions with Tartars invasion. Opposite, Romanians (a very unhappy similar spelling between "Rroma" and "ROMAnians") have very old roots (from Dacs and Romans) and they belong to this country thousand year before "Rromas" started their migration. As a conclusion, rather than called us in your movie "gipsy" and give this name to actors who speak romanian language you should open a history book and learn that because our people who stopped the Turks Empire here on the Danube river you - Western Europeans were able to develop everything you have (we didn't have the "privileges" as you have to build huge castles or palaces as we had to burn all the time our villages and hide the women and children in the woods or caves in order that our men to fight against turks) Regards people and don't forget you have no rights to name us "Rroma" as are no similitudes between us and them(just that they have settled here as a different ethnical)

Review title: Children of men the best movie of 2006
Review_body: well ... it's a great movie, I went to see it 3 times and i would see it again. It possess some important issues that we are starting to confront with, like world hunger, wars, disease, and even though i think these problems are a bit exaggerated, they must be considered never the less. I have't seen a movie like this for a long time, it has a good plot, a bit unrealistic but interesting, and the story is very well told. You are pinned down in your seat the whole movie and you have no idea what's about to happen until the end, and that in my opinion is what makes a movie Oscar material. And again, I must say it's a brilliant movie,it possess really good question marks, great visual effects, don't miss it.

While the movie had excellent effects and potential and good acting it still managed to fail. At the ending I felt like it was an intermission, there was no conclusion, it was like cutting something off at the climax. It could have been such a strong movie with all of the build-up but they didn't carry it through. I was very, very disappointed and shocked that it received such high reviews. See it for the sets and acting but don't be expecting anything in a bigger sense. I loved Jasper especially and everyone in the cast did an excellent job it honestly would have been excellent if they had just continued with it, or done a 5 minute epilogue. I was shocked when it ended as it did. Maybe I am just used to a more thought-based film and was expecting more from the plot and script.

I just returned from watching this movie. The acting is great but the film doesn't show why people do not procreate anymore, why the world is in a bad state, and what will happen after the end of the film. This in contrast with the amount of filming time used for some people moving from one place to another. I read a lot of books of WWII and this film had some shocking parts in it to me as what the civilized (British) world is doing to other people in 2027. Like the film Waterworld, in some part you get to know why the world is all water and what will happen when they found the last peace of land. But in this film you miss out that part. The plot is great to make a good story but things don't add up. And it's beautiful when women are pregnant, but it throws the film to ranks at the bottom when it is predictable that the women has to bare child at the least convenient moment. That has worn out so many times, it doesn't work anymore.

Saving private Ryan meets the wicker man meets (any good film that draws you in emotionally)...well not the story line but in the action and the atmosphere a rather tenuous comparison really but I think you will see what I mean.This film sounds incredible through my sound system. The spontaneity of the violence interspersed with a well crafted story is rather good.The story is rather pathetic; really cheesy science fiction but you can forget all this and just watch the film. It draws you in emotionally with some well crafted characters and acting. Its a good sign for me that i watched the film right to the end including the credits until the screen goes dark and I say to myself that was bloody excellent, then you try to bring yourself back to reality emotionally.

tcleeve from United Kingdom has it exactly right. if you go to the movies for visual excitement and beauty, you might get something out of this. if you go for story, character, acting, and a host of other attributes, you will be awfully disappointed. i am still scratching your head at the amount of good press this mishap has generated. especially among professional critics, the response is overwhelmingly positive. if the film weren't so blatantly, laughably bad, particularly in the 2nd half, i might question my view. luckily, i don't have to; it's that bad. stay away, stare at a blank wall, anything but this. in fact, i signed up for IMDb today just to comment on this movie(!).

This film is fantastic. No, a better description is 'mesmerizing'.The story takes place in the tragically grim world of the year 2027, when the societies of man have broken down, and the idea of homeland security has achieved its inevitable goal of being a boot stamping police state, with Britain being the last bastion of civilization, no less, and due to unknown environmental reasons, all women are infertile and no child has been born in the past 18 years. The world is dying. There are no children.Within this framework, a man is tasked with helping a special refugee to safety: a young Fuji woman pregnant with child. They feel compelled to avoid government involvement, and are driven to connect with the somewhat mythical Human Project, whose goal seems to be salvation of the Earth.The film is remarkable in that it draws you in and gives you a completely realistic portrayal of this darkly apocalyptic future. Utterly believable and absolutely frightening. There was, however, one sequence that drew me out of my movie going experience by its sheer technical brilliance: an 8 or 9 minute one-take of a scramble through a battle zone in a refugee camp that was astonishing.I keep thinking about this movie. It's disturbing, exhilarating, and enlightening.

Review title: Just in time for the third booster shot.
Review_body: Not to be a looney, but it's eerily odd that this takes place in 2027 and revolves around the infertility of the world population.Combine that with the "conspiracy theories" around the JAB and looking at old UK programs like Utopia from 2013, it's hard not to see how we're potentially headed in this direction.Some might call it predictive programming in that it's all to ease the shock for the real event, or call it "predicting the future" ala. The Simpsons, but most people today just want to be entertained then look for potential nuggets of wisdom. Bring on the bread and circuses ...Movie is good, let's just *knock on wood* hope it's not around the corner.

Fiddle-Sticks!!! Did anyone even consider cloning? It is only 2027. there would still be plenty of sperm and eggs stored in Banks from a "healthy" generation to help repopulate the Earth with a fertile population. Also, why would one human baby be the hope for mankind? It would take at least 10,000 female/male babies to create enough genetic diversity to repopulate the Earth. I suppose if you believe in the Adam & Eve fable or suspend all disbelief then you can enjoy this well produced and filmed movie.-FIN

Children of Men constantly tugs at your mind while you watch, pushing your understanding of today by reflecting it in a grim and hopeless tomorrow.The movie works on a number of different levels. Obviously, there is the intellectual attraction in a good examination of a possible future. How we got to where we are is never bluntly explained, but slowly slipped over to you in newspaper clippings taped blotting out windows in the background of an interrogation cell or mentioned in passing in a news broadcast. This subtle exposition leaves sparks as many new questions as it answers, and leaves your mind thirsting for more context and a second viewing.The actors give wonderful performances. Clive Owen is reminiscent of Jimmy Stewart as the worn-down hero pressed by circumstance into an unsought role of protector of humanity's hopes. This is a protagonist who weeps at the death of friends by cowering behind a tree as the shock of the horror he has witnessed (and perpetrated) overcomes him. Julianne Moore provides a textured reading as the leader of an extremist group, clear-eyed but boiling with barely suppressed rage. Michael Caine is a joy to behold as a twinkle-eyed satirical pothead living off the grid while caring for his wife who had been tortured into catatonia by the police.The supporting performances are similarly strong. I was particularly affected by Pam Ferris as Meriam. Introduced as a caregiver to the pregnant Kee, she grows and expands throughout the film, hearkening back to the quiet tragedy as women stopped conceiving children years before.But it was the visual impact of director Alfonso Cuaron and his team who lift this film from good to great. The set design perfectly captures a believable future of no hope: technological improvement at the margins while the dirt and grime only gets worse. The opening scene is filmed in one shot, ending with a devastating shock. But two set pieces stand out far above the rest. A stunning action sequence moves around and outside and back inside a car under attack from a gang of marauders, featuring motorcycle crashes, shootouts, and a complete shift in mood from buoyant playfulness to intense fear and then to despair without a single seam. The camera trickery could come across as showy, but it instead sharply enhances the storytelling by bringing the audience inside sequence.The tour-de-force of the film is a shockingly long 8-minute single shot that begins with Clive Owen's Theo pushing a woman in a wheelchair through a crowd and proceeds through an ambush, series of gun fights, into a bus loading with refugees, a tank attack on an apartment complex seized by heavily armed rebels, a trip into the building and up several flights of stairs, a lengthy exchange of dialog and finally the incredible exit of Theo, the new mother Kee and the first child born on earth in almost two decades through the lines of soldiers, rebels and cowering civilians out of the building and to a waiting boat. The gritty realism of the scene, combined with touches like blood splattering the lens, lend it a documentary quality that greatly increases the power of the film. This is virtuoso film-making that does not overpower the story but instead powers the story to higher intensity.Finally, the film is a powerful political comment on our own times. The refugees crying for help as they stand in cages like animals continue throughout the film and are strongly reminiscent of fascist-occupations in the Second World War. The arrival at a refugee camp evokes images of concentration camps and Abu Gharib, Guantanemo Bay and the gulags. The sharp juxtaposition of images leaves the viewer haunted by the knowledge that this evil is being perpetrated on people right now, by our own government. This is not science fiction, so much as exposure of the costs to liberty suffered in the war on terror. Like the best artists under the soviets or the mullahs of Iran, Cuaron attacks the powerful through carefully veiled fiction.I can hardly wait to see it again.

I have read and re-read the great "1984" by George Orwell. Big Brother is watching you and sure enough, by 1984, he was! We have lost our privacy and our every move can be tracked and watched.Cut to 2006 and this film. In this society, you are not allowed to get pregnant. Although the theme may sound familiar, this version is quite good and makes one think about consequences of going against the "rules".Well acted and very well directed. Keep an open mind when viewing this film and remember that science fiction has a way of becoming science fact. Just ask George Orwell.

Review title: I did wait until the end to run out....
Review_body: Nothing interesting about any of these characters. The writing was poor at best. The look and feel were very good, but none of that matters when I don't care about any of them. I also hated how everything fed to me throughout the whole film. I had to work for nothing nor did I have to wait for anything. Being walked through every reason and relationship like a little child is pretty infuriating. I heard somebody say this was our Blade Runner. And I would have to agree. It is our Blade Runner. Which means it's a far less interesting, patient and entertaining film. Oh yea, the baby was fake. That was the capper for me. Ridiculous.

This movie is retarded. The trailer is by far the best part. Julianne Moore dies in the first 4 minutes. The movie is about a world where women are infertile. They never explain why the women are infertile, nor do the really explore possibilities,which would be very interesting. There is a young black girl who gets pregnant...great...why does SHE get pregnant....who knows...how does she get pregnant...no explanation...what is her relationship to the rest of the characters in this movie....I Don't KNOW...i have a broken thumb and don't feel like typing about this retarded movie but it sucked and was a waste of my 10 dollars. don't see it.
This it's the one of the best film about our future in the world.

I recently saw Children of Men in SF on the big screen and I must say it totally blew me away! I had never even heard of the title since I rarely watch any television or read magazines, etc... The cinematography is absolutely BRILLIANT which might not carry the same effect if it were watched on a small TV. Same goes for the sound which is spot on and deafening at times; it really captures the imagery well. The plot line is pretty great, good dialog, outstanding visuals, and overall very well-paced. I highly recommend seeing it in a movie theater though as you will literally be sucked into some of the scenes, if not all of them. Excellent!

I am sorry but this film is not that great. The premise is extremely flawed and it just threw me for a loop during the entire movie. If the world has not produce a single child in the 18 YEARS, you would think a country such as Britain would embrace immigration. You would think the government would stop indiscriminately killing off people and get busy finding a way to produce again.This flawed premise made me very suspicious. I suspect the writers of this movie script did not think things through and just threw a bunch of their hodgepodge political opinion together and created a plot to shape these opinions.Granted that the movie was very well shot and directed but in the end, the flawed premise took it down several notches.

Review title: poorly explained concepts as excuse for shocking violence
Review_body: I will confirm that the acting is quite good and the cinematography is interesting and well done. However, a real good science fiction movie explains a bit of the underlying plot and at least some of the science, if even as cool and interesting pseudo-science that has no basis in reality, but is at least fun and intriguing to think about. This movie has none of that, but instead only the loosest futuristic concepts that serve merely as an excuse for yet another immensely violent suspense film. The initial rave reviews must be coming from the masses of young sci-fi fans that have read nothing but cheesy comic books, and studied little to no science at all. It's not an absolutely terrible movie, but given the superior acting and cinematography, it could have been fantastic had the storyline been developed at all. If you are a discriminating sci-fi fan that actually expects the writers to think, just a little, then don't bother, or wait for it on Netflix and see it on someone's large flat screen TV with decent surround sound -- if you must. It's not worth the $20 at the theater for a date, especially since you will both have to watch some comedy before sleeping to shake off the CNS shock effects of the gratuitous violence. If you are someone who likes watching hackneyed, silly time travel sci-fi over and over again, or loves idiotic violent movies, then I am sure you will give it at least 8 stars, so go ahead and continue the financing of such drivel.

Review title: 'Children of Men'- avoiding the Hollywood cliques
Review_body: When I read the book by PD James on which this film is based about 15 years ago I thought it was a terrifying concept, a world without future. No more Christmas, no schools, a death of everything that determines the future of man. It put me in touch with how much we, as humans, are driven innately by the knowledge that there is a future beyond our own existence. As it is in most cases the film was not as powerful as the book but I was impressed by the depiction of futuristic London and the glimmer of hope amongst the war zone into which humanity had descended. Michael Caine shines as the eccentric hippie who lovingly attends to his disabled wife and Clive Owen extends himself as the chain smoking hero who doesn't need a cache of firearms to justify this mantle. 'Children of Men' did not descend into 'Hollywoods empty servings' of a film with a neat, predictable platform for the 'major' actors, and instead made the viewer experience the sense of a world that has lost its direction and predictability in deploying the Hollywood formula.

Review title: Worst Movie I've seen in 10 years
Review_body: I don't know what the people who reviewed this movie as being even faintly passable are on but I'd like to try some of it. This movie is pointless and even a six year old could find holes in the so called plot. Julianne Moore is my favorite actress but after this and Freedomland I'll be a little more wise when it comes to seeing a movie just because she's in it. For the twenty minutes that she's actually in it she does a good job with what she was handed (poo). Clive Owen needs a bath and a good nights sleep before his next film. I saw this in a fairly full theater and I noticed I wasn't the only person extremely upset when I left. I'm tired of losing my hard earned 6 dollars to someone's horrible movie. I'd rather watch old reruns of MASH than to have to sit through something like this again. To compare this movie to ANYTHING great is a complete joke.This movie was just horrible. Beyond words. No plot, no resolution, and if you want to call "run and I'll shoot at you" apocalyptic then be my guest. How stupid do you think people are? I will have this directors name tattoo'd on my forehead as a reminder to NEVER see one of his films again. Yep, it's THAT BAD. I'm going to go vomit again.

I can honestly say I don't understand a thing about whats so incredible about this joke of a movie. I watched it tonight with expectations high as hell, and the movie was a complete disaster. With like two semi-memorable scenes and one hundred ridiculous ones it was a major disappointment. This - for me - is the first time the "IMBD grade" is totally out of line. I would've understood if this movie had an average score of 5,5 which it probably deserves, but 8,0?! Give me a break. Although I'm a big fan of Clive Owen, Julianne Moore and especially Michel Caine it didn't deliver in any part. The good thing about the film is that at least its below two hours runtime, which now seems to be the "least standard time", given to any movie no matter if it has a story to match the runtime. As Public Enemy stated: "Don't believe the hype".

I went to see this movie with high expectations. it is an illogical movie. Nothing is given on how the infertility came about. What is being done to correct it. Why things are breaking down. Why is Britian deporting the immigrants, when there is less manpower, as people get older. Add thick English accents and its hard to follow the story line. The movie, for me moved slowly. A few good action scenes, but that was about it. The final scene, with the soldiers in the camp, as they head up the apartment building, and come face to face, with a crying new born baby, with the heavenly music in the background, did not make sense. As soldiers they would have taken the baby. NOT LOGICAL !!Not a good movie, very disappointing.....

Movie gets a three only because of Caine and the cinematography. Story line was not good. Dialogue was not good. Acting was not very good. The movie did not have me believing it for one minute. I was really excited to see this movie, as most of the critics ratings were pretty high. There was also a lot of buzz about one of the chase scenes. The scene was pretty good, but was over quickly. It will be better to appreciate it once the DVD is out and you can slow it down to watch. Michael Caine was a joy as always. One of the few. His on screen wife did a better job of acting than most of the rest of the cast. Oh, well. They got our money. Save yours for something like The Departed, which is a much better movie.

Review title: Horrible film, a travesty to the book
Review_body: This film is appalling. I simply cannot believe the reviews I have read in the press and the incredibly inflated polling numbers on this website. Seriously, it makes me wonder about the veracity of the postings. Is it possible that film studios flood these sites. Please note the very very low ratings that have come out most recently since the release in the U.S.In sequence: No, this is not a good action film. Worse yet, it completely distorts the wonderful work of P.D.James whose original is profoundly religious, not a violent action thriller. There is little to no dialogue, no acting except everyone walks around looking depressed for ninety brief minutes, a lot of chasing and shooting, and a muddled action and sequence to the film. There is no humor or poignancy or relief to the dreary action of cinematography. What was the director thinking? What are the reviewers thinking who voted this as a good film? The film is relentlessly dark, unimaginative, and depressing, but without a point.Why did the director change the sterility of men in the book, to women being unable to have children in the film? The title is, after all, Children of Men. There are many other gratuitous changes and distortions of the original that don't bear noting. But even standing on its own, the film is simply unbearable. ANd incomprehensible. I heard no positive comments in the packed theater where I saw it tonight. And many many complaints, along the lines of "I will never again believe a movie reviewer."And by the way, since the sequence and plot are rushed and over-edited, why such a short film for the eleven bucks I paid per ticket tonight. If you are gonna take on P.D. James, why not do a two and a half hour movie and do justice to the book or the ideas of the book.

the only foreshadow in this movie is the tried and true " pull my finger" line. Talk about a farce, keep in mind that Children of Women dreamed up this plot, or lack of, OK OK so its PC to bash southerns ,christians and men, but please guys, even my girlfriend wants her money back. Obviously Alphonso has seen Dawn of the Dead, Terminator and Saving Private Ryan so many times that he decided to mix them all up in a blender and voilà, children of the privately terminal dead women, or ahh, men, yeah that's it,cause women could never breed anything as wretched as say Nazis, commies, baathist, or even the dreaded capitalist. After my girlfriend groaned for the tenth time, I leaned over and told her, "Dont worry honey, it will be an academy award winner" and from the looks of your website, I was right, cause almost every left wing yellow journalist in the country has jumped on the "bash all the men", bandwagon. Hey me three, Good work guys, I'll avoid the movie theater for ten more years.

Review title: See the movie before reading the book
Review_body: The book is thought provoking and a bit disturbing. When I finished reading the book, I was struck by Theo's transition. At the beginning, he is self absorbed and not empowered. At the end, hope and love transition him to a fulfilling life.What struck me about the movie is it's focus on Baby Boomer's. The movie relies on Beatles style "all we need is love" music; leans toward 60's activists ability to finally make the world right; and a key character, Jaspar, is transformed from an aging, traditional professor in the book to an aging hippie in the movie. This movie shamelessly panders to the Baby Boomer generation. (Yes, I am a Baby Boomer) Boomer's leave the movie theater being even more self absorbed then when they entered the theater.The movie also beats an old drum, war is bad. Vietnam Era generations have this well ingrained in their belief system. The message in the movie is not delivered with enough weight to sway the belief's of the Hawks in the world.I found the book to be thought provoking. I found the movie to be shallow by comparison.

This is a story line to leave the viewer speechless. It should contain sorrow, despair, joy, and celebration. I contains nothing but boring. It leaves very important details unexplained and I really felt that if this were the world that these characters lived in, why are they not fighting more. Clive Owen's character seemed weak and two dimensional at best. I'm not saying that the acting wasn't great. In fact the acting was very good, however I don't think the actors were given much to work with. I feel that most of the movie was about creating a mood and not relaying story line or information about why we should care about what is going on with the characters. Perhaps my expectations were too high going into the movie, but I do feel disappointed. I think that if this story line dropped into a great writers hands, it has the potential to become a legend.

Review title: Was I watching the same movie?
Review_body: As I went to see Children of Men, thoughts of a dark futuristic thriller danced through my mind. After all, one review called it the next "Blade Runner"... so with this thought in mind, the theater grew dark. Frankly, I was stunned at this crappy movie. It wasted 2 hours of my life that I will never ever get back.The movie was like watching an episode of "The Prisoner" with its quiet moments then jarring 60s music. 1/2 of this movie is spent listening to some crappy music while showing landscape scenes. Ruby Tuesday song sucked. Bad editing and an utterly pointless moment at the end when unexpectedly "CHILDREN OF MEN" is emblazoned on the screen. It worked for Gangs of New York, but not this turkey. I got all fidgety desperately wanting the movie to end... crappy dialog and super-bad acting with this cast of nobodies... If I was the executive in charge of green-lighting this project, I would have quietly set the finished product ablaze - or sent it directly to DVD.Good lord, avoid this at all costs.

A wonderful cast, breathtaking cinematography and the end of the world as we know it are unfortunately not enough to make a great or even good film in the case of "The children of man", and it is too bad... The work of such solid-good actors as Owen and Moore and the brilliance of Caine can do little for the script that is simply bad and shallow. Surprisingly so, since Apocalypse is a bottomless resource as far as storytelling goes. The plot is pointless and lacks any kind of imagination. The film touches many painful, important issues but seems to pass them all by not giving any of the subjects enough depth to make them worth even being mentioned. The development of characters is nonexistent and lame, no motivation, no focus, no nothing Cinematography and direction is undoubtedly beautiful, almost perfect, but it too is wasted on a badly written script! A waste, all and all.

From the start of the movie there was not much plot and what there was, was predictable and unbelievable. With a production budget of $76 million you think they could afford a steady cam. The jumpy camera shots started to make my head hurt about half way through the film. Clive Owen, Julianne Moore, and Michael Caine give solid performances though. The film in nothing more than propaganda. Very poorly presented propaganda at that. I felt no compassion for any of the main characters and therefore couldn't bring myself to feel anything for them. I found nothing new or unique in the film or it's message that hadn't already been presented in a better fashion elsewhere.

Review title: Children of Men best film of 2006
Review_body: This is a film -- thanks to its perfect cinematography and good score -- that's more about mood and emotion than selling ideas. It is a "smart" movie that lets you know it's considered all the moral and contemporary angles, but it doesn't try to corner you into any of them. What you take away from this film depends very much on what ideas and beliefs you bring into it. Director Cuaron's approach seemed to be, to swipe a slogan from FOX, "We film, you decide." I find that refreshing.For sure you can watch this film with just about anyone, and afterward have a lively, interesting debate. But the film itself doesn't lower itself to petty didactic arguments: it has a story to tell. Again, how refreshing! Moroever, this film is not "just" genre entertainment, although it is part action and sci-fi escapism. (Despite plenty of shooting and violence, Owens' character never once picks up a gun, even when one would seem to come in handy.) Refusing to beat you over the head with messages, Children of Men nevertheless does stand for some important things which, upon further examination, humbly approach the universal. Without being hackneyed or trite, Children quietly and movingly stands up for the sacredness and dignity of each human life. Owen's character is the only one who "gets" this. Both the liberal-lefty terrorist "Fish" fighting for immigrants' rights, and the fascist security forces using violent, repressive means to stave off anarchy, lose sight of dignity and preciousness of life in pursuit of their zero-sum goals.Even I was tempted to think Owen just didn't get it when the motley Fish leaders, the erstwhile protectors of a young pregnant African refugee, asked him what he thought should be done with her, i.e. how best to use her for the Cause. "I think she needs a doctor," he answers immediately, "I think she needs proper care." The Fish can only scoff at such short-sighted naiveté. With humanity on the brink, I thought to myself then, surely Owen's character was missing the big picture, the pressing political fate of millions? But as events prove, Owen is right and the Fish are wrong. I ended up reproaching my initial reaction as the film reached its climax. Owen is the only one, absent a few non-English speaking refugees, who recognizes the moral imperative to protect innocent life.The awesome, unifying moment of this film, when time slows down several dozen heartbeats, takes place in a tenement building in a refugee city. Suddenly, both jackbooted soldiers and dread-locked terrorists lose the will to fight each other when they're abruptly face-to-face with a miracle: a real live crying infant, the first in 18 years. The truth's liberating effect on them is fleeting, however, as characters revert to form. The moment passes and the fighting resumes in earnest, continuing a masterpiece of real-time, first-person-view urban warfare, but it gives Owen just enough time to stumble away to safety with the future of humanity in his arms.Owen's character also embodies another significant but understated theme, related to the above: politics without a hope & vision for the future is a footrace to the grave. Owen is a "retired" liberal activist who retains strong sympathies for the old Left, including his politically active ex-wife (Juliette Moore), and forest-dwelling hippie mentor (Michael Caine). Director Cuaron contrasts Owen's liberal simpatico with his apparent resignation to "sell out" and work in a dull, gray government bureaucracy for The Man. As the action unfolds, Cuaron makes us think that Owen will surely have to choose: either the unstable leftist Fish, or the fascist forces holding anarchy at bay. Yet Owen's actual choice -- the correct choice -- is neither.Owen, unlike the radical and increasingly violent Fish, has realized that once hope for life is out of the picture, his liberal politics stops meaning anything. For that matter, when life consists of waiting to die, everything stops meaning anything. More broadly, this film shows us that when politics become divorced from mankind's real circumstances -- which have a knack of ignoring our left-right paradigms and pre-conceived notions -- society becomes grotesquely pointless, even dangerous to itself.Giving us spare but effective snippets of Owens' bland, rote, hopeless existence at the start of the film, Cuaron invites us to believe that Owen is a washed up drunk beyond renewal. But Owen's character shows his true mettle as soon as he realizes that, quite literally, hope has been reborn. Without fake bravado, or "dramatic" bouts of doubt a lesser film might give us to increase the suspense, Owen simply and unhesitatingly does the right thing: protecting against all comers the mother-to-be of humanity's first baby in 18 years.I never read the novel upon which this movie was based. Maybe it's great; and I'm sure it's different than the film. But all that is irrelevant. Children of Men stands alone as a great film, and the building inertia of its simple but irresistible narrative and momentous power of its visuals carry all the meaning a viewer can hope for in a film.Finally, not to ruin the ending, but it's just not true that "everyone dies in vain" in this film as Suderman claims. Maybe the ending is not suitably Hollywood enough for Suderman, but that's his problem. Even if everyone did die in this film, and all of Owen's selfless bravery and humanity sans sappy sentiment failed to carry the day, it wouldn't mean that hope was in vain. If there's one thing this movie shows us, it's that hope is the sin qua non for humanity. And like Owen's character, we can only do our humble, stumbling best, as Jesse implored, to keep it alive.

Review title: Awesome Movie, but left unfulfilled at end
Review_body: This is definitely a must see movie. Clive Ownen is amazing in this role and Michael Caine adds a crisp touch of humor to the flick in a time in the world that is so grim. Some of the fighting scenes are somewhat gruesome, but have a touch of reality like those car accident commercials. It is a very scary idea to have no children in the world, a great concept for a movie anyway you look at it. If you are one of those types like me that like the old Twilight Zones where people disappear or other odd things happen, this is for you. I was not satisfied with the ending, I feel they could have made this a 2.5 hour movie.

This movie was beautifully shot and acted. I don't want to spoil anything, but one scene moved me to tears. In the days after seeing the movie I continued to think about it. Some of the things in the movie that are the scariest, we already see the beginnings of. Driving down the road i saw a sign that said "report suspicious behavior" and was struck again by the vision in the movie. Clive Owens acting was excellent. Instead of the usual hero, he was rather sad and pathetic, at least in the beginning. A truly enjoyable experience beyond the usual. I plan on watching it again in the theater and recommending it to others.

I just saw this movie by myself. Now I have no one to talk to about it.
