So I'm writing these comments before my head explodes.I won't go into the details of the plot, the acting, or the cinematography, as other people have already done that here better than I could - I just wanted to add a few points about what the film said to me.Even though everything in the film is so damn depressing, and the world is so horrible, and we're all going to die, no really, we are all going to die, I loved the way that hope was allowed to exist - not as a blinding beacon across a battlefield, but as a subtle nudge or affectation, the winking eye of God.Think kitty getting friendly with Theo's leg, or the sheep dogs who never liked anyone else - they can see the destiny that Theo is literally soaked in (or maybe it's the whiskey?) This is very much like the story of Pandora's Box - after all the evil, scene-stealing nasties came out, there was one tiny, fragile creature left that managed to escape without anyone seeing it. Zeus could be a bit of a **** sometimes, but even he realized that hope could never be sacrificed.Cor blimey, Pan's Labyrinth last week and now Children of Men this week! Go Toro! Go Cuaron! What the hell do they put in the tequila in Mexico anyway? I've just seen two of the best movies I've ever seen in my life in as many days, and deep down I'm sad because I know it's going to be a while before I see any movies this good again...And what is it with Britain being the 'last nation standing' after an apocalypse? They did the same thing in V for Vendetta! Hello? If the bombs start a-dropping, I bet the safest place in the world will be my grand-dad's sheep station in the south of New Zealand!

Review title: Too many loose ends, but beautifully done.
Review_body: I think this movie was beautifully does as far as the cinematography is concerned. Dark, thematic colors were used, very unique way of shooting certain scenes with the use of camera angles, etc.The only thing I'd have to say that really surprised me is that there were so many loose ends that weren't tied up. The very last scene of the movie depicted that you were to assume what happened after the movie ended, which by the way, couldn't have been more abrupt.Julianne Moore and Clive Owen give deep, convincing performances. Michael Caine is superb. Newcomer Claire who plays Kee is excellent and I'm sure we'll be seeing more of her. A great cast. Good cinematography all across the board.

I wouldn't say this is the best movie I've ever seen, but it's close--I'd rate it 10 except for a few nit-picky plot points--and it is without a doubt the most intense. (Schindler's List is the only one I can recall that's even in the same league for intensity.) The director did a brilliant job of fusing action and meaning, so that the film was mesmerizingly exciting but also very rich and moving. Apocalyptic scenarios are a dime a dozen in films, but this one really worked for me, I think, because of the way it very graphically showed the toxic effects of hopelessness... something that is extremely relevant these days. It was incredibly poignant and utterly convincing at the end of the film to see the awesome power of returning hope, at the sight of something as simple as a baby. Brilliant.

OK, all I have to say is that you should watch this movie in theaters unless you have a home theater system with surround sound and a good picture. The way the film is shot puts the audience into the middle of the chaos in the most personal and intense way, but without a loss of clarity. I have to give mad props to the people who made this film. The attention to detail and the realism in everything makes the movie one of the best ones I have seen in a long time. High marks, all across the board. When I first saw the trailer for this film, I thought the premise was a lofty topic and would be difficult to portray. However, the plot is subtle and there is no feeling of being spoon-fed explanations. The audience is just along for the chaotic and thrilling ride. High marks, all across the board.

Review title: Maybe it is because of my faith
Review_body: I say this movie is made well, yet I do not really follow the under story. I understand why there is a sheep in a cage with a sentinel dog on a leash tied to, after seeing a lamb run form left to right; I usually enjoy this type of entertaining. Again, I do like the idea of the man who spoke in "thrid" person is only giving with a gun in his hand. Yet on the other hand the films mind set of the villain is in poor taste if you are not Christian. I am not saying any which way you believe is good or not good and I knew walking into the doorway which had the tittle Children of Men could turn out the way it did. I just had more faith in an open minded view point. I guess the ad which connected this movie with Bladerunner scrambled my hopes. Christ, I hate to make this film sound bad because on the holy whole the cinematography is very good, but if your are not into the spirit of the film it might be better to read a "good book".

Review title: Awful and without any coherent storyline or resolution
Review_body: I am a female college student in computer science who likes distopian movies, action movies, etc. Me and other grads (mostly guys) went to see this because of good reviews. This movies was so bad that I am simply shocked that it has such good reviews. The storyline is absolutely incoherent, the causes and actions of people make no sense, there is no resolution. Even the whole idea of infertility is really not justified with anything coherent. And after the movie, the longer you think about it, the more you realize how bad it is.Please, do not waste your money.

Watching Children of Men was a real wake up call for me. Superb set design, an adult approach to character development, precise and enjoyable performances, gripping premise. But the slap in the face was realising that this was a mainstream film with something to say politically, and the confident manner in which it said it. futuristic films are notoriously fraught with dodgy inventions, bizarre social foibles and a sense that even the actors are sniggering at what's going on around them. Children of Men is a window opened wide upon the genre, a film that dares to treat its audience as thinking, imaginative beings, ones involved and curious as to the world around them. "What could happen if we carry on this way?" is played out on screen in a way that focuses on personal reaction to events and what happens to a society that has lost hope and placed its faith in repression, order and brutality. Go rent it if you need a shot in the arm, if you want to believe in the potential of cinema again.

Review title: What an amazingly beautiful piece of work....
Review_body: I don't have much that I feel hasn't been said, there was not one moment while film rolled that I didn't have my jaw hanging wide open. From the beginning the rhythm of the movie was set to a pace pushed the story forward relentlessly, yet flowed so well it left nothing behind. I was in a state of complete awe, this is without a doubt the absolute best film I have had the good fortune to enjoy. The actors were sincere in their delivery, as you watch their body language, listen to their voices, and look into their eyes you will come to an immediate understanding of the sad and hateful darkness that engulfed the world. Excellent and seemingly well funded sets and action scenes, very graphic, yet poetic and clean. The directing is, to my eyes, without parallel! The ability to draw the watcher so deep into the plot, story line, and character conflict invites the audience into the chaos and madness that are rampant in this future world. Shot angles and camera positioning gave you excellent perspective of the environment and general feeling of the locations. If I were to wager, nothing else released in 2007 will compete with this film, specifically directing and cinematography. Without a doubt in my mind, I will say, this is the best film I've ever seen. Complete. Utter. Phenomenon.

Review title: Too Real, Too Soon, Too Possible
Review_body: A beautifully acted, atmospheric, near end-of-the-world scenario that is yet not depressing. Amazing photography, tremendous diversity among the actors and acting styles and yet all too believable. Pick any character - you can identify with almost any point of view represented. Extreme eloquence by an actress with no lines, grace from Michael Caine, and all the sadness in the world in the eyes of Clive Owen - love this actor, he gives so much underneath the overall restraint. Just re-watched King Arthur last night - amazing film, why didn't it to better at the box office? As regards the present scenario in Children of Men what can we do differently? Don't mess with Mother Nature, she can always get you back!

Review title: This film is a bastard child of Mad Max and 28 Days Later
Review_body: C of M does have some bright spots of some dark spots. That is some of the most violent, jerking scenes in the movie are the best. Now Michael Caine's role in the film is by far the highlight. Caine plays a ppm hippie who grows his own strain of the cabbage smoke called strawberry coff. He does take the pull my finger joke a little far, but that is neither here nor there. The jumpy, blood splattered documemtery style of the action sequences seem to be shot as if they wanted the audience to feel like they are holding the camera. By the end, which i won't give away, I was looking at my watch and cosolidating my candy trash for a quick exit. Ahh, the apocalypse hasn't happened yet. YET!! Duhn duhn duhn.

Watched 3/4 of the movie to figure out was going on,and once you do you realize what a stupid flick.If you're into British accent, turn on bbc and watch reruns of Benny Hill, a much better time fulfillment than this reel of garbage.As far as the acting goes,I guess when your washed up as an actor/actress,you have to do what you have to do to get by.This was the biggest disappointment I've endured in the longest time,especially after all the hype with the commercials on TV.Julianne Moore looks like a crack whore as well as her acting.Clive Owen shouldve just said NO.Why can't Hollywood come up with better things than this?The American public deserves better than this,save the 2 or 3 mil from production of this lamer and feed some hungry kids!!

Review title: Children of Men... but why on a high-school production budget?
Review_body: I feel that this film could have been so much better. The concept is amazing and it could have been so much more exciting and believable if they had shot it on more than a high school production budget (see my comments re props further down). I mean of course, as believable as a science fiction film could be. The reason I say this is because there are several elements in this film which you really can see potentially happening in the future if politics goes stark raving mad and society decides to denigrate to the extent of reverting back a couple of hundred years. But none of it is done convincingly. And it just feels like it takes one heck of a long time to get nowhere.OK.. so the film is being marketed as starring 'Clive Owen, Michael Caine, Julianne Moore'... all names we are familiar with and giving the film that pre-audience prep designed to make you feel like you are setting out to see a real star laden blockbuster of a film.I was happy with the prospect of seeing Julianne Moore with my fellow countrymen Clive Owen and Michael Caine star in a film widely touted as 'Blade Runner for the 21st Century (forgive them Ridley for they really don't know what they say!)... um... except Michael Caine was only in a few brief scenes then killed off... and Julianne Moore fared even worse... as leader of the Fishes she was killed off unceremoniously after her own few brief appearances. Which just left Clive Owen, who looked for the most part as if he had just graduated from the 'Zombie School of Acting' (along with Pam Ferris) and a relatively unknown cast of actors hobbling around for the greater part of the remainder of the film.Don't misunderstand this comment... if the film was touted as 'low budget relatively unknown cast with star cameos' then at least you would be prepared to see the film on those merits... with no expectations of the Blade Runner type action and star studded scenes that you are lead to believe you are paying to see. Please... never mistake this film as a contender for the mantle on which Blade Runner rests... Blade Runner is a far superior film in almost every aspect.The prop budget... in an ever evolving techno age society such as we live in, did the producers really think that the audience wouldn't be fooled by an old Citroen CX with a thinly disguised hood bra to make it look 'futuristic'! And a Fiat Multipla.... is this the future of automotive technology?. Even the rich guy had what looked to be a brand new Rolls Royce, yet it was an old model... will they still be making this car in 20 years time? Did vehicle procreation come to a standstill also? It's laughable. Please, if you are going to make a futuristic film then at least get or make appropriate props.This is too funny.... in a world of stagnated pro-creation... cats can still have kittens!! I mean, if it truly has come to a standstill, what on earth was that kitten doing in the film! Was that an 18 year old kitten! Other 'simple mistakes' that should have been edited out were.. for instance... a woman trying to push a car uphill on her own in the mud to jump start it... have you ever tried that! I'm not even sure that this would have been believable if Mike Tyson had been pushing it...And the ending... ahhh... poor Clive... even he doesn't make it to the end of the film without demise... which was not really necessary or essential to the plot... which kind of tails off into nothingness anyhow.After sitting through this meager and bleak film, which felt like it was being shot with a handy-cam by someone who had just bought one but had not yet read the operating instructions... I'm still scratching my head wondering where all the high praise comments on IMDb are coming from.Again, I feel that this was a fantastic story spoiled by bleak, cheap looking filming with unconvincing and somewhat low key performances which ultimately fell flat on it's backside due to... um... budget constraints? My disappointed sighs weren't the only ones I heard in the cinema... sadly. I expected more.

This is my first review on IMDb and I came here specifically because this movie has been so highly rated here. Sorry to all who have rated this movie above 5 stars, but have you ever seen The Godfather? If you gave Children of Men 8 or 9 stars, what do you give to the really great movies?Things not explained in this movie include: the title, The Human Project, the infertility, the reason for the treatment of the immigrants, what happened to the rest of the world, why Julianne Moore is offed by the Fishes, what the Fishes actually DO to help immigrants (other than kill every native they encounter???), how the Fishes believe that having the baby will save THEM (not just provide hope for humanity), why the army wouldn't immediately take the mother and child into custody rather than letting them stroll through a gun battle, why they wouldn't have gone worldwide public with the news of a pregnancy or birth to begin with given the celebrity of the last youngest person on earth, and I could go on. Michael Caine is a complete sidebar with no real purpose to the story line with holes that you can already drive a tractor trailer through. Things explained in this movie: One fertile woman (and presumably, at least one fertile man) left on earth.I want my two hours and my $8.50 back.

Review title: movie without a decent plot... no go !
Review_body: Even though we are just January in 2007 I can say that I am pretty sure that this is the worst movie I will have seen in 2007. The book seems to be written by a respectable writer but the film director must have been drunk all the time that he didn't notice that this movie was a real disaster. I would not waste my time watching this movie again. I am really disappointed by Clive Owen's acting, normally he never disappoints but this movie made it all up in that matter. If you have nothing better to do on a Sunday afternoon and there is nothing decent on TV well have a go with it.... Movie to forget quickly ! Next time better.

I have anticipated the arrival of this movie for a couple months now, and after watching it wondered why! It is a GREAT story idea, but didn't unravel very well. If you have any idea what the movie is about before seeing it, then assume you have already seen it. The movie starts well, you get a little lost in the middle, and the end, was surprisingly disappointing. I actually thought the movie broke while watching the end, the movie title just pops up. I though it gave a great feeling of, we ran over budget or something. I gave it a 5 out of a 10. I want to stress the story idea, and acting was AMAZING, the movie itself was disappointing. If they put about 5-10 more minutes onto the end, it would have been great. I have never seen a Drama/Suspense movie end on such an emotionless tone..just left you dry. Wait for the DVD, and save yourself the money.not worth running to the movies to go see it.

Don't gimme a doomsday conspiracy again... The same story again.. England under crisis again.. And the protagonist does his bit to save the world..Of course... This movie is a waste of time and money. Yes, the acting is good and the camera work is great. But you can't watch a movie just for that, IT HAS TO HAVE A STORY TO TELL. A WORTHWHILE STORY. The movie has just too much gore and is just meant to excite u in your seat, thats all. The movie has nothing to call its own. It shares its basic theme with '28 days' and shock-value as 'Saw 2 & 3'. Well thats about it and you have been warned.

DEFINITELY go see this with friends. Sometimes a work of art is of great value if for no other reason than the conversations it provokes. This film has the distinction of being a great film, AND a work that inspires great conversation. I went to go see it with a group of women, some of whom would never normally see a SciFi film. Over dinner we had a profound, wide-ranging, challenging conversation inspired by this complex film. Talk ranged from a delightful debate over the film's ambiguities (which were essential and thought-provoking; some viewers these days are too used to every plot element being handed to them on a platter), to the environment, politics, immigration, spirituality, etc. The film itself was gritty, aesthetically gorgeous, eerily believable in it's "not too distant" future setting, and, in the end, quite inspiring. Although all women in our group had different responses, all gave it a thumbs up. Bravo to Director Cuaron and producers Hilary Shor, Abraham, Bernstein, et al.

It was okay. Children of Men has drama, it has high-budget special effects, and it is emotionally turbulent. You become invested in the characters and you root for their success. Yet, beyond all of that lies a formulaic movie: the chronicling of a sort of dystopia that is gracious enough to leave the viewer with a glimmer of hope at the end. We've seen it all before.Children of Men tells the story of a world in which all women have become infertile due to some unnamed factor. Then, we learn that a woman is pregnant with the only baby left on the planet. The majority of the movie is a suspenseful, tumultuous mission to save her in order to ensure the rebirth of society. While I was engrossed for most of the movie, it stayed the cookie-cutter course so stubbornly that toward the end I could not take it seriously anymore.

Review title: Almost as painful as a kidney stone
Review_body: I went to the movies on a whim, with no research as to what was playing or without any films in mind to see. After reading the posters outside of the theater, I chose this movie. After about 20 minutes into it I began to realize that I had paid good money to see the previews, because they were by far the most interesting and entertaining thing that I would see that night. Someone put a lot of money into producing this film, but why? It is the worst movie that I have ever sat completely through. The only reason that I didn't leave early was that I did not want to disturb the other 6 people in there. I feel bad for the actors associated with this film, it's not their fault, as they performed their parts well. Overall this movie should stop playing and someone start a class action lawsuit to get a refund to those of us who were deceived by the poster!!!

Review title: I thought it was a good film
Review_body: I am not pretending to the worlds greatest film critic but i liked the film, i do however think this heavily due to clive owen who has to be the hottest thing eva! i must admit tho i was a bit disappointed when the film ended, it would have been nice to know what happened to the baby after that boat came along. michael cain i thought was very entertaining, and julianne moore was killed off far to quickly. also while the whole war scene was taking place clive owens character (have no idea wot the name of it was to distracted by his life changing face) managed to run around for ages wearing flip flops. now i don't no how many of u have worn flip flops but when u put a pair on for the first time it takes a while to get used to walking in them let alone running. i think that is a terrible downfall in the movie but like i said i'm not the worlds greatest critic so wot wood i no?i don't really have anything more to say apart from clive owen, complete and utter babe!!

Review title: Great action scenes, but not much more.
Review_body: My wife and I went to see this movie because of all the good reviews. I wasn't impressed with this movie. Many others here are calling this a 'thinking man's movie'. Those types of movies are fine, but you have to at least leave the theater with some type of satisfaction. There is no background into anything that was happening in the movie. The only information we had was that no new children had been born in the last 18 years. Well, 27 minus 18 would be 2009. Now, look at how destroyed the world was and how everything is in chaos, wouldn't you think they everyone would be working on trying to figure out why everyone was infertile? There appears to be a lack of updated technology in the movie, but yet in certain scenes you can see what looks like updated technology. A drugged out old man who lives in the woods and smokes pot. This just doesn't seem like a realistic scenario. The reality is that the census would be able to detect a problem like this before it got out of control..there would be a massive panic to collect and save sperm and eggs so that they could create life.The story line is open ended so nobody knows what happens after this. Just a bunch of senseless killing with no story line. Oh, and who would trust a pot smoking cop. The fact is that none of the story line makes any sense at all. It just wasn't a realistic film. The action scenes were great! The scene where he hits the crooked cop across the head with a battery was pretty comical.Save your money and rent it when it comes out on DVD.

This is a warning for all of you who rely on the 8+ star reviews of this website to go and see this movie. If you have savvy and taste for a well made artistic movie you may be sorely disappointed. I am not angry of wasting my money on this absolute stinker. I am angry to discover I cannot rely on the review system of this website. As many before me I suspect that there were trolls here (studio paid reviewers, family members) who extolled the virtues of this amateurishly made and poorly produced flicker. Simplistic plot, bad cinematography, superficiality of acting, or voice cast, implausibility of details (Clive Owen getting to and hijacking a car at the farm under the nose of the guards, etc.). A movie made on the cheap. I am SO disappointed. A friend of mine - she actually liked it, but my sophisticated family members and savvy movie goers did not. I know whom to trust in the future.

I thought it was one of the best films I have seen in a while. I just wanted to open up a small discussion on the symbolism of names in the film. The most obvious example of this would be Theo the main character. Also I was interested in the strange mystic who helps them in the refugee town called Marichka. Last semester I read the Ramayana by Valmiki for the first time, and the main villain's (Ravana) brother was called Maricha. He disguises himself as a golden dear to precipitate the capture of Rama's wife Sita. I was wondering if anyone had any ideas about these and other loaded names in the movie. Also, language aside, symbolism in general throughout the film. Like how Theo is reduced to wearing flip flops at one point, exposing his feet to injury and infection. I thought for sure that the flip flops would go and he would spend the rest of the movie barefoot. I suppose that was too blatant for the director, and he eventually finds sneakers I believe. Anyway, very well put together. Only point of contention might be better score/soundtrack. It just didn't really serve to create emotion or a spartan wasteland (either one I would have accepted). Anyway, good flick.

Review title: A fantastic story ruined by an overtly political director and poor screen writing.
Review_body: I saw this film last night, and was sorely disappointed. After reading the reviews here on IMDb and elsewhere, I was expecting an engaging thought provoking film. What I got was anything but...While I did find "Children of Men" to be masterfully shot, and wonderfully acted, the film itself was a severe disappointment. One is nearly beaten over the head with Director, Alfonso Cuarón's anti-Bush and Anti-Iraq war statements throughout the movie in overtly obvious and uncreative ways.Early in the movie the assault begins, when during an interior shot of the country retreat of Jasper Palmer, wonderfully played by Michael Caine, one is force fed pictures of Anti-Iraq war protesters which supposedly happened twenty years before the events of this film are to have taken place.Later, when the characters reach the "Fugie" refugee camp, the background is filled with reenactments of the Abu-Ghraib photographs. At one point an panning shot shows an man in the olive drab poncho and black hood, standing on top of a box with his arms outstretched in an exact replica of the world famous Abu-Ghraib "torture" photo. Next to him is a cluster of men in their underwear cowering back from a guard and his snarling, barking dog.It is these types of overly political statements that abound in this movie, that show that Alfonso Cuarón was more interested in the making a statement with the film than telling a good story. The real crime, is that those overly overt images were not needed to make the film's viewers consider such deep and meaningful questions. The book's subject matter already invited thought on the subjects of politics and immigration. Mr. Cuaron merely cheapened that internal dialogue, and dated the film with his horrible screenplay.I would recommend that potential viewers wait until this comes to cable, as it is definitely NOT worth paying movie house prices to see. Spend the money on the book, and watch the movie for free once it shows up on HBO or Cinemax.

Review title: One of the Greatest Movies Ever
Review_body: This is definitely one of the best movies that I've seen in a very long time, possibly the best movie that I have ever seen. Everything, and I mean everything, is done absolutely perfect. Clive Owen plays Theo amazingly, as it's the best performance that I've seen him do.Anyways, onto the movie. I was completely immersed in the move the entire way through. It was emotional at some points, such as when Theo and Kee are walking down the stairs with the baby, or when Julian gets killed. I really felt during those parts, and I was almost crying during the scene with the baby. The soundtrack seemed to fit quite well, as far as I could tell. One thing that stood out for me was the use of the music just prior to Julian dying. The line was, "I'm gonna miss you" and then the death scene happens. I thought that was great.The uprising was pretty much just five - ten minutes of straight action, my favourite part of the movie.I would recommend this movie to everybody, crazy awesome.

Review title: Unbelievable! This is an incredible movie but not for everyone
Review_body: Unbelievable! I just want to say that this was one of the most intense movie experiences I've ever had. A masterful movie on so many levels that I don't know where to start. Yes, the performances were all great and Clive Owen restores my faith in the casting of leading men. And yes, the movie has an important message about our current state of affairs as much as the affairs 20 years from now. And of course, the action scenes are among the most creative and heart stopping I've ever seen and will no doubt be copied to death in the years to come. These are all good reasons to see the movie but they are not what make this movie truly great in my mind. What makes this movie outstanding is its honesty and authenticity. Authentic in the big picture: in its depiction of a world in which humanity is faced with its eventual extinction. A gray and dismal life in London under totalitarian dictatorship based on the fear of illegals, and the rest of the world descending into anarchy and chaos, yet people still go to work and bet at the racetrack. Life goes on, albeit for only a short time. Also authentic in the small details: a bomb explodes exactly how it would in real life - no fiery explosion (why does Hollywood need to blow up 1000 gallon gas tanks to make us believe a bomb's impact). Pets are everywhere, I suppose because they are our only substitute for the loss of children. Illegals are rounded up and put in cages while passersby (Theo included) barely notice.A lot of reviewers were disappointed that the movie didn't go far enough to explain the premise of mass infertility or to explore in more detail its ramifications. I think that's unfair. Why do we need to be hand-fed this information? Rather than get bogged down with the details, the movie just asks us to just go with it. As with the ramifications, I think the movie does enough here to get you going. Connect the rest of the dots yourself. I think the movie's main objective is to put you into Theo's life and follow his story to its conclusion.For those that think the movie is a major downer. Well, yes it is. In fact my wife came out of the theater and said it was one of the worst movie experiences she's ever had. I know what she means. Its rawness and bleakness and overall vision of the future are tough to take. But what also got to her was its authenticity. It was such a realistic portrayal of a bleak future and how humans would interact in that world that she couldn't discount it like she could other movies that were as violent or bleak. But it's not all bleak. There are true moments of tenderness and compassion that transcend the violence and chaos. Some scenes are so poignant I can't get them out of my mind. Such as the gypsy women helping Kee and Theo escape. She takes the baby so they can get through a tight door and leaves the camera for a few seconds. I'm thinking she's stolen the baby and I'm sure everyone else in that audience is as well even though the director has given us no good reason to suspect her. She comes back of course and in that instance I'm left feeling sheepish for my assumptions (would I have thought this if an English speaking women was in her place or even if she just simply wasn't a "Gypsy") and immensely happy and relieved as if this women in that one instance restored my faith in humanity. And of course there is the baby. The film's ending is somewhat ambiguous but in my mind it is hopeful.

Review title: What did I not get about this god-awful movie?
Review_body: I can't believe the great reviews that this movie has gotten. People must just be infatuated with Alfonso Cuaron's innovative and excellent directing. Unfortunately, it was hard for me to really appreciate the direction of a story that just didn't make ANY sense.If you saw the trailer or read a review, you know one of the major components of the story going in--there has not been a human birth for 18 years because all (and just?) women on Earth have become infertile. OK, fine, hard to fathom, but certainly an interesting premise. The entire context of the rest of the story goes completely downhill from here.For some reason, the infertility issue has caused a near-total collapse of most of civilization. That makes some sense. Not having any children in the world would certainly cause a pretty dramatic ripple effect on the world's economy and collective psyche. However, while the rest of the world is going to hell in hand basket, for some completely unexplained (and barely noted) reason, Great Britain is the only country that is still functioning (for the most part, at least). This means that everyone else in the world wants to move there. So, to deal with the massive influx of new immigrants, Britain reacts with draconian anti-immigration laws and refugee camps.Now we are introduced to the dramatic miracle of a pregnant Kee. An immigration rights terrorist group somehow learns about her and manages to keep this pregnancy a secret (in an era where there are presumably even more cameras, media, etc. than there are in 2007, if that's even possible). Their apparent goal is to get Kee safely in the hands of a mysterious and ambiguous group called "The Human Project," which is apparently a group of world-renowned doctors, scientists, and experts that are working to find an answer and cure to the infertility epidemic. Even though the rest of the world is on the verge of complete societal collapse, The Human Project is for some reason not located in the last bastion of civilization (Britain), so Kee and Theo have to get off the island. In another complete lapse of logic, she needs illegally-acquired papers to LEAVE Britain. It's never explained why the ferociously anti-immigration British government would have any problem just letting an illegal immigrant leave if he or she wanted to. (Isn't that what they want the illegals to do? Leave??) So, anyway, most of the movie is Kee and Theo trying to get her out of Britain. It's filled with compelling and gritty action sequences, and plenty of ridiculous and illogical bits of "story." For example, Kee has her baby before she can get off the island. As she and Theo try to escape a besieged refugee camp building, people (terrorist/rebel refugees, innocent bystanders, and the British army) hear and see the baby she holds in her arms. They stare in shock and amazement at this miracle in their midst, but as soon as Kee and Theo get out among the British soldiers, everyone goes back to fighting immediately and Kee and Theo run away. You're telling me that no one (like the senior British army officer there) would be very interested in stopping them and protecting this miracle child? They would really just let them keep going? This movie is just filled with complete lapses of logic and coherence. I spent most of the time sitting there just trying to make any sense of the story I was being presented. And despite Cuaron's expert direction, that's why you go to a movie--to see a good story. "Children of Men" just doesn't have one. It's an intriguing premise that never goes anywhere.

Review title: Worst adaptation of a book in recent memory
Review_body: Has anyone read the excellent book? This movie was a mess from start to finish. I cannot believe the number of glowing comments and reviews. Actually I do remember a recent film that was just as bad - the remake of that classic film The Haunting - another utter disaster. I hope some of the people who saw the film will read the book and realize what a mess it truly was. How could the author approve this screenplay? Spoilers:In the book: Julian is pregnant Men are infertile, not women Theo lives and gains power Mass "suicides" are forced upon the elderly Jasper commits suicide There is strong underlying religious content and Christian symbolism Etc. etc. etc.

Loved it! I went in with high expectations from the reviews and comments here and I must say I wasn't disappointed. THE "Must See" movie of the year and I was very disappointed it didn't get anymore Oscar recognitions. Clive Owen was superb as the "I don't give a F*ck" office drone and then turns into the "I'll do anything to see the job through" hero. Micheal Caine as the stoner hippie was great as well...Pull my Finger!;-) But there was not enough Julianne Moore for my tastes but I did like the way it all played out. The actress that played Kee had a very strong part to play and in the end it came off perfectly. The plot had very nice twists and the film as a whole had great shock value and makes you think for sure. The "Homeland Security" reference makes you wonder what old GW may have in store for us in the future. I think the story could be looked at as Joseph trying to get Mary through Bagdad 2006.

The director, the director of photography and the camera person should be ashamed of themselves. Camera panning causes blurred images on screen which cause eye stain. Extended camera shots in boat on water actually caused motion sickness. In the scene where some blood splatters on the lens (too long on lens) made it seem like a documentary. The blood splatter was good but as the action moved on, it should have been removed. The storyline was OK but left me wondering, what is the "Human Project". It was never clearly explained what it is.I think Clive Owen did a great job with his character and I have always liked Michael Caine. His portrayal of a life long hippie was great.

The plot is well thought out and interesting, and the acting exceptionally good, however the photographer often pans the camera without focusing and jumps the scenery around as the story moves forward. The visual effect they created made me physically sick during the viewing, did manage to see the entire film, though, and would not recommend it to others because of the nauseating effect of the photography. My escort also felt the shooting was making him motion sick, so it wasn't just me. At one point there is blood on the camera lens that they leave in place for a prolonged period. This distracted from the plot because the viewer starts to wonder who is following Clive Owen's character around filming him. Not entertaining.

This was a complete disappointment! The movie did not live up to the rave reviews it seems to have miraculously generated. I don't know what people saw in it. The story itself had great potential. I can't even say that I was disappointed, cause I did not know anything about this film going in... No Expectations: only dis-belief.I like Julienne and Clive and thought, 'hey, I'm IN'. Review title: Great Book, Great Acting, Horrific Adaptation
Review_body: Hollywood's done it again. Taken a great novel, loaded with intrigue, characters who draw you in and a sci-fi twist that gives pause, then turns it into blood and gore and 20 mind numbing minutes where literally HUNDREDS are savagely blown apart for no apparent reason. Only the original elements of this novel are held dear--it's the future, they're infertile and the world's clinically depressed. All the details are changed with the same deftness of a popcorn maker. You have to wonder if the adapters were the whizzes they think they are, they would have written the novel more than a decade ago, as did PD James. They didn't, of course. Save your money. Read the book.On behalf of American film goers (or would be), apologies to PD James. You deserve better.

I read the comments here quite often. I was shocked by the extremely high rating for this movie. After reading some of the comments, I can't help but wonder if they aren't being left by the marketing team for the movie.THIS MOVIE WAS HORRIBLE!!! It was extremely boring. I can't figure out why anyone was in it other than a paycheck. As one reader has pointed out, the scenes are very long and overdone. However, this was NOT a good thing as some of the previous posters had pointed out. I found myself sitting there saying "I know it's dreary... I know it's depressing...Get on with it!!!" The story wasn't presented very well. Also, maybe I missed it, but there really wasn't much of a story. This is another one of those movies that just kind of ends. You get to the end and say "That's it!" What happened with ...? What was ...?Oh well.. If you have a couple hours to bang your head against the wall and then feel good when it's over...then watch this film.

Review title: Did I not get it, or was that a plot hole so big you could drive a truck through it?
Review_body: Total spoilers below- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -OK, I saw this movie today and I had one BIG QUESTION about it.The entire movie is about the fact the world has gone sterile. Not one baby born in 18 years anywhere.Clive Owen is asked to transport a pregnant woman to the coast to be smuggled out of the country on a boat.The woman gives birth in a refugee camp just before they are supposed to leave. The group that arranged for him to help her had done a coup on their old leader and now want the baby to stay in the country and attack the camp to gain control of the baby. The government forces arrive in great numbers to control the camp and the refugee uprising in it. In the middle of this battle the woman who now has had the baby is leaving a building and all the refugees in the building are in total awe of the sight of the first baby on Earth anywhere in 18 years, as are the government soldiers who have now moved into the building and call a cease fire. Clive and the woman now slowly make their way past the awestruck soldiers who have weapons, radios and all the usual military hardware.Yet not one of them takes control of this baby or her mother, calls it in on the radio, asks for orders what to do, takes them to safety after the shooting resumes. They do NOTHING!Clive, the woman and the baby just walk away!How could they not freak out, call headquarters, escort the baby out of harm's way, lock them in the nearest armored vehicle and escort them to the capital or nearest hospital? I just don't get it and it really ruined the movie for me that they would just let this total miracle the whole planet has been waiting for just take a hike. Can anyone who has seen this movie attempt to explain this?

I waited for this movie to come out in theaters in the U.S. for 3 or 4 months trying as hard as i could to just wait a bit longer until the end of next month and then the end of next month until it was finally released! I was so excited I took my girlfriend with me to see it opening day! As you can probably tell I had great expectations for this movie (my girlfriend wasn't so sure about it) but I am happy to say after seeing this beautifully made movie it turned out to be more than I expected and even more than my girlfriend expected! This movie has a wonderful cast, beautiful cinematography, a great score and a good steady pace. It has a great combination of action and emotions. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a good movie about war,corruption, and hope. Right after my girlfriend and I left the theater she turned to look at me and said, "I want to buy that when it comes out on DVD." So if you had doubts about this movie I just wanted to let you know that you weren't the only one but even after seeing it the one with doubts (my girlfriend) had changed her mind, maybe you can too.

the movie though in the very beginning I thought it was going to be boring,I found it that I cannot move from my place till the movie is done...! a great movie and I think a very touching story based on a very simple idea.... the whole story i think is one of the finest i saw on screen the last days,directing was good but I think there could be a little bit more of the story..the war seen was done very nicely and the director really succeeded in making me complete the movie till the end. the end itself was very good and I couldn't imagine it. the rating is very suitable for the movie and I guess it deserves to be one of the finest movies in the year 2006.

OK... so it was good... neat sci-fi, post apocalyptic world, humanity at the brink, blah blah blah... Clive Owens has needed a part like this since his first appearance, Michel Caine is awesome as always. And a great soundtrack, but,Watch American Cyborg: Steel Warrior,http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109098/ That was bad, but in a great way, and it was made 14 years ago. This is great in a bad way. I think everyone should see Children of Man, but watch American Cyborg: Steel Warrior, first, if you can find it. OK... swap UK for USA (great choice!), add several million for budget, Some great actors, and you have the same movie.

Review title: Amazing film totally mindblowing and well worth a look
Review_body: I watched Children of men the other night and was totally blown away. I read some of the reviews and could not wait to see this movie. The movie has an extremely intense beginning and doesn't stop. Although the movie is very touching it doesn't wimp out of the violence and action sequences. I was really shocked at one incident involving a car and a motorbike. I was glued to every moment of this film it is one of the best movies I have seen in a while and would recommend it to everyone. The last 30 minutes of the film are extremely intense and keeps you on the edge of your seat; the camera work is gritty yet beautiful and creates a really involving sequence that is enhanced by the long drawn out action sequences and camera work. The characters are also very original and have that key element that makes the audience feel for them. The acting is also perfect and surprisingly touching,you must see this movie to believe it 10/10

This film is an excellent watch for anyone who either enjoys the post-apocalypse genre, or is interested in one possible future of our current socio-political failings.A good review from a good site can be found at: http://www.truthout.org/docs_2006/022207B.shtml.The cinematography and effects of the movie are so impacting I recommend seeing this in the theaters (btw, I hate paying to go to the movies, so take that as a serious recommendation).As the review above mentions, the film aptly subsumes criticisms of contemporary maladies in politics, media and science. It blends with this good, but abrupt character development, and more general themes on gender, morality, and religion.If I have one criticism of the film, it's the repeated use of deus ex machina to get the protagonist out of serious situations (car engine starting, his attackers being distracted by other attackers, etc).

I can't believe that this film is rated so highly -- I was shocked to see that it had been nominated for 3 academy awards.It's not the worst film I've seen this year, but the acting isn't great and the plot is very contrived. Though I tend to agree with the (not too subtle) political messages contained in the film (that we are moving towards a police state, that our crusade against illegal immigration is a bad thing, that the government shouldn't be trusted), I think that these messages are inappropriately conveyed.Successful films, even romances, are successful because they allow the viewer to suspend disbelief, and Children of Men didn't do it for me. It's not realistic, yet still highly predictable. The actors do a poor job of creating a sense of "character". The camera work and editing are good, but without a believable story line that I can identify with, what's the point? Why bother?

I have visited IMDb for many years and I have been so moved by the fuss about this film that I had to register and comment. What is a film without a real story? The cinematography is good but I have just come away from watching this film with a sense of nothing. It is 1984 without being sinister. It is the same as "28 Days". There are no explanations to anything in the plot. Characters are one dimensional and poorly developed, and has just been pointed out by my fiancé that the continuity in the scene with the ginger cat is awful !!! The person who chose the soundtrack deserves to be employed again as it was one of the few reasons to sit through the credits at the end of them film. Distinctly average !

Once again, I'm subjected to a film that is style over content. I'm seriously disappointed by this film, especial since it is directed by Alfonso Cuarón, who gave us "Y tu Mama Tambien" a film with soul and so much richness and depth. This film lacks that entirely and by the end I felt nothing for any of the characters, I couldn't have cared less if they lived or died, I just wanted to escape them. To be honest I'm not usually a Clive Owen fan, but I have to say his performance in this film was very good. Now I don't want to be negative,but I can't help it here, this film should have had at least half an hour shaved off it and a lot of the dialogue changed as left me feeling patronised, I'm not stupid and neither are most movie goers, for instance - an alarm goes off and what does Micael Caine's character say "It's the alarm" WE KNOW unless we are deaf.Sorry, but, well there it is. Don't take my word for it watch it for yourself, make up your own, at the end of the day it's only my opinion and opinions are like arseholes, everyone's got one.

I loved this movie and the director for 2 main reasons.1) Anyone who can incorporate the King Crimson song "In the Court of the Crimson King" into the soundtrack of a movie is amazing.2) Shortly after the King Crimson song, Theo is having a conversation with his cousin in front of some large windows. Outside the windows, the background looks exactly the same as the cover of Pink Floyd's "Animals" album. With the floating pig, smoke stacks and everything. I think I am one of the few who caught that.The movie also contains a very good chase scene.Can't wait to see what Alfonso Cuaron does next.

The commercial for this movie compared it to Blade Runner. Blade Runner had a plot. This movie does not.I can summarize this movie easily.For some unknown reason that is never explained, women can't have babies in the future. We get in a big chase for the entire length of the movie because one woman can have a baby, once again, for unknown reasons.Blade runner is light years better than this movie.The best thing about this movie is that it does not feel 'scripted'. It feels natural. However, that does not help us when we are scratching our heads at the end, asking ourselves 'WTF?'.

Well I will say the film was well made. Acting and directing was great and the film did create a gritty foreboding impression of the future which I so enjoy. However the plot does not really make any sense at all. No one has given birth in 18 years. OK, how does that then drive the countries of the world to ultra nationalism and isolationism? One of the main reasons that western Europe including the U.K. has allowed so much of an influx of immigration from all over the world is the fact that birth rates in these nations have been so very low. These nations need a large tax base to support their governmental structures. If there where no babies born, logic would dictate they would welcome in even more immigrants. It's as if they thought of this really cool idea of a zero birth rate future, but then threw in a subtle swipe against nationalism and anyone who believes in any form of immigration restrictions. There was a scene in which Muslim's in the Warsaw ghetto type "refugee camp" where chanting "allah akbar". As if they were a part of "the uprising". So its just the same old tripe of making the terrorists look like the poor little victims and the white Englishmen as the evil oppressors.

I have many reasons for naming Children of Men the best film to be released in the sci-fi genre but mainly for its incredible storytelling and incredible action sequences. The acting in this movie is also what many would expect from an epic such as this. I have never seen a movie with such an realistic and grim vision of a futuristic Totalitarian society with the exception of 1984 or Twelve Monkeys (both movies are not even in the same league as Children of Men). This is a must see for anyone wanting to watch a serious and truly epic vision of the future, you will be blown away by the incredible storytelling and cinematography. Best film of 2006.

Having read 10 pages of reviews, the plot (what there is of it) has thoroughly been described. So, I'll skip straight to what's terrible about this film. When writing even a newspaper article, you're supposed to explain: who, what, when, where, how and why. In 2 hours of running time, this film barely explains any of these. Instead, the 2 hours are packed with mostly gratuitous violence. When any explanation is given, the soundtrack is so bad, the accent so thick, that even my British husband couldn't understand what was being said.What isn't explained: Why women can't have children. Why no one cares who the father of the baby is. Why the "fish" need the baby to serve their purpose, or even what that purpose ultimately is. Why Julian is killed. Why immigrants are treated so badly, when there's zero natural population growth. Why young people stand around throwing rocks at trains and cars. What the Human Project is, and why it's the only hope for saving the baby, especially since it may not even exist. Why it's assumed that every other option is so much more dangerous, that it's preferable to put the mother and baby in the middle of a filthy, violent, unstable immigrant camp. Why they had to be arrested, go to the camp and risk their lives to get a rowboat. Why no one took the mother and baby into custody as they were walking through a crowd of soldiers. Why the unexplained birth of one single, female baby will "save the world" when taken in by the mysterious, mythical Human Project. But, again, plenty of time for random shooting, killing and gore.Even smaller plot points were annoying. Why have Jasper telling his stupid fart joke repeatedly, as he's getting killed? Why is there a pile of cow carcasses burning in a field? And do they really expect us to believe that the "heros" can escape from the "fish" when they're making all kinds of noise, up to within a few feet of the guards, in a car that won't even start? Even the cover of Ruby Tuesday was horrible. Believe it or not, I could keep going. I'm not the smartest or most sophisticated film viewer, but I know when a movie is too smart for me and over my head. This one isn't. It's just tissue paper thin, lazy, insulting and sloppy. The only reason I gave it 2 stars is because the cinematography is good.

If you enjoy a dark dark film, this is for you. The kind that makes you reflect on the plight of man and makes you want to slit your wrists. I was impressed with this entire film, the stark film techniques, the dark message, the fantastic acting. A must see for all sci-fi fanatics. This is advertised as a new-age Blade Runner. Wrong, this is better than Blade Runner. Ladies take some Kleenex with you. There is a heart wrenching scene that will tear your heart out. Men, get ready to gird your loins. The action scenes are stark, chilling and very in your face. But do be prepared to hear well spiced language. Definitely not a movie for children, or even young adults. A very mature film. See it !!!!

Review title: did i buy the wrong movie???
Review_body: this was by far one of the most horrific movies iv seen in a long time. i thought it was going to put me on the edge of my seat when all it did was force me to break it in half when it was over. the plot was dull and confusing, never explaining anything and assuming you know everything. meanwhile they make references to things that are completely irrelevant to the story. they never really explained why everyone was infertile. even the slightest bits of info like how people knew each other was left out. i couldn't believe i wasted my money on this. was this supposed to be one of the greatest movies of the year? well i hope my garbage likes it.

Although it was a good movie, I'll give it 5 out of 10 because of the way the Hollywood producers treat the ethnic problem in Romania. I saw a good deal of movies where Gypsies speak the Romanian language, consciously mistaking them(The Man Who Cried is another example, out of many). This is very harmful for Romanians, who are DIFFERENT than Gypsies. They live in our country too, but they are spread all over Europe. They have their own tradition, they respect their own laws and this is a big problem for the Romanians, being considered Gypsies and pointed out wherever they go. Can't these Hollywood producers do a film where the Gypsies speak their language (which is totally different than Romanian)? Excuse me if I can't see the loss or the disadvantages in that.Another problem is that in the film, almost 50% of the immigrants (in the Bexville prison) are Romanians or Gypsies (doesn't seem to matter). I mean, England was the only country standing all over the Globe and all nations tried to escape there. Is this supposed to mean that Romanians are 50% of the global population? I should mentions other intolerable facts but it will became boring. In the end it is cruel, how some people mock us, straight in the face (i bet that in P.D. James' book not all immigrants are Romanian). Hoping that this will make a small difference...

I liked this movie; I believe its main criticism is directed at modernity and its blind faith in rationality and science. It reveals the consequences when groups and individuals make rational logical decisions over morality and human dignity. The government in trying to keep order treats the illegal immigrants and opposition groups horribly. Not unlike how the USA and other liberal democratic nations treat suspected terrorists today. However it also shows the fugges as committing the same error exemplified best by the murder of Julian Moore and Michael Caine. This is reminiscent of the current question among socialist thinkers, of whether a revolution should suspend individual democratic rights in order to facilitate its ultimate goals. History has shown however that a temporary rule of the proletariat leads to a dictatorship over the proletariat. I like how the film makes note that science does not have an answer to why the women of the world have become infertile. I am reminded here of recent writers who criticize that scientism (the belief that science will solve all social problems) plagues modern societies and is founded on myth. However Caine's speech alludes that the problem is most likely a result of modern societies disregard and domination of Mother Nature. Overall a good movie as it grapples with ideas and problems that societies will have to face in the coming years.

What bothered me most about this movie was the conceit that being deprived of progeny, humankind would descend into chaos and in turn undertake mass migrations from one's homeland into the hostile bosom of another nation. It just does not make sense.I think it is fair to say that the more likely human response would be disbelief, bewilderment, sadness and depressive passivity. People would turn inward, questioning their fate and their place in the world. After the initial reaction abated into resignation or denial, people would entreat their government and their scientific communities for explanations and solutions. I think people would live out their lives as quietly and constructively as possible.The level of violence, anarchy and animus in this movie seemed far more appropriate for a society that had something for which to fight: a future for their children, racial or religious hegemony, economic redress and/or freedom from repression. This is why we usually fight.Granted there are few mad individuals who are angry at the worlda sociopath or disgruntled employee. But they see the world as having more than they have. In the instance of this movie, everyone is in the same boat. You might rail against the heavens, but not your neighbor.The movie's premise, I make no reference to the book, is an interesting one and worth examining. It certainly teases the mind. One woman's becoming pregnant after years of societal barrenness, would provoke delicious scenarios. Who was the father? Was there a father at all? What are the implications of the woman's being black--not white or brown etc? Could a new a new Eden be established and the world start afresh?Done well, dodging bullets in the streets and pitched battle scenes make for good cinema. We only have to look at Saving Private Ryan, Full Metal Jacket or Black Hawk Down. These riveting movies kept your jaws clenched and your knuckles white.Gone with the Wind was a passionate love story perfectly set with the US Civil War as its backdrop. Children of Men was an intriguing story of societal demise and tenuous rebirth set against a populace who was too busy fighting to take much note of it.

There is a plot, although it is never developed, and you feel nothing for any of the characters in the movie (except Jasper). This movie is an escape-and-chase movie with shooting... nothing more. We never find out what happened in history, or why, or who is behind the violence, or what happens.... very disappointing, for a movie that had such a promising concept.If you want a movie that is just car chases and shooting, I imagine there are a lot out there with just as much plot, but better effects. Same goes for action. This film pretends to be a drama, but falls short. I think 28 days later is a film that hits the mark from a "doomsday" point of view (but, 28 weeks later misses... but I digress).

This movie was mostly modern-day left wing propaganda. The previews gave me the impression that this was going to be fun and creative. However, it was neither. There are several layers of religious bigotry (that's bigotry against religion), along with views that if women stop having the ability to have babies, somehow most white Britons would become extremely racist and hateful. There were several themes from today, like illegal immigration and homeland security, which were taken to Hitler like extremes. Illegal aliens were carted away in buses similar to what happened during the holocaust. The idea that people that support tough borders and the deportation of ILLEGAL aliens are racist and would have it announced every five minutes over loudspeakers that illegal aliens must be deported is really an ignorant view of the true motives of people to the political right. This was really a hateful film. The idea that there will be a people in 20 years who want to target innocent Muslims, send illegal aliens to death camps and nuke anyone who is not like them seems very close to how extreme left-wingers view the right today. The movie even suggest that this all started back in 2008, and with the use of images in the background makes a connection to the current President of the U.S., George Bush.Occasionally we watch politically charged movies, but can at least find some bit of creativity that allows us to look beyond a certain bias. This movie had no redeeming qualities, certainly no creativity. Go to the streets of Portland Oregon during an anti-war demonstration and you'll hear all the themes and conspiracies of this movie and then some. Take notes, make a movie of the conspiracies and you too can have a movie just like Children of Men.

Review title: Terrible movie-making around a lacking story
Review_body: I just finished viewing Children of Men which is said to be a thought provoking and intelligent movie that received nothing but praise from just about anyone who has seen it.Disappointment is not the most accurate term to describe my feelings while and after viewing it. So let me just sum up this movie for you: The world is in utter chaos, for some unexplained reason all women are infertile, no children have been born in roughly 20 years. One woman miraculously gets pregnant for evenly unknown reasons. For yet again unknown reasons she is being chased down by various parties who seem to enjoy shooting automatic weapons at her. The baby is born and with the aid of a guy she makes it to some boat and Hooray! the world is savedintelligent stuff ey? Well, if this is mankind's solution to end all the worlds misery then I got a great idea. Let's send babies to all the troubled regions of the world. We can drop them by parachute from airplanes called 'Tomorrow' and I'm sure the senseless violence will immediately stop. We will wrap the babies in flyers with incredible thought provoking slogans like: "all governments are bad" and "Life's like a box of chocolates".And when the turmoil is over, we can send Alfonso Cueron to those regions to make action-packed chase movies out of local literature with profound religious overtones. He can start with the Bible and have Mary and baby Jezus being chased down by all the other characters in the Holy Book carrying heavy artillery while they are being aided by a young Judas.In these movies we will see an even more realistic hand-held cam imagery than what CoM had to offer us. One of them can feature an unexplained global outbreak of a virus which causes diarrhea that will make key figures in the movie take endless dumps on toilets with dung-splatter on the camera-lens. The splatter will be handsomely edited out later on, for it is more important to handle the style than any real content. God forbid it wouldn't be an uninterrupted long-shot.The movies will all be without closure and will all go black at the end emblazing the title of the movie onto the screen while in the distance we can hear Axl Rose vaguely doing a Bob Dylan cover which will later be explained by vivid fans of the movie that there is probably a new G 'n R album coming out.The movies will all have cameo's of top local actors. The actors are all unceremonially killed off early in the film to save budget. Then 30% of the remaining budget will go into the cinematography and what remains is quickly wired to professional movie critics so say something really nice about the production.Children of (wo)Men, Soon in a dumpster near you!

Review title: Waiting for a story which is just not there
Review_body: Watching Children of Men was a really odd experience. Expecting at least something above average, all I got was something almost amateuristic.I don't know, but I like my movies with something of a story or plot to it. Especially when a premise as in Children of Men provides an abundance of opportunity to do just that. What they did with it, came off slightly B-movie-ish and so did much of the cinematography with that nauseating homevideo-style cameramatics and bits of the acting as well. Why this movie is adored by so many people I cannot begin to fathom. Was the polling rigged in some way?The movie is basically a chase-flick in which a woman and her baby are escorted to a safe-haven while everyone helping her get offed during the travel. The whole premise of a barren world was completely wasted when the movie sloppily turns into this chase-vehicle, leaving its original dystopian backstory being merely an afterthought. The way they tried to pull it back in during the chase-sequences (e.g. the abandoned classroom scene) was clumsily forced, as were all the 'references' to: the immigration issue, Abu Ghraib, Guantanamo, The Bush Empire and what have you more. If you have something to say about these issues then say it, a movie is a great format for that. But surely they deserve much more than just a lazy nod in their general direction in some underdeveloped chase-movie. What I truly don't understand is why they didn't make the characters more likable. After all, we as onlookers are following their plight and should be concerned with it. When I watched this movie I had no sympathy or empathy for any of the characters or their predicament. This simply because they were either not very well portrayed (The sketchy part of Jullianne Moore), unlikable (Theo, Kee, the 'Fish') or Simpsons-like cartoon-figures (Sid, Jasper, that gypsy woman).I am a sucker for chase movies and that was the only reason I sat through the entirety of this mess. But even the chase plot didn't work for me at all. So many improbabilities* in the shovel-fed storyline and the pacing was just so off, rendering it ultra boring. A patronizing script making sure that every imbecile and his five brain cells got what was going on and the jarring soundtrack suitably missed the mark completely while multi-featuring the worst Stones-cover to date. Which was rather annoying.*I mean if Tom Hanks can build a raft from FedEx wrapping paper, I'm sure they could have built something seaworthy from the abundant piles of trash scattered throughout the sets.. did they really have to go to that refugee camp being exposed to all that violence with a baby? I thought they were trying to save it, not getting it killed...A complete mishap as far as I'm concerned with a most embarrassing 'ending' when almost out of nothing "Children of men" is blazon upon the screen in bold print. My oh my...Acting: 5 Story: 2 Cinematography:3 Script: 2 Soundtrack: 2

Review title: This has to be a joke....(a 5 user resume)
Review_body: Unbelievable what I read about this movie! I don't have one single positive comment to make about it since during the entire movie I only contemplated whether to leave or see it through hoping to see it turn for the better and at least get my money's worth.What a bore. What a lack of suspense. What an inane script. What a poor plot, it leads nowhere. The story totally fails to unravel, it is poorly acted, especially by Clair Hope Ashity who puts in an abysmal amateur performance and Julianne Moore who is just an add on to attract some viewers but more than clearly fails to impress during her way too brief appearance. The Human Project is mentioned continuously during the movie and comes up as a boat named Tomorrow? Please! Give us a break! You would think that somewhere in the process of writing, directing, and producing this unmitigated disaster of a film, someone would have paused and said "eh...guys....what 'TF' are we doing here exactly?". The characters have absolutely zero depth, the setting is more artificial than a Borg cube, and the storyline....well, I'm still trying to figure out what the storyline WAS, exactly.Things not explained in this movie include: the title, The Human Project, the infertility, the reason for the treatment of the immigrants, what happened to the rest of the world, why Julianne Moore is offed by the Fishes, what the Fishes actually DO to help immigrants (other than kill every native they encounter???), how the Fishes believe that having the baby will save THEM (not just provide hope for humanity), why the army wouldn't immediately take the mother and child into custody rather than letting them stroll through a gun battle, why they wouldn't have gone worldwide public with the news of a pregnancy or birth to begin with, given the celebrity of the youngest person on earth, and I could go on and on and on. If this is the thought-provoking side of this film everyone is talking about then I think I just wet my pants. That's not thought provoking, it'splain stupidity? And the lack of logic in the movie is just stupendous.Starting with their "silent" escape from the farm, when they were opening and closing car doors and trunks with enormous noise 5 meters from their captors. And ending with the unreasonably hopeful mood of the terrible 'ending', despite the absolute uselessness of having one accidental baby for the restoration of the world. Sweet lord, some of you reviewers are seriously disparate for a hopeful state of mind, aren't you.This is the third movie I recently saw based on high ratings and claims of superb acting, story, directing and cinematography and have been utterly disappointed with. We all know that there will be film companies out there writing their own rave reviews, but I'm beginning to question if there are not now rave review factories fixing the movie ratings on IMDb. Just as is done with internet search engines. I simply don't believe that a movie can get such great reviews and then turn out to be so blatantly poor.

Review title: A disgrace to the author's vision
Review_body: I read the book several years before Children of Men came to screen and was haunted by the tale that P.D James unraveled. When I heard there was to be made I looked forward to see how it was portrayed. This film was one of the greatest disappointments of books turned into film. The major plot points were completely disregarded and the story torn to pieces. Even looking at the film from a non-biased point of view, the story got lost in ridiculous gun battles and was not pieced well together. It lacked flow that makes a film watchable. I've told everyone I know that this film will disappoint them and those that did eventually see it hated it as well.

Man! This movie was such a disappointment! I have been wanting to see this film ever since I first saw the trailer, and I waited nearly a year to see it on Pay Per View last night. It had good actors and seemed to have a great story line! Where could I go wrong? Oh, and it has Sigur Ros playing on the trailer!! Boy, was I wrong! From the very beginning you're just throwin into a chaotic jungle of craziness. You find out that the world hasn't had a new born in a long while (of course, it never explains why) and (of course, you find THAT out in the trailer itself)....I very excited to see Julian Moore in the cast, but she dies within the first 20 minutes of the movie and doesn't serve any purpose to the story line. Well, she does throw a pregnate lady at the main character (whom I guess is the main character?) and then dies shortly after (apparently they have some past romantic life with him, but who cares??? SHE DIES). There are a whole bunch of other "terrorist" that help her out, but it never explains their roles either.There are also these people that are also trying to help the baby out, but it doesn't explain their role either. Why are they helping? Who knows! Why can't they tell anybody else? Who knows! The main character played by Clive Owen doesn't even know why he's helping out this girl, except for the fact that she has the last born baby....but, why does he care? It's not going to save his life? But apparently, Julian Moore told him so! Umm, what else? So, there's this really crazy, hippie dude that is friends with Clive Owen...we don't' know their history together, but the audience only knows that their friends. I had no emotional attachment to the guy, but of course..he dies...and I guess it was kinda sad to see an old man die.So, here's basically the story line.A girl who's pregnant runs around England with Clive Owen (with some random lady with crazy hair *not sure why she's there either*). There world is out of wack and England has a Nazi-like regime. There's a thing called the Human Project, and it apparently saves babies. There's a crazy lady at the ending who helps put Clive and the baby's mama in a crappy boat. And Clive dies at the end...with a horrible open ending (probably one of the worse open endings i've ever seen)....I never write about movies, but I felt strong enough to let the world now I disappointed I am. It could have been SO much better.

I was looking forward to watching this film, as its reviews were so positive. The characterisation was undeveloped and missed much of the thrust of the original story. There was a sense of annoying vision of the future with sites of London mashed together- the Tate Modern and Battersea Power Station became one! For those of us who know London, it was poor and shattered the narrative. The details of the future were also poor they made me think that production designer popped out to Camberwell to buy second hand fruit machines and a fiat multipla. The plot felt disjointed jumping the characters in unknown places to exactly where they were supposed to be, and the refugees spoke German. All in all the film was a bit of a poor experience and only benefited from good costumes, flip-flops and Michael Cane of course. The birth scene was so unrealistic and filmed from the other side of the room! How did this get awards?

This film doesn't merit a full whack of 10 stars, yet it obviously deserves more than average-skewing 'ones' and 'twos'. I wish people wouldn't do that...I found C.O.M disappointing. Like many, I was keen to see it after reading positive reviews. Visually, I have no complains. Believable, gritty, oppressive. The story's premise, I have no complaints with. A lack of explanation for the infertility is inconsequential. In this film the intrigue lies not in the reasons behind the apocalypse, but how the characters react to the aftermath.My main problems with the film were that I cared little for the characters, as others have said, there are few if any genuinely likable characters. Fair enough, they've all been brutilised by society's implosion, but the middle aged lady with the dreds is annoying, the girl is hardly endearing, and Clive has got a pole up him. if they had all met grisly ends on screen, I wouldn't have flinched.Also, I was suspicious as to the films message. The characters we are supposed to view positively seem to lean towards the idealistic hippy school of thought and I fail to grasp how the issues raised by the film could have been mitigated by pot smoking, liberal attitudes to farting, or new age lifestyles.Any film that gets you thinking has to be given credit however, add that to the visual element and the cinematography and I think we're talking about a reasonable piece of work.

This movie was great! More than anything, the way in which it was shot contributed to how fascinating the movie was. Two scenes especially: when Theo, Luke, Julian, etc. are ambushed on the road; and in the fire-fight during the raid/battle scene. It reminded me of the battle scenes in Saving Private Ryan b/c in both there was no soundtrack music (which can mask sounds and remind the viewer that "it's just a movie"), no cgi, nothing that seemed over-the-top. Like "Ryan", Children of Men keeps the viewers on the edge of the seat by allowing us to see and hear everything that the characters would see and hear during those gun fights. Because of this, one can get a true feel for what those characters are going through.I saw this last night for the first time on SD TV. I'm making it a point to buy this movie on DVD (or HD DVD when I get a player).

Review title: Atrocious. A travesty of PD James's not very good book
Review_body: I was lukewarm about the book, but the film is atrocious. The Mexican director has thrown away almost everything that was good about the book - mostly the first part - and retained just the concept and the names of the characters, and written his own left-wing political thriller about illegal immigrants and Guantanamo Bay. He has produced a trivial shoot 'em up, noisy, foul-mouthed story with poor continuity. If you want to hear the dialogue, turn the sub-titles on, but if you don't, you will hardly have missed anything. I looked in vain for how people would really react to a world without children.
