Where was the use as pets as substitutes? Where were the deserted playgrounds? Instead of ennui from Clive Owen, all we got was a colossal sulk. Too little was made of the idea of Quietus. I can understand how a movie like this fits with the current tribe of critics, armchair revolutionaries to a man, but PD James is a Church of England old lady, regretting the passing of pleasure and deserves better than this.

Review title: a must see= brilliant and fresh
Review_body: this film is one of the best things i have seen this year. It's an improbable cross between "Brazil" "a clockwork orange" and the video game HALF-LIFE2 (from which it borrows it's final sequences and use of on shot action-sequences) it manages to be both entertaining in the Hollywood way (with incredible action sequences and a very clever way of using digital effects) yet very sad and different with a very very dark and realistic overtone. No comic relief, no cartoon character bravery, only human behavior in it's best and most horrible way. This realistic overtone makes the main characters very engaging and moving. CLive owen (whose i have always disliked) is excellent as the man drowned into an adventure too big for him (sorry for my bad English)It's the same kind of film than V for vendetta (both taking place in a futuristic fascist British society) different from the usual mainstrean studio teenager pleaser crapGO see it! help intelligent cinema

Review title: very good movie - it draws your attention to...
Review_body: i've not read the book.what i see here is a very good movie. if you haven't seen it, please don't hesitate.it draws your attention to what you don't want to happen to our planet and also mankind in the future.the set is very good.you really delve in it. it projects clearly a scene of desolation edge.2 types of desolation...mankind is vanishing and so is the planet.let's take care of the blue planet and take care of the future. (for me) the baby here represents the new born hope, another chance, the miracle.

There are few films among the masses that grant the viewer a long-lasting impression. Children of Men delivers a unique apocalyptic view into the future. Imagine a world where humans could no longer reproduce and the youngest man on earth is eighteen years old. Every country except your own has either collapsed or is in a violent civil war. Every human in your country is pushed to work for a future that may not even exist. Every day counts closer to the end of man. This is the vision that director Alfonso Cuarón brilliantly displays on screen. Set in the year 2027, Children of Men takes place in Britain after a full 18 years since the last baby was born. Theo Faron, Clive Owen, is trapped with a moral dilemma to continue with routine life or join an old friend in saving a woman with the key to the future. Either way Theo must face the end of man with courage to persist with habit or risk the little order remaining. Michael Caine and Julianne Moore both play excellent supporting roles and make the most of their screen time. Children of Men is full of striking emotion, cinematography, and meaning. The emotion given by the characters is extraordinary. You feel that each character believes their position to the crisis in the world and will die protecting it. The actors bring out the personality of their characters whether it is humorous or stern. You feel connected to the story and pray for resolution all the way to the end. Owen's performance is in tune with the environment from start to finish. Theo is forced to run through and interact in prison camps, war-zones, and forests. Theo speaks to other characters about his concerns and worries. As you travel through the movie you develop your own feelings and attitudes towards each character praying for resolution.The cinematography is astonishing from start to finish. The scenery and setting are beautiful with complete attention to detail. The viewer is completely entrapped and believes they are part of this futuristic Britain. Broken down buses, buildings, and trains all add to this. You really feel that if the world continues downhill that the cities will become bleaker and rundown. The camera captures all the emotion the characters produce through each sign of dialogue. The movie also contains two long-shots that are possibly the best camera-work I have seen in a single camera pan. One shot was possibly one of the greatest and most believable action sequences as well. The message and meaning of the movie also present a great addition to the movie's analysis. I spent a long time reflecting over the ending and the message the director is trying to convey. The entire film is full of insightful dialogue and shows the relationships we are capable to build with our friends along with our enemies. It shows the will of people in sacrificing themselves for what they believe. Most importantly it shows how man must stand together in order to create a secure future. The selfless actions that Theo Faran learns to accept show how man can change in order to protect the human race are complex and believable. It comforts you knowing I would come to the aid of others.After witnessing this great film, I say it's a must watch for anyone who appreciates insightful movies. Alfonso Cuarón does an excellent job of leading you down a path towards enlightenment. After an in depth viewing of this film you will feel the need to reflect upon it for awhile and possibly watch it again. The effort put forth by the actors shows the whole cast and crew put their whole attention to creating a truly special film. Future movies will take note of the excellent camera-work and cinematography to try and recreate these brilliant shots. I am unable to stress the wonders this movie has brought to my eyes. Some may complain about straying from the novel, but as a film this is excellent.

I'm confused. Very much so even...I just saw Children of Men. A movie which currently holds a stunning nr 147# position on IMDb and is critically acclaimed. A movie with also little to no plot (and what it had was dumbfoundingly illogical and übersimplistic), wasted performances by otherwise fine to even great actors and a political or social slant so inane, so completely sophomoric that it's hard to believe this movie was made as a serious attempt at social commentary. Alas, the extra's on the DVD leave no room for ambiguity. No spoof here, this was meant to be serious...So we have one fertile/pregnant woman amidst 3 billion who are not. We have an organisation presented to us in a lame stork-joke, which ocupies itself with getting the human race fertile again. That is, if this organisation even exists. They set out to find a raft to paddle to that phantom organisation which is said to bob somewhere around the coast of England. Why they chose to not just buy a raft but get one in one of the most violent parts of the country where bullets fly freely, tanks shoot at anything that moves and walking cameramen are trying to set records for the longest single-take ever made, all this with presumably the only infant alive in the world, is never even remotely tried to be explained. I really don't mind that pompous, vacuous films are being made under the pretext of being subtle, deep and insightful. What gets a rise out of me is that people can't see a really terribly made movie for what it is, but in stead sing praise, forgive the exuberant defects they are willing to admit this movie has and vote it a ten anyway, without breaking a sweat. Like the headline-reading buffoons or game-console addicts they are.Shame, especially to the professional moviecritics who along their careers surely must have seen movies like The Usual Suspects for plot and suspense, Full Metal Jacket for steadycam cinematography, It happened One Night for social commentary and God knows how many other quality films that have been produced over the years.No, these movies were in fact never made. Apparently the line was drawn at October 2006, conveniently forgetting that a particular scene should display some profundity if you accompany it by long and abstruse orchestral manouvres. Forgetting that movies used to have some form of plot other than something any writer for Sesame Street could come up with using nothing but a broken pen and a paper napkin. And Forgetting that overexposing, completely plotdriven and patronizing scripts don't usually help the actors to do their jobs convincingly nor challenge a moviegoer in any way.But..you've already seen this caper.

It's 2027 in Children of Men. Through advertisements, commercials and newscaster innuendo we learn that civilization has broken down on a global level. Only England somehow manages to 'battle on' and is suffering from large streams of illegal immigrants because of this. They the government, deal with it harshly; killing or deporting them as soon as they are rounded up and put in cages. We also learn that the entire world has become infertile; no children have been born in eighteen years. No one seems to know why and the hinted causality of growing pollution, global warming, and food manipulation as a reason for the infertility makes little to no sense. It is here where the logic in the film is starting to buckle, which is shortly after the opening credits. For the human race to fully stop being fertile all of a sudden, something more catastrophic and acute is needed. Also it would not explain why animals would be able to procreate amidst this eco disaster or why the term 'cloning' somehow seems to have vaporised from the dictionary. Obviously the existence of something acute did not fit writer/director Cuaron's agenda because it would ultimately lose the film's connection with the present world. Of course, if Cuaron had stayed true to the book, the problem would not have been so obvious. Too bad he (admittedly) never even read it.All this hardly matters because Children of Men comes off the shelf of the so-called thought-provoking movies. Which in this case means that its OK to INvoke some thought, but surely not to get too carried away with it. Judging by the way the script is handled, presenting the scarce plotpoints through ham-fisted explanatory dialog, I don't think this movie was meant to be thought provoking at all. At best it's a silly reminder of things we learn in school at age 10 and up or see in the news every time we turn the telly on.The film itself plays out like a big formulaic chase in which our protagonists, mainly Theo (Clive Owen) and a black pregnant woman, 'mysteriously' named Kee (Claire Hope Ashity), are chased down by a terrorist group named The Fishes who want the soon to be born child for themselves in order tocuddle it? Their motivations remain a complete mystery. The quest leads Kee and Theo through England's countryside, which is kind of a plod, also for the viewer. Fortunately we can listen to a jarring and bloated soundtrack that accompanies the bleak and unappealing shaky visuals the viewer is presented. The plot of the movie seems to revolve around getting Kee and her later to be born baby to another group called the Human Project that is not sure to even exist. But if they do exist, we can be sure that the human race, thanks to one little squealing baby human, will be saved.or something.Children of Men is a clumsy experiment gone terribly wrong. Director Alfonso Cuaron is know to despise too much exposition in films and if he is referring to the 'Hollywood way' of telling stories, I would somewhat agree with him. But Cuaron fails to properly compensate for the lack of exposition in the way the story is unfolding and scenes are constructed. He compensates by making the dialog throughout the entire movie so unnaturally explanatory that it is far too obvious that he is just informing the viewer. Being taken by the hand through every reason and meaning of the plotpoints like a little kid is pretty infuriating. And this doesn't just hamper the acting by otherwise capable actors, it also ruins any character development in the movie which in turn is not compensated for. Furthermore the movie is pompous and monotonous with its one-sided political overtone. It is all the same evasive when it comes to answering, or even questioning the issues it nonetheless throws up. The symbolism and churlish nods to contemporary issues is far too conspicuous and highly annoying as such (The one captured immigrant they allow to be heared, speaks German!, yeah, let's deport a former Nazi...seriously people, who writes this stuff?) And the logic of the plot that a single baby/person will be able to save the world in a movie that is supposed to have a serious message, is, to put it kindly, ludicrous, puerile and as original as a beer commercial.Although there is some fancy camera-work and editing in especially the last segment of the movie (a Kubrick homage?), I would not go as far as recommending this movie for just that bit alone as others have suggested. I think it is tragic that the talents of an artdirector like Lubezki were wasted on a bleak, rather predictable and messy film with zero likable characters, a questionable script and a too obvious political viewpoint which is shoved up the arse of the viewer over and over again. The film leaves out so much backstory and tries to compensate for this with so many minuscule silly details that even a second or third watch will not help to really put all the pieces together because too many important and interesting ones were simply left in the box.Although the attempt is somewhat admirable and despite the absurd high rating, not recommended at all.3/10

Reading through all the glorifying reviews, I'm wondering if people are slowly becoming deranged.The basic idea of the human race being unable to sire children anymore was interesting. However, the execution was so lame and vapid and was only made worse by the most nonsensical script I heard since I saw 'Transformers'.The acting was pretty half baked. The little plot they had was full of lazy holes. Characters weren't build but just thrown at the audience. Back story was only mildly touched upon but never fleshed out or explained in any way.....I could go on, but I am wasting even more of my time here.Basically, the only thing that rated above poor was the editing. So if that's all you look for in a movie, then this one could be for you.If you are looking for anything else, like even the slightest bit of substance or logic to a story, then stay well clear.

As the end of this movie was blazon upon the screen like they abruptly ran out of ideas for any more vapid script, thoughts of tearing apart the DVD crossed my mind. Since it was a rewritable one, I disregarded that thought and decided to draw up this short review.Seriously people, this must be a new low as far as science fiction movies go, as far as insult to the intelligence goes or very, very poor scripts for that matter.What is everybody so impressed with? Did everyone turn off the news 10 years ago never to put it back on again, or have ye all been hiding in a cave for the last 30 years and didn't get around to see any movies? Extremely poor writing, half baked plot points, hammy acting, grotty visuals, no cleverness or subtleness whatsoever in its already outdated political reference, unlikable leads, one implausible scene after another, sub-characters straight out of a Simpsons episode and morality lessons fit to put into a TV-show for the mentally retarded. Is this what quality movies are about these days? I'm simply appalled reading the exalted reviews I'm still hoping 82.000 people were paid to give their 2+ stars, but I dread they were not Ugh!

Children of Men is Oscar material, often you go to a movie and the next day you forget the details.Very though provoking movie, a must see for all adults.The movie made me uneasy, angry, happy, in short it took me through a full range of emotions.I love the way it presented the messages on so many current social issues.This movie has pointed the way without preaching, great writing.The characters were well developed and orchestrated.There were multiple themes running throughout the story, of Love, sacrifice, deception and greed.The self conflicts of leadership was also clearly addressed.Global warming um, what about what we are doing to each other? As a writer filmmaker in the end I was satisfied with the setup expectations.It is one of the all time intellectual movies to see.

First off, this is an exceptional movie. The direction is top notch and Clive Owen and Michael Caine were fantastic. But the thing that really sets this movie apart from others is its incredible tracking shots. These long cuts give a sense of realism to the movie, it gives it a feeling similar to a documentary, as if this is simply a glance into the future. There are two shots in particular that really stand out. First is the car scene when they are attacked by all of the people. The camera rig they constructed for the film was completely original. It allowed a 360 view of everyone and everything inside and outside of the car. This single shot is completed to stunning, emotional effect. The second shot, near the end of the film rivals the famous tracking shots in movies such as Goodfellas, Boogie Nights, and Magnolia. The shocking chase through the war torn city to save the child, and the impact the baby has on the war scene is breathtaking. All of the subtle nuances in the rich environment demand multiple viewings to fully appreciate. One of my favorite moments in the long shot is when the blood spatters on the camera lens in the bus. I believe this film has gotten a hard rap. People just need to appreciate how well made a movie this really is.

I've actually created a profile simply for this comment.This is currently rated as 8.1 out of 10. Having just watched this film I can see that this is blatantly a result of some kind of vote fixing.This film isn't even worth commenting on, other than to warn anyone thinking of wasting their time on it, not to bother.It's just a stupid, incoherent bloody mess. There are so many holes in the storyline that it ends up making absolutely no sense. It really is an embarrassment, anyone involved in this film should be ashamed of themselves.Come on IMDb, sort this out......if you allow this kind of thing to go on, people are going to lose all respect for the site.

Review title: "When a child cryes, the guns have to stay still."
Review_body: "Cand un copil plange, armele trebuie sa taca." "When a child cryes, the guns have to stay still." What can i say more? The movie is fantastic. I watched it more than one time and still i am impressed by the final scenes. The world we are living in is forgetting the miracle of birth, the miracle of childhood. We are all forgetting the purity of a child. The cast is perfect. Julian Moore, Oana Pelea, Clive Owen and all the them. The script is perfect. It moved me. It touched me. I don't wanna be pathetic, but it's a movie really, really worth seeing. Great movie, it makes you think about your own life and about what you are. And again i have to say: When a child cryes, the guns have to shut up.

Just back from seeing 28 Days later which was a total let down and only reminded me of how stunning this film is. When it comes to the dystopia views of the not too distant future Britiain then this film has it down perfectly. Everything is excellent. The acting is just enough, camera work is not so shaky your left feeling sick as with most modern thrillers, the music is notable for its sparse use and the editing is unobtrusive and unnoticeable to the point of genius. A take that lasts ten minutes towards the end leaves you on the edge of your seat in awe with the stunning execution of its grace (did I just type that?!?). the story is incredibly plausible and it only goes to prove that us Brit's are the best at the bleak future pictures and have no problems leaving out the sugary sub-plots of romance and the Speilbergian "cute kid".Fantastic. A+Also pick up the DVD for a great documentary as an extra.

Review title: My favorite movie to date! An action-loving philosopher's film!
Review_body: How do you feel about euthanasia? The role of the government in a crumbling civilization? The efforts of depraved religion? Genocide? What about the extinction of the human race and the implications on our behavior if we knew the end was inevitable? In a time when the sound of a child's laughter has become a distant memory we find a society of middle-aged adults surviving in a colorless world. It's a time when the phrase, "Get busy living or get busy dying," bears greater meaning than ever before.When I try to think of the all the movies I've seen that have made me go, "Wow," I can only name a handful: American Beauty, The Shawshank Redemption, Glory, Schindler's List... and Children of Men. Not only is the cinematography exponentially superior to anything else (keep your eyes open for the two extended scenes without any breaks in the film sequence), but it really, truly opens your mind and your heart to some outstanding questions. This is a movie to watch either by yourself so that you are immersed in the themes present throughout the plot or to sit down with a bunch of your equally philosophical college friends and then debate for hours when it's over. Really, after you've watched it once you'll feel like you have to watch it again just to try and understand the horrors of living in such a depraved time. It's hard to pinpoint just what kind of movie this is: it is what you interpret it to be. I'd call it an intriguing film with the feel of a documentary and the fast-action pace of other movies featuring Clive Owen. I beseech you: watch it!

Children of Men belongs to a small group of SF films that stand above the clichéd plots, unintelligible dialogue and in-your-face CGI that infest the multiplexes.An excellent example of a well developed dramatic idea and creative restraint in constructing a very convincing future. Plot explication is subtly layered with various devices such as newscasts, signage, graffiti and headlines that give depth and background to the life and times of this brave new world.Great relief at the lack of gemutlich sentimentality that would have killed CoM if it had been produced in Hollywoodland.Up there with District 9, Blade Runner and the rest of Real SF Canon!

Review title: One of the most underrated movies in cinema history.
Review_body: Looking at the original cover and hearing the title it sounded like some cheesy acted action chick flick, but man I could have never been more wrong. This is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen, and I am one of the harshest film critics. The impossibility of directing some of these 5 minute long takes (the camera literally doesn't cut) as the characters go through some of the best action sequences (and most realistic) you will EVER see. Owen really never had his 'role', and this was it. He plays the reluctant, dis-envisioned loner Theo who, despite his poverty and the fact that the entire world is crumbling around him, maintains his composure through constant flask drinking, gambling, and weed. When his old liaison, Julian Moore, approaches him for an offer, he reluctantly agrees after learning of the money he is promised. Unaware of the situation he is entering himself into, he is thrown into the melee when the transport of an illegal immigrant goes horribly wrong and he is stuck trying to smuggle the last pregnant woman on earth out of the country, while being discovered, hunted, and chased by multiple terrorist groups. Meanwhile the country is in an uproar about illegals because of how dangerous the rest of the entire world has become most illegal immigrants are murderous and in gangs, and they highly outnumber the rest of the population. The baby is a source of political motives, being that it's the last on earth, and Theo quickly realizes that besides the mother he is the only one looking out for its best interests.It becomes readily apparent that despite always being drunk and stoned Theo becomes a quick witted, highly agile escape artist when his adrenaline kicks in. He battles through hell, alone, and for most of the movie without shoes, striving to get this woman and her baby to safety. In one of the last scenes, Theo is walled in with the woman in a refugee camp being invaded by multiple terrorist organizations, and scheduled to be bombed by the military. I've never had such admiration for a hero as I did watching Theo run through the streets dodging bullets and cheating death, it was one of my most favorite scenes in movie history, and it was over 7 minutes of non-cut camera action. You witness first hand the horrors of war, as everyone around him annihilates each other. It will have you on the edge of your seat. This will always be one of, if not, my favorite movie of all time. It set a landmark with its camera-work, no one has yet to accomplish anything like this. It should have won multiple Oscars, no argument. To me Theo is one of the greatest heroes in movie history. This is one of my few movie reviews in 10-15 years on this site, because this movie truly deserves it. Trust me, see it. Give it a half hour and the action will start and it wont stop. 12 out of 10. Great movie. I've recommended it to so many people, more than any movie I know, and most of the times they've never heard of it, and are always happy they saw it. When I first came to IMDb it had a rating of 6.3, now it's 8.0, and it's still too low. Owens' acting in this movie is some of the best I have EVER seen. It's a lot harder to act when the camera isn't cutting for 5 minutes, your flaws come out, and it just exposed how amazing he was. Just watching him break down in tears was flawless, the spit connecting from his hands and he tried to wipe them away and everything, it reminded me of Day Lewis in TWBB. Truly remarkable.

It has 2 years since I first saw this film, and now, after watching it about a dozen times at home in the interim, its power has not abated. I gather from the other comments that I am not alone in considering it one of the finest films in the history of the medium. The action scenes alone would be enough to distinguish it as groundbreaking, but when combined with the cinematography, incredible acting, and intelligent, devastating script, I think Children of Men will stand out as one of the classics of cinema for decades to come. I have read a lot of comparisons to Blade Runner, which was certainly groundbreaking in its look and special effects, but I feel Citizen Kane or Chinatown or Apocalypse Now are more relevant comparisons. I am constantly saddened by how little attention this film received in the US. This is one for the ages, and I can only hope more and more people here in the States will discover it on DVD.

Review title: Tell him he's a fascist pig
Review_body: Great story, strong characters, excellent performances. The long shots are beautifully intense and intimate. The well-written narrative allows for Cuaron's dystopian commentary on the police state, illegal immigration, environmental pollution and the rise of religiosity in times of crisis. Some of the scenes are a little unrealistic but do not take away from the experience. Worth a watch.

Review title: "You cannot imagine what happen to a world without children".
Review_body: Regarding movies, I have to admit I am definitely hedonistically oriented. I am systematically avoiding productions declaimed in the media as real cinematography, opposing it to movies for the masses. Still I like to be surprised and artistically blessed from time to time. This is what happened with Children of men.I won't focus on the technical part of the film, like lengthy single-shot sequences or performance of the various actors. A lot of people described it in previous posts, far better than I would do. As a convinced hedonist, I will just say that the film is sufficiently well made and played, for the audience to stuck to the drama taking place. Taking advantage of the fact that I write this review nearly two years after watching the film, I will rather focus on the reminiscent feeling inhabiting me since I watched it.This film has many layers, like for example the presentation of human nature facing moral collapse or the strong pastiche of British society and political activism. But me, I perceive this film mainly like a biography convenient for most men with a heart and an independent mind. The main character, is a former idealist disappointed by life, who became a frustrated pragmatic. Children of men is the story of his initiatory journey toward salvation, not only of human race, but also his own. It is about hope and devotion which make us human. The answer given by the film will be close to the heart of every loving father.This film created an impression that is still living in me. I guess this the best definition for art. As impressions are subjective by definition, so is art. That's why I accept that people could be disappointed by this film (still, a lot of criticism is really unfair and simply not relevant). Despite the unforgettable atmosphere of this film, it is not convincing after reflexion, as a post-apocalyptic vision. Don't expect it or you could be disappointed. Still, this is the kind of film, that will give you a strong impression, if only you open your mind to the main stream of the story. The clue is given in the title of my post.At the end, I will add that I love battle scenes with a lot of special effects and 3D animations. But Theo Faron, the film's protagonist, took a dimension far beyond Batman's armor or Neo's capacities in Matrix. If I remember correctly without a single shot.

When I first heard about this movie, my dad had been to see it and he stated it was an amazing film. So whilst sitting at home flicking through channels i stumbled upon this and thought okay i'll give it a go. I'm glad i did. The plot in the film is so gripping and the action scenes towards the end were stunning, made even more so by the single shot technique which went on for seven minutes. I advise anyone who displays an interest in sci-fi watch it. This film explores the themes of hope and faith in the face of overwhelming futility and despair. I wont go into detail on the plot. Watch it yourself and you will see what a great movie this is.

Review title: Can You Compare it with these 4 Movies ?
Review_body: I can't say I didn't like this movie but I expected something much better than what I watched..Ch.of Men has a good starting idea about how the world will be in like 20years.the director showed us what he wanted us to see in a perfect way.The problem is that what he wants us to see is just another chase movie..If you think of movies like V for Vendetta , 12 Monkeys , Minority Report , Equilibrium etc and compare them to Children of Men you will get what I mean.The above movies started with a good idea and their story was based on that idea for the rest of the movie.Children of Men starts with a better idea than these movies so we are all impressed in the beginning..but after this all you see is Clive Owen and the pregnant girl running and being chased all the time.Honestly , in many scenes during this movie I didn't think of the reason these people are trying to get away.They just run,and run,and run and make you forget the situation the world is on 2030.You don't focus on the social problem but on the action , the special effects etc.That's why when we finally see a scene that "fits" in the starting idea of the movie, we get emotional (I'm talking about the scene when everybody sees the baby and even the soldiers stop shooting)They had a GREAT idea of how the world can be some years later and they ruined it all making another..action movie.At least in the movies i mentioned above , all the action is relevant to its starting plot.Better go watch a movie with Jet-Li if you want to see an action movie :SSorry for my bad English :)

I saw the great points that this movie received so I was curious to watch it. I went to the local theater and after watching 30 minutes I realized that nothing happened yet, that stayed on for another 30 minutes. I think it's a movie that is very slow. I was not my kind of thing. It lacks action and the story isn't that good at all. Although it wasn't bad at all, I only give it a score of 6 out of 10.The film starts very promising, it made me think of a game called "Half Life 2" Where a guy needs to get to the other side of a totally spooked town with all kind of strange things happening. In the movie the same things happens but the guy here has a pregnant woman with him. It's all very good but they could have shown that in 60 minutes and make a more closing ending. That's just my point of view.

Review title: Good intentions not necessarily make a good movie.
Review_body: This is a movie of good will and good intentions but definitely not a good movie (consider at least the acting, for god sake, at no point in the movie they were credible...).It also is a mystery how it can be so highly rate on IMDb.. 8.1 with over 20k votes at the time of writing.It is either there is an extreme need of good intentions or good intentions have been used to cover bad ones..Let's hope it's just the first case, but I suspect that the second one is more likely.However, a rating fictitiously created to make a fool of the public.

Review title: A Waste of a Great Idea
Review_body: The idea of human infertility in a global scale would have the potential to generate a great movie. Unfortunately this movie wastes this idea completely. It just boringly depicts a scenario that is at least very implausible. No attempt is made to explain (or to encourage the audience to come up with its own explanations) why infertility would have brought the world to that dystopian state. It is much more probable that the world would get economically better in the first 18 years without children, since the costs of raising children would gradually disappear. It would only slowly start to get economically worse after the first 18 years.With a diminishing population, resources per capita would increase across the world, and hence the amount of illegal immigrants who immigrate searching for better conditions for themselves and especially for their children, would decrease, instead of increasing as shown in this movie. The only explanation why the movie shows an increase in immigration seems to be the British xenophobia. Even under a condition (i.e. global infertility) that would actually decrease the number of illegal immigrants in their country, they manage to imagine that their country would be even more "attacked" by illegal immigrants. And as the movie shows, apparently they believe that such an increased inflow of immigrants would then justify locking all these immigrants in concentration camps...It is improbable that, in a world where humanity faces extinction, people would start killing each other, instead of focusing on discovering what caused the infertility and solving it. The whole movie is just about escaping from these meaningless and random killings.It is simply very boring. I cannot believe it got so many awards and a high rating in IMDb. And it is really a pity that this movie wasted its original idea of global infertility. Now, even if other movies do a better job with this idea, it will just not be that original anymore.

Really, i'm fed up. This movie is a completely waste of time. OK, i got the message: children are the world's hope. So... it could be said in a short way, not in about 2 hours. All in all, I just wanted to tell you how disappointed i'm with the plot. In the other hand, the casting is amazing and obviously our stars (Julianne Moore, Clive Owen and Chiwetel Ejiofor) had a perfect performance, moreover the special effects were well done, i did like it, including the scene when the camera gets bloodstained and all of sudden it's clear again. By the way, i didn't get the reason why humans can no longer procreate, let's pretend it makes sense. Furthermore, I see at no point, what makes it so good, to have been nominated for 3 Oscars, 20 wins and 25 nominations... I'm like, what for all those awards? Needless. In fact, it's not worth watching it. By the way, this theme is so dramatic, you know, and this is not the first, or the last, to talk about humanity's end such as 2012. I swear, i'd love to ask my money back at the cinema's ticket office. Unpleasant and tiring, there's a moment you're sick and tired of watching it. Boil or Boil, who said publicity is the business soul, is a genius. That's all people.

I saw this movie because I was intrigued by its premise, an infertile world, the beginning of the end for the human race. Instead of an intelligent science fiction movie I viewed another Hollywood action movie packed with near death chases and cliché heroic actions.I wish the filmmakers concentrated more on the mystery surrounding the infertility and Human Project rather than making another predictable, boring excuse to spend $10. Im sick of these stupid movies already, I cant remember the last time I felt satisfied walking out of a movie theater, maybe Memento.Although the acting in this movie was not half bad, it could not make up for the lack of script. And besides, these peoople should act well in their movies. Plumbers fix sinks and actors act.

The theme of Children of Men is hope, and in Alfonso Cuaron's film, it has to overcome the most daunting of odds. Clive Owen plays Theo, a man living in London during a time when women are no longer capable of giving birth, and the extinction of the human race is not only certainly at end, it has been accepted by the people themselves. London is in a militarized state, and suicide is not only common, but encouraged by the government as an alternative to the violence taking place.As expected by the mood of the plot, and Cuaron's past films, such as Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Children of Men is a dark film. After all, the human race is coming to an end. The lighting is dark and the environs are dirty, which draws comparisons to Azkaban, which was by far the darkest of the Harry Potter series. Even the scenes filmed during the day are dark, which is just a further reinforcement of the message that we don't want to live in a world where hope is this far gone.There is a hope, and it lies in one woman, Kee, played by Clare-Hope Ashitey, who is the last pregnant woman alive. Theo is quickly drawn into the mix and must protect Kee at all costs, and ensure that the baby and mother are delivered to safety, in both senses of the word. There are supporting characters that lend to his quest, such as Jasper, played by Michael Caine, Theo's old activist buddy, and Julianne Moore as Julian, Theo's ex-wife. Jasper is a burnout that is the noblest of men when he is challenged, and Moore's character provides an inspiring side story of her and Theo regaining trust for each other.Children of Men is a masterful display of the long shot. Large battle sequences and escape scenes are filmed in one long shot, which helps the audience feel as if they are in the thick of the action. Blood splatters, dirt and shaky camera's give some scenes the feeling of a documentary, as if the audience is watching true events unfold. Children of Men is a film that puts fear and hope against one another, in the most dire of circumstances, with the human race in control of the outcome, and with the most stakes involved. Even at its calmest moments, Children of Men is full of suspense and drama.

Children of Men, directed by Alfonso Cuaron, is set in England in 2027, where the human race has become no longer able to reproduce. England is also in the middle of complete chaos and internal war, due to the overpowering of a fascist government. Clive Owen plays Theo, a man who teams up with a rebel group called The Fishes, to help save a young woman who he finds out is pregnant. Since the young woman is the first to give birth in over 18 years, Theo, Julian, played by Julian Moore, and the group must fight to save her from stray bullets and the English police who will get rid of anyone in their path.The movie reflects the theme of a threat to the existence of humankind. Being that no one in the film was able to conceive in over 18 years, the future of the human race was being questioned. In the beginning of the film, Theo seemed to have become comfortable with the situations happening around him and was just living his life. But when Julian, who is also his ex-wife, approaches him for help with her cause, he starts to show personal concern with getting the girl and the baby to safety. With the help of his good friend, Jasper, played by Michael Caine, Theo soon believed that the world could in fact be saved from total extinction.Another film that relates to the same theme is 28 Days Later. 28 Days Later also tells of how humankind is in danger of being lost forever. In this particular film, contaminated chimpanzees threaten the lives of humans after a vicious attack on them. Both films present characters that have to fight for their own lives as well as the lives of others in order for humans to have a future on earth.I thought this film was great. Was very entertaining and presented a story line that kept me interested. Clive Owen and Julianne Moore also added significant acting abilities to the film as well.

Warning: May contain traces of a spoilerFirst of all, I am very much into movies where the future goes wrong in some way, but I think the 8 points are way overrated. I mean hello, reality check, this means that this movies is as good as 12 Monkeys (which it isn't). The story is flat, not convincing and leaves me wondering in how far humankind might be saved just because one woman manages to get pregnant. Also I did not like the obvious comparison to the Jesus story (one guy is the Savior, couple on the run etc.). Also kind of a shame to make a movie that plays at around 2030 and then go ahead and take cars like the Renault Avantime (or Fiat Multipla?) and put some cardboard around it to fake a "futuristic" car. Come on.Tip: Watch 12 Monkeys, Equilibrium or GATTACA instead if you haven't seen those.

Review title: visceral and intimately powerful - a masterpiece
Review_body: I can't remember the last time I was as moved or as engaged with a piece of work in my life. I am as cynical and critical a film-goer as you are likely ever to find, and during Children of Men I was truly on the edge of my seat, incapable of turning away for much of the film. This movie at times thought provoking, touching, heart wrenching and darkly comical, but always brutal and immediate in it's depiction of a dystopian future of shocking violence and desperation. Truly the vision of a master filmmaker at work, Cuaron deserves the Best Director Oscar for the next five years for this one - you will be blown away, as was I.

Review title: Alfonso Cuarón must have been to busy printing cash to read the book
Review_body: I highly recommend that you watch the movie before reading the book. The movie is almost nothing like the book, they only share a title, character names, and the most general tag-line of a plot "In the near future, people are no longer able to have children...". If you read the book first the problems with the movie make it hard to enjoy.Acting:Clive is pretty good, I am assuming he was doing exactly what the director wanted (which is nothing like the character Theo).Julianne Moore's 'Julian' is a very shallow character (as directed I assume), would have been a much better performance if she had been given the role of Julian in the book.Michael Caine plays a caricature of a ridiculous hippie (again, as directed), he does it well. It has absolutely nothing to do with Jasper.Cinematography - reminded me of 28 Days Later, not better, not worse, just similar, color and angle are the main things they share.Writing - This is pure writing by committee, there are 5 writers (other than the author of the book this movie is supposedly based on). I would be inclined to guess that none of them actually read Children of Men, and what they came up with is basically framed in our current political climate and will not endure as an important work. Directing - Well, he has a writing credit and should be blamed along with them for this travesty. I am sure he is a fine director, but let someone familiar with the subject matter assist with the storytelling. **Major spoilers for the book follow, but hell, who out here actually reads books?** (they have nothing at all to do with the movie I just watched) Theo is supposed to be the anti-hero, the elitist self-serving Oxford history prof, who doesn't want the inconvenience of having old friends (Jasper and veggie wife, Jasper is another history prof, not a hippie) move into his 5-story apartment in the city, he is not the drunk/trustworthy guy. He is not poor. He is not a drunk. He is a smart-ass, who is always talking down to people.Theo's cousin is the 'Warden of England' and rules very harshly with the council. Julian's group approach Theo to bring a list of complaints to the Warden.After he takes the complaints to the Warden he goes on a very long vacation, after he returns the mid-wife shows up and tells him that Julian needs him.Julian is not Theo's wife, and Julian is the one that ends up pregnant, and white, and the baby is male. The mid-wife is black, and there is no weird religious aspect to her, in fact she like many others in the book are agnostic, if not full blown atheists.The 'fishes' main complaint is the 'suicides' that are called Quietus, where old people are drowned at sea, some forcibly (one that Theo witnesses which is why he decides to help the group). Other complaints are the treatment of criminals on the Isle of Man (lawless prison colony, think - 'Escape from New York'), forced (futile) reproductive testing on men and women, the treatment of foreign workers (nothing like the movie), and the state sponsored porn shops.The main mention of religious extremists, are of the white variety, think televangelists, there is no parade of Muslims with ak-47s in the book.When Theo was a young husband and father, he backed over his baby by accident, he wasn't wild about the baby and his wife knew it (which is why they got divorced). His wife is not a terrorist, she lives in a nice house in a nice neighborhood with her new young husband and their cats.Julian, who Theo does end up loving, is deformed (physically), the priest/father (not her husband) is epileptic. That is why their fertility was unknown, they were exempt from testing.The last generation of children are called 'Omegas', some of them rove about the countryside in gangs and kill people, but they only want to kill one person from a group, they also like to torch cars.They never pretend to be illegal immigrants, they are never in custody, Theo is never in the vicinity when a bomb goes off. The 'fish' only blow up docks where the 'suicides' would be taking place.Jasper kills his wife and commits suicide. He commits suicide by shooting himself in the head, and Theo takes the gun (only one bullet).Julian, Theo, and the Midwife never get to the water, they turn back when Julian's husband abandons them and goes to turn them in to the Warden.Julian with the help of the mid-wife gives birth to the baby in a woodshed (which is secluded). Theo, Julian and the baby are the only main characters that live, and they all live, and Theo becomes the 'Warden of England' after shooting the Warden with his one bullet.

Review title: Futuristic, bleak, depressing....but really rather good
Review_body: Wow. In a word. There is a sense of scale in this film, though set only in the U.K, that sets it apart from most films that have been released in the last few years. The futuristic London is, scarily, completely believable. The gritty dirtiness of the place led me to believe i was watching a Terry Gilliam film. The film features long takes where Clive Owen is followed around by the camera for 10 to 15 minutes at a time. This all helps towards the wow factor. Clive Owen puts in a good performance as the man who's given up hope, as does an upbeat Michael Caine. This film will keep you glued to it. Take the time out to see this wonderful film. It's shocking, depressing and awe inspiring. You won't be disappointed.

I was moved by the film in many ways.However, a couple of things in particular struck me.... the inclusion of dogs in the movie as benign companions. On the surface, it makes sense, because people who have no children would grasp onto dogs as substitutes. Still, I think there is something more here, but would like others to comment.Sheep. A clearly judeo-Christian symbol. They are shown being herded a couple of timesHorses/Cows. The scenes of dead herd animals burning.Boats. Another Christian symbol... then there is the group called "The Fish".I don't have any insight, just some observations.

Children of Men BLEW ME AWAY. Having played Half-Life 2 the world it takes place in reminded me of that game. But everything about CoM is excellent. The acting, storyline, action, music and so on. It's just a perfect movie from start to finish, and I can't wait to see it again.Clive Owen proves (yet again) that he's a brilliant actor and the same goes for Michael Caine (the rest of the cast is equally brilliant).I simply cannot recommend this movie enough. GO SEE IT. If you don't, then you are missing out on the best movie of 2006.Technically the movie is out of this world (when you see the urban war zone scenes, you will know what I mean). A couple of times I was thinking "how the hell did they do that??".

Review title: Would have been a better story
Review_body: Well, Cliwe Owen got another well-played role. But the point that I didn't like the movie that much was about the evolution and the conclusion of the story. I appreciate the way that they describe the occasion valuable and dramatic. The situation that the world can involve in this case was shown realistic and satisfied. The middle east influence in the refugees life was highly expected and you can clearly see these guys are the typical poor unwanted people to use in your movie. I wouldn't tell I like it. On the other hand, cinematography of the movie was incredible and needs respect to be shown. To sum up, in my opinion, the movie deserves a perfect six. Not more not less.

Many times in this movie, I felt like I was simply watching someone play a shooting game on xbox. If they were going for that for whatever reason, it is extremely obvious and takes away from following the story.This movie could have been done a lot better if it had a stronger plot than it did. They were on the run and then they stopped being on the run and it was over. I kept waiting for a huge plot twist and it never came. This movie could have been just one 1 hour episode for some TV show and accomplished just as much.However it was interesting to see a portrayal of the future. That part of the movie I liked, it just wasn't strong enough to carry the rest of the weak parts. Its rare to see, but this might actually be a case where if someone else wrote a sequel to this movie it could be much better than the original.

We went to see this movie with great expectations and walked out in awe of how unwatchable it was. The basic premise was interesting and the beginning showed promise, but it quickly degenerated into a dark, depressing and exceedingly violent production.The story made virtually no sense at all. It was a dark, somber, difficult to follow film which got progressively worse. The last half hour was unbelievably violent with no purpose. Clive Owen (one of our favorite actors) was wasted as was the brief appearance of Julianne Moore.Don't waste your time or money. Wait for the DVD and then don't bother to rent it.

Review title: Big names do not a good movie make
Review_body: I'm glad that this was my periodic freebie rental at my local DVD gallery, but it was still a total waste of my time.First, the premise of the movie is completely impossible. How could the human race exist for even ten minutes without children? For instance, would do all the sweatshop labor all over the world that keeps things rolling? And don't you think the population would be fairly well freaked out into a total frenzy instead of blithely going about their daily routines, going to dog races, etc?? This is like those dumb sci-fi flicks of the past where Imminent Doom is upon the planet and the populace patiently goes about their normal business while waiting for the fearless leaders to Save The Day. Give me a break! In addition, I was annoyed that the big name actors were so ill-used. Moore and Caine were little more than cameo props. And why did Julianne Moore's character have to be offed so soon? To save $ for all those "exciting" chase scenes? Ugh...I just couldn't swallow any of it and had to turn it off before it ended (just like I have to end this little review). Life is too short...I already wasted my time, and that's why I wrote this: for you!

My boyfriend and I are beginning to wonder just how corrupt the film  reviews are, after wasting a Saturday evening and £14.00 on the  unbelievably overrated film The Children of Men. The frankly ridiculous  script kills off the only credible actors (Julienne Moore and Michael  Caine) early on in the film, leaving the floundering storyline to the  mercy of Clive Owen's limited acting abilities. This film is supposed  to be a thinking person's action movie but is in fact an insult to the  intelligence of cinema goers. How many more turkeys like this are going  to slip through the net before people choose to ignore film reviews and  stop going to the cinema?

Review title: Disappointing, but to each his own!
Review_body: After seeing the trailer to the Children of men, I was at first excited to see this feature, it had looked interesting. During the months that passed, I got my hand on the Children of men novel, read it, and wasn't sure whether the movie would be good or bad. The book left me overtly disappointed.As I watched the movie, I felt, indifferent. I was not moved to tears by any of the scenes that were suppose to provide an emotional uplifting or an emotional downpour. Clive Owen although a good actor didn't really strike me as someone who I could be touched by. I did not feel a whole lot different.The movie, neither left me with any positive or anything negative. I think the positive image of hope is deplorable and it's completely cliché. Why did the girl suddenly have a child, they did not explain this and although the book itself was rather weak at the reasoning it was more or less better at trying to do so.Overall a disappointing feature and I think that the budget and the effort could have been channelled into providing something more than just entertainment, more than just an hour and a half of sitting waiting for something to happen.

Review title: Can't stop thinking about this movie
Review_body: This is not a movie that fits into the recent formula films we are seeing out of Hollywood. Nor is it the garbage that critics and award voters like but that no one can stand watching. (e.g. Babal) The less you know about this film before you see it the better. It is hard to describe; it is not a 'feel good' movie but it is a fantastic film and story. I actually found the film creepy and scary for a simple reason, it could easily happen. The film is NOT in the distant future, it does not have space ships, dinosaurs, dragons, aliens, ridiculous science, or anything remotely hard to believe. Like most good stories, especially sci-fi, the story is based on 'what if'. What if something happens, how would that something change other things? Now I loved "Reign of Fire" (also based in England), that movie is 'what if dragons are real and woke up'. Great movie but really, how likely is it that dragons live under London? The 'what if' in this movie is not only easy to believe it is more plausible than people would think. If you are a science type person this film will freak you out because it could so easily happen. Can't wait to see it again.

Review title: I wept for the Knight Errant
Review_body: This movie is a futuristic version of the old stories around the time of the Black Plague. A world cursed, the people lament, and the true Knight goes forth to save them. Like many great men, he didn't want the burden, but accepted it. I wept for the courage he showed. Never mind the political dialogue, the movie reaffirmed my faith that there will always be some who will do the right thing in the end, no matter what. The movie itself is a cinematic masterpiece. From the opening scene to the final conclusion the imagery and long camera shots brought the movie into focus even more than the actors did. Thats not to say that the actors didn't do a great job themselves. Clive Owen once again proves his brilliance as an actor, even saving Julianne Moore's rather mediocre performance. Watch the movie, watch it several times. Make sure you keep your finger on the pause button for there are many 3 - 10 frame shots that are breathtaking.

Unrealistic on the science side of things.Unrealistic on the surveillance technologies and law enforcement capabilities of 2027 (projecting current status in to the future).Great cinematography, almost a documentary at some points.Accurate on the craziness of human kind.Predicts how the world could become if we leave it to fundamentalists of any kind.Religious, political, scientific fundamentalists are poisoning our society. Describes the new dark age that awaits for us if we don't shape up.

Review_body: one of the worst movies ever made, the film should be destroyed it was horrible and gory and violent and the movie made absolutely no sense and what the hell was the deal with all the dogs. one of the most ridiculous movie's ever do not waste your money and time on it. words cannot express how horrifically horrible this movie is. what a waste it felt like it was a documentary on the iraq war and the ending was one of the worst. the movie in whole was just plain dumb 20027 the future??? noooot i could see if it was the year 40000 or something. what a terrible and depressing movie. i have to write more lines here i have nothing else to say about how sick this movie was and what a waste of money to make. terrible, terrible, terrible, sick movie i hated it

Review title: Hands Down Best Film of the Year So Far
Review_body: "Children of Men" opened here in Britain today, and I've just got back from seeing it this afternoon. It's easily best film I've seen at the cinema so far this year, and probably one of the best sf movies for a hell of a long time (maybe one of the best ever). Obviously I loved it - here's why: the depiction of Britain in the future is absolutely spot on - there are so many little references (Bexhill as a refugee camp is a terrific injoke for anyone who's ever been there - I live down the road) and locations shown to the point of decay that look and feel just right (it's now, just more so). The detail in the film is meticulous to the extreme, locations that I've walked around have been revamped and everything is completely realistic. There is no fake looking CGI in this film - it's like walking around the real world, and sucks you in completely. The camera-work is truly extraordinary - incredibly long hand held shots that follow Clive Owen through increasingly large and scarily real battle scenes (particularly a scene in a car getting ambushed and another run through a full scale battle zone are jawdroppingly good - outdoing anything in Spielberg's "War of the Worlds" or "Saving Private Ryan" - the only two films where I' ve seen anything that comes close to this). Alfonso Cuaron's best film so far. It's got the heavyweight message and performances of a great drama with the tension, excitement and spectacle of a big time action movie. Clive Owen is perfectly cast - it really is his film - everyone else (as good as they are) are just there for support. I've often found him a little wooden before - but his cynical, grizzled character here is one he was born to play. It's really knocked me for six, and I honestly can't recommend this enough - it's got the truth and integrity of an indie film with the sheer verve and emotion of great Hollywood cinema. A future classic.

Review title: One of the best directed films of all time.
Review_body: I'm an American traveling through Europe, and I saw this film in the U.K. I'd been looking forward to it ever since the trailer blew me away, and, I'm happy to say, it was even better than I expected. Cuaron directed the hell out of this film! The script is pretty decent (interesting but reasonably standard sci-fi), but Cuaron elevates it so much higher. It brings you to such emotional highs and lows, all while looking completely believable. I don't want to give anything away, but this movie affected me deeply; I felt honestly shaken after leaving the theater. Technically, the film will floor you. It contains some of the most impressive set pieces in movie history, some of them shown as a continuous shot, with no cuts. You'll never forget the experience.
Just put yourself in the place of the head character and set out. The movie will make you feel the rest of you.

While the idea of the movie may be interesting and inspiring, the movie itself does not answer any of the questions it raised. I regard this as a waste of an idea.(Spoilers start here) Instead of telling us what is the reason for this strange infertility problem, the movie shows us the quest of the protagonist, and the only pregnant girl in the world, whom he has to deliver to the strange organization called The Human Project.The movie doesn't tell us what is the reason for that infertility that struck earth. It just concentrates on the quest. And while I like the portrayal of future earth, it is apparently the only thing I liked about the movie.Oh, and the sun eclipse that you can see in the movie logo? It is not mentioned in the movie at all.Very disappointing.

I wanted to like this flick so much - but there were too many flaws. I finished with 6/10 considering the fact I wouldn't even finish a movie below 5.Acting is adequate, and indeed Owen is solid and Caine shines. No worries here.Camera was really impressive. This is the movies strongest point indeed.Story telling really laked in many cases in my opinion, well, I guess I have to "go read the book" to judge this after all.The set was quite okay, but had some cheap (="realistic" ?) feeling to it. Don't know what didn't feel right for me in detail... Kinda B-movie-esquire.Over emphasize of the guerrilla (rather war) picture was disturbing at best and annoying most of the time. Too long, too superficial.As this is a "we have a message" film, I might just point out that I got "the message" and I still would have preferred to keep Holy Mary motives out of it. Not my piece of cake for sure.Still I think that is one thing to remember: All apocalyptic dictatorship movies have this too obvious "1984", "Fahrenheit 451", "Soylent Green", "Brazil" and to a lesser extent "Planet of the apes", "Bladerunner", "12 Monkeys" references. So very limited originality.I just hope that the age of "mashups" in which we are in doesn't limit creativity all of the time.Currently it is rated at 8.0 at IMDb. This is going to change indeed, but I cannot see any "true classic" quality here.

Looking at the original cover and hearing the title it sounded like some cheesy acted action chick flick, but man I could have never been more wrong. This is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen, and I am one of the harshest film critics. The impossibility of directing some of these 5 minute long takes (the camera literally doesn't cut in many scenes) as the characters go through some of the best action sequences (and most realistic) you will EVER see. This was nothing short of a Masterpiece, and that's understating it.Owen really never had his 'role', and this was it. He plays the reluctant, dis-envisioned loner Theo who, despite his poverty and the fact that the entire world is crumbling around him, maintains his composure through constant flask drinking, gambling, and herbal remedies with his old friend Jasper. When his old liaison, Julian Moore, approaches him for an offer, he reluctantly agrees after learning of the money he is promised. Unaware of the situation he is entering himself into, he is thrown into the melee when the transport of an illegal immigrant goes horribly wrong and he is stuck trying to smuggle the last pregnant woman on earth out of the country, while being discovered, hunted, and chased by multiple terrorist groups. Meanwhile the country is in an uproar about illegals. Because of how dangerous the rest of the entire world has become most illegal immigrants are murderous and in gangs (or perceived as such), and they highly outnumber the rest of the population. The baby is a source of political motives, being that it's the last on earth, and Theo quickly realizes that besides the mother he is the only one looking out for its best interests.It becomes readily apparent that despite always being drunk, stoned and unarmed Theo becomes a quick witted, highly agile escape artist when his adrenaline kicks in. He battles through hell, alone, and for most of the movie without shoes, striving to get this woman and her baby to safety. In one of the final scenes, Theo is walled in with her in a refugee camp being invaded by multiple terrorist organizations, and scheduled to be bombed by the military. I've never had such admiration for a hero as I did watching Theo run through the streets dodging bullets and cheating death, it was one of my most favorite scenes in movie history, and it was over 7 minutes of non-cut camera action. You witness firsthand the horrors of war, as everyone around him annihilates each other. It will have you on the edge of your seat, and then falling off it. This will ALWAYS be one of, if not, my favorite movie of all time. It has set a landmark with its camera-work and cinematography. No one has yet to accomplish anything like this. It should have won multiple Oscars, no argument. To me Theo is one of the greatest heroes in movie history. Trust me, see it. Give it a half hour and the action will start and it won't stop. 12 out of 10. As far as the casting and acting, it's beyond flawless. With the camera not cutting you must choreograph everything down to the exact detail, and timing becomes a science. Owens' acting in this movie is some of the best I have EVER seen, it just exposed how amazing he was. Just watching him break down in tears was PERFECT, the spit connecting from his hands and he tried to wipe it away while breaking down in an attempt to light a cigarette, spine-tingling perfection, Art at its finest. It astonishes me that anyone could not like this movie, or even comment on the cast or the storyline or plot remaining undeveloped. The director takes you on a journey and has you perceive everything unfold. You witness a lot of what's happened by seeing headlines of old newspapers reused as wallpaper, you witness cattle being burned in circles on the countryside, you see chimneys reminiscent of Auschwitz expelling black smoke near refugee camps as they pass on the road. This is not for the Transformers or Jet Li fan boys. This is true film. It's gritty and it will pull you in. Truly remarkable.

Review title: Poor script and acting ruined a good idea.
Review_body: I looked forward to this movie after seeing the casting and watching the trailer.On watching the full movie I found it little better than a glorified television production with a rushed script,unbelievably poor action scenes and cardboard acting.On the positive side I found the sound effects first-class but the refugee camp and the subsequent attack on it beggared belief. I feel you can get away with this sort of poor production in a normal action movie but surely the subject dealt with in this movie is serious enough to deserve a much better production. Will someone please stop casting Michael Caine in these 'bit'roles as he is now only playing cameos to add to his bulging coffers.

Review title: Well acting, superb camera work and editing.
Review_body: Absolutely awesome. Well acted, written, fresh, realistic looking and beautifully shot movie. The story and events are believable -and scary. You can't help thinking is the world really going to be like this after a few decades? This film is well done from every aspect. The work with shooting all those long, long scenes is just unbelievable, it almost seems that whole film is done with authentic lightning. Especially the ambush scene in the forest, how they managed to make it look so complete? The camera's first moving around inside the vehicle, and suddenly after all the action, it kinda slides outside, settles still and we see the car driving away. Left me and my friend wondering is it only well edited or actually shot in one piece.. Oh, and Michael Caine's there too. Check it out.

After reading some reviews and seeing the movie, i felt the need to write a comment. I can not understand how every comment is either 10 or 1. How can a movie like this be one? My only guess is that people want to appear in love it or hate it. I believe that the movie is interesting by its story and by the acting but is far from being perfect. It just feels like they didn't study the details. For example In a world in the future, war everyone, no one is safe.. a car as collision detection and as no bulletproof windows. The movie gives the impression that situations like that happens everyday. just doesn't make any sense In the movie the girl says that Leo will help her because he needs money. He as a big plasma screen in his room. He works, has no car, wife or kids. Why does he need money? The group fish as incredible resources... u gives then? a little line would be nice.I believe this details are important because if u are seeing a movie and start thinking on then u are not concentrated in the movie.For that reason i cant give a 9 or a 10. I will not give 8, as i believe that a movie should always be a bit entertaining.So 7 I advise everyone to see it, as it is a movie that creates a open discussion between ppl. What happens next, what do u think of the future, how would u react if you knew u would never have kids etc etc...sorry for the mistakes, but English is not my native language

The more I watch Children of Men, the more I'm convinced it holds all the elements of a perfect film. Great plot, great cast & incredible cinematography (what else do we expect from Lubezki?). It is part drama, sci-fi romp, psychological thriller and comedy; full of chase sequences and poignant monologues, with the most realistic imaginings of dystopia I've seen on screen. Cuaron has gone on to win Oscar's, and countless other awards, however this film may be my favourite of his collection. How we are spoilt with his ingenuity and creativity. Two of the most memorable scenes are the initial chase, where in which one the main stars takes a shocking and wholly unexpected ending, and the end sequence which takes you along for every bump, near scrape and death defying moment. The one shot take almost a trademark of Lubezki, but in no way a tired one. Alongside Wally Pfister, he is at the top of the DP ladder.Truly astonishing work from cast and crew at the top of their game.

Review title: Why this movie is so great
Review_body: This movie is one of those very few and rare movies that made me get up after I watched it and just pace around saying 'Holy crap, how is that movie that good?!'. This movie made me forget that I was sitting in my desk chair watching a movie on my monitor, it made me think I was in London in 2027 when this movie takes place.This movie is about how society deals with the sudden infertility of people and the inability to make babies. Clive Owen gives an outstanding performance as Theo, the man who tries to help society get back on its feet. The camera is always with him as he goes through a couple of turbulent days and he never fails to impress. I didn't see an actor on a sound stage in front of a crew; I saw a person struggling to deal with the cards he was dealt, or Theo. Julianne Moore was also great in this movie. She helped to elevate the parts of the movie that she was in. Her chemistry with Clive Owen made their relationship believable and not forced in any way. Michael Caine did exceptionally as a hippie, which I wasn't really sure if he could pull it off. Chiwetel Ejiofor also managed to pull off his role as a very complex character in his limited screen time. Even Clare-Hope Ashitey really embodied her character; as someone who was in a place she didn't belong with something that didn't belong The whole cast meshed well and made this feel like an actual place instead of some far-reaching idea.The plot of this movie is unique except it still seems very realistic. Throughout this movie I found myself asking if this could possibly happen in the future. The answer is yes. This movie seems like it could happen down the road in 20 years and all the things that happen with infertility make sense. All the decisions by the characters are logical and don't seem forced or stupid. Yet it still makes you wonder what is going to happen next as that unpredictability drives the movie forward. This isn't a movie where halfway through you can tell how it is going to end. You don't know who is going to die and who is going to live. Its structure is complex enough you fully enthralled with it but it doesn't lose you.The script of this movie is phenomenal. The dialogue seems lifelike and not wooden. Some of the things that are said are things I would say and the things that I wouldn't say are things that I want to say in the future. It really makes the characters more believable as actual human beings. The writers knew when to insert certain parts of light-heartedness to really tie the plot together or help with a big event. Nothing in this movie was left untouched, as everything tied together.This movie is one of the best looking films I have ever seen. There are at least three shots that are continuous takes of 3 minutes or more. The camera is an actor in this movie, and it would win an Academy Award for it. At4 points in this movie I had to stop and think to myself about how great this movie looked. The way the camera effortlessly follows the actors makes you a part of this world. It has one of the best car chase scenes I have ever seen and some of the most wonderful scenes of all time.The direction was astounding. Everything was precisely planned and everything made sense. It was like watching Picasso paint a picture. The way Cuaron was able to weave this movie together is inspiring. He made this movie real.You may think that I am over hyping this movie. I am not. I really cannot put into words how beautiful and wonderful every aspect of this movie is. I had absolutely zero complaints. This is one of the few that exceeds already high expectations and really helps you understand the concept of how great a film can be.100/100 A+

Just saw "Children of Men" yesterday. I have heard very praised words about it, so my expectations was relatively high. It starts well. Then after 15-20 minutes I sit more and more waiting the story to unfold. Was is behind (the plot) and who are these people (the main characters)? As the minutes passing by we get almost nothing really to know about them. The lesser characters is, friendly spoken, sketchy The story stay throughout very thin and untrustworthy - had the makers not the slightest knowledge of human psychology? Both concerning the character's playing and reactions as well as the viewers? Where is the suspense for example? A thriller? A horror movie? Nope - it getting more and more boring as time passes and the involvement in the characters are almost zero. Sad, because it could have been an interesting movie if the screenplay has been much better and the characters given more to work with. An artistic movie? The cinematography works but that's it.A political movie? I am nor member of a sect or a special political party looking thru special colored glasses. I am a viewer who use eyes, ears, senses, logic as well as emotions (not much of emotional stimulation in this empty going movie though). You need to tell some story to get the audience interested. And a story can be told in many ways - but need to be there! The whole "plot" appears both very illogical and poorly explained. The worst thing is - until the end - still hoping for some explanation or revelation of just something. Nope. A decent ending, a conclusion and alike could have saved something in this movie - but no. I understand a certain hype had been around this actually under average movie - but the movie makers need their money back. I don't see any deeper philosophical or many thoughtful levels for the the "Mensa- peoples". The story is so very straight and poorly told and "drowning" in its own often noisy/hysterical surroundings. Humor is lacking - the intended jokes fail and the fun episodes are not intended (the escape in a jump-start-trying car!). The worst is when you see something and have a feeling of this could have been good but the audience/viewers are somewhat neglected in this process, like in "Inception", another over-hyped movie. Some like it, fine - but if it was a book as told in the movie it would be even more boring..

Review title: This movie remains relevant to this day.
Review_body: This is probably one of my favorite movies of all time. I have watched it countless times, and throughout the years, I am constantly reminded of it by current events. From the war in the middle east, to syrian refugee crisis, border camps in the us, and now covid, this film just continues to be relevant to this day.It is masterfully shot and directed. The cinematography is amazing, and the viewer is immersed in an incredibly realistic depiction of the best and worst humanity has to offer when faced with hardship\. Everything is spot on, and I expect this movie to continue to be relevant and we will be reminded of it again in future events to come.If you have not seen it yet, I highly recommend that you do. It is a story about hope and despair, faith and chance, humanity and inhumanity, with incredible ambient world-building and it somehow manages to to be timeless.
