Review title: It was my favorite movie of 2006, but it there were some problems.
Review_body: First off before I go any further, I want to say that this, along with The Departed was a movie that blew me away on so many levels. It had by far the best cinematography I've seen, and the acting I felt actually improved as the film progressed.But a common theme on this board right now seems to be that if you dare explore the possibility that Cuarón made a few errors in judgement by leaving out key details, then you are not capable of "appreciating" the film. This just isn't true.I'm 100% fine with the open ending, where you don't know what the Human Project is all about, and what will happen to the world once Key is aboard the boat. The children laughing at the very end gave the impression of a positive outcome but certainly guaranteed nothing. This is the best example of what should have been undisclosed.However, why is it totally unacceptable to want to know more about the plot itself? I didn't necessarily need to know exactly why women were infertile, but I think if Cuarón had led us a little more towards some sort of reason other than a few suggestions made by Jasper in the beginning, then I would have been much more comfortable through out the film. I didn't NEED these details, but when you are watching a film about women being infertile, you do expect at some point for the director to address why, seeing as it was the basis for the problem the world was enduring.The problem wasn't that I didn't know, but rather I was waiting for an answer during the movie and it never came (which took away from the watching experience itself). All in all I felt that the leaving the idea of what was to become of planet Earth and the human race a secret was brilliant and thought provoking, but also felt that the basis of why the events were actually occurring needed more explanation. Again, not necessarily a definitive answer, but more about the worlds' explanation of "why it was happening." Still, Unbelievable good movie. I've seen it twice in the theatres this week... something I haven't done in God knows how long. 9/10 for me.

Brilliant film, I absolutely loved it but I was slightly let down by the ending. I felt that it was left hanging too much and I wanted to know more. The use of camera shots throughout the film was excellent as there was a lot of moving about with the characters. It was extremely emotional, especially when certain characters died. Fairly scary to think about because the human race doesn't seem so far off what is portrayed in the film. This is what makes it seem so realistic. The acting was fantastic, Clive Owen played the part extremely well and Julianne Moore, although only in it for about 15 minutes, was phenomenal. The violent scenes reminded me of two things. 1. World War II with concentration camp-like settings 2. The war in Iraq with the constant fighting in the streets These aspects truly brought to life the realistic side of the film and showed quite accurately what would happen to the human race if an epidemic as serious as this were to happen. Overall i thought the production was fantastic and although the ending was a bit shaky, it definitely did not spoil it for me.

From a 'cinematic' standpoint, this is an extremely well-crafted movie. It's very intense, and it has some very heart-wrenching moments (the Michael Caine character's last scene, for example). But after ninety or so minutes of torturing the audience, the movie just ends. And after very effectively promoting for that ninety or so minutes the idea that the human race is just a brutal mob, why am I supposed to care that women have stopped having babies? Unfortunately, this movie is ultimately just a macho fantasy, even to the title: "Children of MEN(?)". Babies are beautiful, no doubt about that, but in our actual real world where every single problem the planet faces today - social, political, environmental - can be traced directly to overpopulation, do we really need a movie whose subliminal message is "a baby will fix everything"?

... and it's being buried by Universal. If there's any justice, a grassroots groundswell will bring it to people's attention. Literally the best film I've seen in several years. The performances are tremendous, and the layers - entertainment, art, action-suspense flick, futuristic thriller, social and spiritual commentary, subtle religious referencing-cum-subverting - are so many and so rich that you shake your head at the level of craft involved. Cuaron is, for my money, the most gifted of the three very talented Mexican filmmakers working prominently this holiday season. His is the most mature sensibility, the most subtle and accomplished; the ease with which he does so many things at the same time so effortlessly in this movie will take your breath away. Never clichéd, always surprising, and yet each choice is so perfect you can't imagine it having been done differently. A classic - not "instant," because people are discovering it slowly, but a true, true classic.

Review title: Riveting and Powerful Movie ¡Gracias, Alfonso Cuarón!
Review_body: My son dragged the whole family to see this movie as his holiday present to all of us. I was eager to see another movie by Alfonso - I really liked "Y tu mamá también" and how his camera shots captured the live, syncopated rhythm of timing better than any other director I had seen. He doesn't overuse closeups like most American movies and treats the environment as an actor in his scenes. I sat down to watch this movie and I was engaged, enthralled, entertained thoroughly for every minute of the film! "Children of Men" is ONE OF THE BEST movies I have seen - EVER! No spoilers but this movie contains what I believe is the most powerful scene I've ever watched - it was extremely emotional and I was certainly game for all the punches it threw. Clive Owens is certainly a good vehicle for drawing the viewer into a very first-person experience. While one might cite a distraction in the "overuse" of current news buzz the fabric held firm and the film was woven so well together that I really don't see fault.I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a totally new, invigorating and fresh experience in movies apart from the boring Hollywood mainstream.

Review_body: I'll keep this review brief, since most are becoming long-winded diatribes on the state of cinema.I went in to this movie with no expectations other than it looked good in the previews I had seen and I really enjoy most of Clive Owen's performances. Review title: Good entertainment, but another great unfulfilled idea
Review_body: First I have to say that I liked the movie, had an overall good feeling when I left the cinema. But it was not the same feeling when I first walked in, expecting something more.The idea of a near future where something like global infertility has effected everyone with out of control chaos and forced order in society appeals as a good main story, too bad it is only a background one here. This movie is more about hope, good vs evil, redemption, and maybe a little love. We also see that the chaos in the setting of the story has its roots in the issues we have to today. Issues like terrorism, immigration, homeland security, dirty politics and many others. Unfortunately, Hollywood prevails, and even though i have not read the novel, i doubt the movie is a close adaptation, there is forced added-in humor all around, sometimes unexplained things and extraordinary feats, and useless detours that felt out of place.(I am talking about the urban firefights near the end, that were visually very well done, but did fit-in for this movie)I would of like to see more of the world's state and how society lived, especially in other countries. So if you think this "Children of Men" is the new "1984" your wrong(sadly)If you are just looking for a "better" Saturday night film this is it, its thought provoking, good acting, entertaining and visually spectacular. A 8 out of 10 for me because i never forget it could of been made better.

It's not easy for a director to treat with a futuristic and science-fiction script with the elegance and firmness that Cuarón achieves. Although the first half of the film is quite pretentious - it looks like a typical American blockbuster -, the rest of the film is told with such a frenetic tempo, the one who keeps the viewer always watchful. Definitely, this is a must-view film: mystery, violence,... Clive Owen becomes the central axis of the film along with the pregnant girl. They will be the inseparable couple. Another thing that really amazed me was the facility to kill so many important - or, at least, they seem important - characters. This makes the film work at a high speed - the viewer feels like he can't control the rhythm of the script and of what's he's watching. Finally, I want to highlight the final battle sequence.

So, I just returned from watching 'Children of Men' and thought I'd have a go at the review. Over all, I'd say it was interesting and entertaining if ultimately preachy. There were moments of humor, and moments of mind-boggling confusion, and of course, lots of explosions to keep your heart pounding.'Children of Men' follows the story of a world thrown into chaos by 18 years of world-wide infertility. At last, a child is born to an unknown black refugee from Fuji, and it the job of Clive Owen to keep her safe and keep the Messiah of the modern world alive.If you like movies about hope for the world, or you just like lots of explosions, see this film. If you're a cynic, I'd recommend not. You'll just be disappointed.

Often, when discussing dystopian or post-apocalyptic films, the one topic that comes to mind is in fact the weather of Britain. This is because our grey skies or wet, spitting rain is the backdrop for most of the truly depressing dystopic films. What I mean by this is that I believe there are separate genres within the dystopian genres, and the boundaries of these genres are often the weather. Having bright sunny skies in a dull, gritty film just does not work. So that is why all the young adult films (The Hunger Games, Divergent etc) , which often share the same ideas like class disparity in society found in the genre , yet are not depressing enough to be thought of as dystopian, are all filmed and set in America. However, the films which are about people working under a vicious government who can be called oppressive simply by having policies which can be related with seeping the colour out of everyday life, Most of the time happen to be British films (Brazil, 1984, even V for Vendetta was set in Britain). But the best possible example is Children of Men, an adaptation of the novel of the same name, whose opening sequence consists of the central protagonist- a man by the name of Theo Faron (played by Clive Owen), finding out in a café that the youngest person in the world was killed when he refused to sign an autograph. When he exits, the Café is blown up by a terrorist in one of the most realistic explosions I have ever seen. But Theo does not go in to look around, he crouches back into the corner in a panic- the Hunger Games this is not. This opening sequence sets the tone of the film perfectly, and the overall central idea; what if, in the future, humans lost the ability to reproduce? As a result, the film suggests that the rest of the world has collapsed economically, and only Britain is left, and has walled itself up like a prison, increasing immigration policies to the highest extremities. This is an amazing setup, and one the filmmakers have respected. When most dystopian films are post-apocalyptic, this one is set during the apocalypse. But it is a long, drawn out one, which gives the people lots of time to think about and dread the upcoming destruction of humanity. So after the opening sequence, we see Theo kidnapped by a terrorist group named the Fishes, led by his ex-wife Julian (played by Julianne Moore). He is tasked with escorting a young immigrant named Kee (played by Clare-Hope-Ashley) across the country to the east coast. The reason why she needs to be taken there is because of one simple fact: she is pregnant. And if she is revealed to the public, the government will simply kill her and replace her with another British woman. And so along the way we are personally taken on a tour of the worst that Britain has to offer, including graffiti stained London, a corrupt activist headquarters, and even Bexhill, reinvented as a nightmare, bombed-out, immigrant prison town which could have come out of any war film. This is the greatest strength of the film- the atmosphere. This is the most realistic take on the genre ever made hands-down. If this was in the hands of another set of action filmmakers- they would want beautifully choreographed battles. However, the director Alfonso Cuarón, who also directed the film Gravity, knows that this is the opposite of what the original author P.D. James would have wanted, and instead encourages the cast to trip over, as it would make the panic look more realistic. Said cast, by the way, are wonderful. Clive Owen really brings the misery and depression needed to Theo, While Julianne Moore is solid as Julian. Michael Caine, meanwhile, brings some much needed humanity and heart to the film as Theo's old friend Jasper. The direction from Alfonso is also really good, and the cinematography is amazing, which comes from Oscar-winner Emmanuel Lubezki. But the film is not perfect, it begins to get repetitive near the end of the second act, and the character of Syd, Jaspers potentially psychopathic, corrupt-guard friend is so out of place its actually rather irritating when he was clearly designed to be comical. The biblical symbolism, meanwhile, is so blatant that it makes the viewer wonder if the entire premise existed to make a certain scene (soldiers even make religious gestures at points). However, the last 20 minutes more than makes up for it, as we are treated to one continuous long shot, as Theo struggles around in a poverty ridden building amidst a bloody battle rages around him, to find Kee. It's a beautifully realised sequence that leaves the audience on the edge of their seat with suspense, to see if he can find her and make it out alive. The ending might seem abrupt but leaves the viewer on a sentimental note, as the laughter of children plagues the credits. It makes you realise that while critics sneer at films containing children, the film makes you wonder at how we might ever get on in life without them.

If there is one thing that I can say about this film it is that I earnestly want all the people that I love to go and watch it. There was not a moment during the screening that I was not won over by its visual narrative brilliance. Alfonso Cuarón manages to create a completely believable landscape of ecological and cultural devastation that starkly mirrors the darkest aspects of our own age. Like the best Dostoevsky novels, the atmosphere of absolute despair through which the characters move is pierced by only the faintest and most fragile hope; a hope that is not fulfilled until the very last frame of the picture. And like the truest tragedy, the catharsis experienced by the characters is shared by the audience. Smart and challenging, this is worth it.

Review title: A movie I would not recommend that is, for the most part, fairly well made
Review_body: Many great Science Fiction works have problems of today's society couched in issues of the future. The original Star Trek series did this successfully numerous times, this movie does not.The directory, Alfonso Cuaron, has used this movie purely as a vehicle to push his personal political agenda. The premise of this movie borrows heavily from Margaret Atwood's the Handmaiden's Tale. Children of Men is set in England 20 years in the future, 18 years after all women are infertile and unable to conceive children. In this bleak future, society begins to collapse and wars, terrorist groups, and apocalyptic religious cults are ubiquitous. In this futurist England, the government has used the strife caused by women's infertility to turn the country into a police state. From what I can determine, the main goal of this police state, which the director hammers home, time, and time again throughout the entire movie, is to stop illegal immigration. Meaning the British government has police squads that round up illegal immigrants, places them in internment camps that resemble Manhattan in Escape from New York, and I assume eventually deports them. However, the main plot is suppose to be about a lone girl that somehow managed to conceive a baby, getting her to a safe place to raise her child, and hopefully finding out why she can conceive children.Such a plot gives ample means to deliver a compelling story. For example, maybe the government plans to use the girl to repopulate the earth through selective breeding, or some other means. However, Cuaron chose a different path.The movie has many plot holes and does not fully explain why they must get this girl to safety and he even contradicts himself regarding people's supposed reactions and actual reactions to this girl. Furthermore, throughout the entire movie he mottles the plot with his pro-illegal immigrant political message. However, the main question that comes mind is that if women have not been able to conceive children for 20 years, certainly the population of every country would start to decrease. So, why would the government be so concerned with stopping illegal immigration? If the population decreases the government's tax base would decrease, to combat this they would need to attract immigrants. Huhh, I guess the director did not think that far ahead.Anyway, what I took away from this movie is that Alfonso Cuaron being Mexican is unhappy with the US's illegal immigration policy that affects so many of his countrymen, which is not suppose to be the premise of this movie.

I really wasn't sure what to expect going into this film. I was expecting a rather intellectual film with very little action. Well, the film delivered on the intellectual front and it also delivered on the spectacle. The action scenes were tense and emotional at times, visceral in a way that hasn't been seen since Blackhawk Down.The film starts sedately enough in the near future, far enough for newspapers and advert signs to all be electronic, but not far enough for things to look much different. It quickly becomes obvious, through the use of TV news reals, that the youngest person in the world is an 18 year old Argentinian and that no other children have been born since him. As you watch the film you get a sense that something is missing, not quite right, until you realise that there are no children in the film. That would explain why there are so many animals, from dogs to chickens to pigs etc. These are presumably there to replace the children that people long for but are unable to have.From a rather slow start the film slowly winds up the tension and suddenly changes from a Gattica type film to something more akin to The Fugitive. The acting is first rate, with some very well known British actors and actresses putting in some terrific performances. Clive Owen plays the party superbly, with an understated style that makes his character at once more believable and more sympathetic.In the end, the story is a rather simple one, but it is expertly directed and told with sense that it both European and Hispanic - definitely not the usual Hollywood fare. I am not surprised that many Americans did not get the film or appreciate it - no sex, one-liners or pointless violence. It is roller-coaster of a film that surprises at every turn and in the end leaves you wanting more.My rating, 9 out of ten.

i just saw this film last night and i can't stop thinking about it. definitely one of the best movies i've seen in the past couple of years. what blows my mind is how there's been almost no marketing for this movie when not only is it superbly written, acted and directed but has huge blockbuster potential. the action sequences are amazing. maybe it's universal's marketing strategy to have the least impressive box office for their most promising picture to ensure some sort of cult status. that's the only plausible thing i can deduce from their failure to promote this movie. prove them wrong. if you don't like it i'll give you your money back.

Director Alfonso Cuarón has crafted a solid body of work over the past three decades, but "Children of Men" is his uncontested masterpiece. I'm surely not alone in considering it among the greatest films ever made.Imagine jaw-dropping spectacle, but presented in a peculiarly British way that never says, "See how amazing I am?"; imagine hyper-intelligent oblique dialogue that suggests universes of hurt and hope behind the weary eyes of tortured but resolute survivors; imagine shock and childlike wonder in equal part (at the most unexpected times and places), and you'll have an idea of the sublime level at which "Children" operates.This is a work of unbridled genius, and one can only wonder at the thousands of hours of work that went into making it seem so seamless and effortless. The massive set-pieces stun and amaze, but it's the smallest and most human of touches that disarm us.Consider the fantastically minimalist audio track with which the credits roll-- Cuarón is most interested in reminding us about what we truly value, and the tragic possibility of taking it for granted.

Children of Men creates a chaotic world uncomfortably similar to the one we live in right now. It gives a palpable story of a society who has experienced no births in eighteen years. However, a new baby is born and Theo has to face a lot of trouble just to keep him safe. The story is interesting from beginning to end. The way it emotionally connects you with Theo throughout all his struggles to save Kee and her baby is amazing. You get to really feel what these characters are experiencing, you get to cry with them, feel frustrated with them, have moments of happiness like they did Through this, the message that the director wants to transmit is successfully delivered. It gives a powerful social and political message. It opens our eyes to show us that we are not very far from a dystopia like that one. With unexpected plot twists and deep messages, this movie is not only a fun movie to watch, but one that everyone should watch to understand more about modern society.

Throughout the movie you could watch that the people didn't have a hope of a change or of a difference and when the movie ended, the baby was the miracle and the hope that people were not expecting which you could notice how the people were surprised by it, and how they acted when they saw the baby. You can relate today's society with the movie by that, because people is losing their identity and hope and are just following the crowd instead of being like Theo and risking his life or taking action and not letting their fear win. (participating on a difference) Sometimes we need to put our hope or our trust in other people, because we don't really know if we are going to keep leaving or sometimes we just need help. Everything will matter at the end. For example with Juliana, when she died, she told the woman to only trust Theo, and so she did. At the beginning it was difficult for her because she believed what the others said which at the end were saying the opposite of what Juliana was telling them to do. Also, sometimes we need to risk our lives for the people we care or love in order for them to be safe for example the old man with Theo and the lady's guardian that was in the bus and an official took her and killed her in order for them to continue their mission and to save the world.

I have just watched this movie on DVD with some friends and we were all simply dismayed. We had read some really good reviews and are left to feel that the movie producers must have written them all. The plot is poorly developed, leaving gaping holes in continuity and nothing but questions about who?, what? why? and how? Michael Caine's character is the most memorable but his relationship with Theo is never really explained. Indeed no relationships are either explained or explored. There is little or no character development and the viewer is left to fumble through the movie, avoiding sporadic and meaningless violence, without knowing why. Some elements of this movie, particularly the use of animals and an apparent footwear fetish, add nothing to the movie except further confusion. To add insult to injury, there is no outcome. At the end of 2 hours of pure bewilderment we are left with no better understanding of what we have just watched. I am dismayed by the number of positive reviews. The movie was poorly acted for the most part, gratuitously depressing throughout and failed to explain its premise. It reminds me of a TV segment I saw some time ago which illustrated the stupidity of so called art lovers who paid ridiculous sums of money for painting done by elephants. A bunch of supercilious nitwits standing in a gallery discussing the meaning and brilliance of randomly splattered paint from brushes wielded by an elephant's trunk. I think the elephants could have made a better movie than this. If you are offered the chance to see this movie - don't.

I waited a long time to see this movie as i missed it in the cinema. when i eventually saw it, i have to say it was the worst most poorly acted least thought through film i have ever seen. The premise of the film is excellent an Orwellian 1984 society but the actual follow through is rot of the highest order. the script is poor and full of clichés. the actors are wooden and the whole story is just not there. you feel no sympathy or empathy towards any of the characters and to be honest i just couldn't wait until this film ended. i was left very disappointed by a film i had very high hopes for. i would go so far as to say avoid at all costs

I get the basic plot of the movie. However, the movie continually introduces people, places, things, activities with no explanation for them. Why has the infertile world resulted to rounding up immigrants and deporting them? It seems if the entire world was in a state of declining population deporting immigrants would be counterproductive. The movie just isn't very logical. There are a lot of hints about various items throughout the movie but don't expect any clear explanation. The hero Theo gets the pregnant Kee to her destination of the ship "Tomorrow" so the "Human Project" can research why Kee is fertile. Presumably, the "Human Project" restores human fertility through this research because during the credits there are children laughing. Honestly, that's about all you need to know. Don't waste 2 hrs!

Review title: It's not pretty but it tells the truth!
Review_body: This movie shows what homeland security and other present political directions will lead us to, with or without children.The thread and absurdity of a modern police state is depicted in a very realistic and probable way by showing the cruelty and stubbornness of the system and contrasting it with the helplessness and purity of a naked human life. The aesthetics of the film have a hyper-real "right there, right now" feel to it, due to long shots in "action" sequences, a very tense screenplay and effective cinematography. Also big credit to the art department for creating totally believable sets that also tell a part of the story, shifting our everyday environment into a careless future with people only worrying about themselves.

Review title: brilliant film - from start to finish!
Review_body: I use IMDb a lot and always check out reviews to films - This is my first review as the film was that good I have to write something about it.I went to the cinema with high expectations, and usually i am let down, i am pleased to say this time was not one of them. This movie blew me away and went above my expectations, they detail in this film is awesome - every single scene has been thought about.Clive Owen is one of my favourite actors at the moment and in this he really showed how great he can be, i don't think anybody would be let down by his performance.I loved the futuristic england which has been portrayed in this film, and the battle/war scenes have been shot in a way which really makes you feel in the thick of it.I don't want to spoil the film but towards the end of the film i actually got goose bumps it really churned up my emotions! brilliant from start to finish i cant imagine anybody now liking this.Fantastic job, i can see this being a cult classic scifi in a few years, go watch it!

I saw this film two evenings ago, and was fully blown away. Not only was Children of Men the intelligent, "thinky" movie I was expecting, it was also a balls-to-the-wall action thriller of the highest.It is quite easily Clive Owen's best performance to date, casting him as the truly believable Theo, playing opposite Clare Ashitey's Kee for a large portion of the film. The chemistry between the two is unexpected, but creates a truly brilliant sense of camaraderie in their race to "save mankind" (sort of...) Michael Caine deftly brings us Jasper, Theo's pot smoking ally, and Julianne Moore's Julian was, while surprisingly short-lived, a joy to watch. Chiwetel Ejiofor is equally good in his deeply sinister role as Luke.Now, having dispensed with the usual gushy stuff about actors, I feel I should extol the pure genius of Alfonso Cuarón. This man is actually a genius. Properly. Alongside Mike Leigh's 1993 indie-classic "Naked", this is the most expertly put together movie I have ever seen. Every single shot screams "this was really, really thought about!", and the action scenes are fantastic. There's a sequence towards the end of the film, and i'm pretty certain there was around 10 minutes of the film taken in a single, hand held shot. It felt oddly like i was playing Call of Duty, and following Clive Owen around. I felt truly overjoyed that someone was doing hand-held filming properly: while it retains the pace and energy an audience is looking for, none of the film's clarity or meaning was lost, unlike so many other action films of late (need I mention the truly dire camera work in Miami Vice?) I can't express truly how brilliant this film is; all I can say is GO AND SEE IT! NOW!

Did anyone notice that despite the fact that Theo is at odds with almost everyone he encounters, as well as the fact that he also has multiple times to access a gun, that he never actually picks one up, let alone shoot at anyone? The only time he uses force is when Syd is shooting at him and he uses the most blunt object he can find (a car battery). Just thought that it showed a decidedly anti-war stance as far as the main character went. Also, the most powerful weapon in the movie is actually Kee's Baby, in the scene where she carries her through a war-zone and everyone stops shooting. I felt that the point of this was that we are oblivious to the fact that so many young people are dying as the result of war in the world. Could it be that Cuaron believes that the most powerful weapon we have is our ability to not pick up a weapon? i donno...just a thought.

Review title: Gruesome and far too extremist views
Review_body: I went in with a view that this might be a really thought provoking film. I came out mortified for want of a better word.Having relatives from another country (also historically political prisoners of war) I was utterly devastated to see how they had portrayed things. I felt that it was a very dismal way to portray people and the very first scene at the coffee house seemed to try and show an almost 'Untouchables' level of shock and failed to deliver.I always find these kind of films degrade and fail to portray the horrors of peoples torture and I was completely against the age rating. I would expect any fifteen year old to come home and want to hide in their room petrified, especially if they had any foreign roots in them. I cannot agree with the rating if anything else. There should be more warnings! They probably could have skipped out the premise of last child/first child and just gone for 'get the hell out of here' style guns and running. The premise was completely detracted by the high level of guns, gratuitous violence, blood and guts.All in all completely angered and unimpressed.

Review title: A good movie that could have been great.
Review_body: My biggest beef with "Children of Men" is that it strays so wildly from P.D. James' book - not even necessarily in plot line or character qualities (though it does do that) but thematically and morally. The book is quite explicitly (and implicitly) Christian in its narrative arc and in the protagonist's crisis of conscience and evolution. The creators of the film appear to have deliberately omitted this crucial underpinning of the novel, only making a shallow nod to it in the midwife's loopy pastiche of new-age spirituality. I found the midwife incredibly irritating in the movie, incidentally, whereas I didn't in the book. Luke is a completely different character in the movie than he is in the book - and I mean COMPLETELY different. Unrecognizable. I know, it's an adaption of the book, and a facsimile shouldn't be expected... but I resent the almost complete excoriation of what I believe to be the author's intent in telling a redemptive story based in Christianity. To me, this is not really an adaptation of the book but an entirely different story with a similar premise. Stylistically, it is incredibly well done, the acting is fabulous, Clive Owen is brilliant, and there are some beautiful scenes (Theo escorting Kee out of the crumbling building comes to mind). But, having read the book, the film rang shallow overall to me. Also, a mild peeve: I get that bad guys use rough language. That's realistic. But the f-word as noun, verb and adjective in the same sentence, over and over and over? Incredibly annoying.

Review title: An amazingly real and stark view of the future
Review_body: Apart from one scene of dodgy acting, and some continuity problems, this film completely blew me away. The scene in the refugee camp when they are fleeing the fish is just incredible, even when the blood splatters on the lens. I had no idea what this film was about before I watched it, which made it all the more amazing (I thought it was about Bosnia from the trailers!). Clive Owen is very well cast. At one point, he puts on a pair of flip flops, which you can then hear throughout the rest of the movie. It was this attention to detail which also stood out. The acting is excellent and the direction is superb. And the special effects are awesome. Really really good stuff!

I felt compelled to register to IMDb to review this movie.I have used this site many times for reference and recommendations and have found it very useful.NEVER, have I been more disappointed and utterly confused regarding the many positive reviews of this absolute steaming pile of manure..At no point did I feel engaged with the film, the characters or the "story".There is no explanation or background for the totally unbelievable situation the characters find themselves in, there is no development of any sort of story and the ending is terrible.I can easily suspend my disbelief when I am taken into and feel involved with a film but this movie for me was lacking in virtually every respect.Caine was OK, but no wonder he wanted to be shot way before the dismal and uninspiring ending.

Review title: Great movie with some major problems
Review_body: Well its a good movie have a new plot and all but they get it going so sadly.First of all. How come England is saved from all problems when the rest of the world is in huge problems? England should have it share of problems as well but we newer really see any problems besides some minor problems with immigrants (that England could easily avoid if they didn't have any ship or plane arriving in England.The plot seems alright at first but there are some problems. First of all why is it everyone seems to be interested in claiming the baby? what is it they could get from claiming the baby after what the movie tells nothing.The last fight in the town where the place where the movie lost me. Its way to "big" for just some small problems with fugitives that think they should change the world and way to unrealistic to really tell the story more like "how can we get a lot of action into this plot" stile of thinking which isn't what this movie is about

Review title: A lovely film with some dark bits.
Review_body: I came to this film after recording everything I could over Xmas that I hadn't seen but had a reputation. Michael Caine is superb in this. Somewhere between the mad scientist in Independence Day and Cheech Marin. Love him not just because we went to the same school but also because he is so damned natural. I've never been sure about Clive Owen but he is totally real in this. The other players including Ms Moore are with the programme and the scenery is dark South London plus West Sussex doubling for Surrey (guess). I won't put spoilers here as I had seen none before I saw this. It comes under Sci Fi as set in the future but it tries effectively to project a world only 20 years ahead and is believable, no lasers, no space ships, no time travel, it portrays a violent world but one not unbelievable which adds to the effect which may be good or bad. It is all the more topical for the 10 years since it was filmed. Either way it was the best film I've seen in a while and I'm pleased to have discovered a gem I missed at the time. Very English. A great watch.

Review title: this movie should have been at least nominated for Oscar!!!!
Review_body: OK listen when i first saw the trailer i thought it would be a crappy movie. but when i actually saw it it shocked me. this movie should be nominated for best picture let me tell you why. because this movie was created an original idea. for example the scene were Owen and the woman and her daughter come out of the building and all of the sudden the fighting stops! ya that scene it was fantastic i don't think even Babel chould beat that. i think that children of men should win the best picture but not the best director why? cause Babel should win that one because the director of babel change the setting so beautifully and it wasn't the edditing it was how he directed the scenes it was beautiful!!!!!!! now that i think about it, children of men is going to be nominated for the CANN film festival and cann is 10x better than Oscars and golden globes. (sry for my grammar and spelling)

Review title: Intense as hell, maybe even an instant classic
Review_body: This movie is great. That could've been the review by itself because it pretty much says it all. This movie starts off really strong and you are instantly dropped in the middle of the mayhem.The hand-held camera was a great idea and it almost felt like you as the spectator was following Theo behind him trying to get to safety. Here I must respond to the reviewer above/below me. I think they did cut the hand-held together to make it look like it was one shot. It would've simply be TOO hard to shoot it as an actual one shot.I must say that the story is amazing, not unique but a super force government that checks up on everything is always strong. The infertility was just a great idea to make this movie stand out! This movie is the kind of movie that will have a sequel, but instead of a progression of the story it should show the same time line from a different perspective. There are so many different parties involved it and the story is that intense, it would help (and work!!!) to show the same thing through the eyes of a different party.All in all this movie is an instant classic.

children of men is a fantastic movie that gives a great message about humanity and what might happen in our society in the future.Alfonso cuaron made a world in 2027 without futuristic elements or flying cars but making a realistic world which is all the better for it.This movie was directed so beautifully that it didn't just want the audience member to focus to the foreground(which almost every movie wants to do) but to focus on the background.The acting of this movie is terrific all around and the cinematography is beautiful.One thing that impressed me so much also was a lot of scenes were only on one shot take.This was handled amazingly because some scenes that were really intense and suspenseful worked because it felt real and authentic.I believe that this movie within the next decade probably is gonna be considered a classic piece of science fiction cinema.One of my all-time favorites

Review title: visionary portrayal of what could be
Review_body: Children of Men is a surprising, vital and fascinating movie portraying a future in which immigrant-phobia becomes malignant. Without reviewing the story here, the script is an extraordinarily timely one, taking to the extreme a possible scenario resulting from extreme "Homeland Security", and lack of understanding that immigrants are people too, something that is already happening here, and abroad. I particularly liked the allusion to the birth of Jesus with the concept that it was an immigrant baby that was the savior of the future of mankind, not to mention that the movie came out Christmas weekend . The scenes are stark, brutal and terrifying because of their realistic possibility. Of the actors, Clive Owen is spectacular as he goes from an apathetic man, having lost his child, and all hope, wandering aimlessly through the gray and crumbling city, to a man who cares desperately, for the new mother, the baby, and hope of a future. Michael Caine is marvelous as the quirky ex-hippie friend of Theo (Clive), and the actor who plays Sid is wonderful as well. Julianne Moore has a very small part in this movie...she didn't do much except play that pure good person she always plays. But, the character's early death in the movie made real the impact her death had on Theos' despair, and really added to the sadness of the movie. A wonderful script!!

Review title: Surreal vision of the future...almost disturbing
Review_body: I can't think of anything wrong with that movie, especially 24 hours after I saw it. I had time to think about it, understand it and realizing it.The director is doing a wonderful job with the actors and numerous supernumerary playing their part in the movie. Clive Owen is the perfect guy for this role. Couldn't find a better actor with his roughed look to play Faron. Too bad Julianne Moore dies too soon but her presence was enough to help us understand the whole concept of the story. And all the other ones? They were playing natural, almost too natural as if they were really living this story themselves. Dirty, sad and mad people hanging around hopeless.Special effects? Yes but it was mostly to create an "ambiance" of darkness, hopelessness, dirtiness by keeping the image dark and dirty. Not much on the fact that it was held in 2027.Some great moments especially when the most important human in the movie is seeing by the people. It's a "must-see" if you want your brain filled with dark and at the same time hopeful and optimistic emotions that will keep you busy pondering for a while....

If anybody has watched a Cuaron's movie, he/she must be aware of his mastery in the use of the camera. The credit goes to lubezki for those long single shots which were so captivating. The intermittent use of music enhances the watching experience to a new level. What I personally loved about the movie, is how it ended. With the sense of desperation finally reaching a calm. Even though i watched it after ROMA, possibly the directors best work, yet I thoroughly enjoyed watching it.

There isn't much more to say, this film is boring from beginning to end. Nothing interesting happens. Sure, the idea of global infertility is an intriguing one and so is the idea of one single woman who after 18 years turns out to be pregnant, but this is simply not enough to make a movie.

When i saw the ad for Children Of Men i said to myself that I have got to see that film. Little did i know that it would be one of the most exciting films i would ever see! The plot is so different than any other film i have seen before. Children Of Men is set in the near future; which in my opinion is the most believable future set film to date. No disrespect to any other writers but some films would have flying crafts landing on buildings as a daily sighting in the middle of a spotless London. Alfonso Cuáron makes us believe that we are seeing the future. He adds a few futuristic features such as moving ads on the sides of buildings and buses and to add to the realism, there is rubbish on the streets. Cuáron delivers us breathtaking sequences such as the five minute long sequence which follows Theo trying to find Kay in a war stricken area. The tension is persistent in this movie. The escape from the farmhouse left me on the edge of my seat. Not only is the plot strong but the performances are as real as the setting. I think this is one of Clive Owens' best features and deservedly so. This is a movie worth watching.

I have to start out by saying that I expected this movie to be great. It had a unique subject (global human infertility) and it had a good cast. But somewhere in the middle of the movie, I realized that this wasn't entertaining me. Fine. So does it at least have a good message, or anything thought-provoking that might make it interesting? No. You see, after I saw that it was casting hippies and left-wing activists as the heroes, I realized that it was just more Hollywood trash. The last straw was when the illegal immigrants were taken to their refugee camp and some of them were being slain Auchwitz-style, and the banner over the door read "Homeland Security." There were more instances that I won't get into. You see, I hear enough Bush-sniping in the news and at school that I don't think that even my entertainment has to bombard me with this indirect Bush, Christians, and business are the devil baloney. If you're a liberal, this movie might inspire you. If you are a conservative like me who looks at the underlying messages in movies, it will likely annoy you. Neither of you will likely be entertained much though.
No words can decribe how amazing this movie is.love it

This film attempts to be smart and fails with shining stars. The direction is great, high quality actors, and a non-existent plot. Attempted metaphors (the name of the ship) are clunkily forced, and back story is delivered through the drug-induced ramblings of Michael Caine. There is no desire to sympathize with the characters, and the idea that the whole world has gone to hell with the exception of Great Britain is implausible. Amazing that Julian's terrorist group magically appeared at both Michael Caine's home as well as the obscure refugee camp at the end... How would they be able to know about either place? Caine gave no information before they executed him, yet there they were at the conclusion of the film.Imagine the "Wizard of Oz" stopping before Dorothy ever meets the wizard. The lion, the tin man, and the scarecrow are all killed off before she reaches the Emerald City; and the screen goes black, followed by "Wizard of Oz" in bold print. That's the final scene of this movie.

Review title: well- a very haunting piece of work
Review_body: well,I did like the film, especially the role of Michael Caine(I just like the guy)-good acting almost throughout actually,good camera-work too and great sites really. It is a very interesting piece of film,really,challenging- there's just one thing missing :The correlation of the whole story.If you've read the book may be then you might have the overview and see the connections. But if you didn't -you're pretty much thrown into the scenery not really getting the idea of a bigger interrelation .But may be you just go home and imagine it by yourself-somehow one just has to,it's such an arousing round dance of little sceneries that demand it, they're much to lovable to just let them stand alone,unlinked. The only thing one really knows for sure is that it is about that girl that has to be brought away(why?) and later it's her baby. But why all the rest is taking place is just not cutted out properly enough and there's a whole lot more going on here.- After all the film is much to haunting not to be enthralled by it.But still it remains -I am upset they didn't work the overall correlation a little more out- that's the only aggravation.

I can't believe this movie got an 8.1/10 rating from other IMDb users. It was so bad. The plot starts out promising and the opening cinematography is spectacular, but after that it just gets so ridiculous. The plot sucks and is full of holes. The ending is one big joke. Kee was terrible - I kept wishing she would die so that I wouldn't have to see her on screen anymore. Clive Owen did an okay job and Michael Caine was okay, but this was certainly no award-worthy performance.I watched Babel the next day, and it was way better than this. (Not that Babel deserved the high ratings it got either). Save your money and your time. Skip this movie.

Review title: What-would-be-when-it-would-be. Good idea, it's only that.. something is missing :(
Review_body: I do not know what the fuss about this movie was all about. I just returned from the cinema and I feel as I have just seen a mid-seventies Irish social drama; made entirely more like a social documentary than movie "with a message". I do however think it is truly realistic in the whole idea of "what-would-be-if-it-would-be", but nothing beyond that. Casting is excellent, Owen is *the* man for the role, the others are good as well, but there's nothing that leaves that stunning impression like in "Babel"- Since it is the AA-nominee, it is obvious why it is like that - I merely think that something is missing somewhere. The same as seeing "V for Vendetta" - the general idea is great it's just that I expected more. More story, more reasons, more who'n'why.. But there it is as it is.. Unfortunately. I don't think I'd have a wish seeing it on DVD in the near future. But that's just me.

Review title: Far better acted view of a dystopian future
Review_body: I don't think my comments contain spoilers,but here goes. Some of the pseudo-intellectuals posting seem to think that plot gets in the way of good movie making and that if you are left to supply what various elements of a virtually plot less exercise out of your own imagination, why this is the ultimate in movie making.I strongly disagree. A far better acted movie of a dystopian future exists. It is called BLADERUNNER. Bladerunner discusses the nature of existence, consciousness,the very idea of what it means to be human, and much more. Furthermore, it is also very violent, but not gratuitously so. Ample time is given the viewer to exercise his/her imagination. Perhaps this is why there are at least 8 different versions available.Feel free to contrast Rutger Hauer's performance on the roof of the Tyrrel building to any scene in this worthless piece of trash.I rest my case. To paraphrase one of the contributors, this movie is bloody awful.

Review title: Good movie...but nothing of other world
Review_body: In my country(as in many places of the world)when a compatriot excels in a department of science, entertainment,etc,his people praise him,celebrate his triumph's and is called "a national pride". This is the case of Alfonso Cuarón (and Iñarritu, del Toro and many more)who is very important for the Mexican critics.Unfortunately the national critics have to placed on top the patriotic pride to the cinematographic judgment and they have overrated Children of men because Cuaron directed it ("He's a Mexican, all his movies are masterpieces"they say).I'm Mexican, but I saw this movie as any movie, and I didn't matter who directed it(after all, the only thing that matters is the film's quality and not its director's nationality).Well, I think Children of men is a good movie,but is not excellent.It's not the masterpiece that the Mexican critics say is it.Personally, I liked it because is shocking,interesting, absorbing and very moving (I almost cried in the scene of childbirth).Good performances of Clive Owen (please, give him an Oscar!),Julianne Moore, Michael Caine (his role is very nice and funny, he made me smile)and Claire-Hope Ashitey.Good direction of Cuaron (I have to admit it)and a good and interesting plot (it's very worrisome the human infertility and the impossibility of procreate).But some things didn't like me so much:there's some crude violence and the ending cuts the movie in a sad indefinite point where I expected more scenes after that.If I was Cuaron, I will add a final scene where Theo is buried in a beautiful place and Kee thanks him all he did for her and her baby (well, I think that's not in the book, so finally I won't add it, but I will made a more definite ending!).If I have to describe this movie using one word, I would use "sad".I think Children of men must be nominate for the Oscar, because is a good movie, not a masterpiece, but a good movie after all.I don't know how could be completely ignored in the Golden Globes! Finally, I want ask you one thing:please, see this movie.

This was an excellent movie! Though very graphic, the camera-work and acting were extraordinary! The movie takes place in the future, and the viewer gets a sense of that, but it is not so far into the future that the viewer can not relate to it. The characters, too, are very relate-able. Children of Men uses very drab colors throughout the film, allowing the idea of a chaotic world to really sink in, but uses Kee as a hope for all within and without the movie.My one complaint is that the ending was cut too short. There was never that "just breathe" moment, and there truly should have been. I thought at first that the reel was being switched! This feeling should not have been left with the viewer.

I have to say that I was very disappointed in this film, though I had very high expectations. Clive Owen just doesn't do it in this one, It all just seems so phony, fake and sometimes even ridiculous. I just think this one tried a little too hard to be futuristic, but just didn't quite do it. It began really great, but it wasn't good enough to engage me for so long. However, there are a few good performances: Julianne Moore does a great job, so does legend Michael Caine, and they are really helping to raise the level of the film. I know it must be very hard to make a film that takes place in the future, but hey, War of the Worlds did it! Well, anyway, if you don't have anything better to do, you could see it. But I would rather recommend Dreamgirls or Rocky Balboa.

The makers of this movie went out of their way to remind viewers about Abu Graib and the war in Iraq.It was obvious they wanted to associate George Bush, America, with the bad guys. Images of 'Homeland Security'and the hooded man were clearly visible.To me these things added nothing to the movie so I assume the people that made it just wanted to use these images in the film to take yet another swipe at America.If the fanatics that this country is fighting win, there won't be anymore movies like this.

Review title: Not Deserving of its Present Rating
Review_body: After reading various reviews and seeing the previews, I was quite excited to see "Children of Men". Upon viewing the movie, however, I was unable to see why users were rating it so highly. I believe there is a predilection to highly rate any Futuristic Dystopia, as they graphically transport us to a time that we are ever so interested in -- our not-too-distant future. "Children of Men" does this better than most, since -- with the exception of the infertility theme -- it does not highly disconnect us from what our future is likely to be.Other than that, however, the movie lacks what it was claimed to be; it is not "Bladerunner" Redux -- not even close. The movie does not operate on multiple philosophical levels, and those attempting to dissect it are having difficulty not because it is especially deep, but because it lacks much beyond its initial layer. As a futuristic thriller (and very graphically violent, at that) it works marginally well, as there were a couple of moments when I felt my heart pitter-patter in that movie-theater way. Outside of that, there is not much going on here, besides the obvious: the world is going to hell and there are too many guns. Get on with it.

I loved this movie. It was incredibly sad, uplifting, funny, tragic...it took me through every human emotion possible. The acting, directing, and cinematography couldn't have been any better. I gave this movie a 10, which I never do because a movie can't be perfect. But this one is pretty darn close. I wouldn't change a thing about it. I saw it with my sister and she would have liked it to be more uplifting, especially at the end. The uplifting parts are more subtle because of the horrible surroundings, so I didn't mind this. I would compare this movie to War of the Worlds (the Tom Cruise version). So if you liked that movie, consider seeing this one. But if you didn't like WOTW, don't let that put you off seeing this one.

Review title: Pleasing to the eyes, nothing more.
Review_body: When i went to watch this movie i had a lot of expectations, since this was in Top 250 of the IMDb.I wont lie, i was very disappointed. This is a movie which will make you laugh, breath deep, breath in relief, and it is pleasing to the eyes as it has some action scenes with our main actor running in a middle of a small war, and some futuristic scenarios, but it has so much more to cover with this kind of argument... Really a pity. The history of secondary actors was more appealing and less explained then the ones from the main actors. Even the end of the movie could be a little more original, as it will be a remake of pretty much all the ends of these kind of movies.Children of Men will keep you interested during the movie, but will disappoint whoever goes to watch it expecting a story that will make him/her think about it in the future.
Quite slow, but nice plot. Loved the cinematics. The music was fitting, and I think the actors did a good joob.

Sorry, but this movie was flat-out awful. I absolutely hated it, as did the two others who watched it with me. Far and away, it was the worst movie I've ever seen. A total stinko. To make it even worse, Clive Owen, in my opinion, is the most unlikeable actor since Michael Caine. I can't believe that I wasted my time on this. And I can't believe that this is what people like in movies these days. This really shows you how far our cultural tastes have deteriorated during the past decade or so, which is why garbage such as this is continually forced on us rather than good, intelligent, meaningful, real-to-life drama, or movies that touch upon human emotion, moral values and lessons to be learned.

I got this the day it came out at Redbox. I was excited to see it and had the whole family around to watch it. If I was by myself I would have lasted 5 minutes but as a family we tried to stick it out. We lasted until Julianne Moore(?) got shot and we couldn't take it anymore. This movie was stupid and depressing and didn't make any sense. Did we see the same movie because I would never give this a 10 ever, ever, ever, ever. I was actually mad that I turned off the movie at 6:55, too late to avoid an extra dollar fee from Redbox. That was the worst $2 I've ever spent. I want my 1/2 hour back because this movie doesn't receive the praise it's been getting and I only watched it because of the praise. I should remember how much I hated Insomnia after it received tons of praise. Save your money even if its only $1 or $2

One of my friends had been telling me to watch Children of Men since it came out in December but I kept putting it off. I finally saw it today and it was in one word: Amazing! From Cuaron's 6-minute-long single shot to the very subtle Pink Floyd reference - the entire movie was amazingly well done. The Dystopian UK setting reminded me of A Clockwork Orange. The movie resonates the same level of brilliance as Kubrick's work. Clive Owen's acting is unparalleled - he brilliantly pulled off what seems to me to be a very challenging role. And Claire-Hope who played Kee did a very great job for a young newcomer. I'm amazed that this movie managed to miss the spotlight at the Oscars. Shame on the academy. Anyway, Insanely Well done Cuaron and co.!

A lot of people thought that getting the job of directing the third Harry Potter movie would be Alfonso Cuarón's big break. Yet oddly enough, this Mexican director's big break would not only come years later, it would also be one he made for himself. Children of Men is that big break.This movie is, without a doubt, n of the most "in your ace films" you will see all year. Cuarón made a decision about how he was going to present this film and did not look back. The environments are dirty and decaying, the people are all overshadowed by the hopelessness of their situation, and the only remaining signs of government we see are of the "mighty" English.Clive Owen plays a man who has given into this life and world and has ceased to care. He lives his life as though the events that unfold around him don't matter unless they directly affect them. Owen gives a great performance as the man who has given up to avoid pain, but is cast right back into life with the revelation that a young woman is pregnant.From there, Children takes off with the care and percussion of a director far more experienced then one would expect Cuarón to be. The action sequences in this film are amazing on their own, but become even better with the realization that a lot of them are done in long shots that go an ungodly amount of time without cutting. This film also contains (near its end) what may be the greatest urban combat sequence ever caught on film.However, for everything that is great about this film, there are also a lot of things wrong with it. For one, Cuarón takes a great deal of care to make things very real to the viewers. While not a bad thing in and of it self, it makes it annoying when he cuts out of a situation that is a major problem (a major medical operation that is handled in only a very few minutes and left unresolved by a cut to when it's all over) or has some implausible action scenes (the car rolling down the hill that the men on foot would have caught). Also, one too many sequences in this film are played for laughs. Cain's performance does not fall into the category, but chasing the car down the hill does. And finally, and this is really the big one, the movie is so sad and so depressing that by the end, you have either left or have made yourself indifferent to the death and violence as a way of coping. This films last few scenes display the problem as Cuarón tries for an emotional ending that I could not latch onto because of how damaged I already was.Despite its flaws, this really is one of the best films of the year.

I went into "Children of Men" expecting a very good movie. A friend told me it was one of the best movies he had seen all year (meaning 2006). Unfortunately, I was somewhat disappointed. While I didn't think the movie was bad, I don't see what the incredible hype is all about. I did think it was above average (hence why I gave it slightly better than a 5 rating), but it wasn't the type of film I would be truly excited to see again.On the plus side, the cinematography was excellent, and the war scenes/explosion scenes were top notch. I thought the one extended scene that Cuaron shot without a cut (which apparently cost $1 million to shoot) was incredible and the blood droplets that hit the camera added some realism to the shot in my opinion. I know some people have had mixed reviews on this scene, but I really enjoyed it and felt like I was really there running through the shrapnel and gunshots. I also thought the acting was quite good. Clive Owen was great, and I really enjoyed the quirky character that Michael Caine portrays. Julianne Moore was solid as well, although I don't understand why people are saying she deserves an Oscar nomination (she just isn't in enough of the movie to warrant that honor).Here is what I didn't like about the movie. First off, I felt like there were some things Cuaron (the director) was trying to say in his film that he decided to drive into the viewer's brain instead of being subtle about it. He names the xenophobic government's wing that wants to keep foreigners out of England "The Department of Homeland Security." Yes, Alfonso, we understand that you are making a point about treating aliens in a poor way. You didn't need to go that far and link it to America trying to keep illegal aliens from crossing the Mexican border to make said point. Also, the boat at the movie's end which is supposed to bring hope for the future is called (surprise!) "Tomorrow." If you are going to use that little subtlety, why not just name Kee's character Mary, her baby Jesus, and Theo's character Joseph? I feel like because of the message he is trying to get across to the audience, Cuaron gets a free pass in how he does it. I thought he could have gotten the point across in a much more subtle manner and not treated us like we couldn't understand simple symbolism. Granted some of this could have been taken directly from the novel, in which case my problem is more with the author than with Alfonso Cuaron.A few plot points also troubled me. I'm pretty confused as to how the group of anarchists keeps finding Kee and Theo throughout the film. Do they have some sort of tracking bug on them or something? Michael Caine's cabin is in the middle of the woods in a remote place that even the government doesn't know exists. How do these guys manage to find it? Then they somehow manage to find them again later on in a city of people who have been arrested and is filled with war zones? Give me a break! Also, why would the government be giving out suicide kits to citizens when the human race is slowly being diminished? Shouldn't they be trying to keep people alive for as long as possible to try and find a way to prolong the species? Perhaps the biggest problem I had was with the main point that we as human beings should take a look at where we are headed before it is too late. It is a very good message, but why does it make sense that if women are infertile, the world would fall into anarchy? Maybe I am just too optimistic, but I would think there would be more "The Human Project" stuff going on where countries tried to solve the problem and less total anarchy and violence. I just feel like there would be less war and more working together to discover what was wrong in a situation like this. I guess that is the main thing that troubled me about the story.In the end I would recommend a viewing of the movie as I thought its positives outweighed my problems with it. I just thought it could have been better.

I was very surprised to see the user ratings so high for this movie. I picked it up on DVD to watch one evening with the wife. She wanted to go to bed after about 30 minutes or so but stuck it out to the end. Sorry but we both didn't find it that great at all, slightly predictable and improbable in reality. Like one of the other reviews mentioned, "This is a pork chop labelled as a steak", spot on I think.The plus of it, the photography was very good indeed I think that's the one thing I noticed from the start. But the rest of it, the storyline and ending left us feeling somewhat cheated. No matter, thats just our opinion Like I said to my work colleagues, "Overrated in my opinion, but best they see it and decide for themselves."

Review title: Cuaron has created a masterpiece: brilliant and devastating
Review_body: Do you remember when a new Kubrick film came out, and it turned out to be "Dr. Strangelove" or "A Clockwork Orange?" When Altman was at his height in the 70's (or any one of a number of the finest directors from that time)? This film is one for the record books with all of its creators at the top of their game (and Lubezki certainly deserved the Oscar; he could be the Almendros of his generation). It propels the viewer right into the story (leaving clueless critics lamenting the "glossing over of many of the specifics" as they remain grotesquely obtuse to the clarity of the film's situation and the value of mystery and pace in a good story), but dwells on quiet and poignant angles and moments to reach into the deepest reservoirs of storytelling about our times. Just take one scene: the protagonist Theo (Clive Owen), fleeing the revolutionaries who had been his accomplices, works at finding a pair of shoes in the home of his friend Jasper (Michael Caine) and then happens upon a conversation between his fellow travelers and Jasper. He stays hidden on the other side of the room, and Alfonso Cuaron uses the entire space of the screen to tell Theo's story and his solitude; the lighting and mise en scène of the camera are nothing short of brilliant. The ensuing reels of film are among the most compelling and wrenching that I've ever witnessed; both my wife and I were brought to tears by the intensity of this film, and this almost never happens these days. So we flip in the DVD: oh, yeah, another movie. Whoop-de-doo. Oh, that performance sucks, he's just so, just so, uh, ... Can movies retain their importance, just as with any artistic medium of consequence? Can we be enveloped by their worlds, their messages, their moving tales and artistry?I hope so.

This plot is ridiculous. For some unexplained reason, all the women in Britain in 2027 are infertile. Or are all the men sterile? Is it a sperm-thing, an egg-thing, a uterus-thing, a vagina-thing? No one seems to know or care why, which doesn't inspire me to want to understand either.And all the other countries of the world are annihilated? Is that it? Again, no one seems to know or care, and I didn't either. Clive Owen sure didn't care about the plight of the world; he was just sucked into a chaotic and baffling activist-driven rescue mission, because he happens to be the former husband of Julianne Moore, who's in the movie for 15 minutes and hands the mantle of leadership over to Mr. Owen, who very reluctantly agrees to help. Not very convincing for the ostensible hero of a thriller movie.Really, he didn't seem to care about his character's plight, and this reflected poorly on the other actors, too. Even the female lead, newcomer Claire-Hope Ashitey, seemed to be sleep-walking through much of the scenes.This is the ultimate example of lazy writing. The screenwriter doesn't want to extend the energy to give a little context for his character's plight. The director plods them through all these ridiculous, long-winded conversations about their rescue mission, and the chases are unrealistic and boring. By the time they reached the end of their mission, everyone around me in the theater seemed to be appropriately confused and ready to ask for their money back.

It's an interesting premise and the future society, where Britain is practically the last nation still standing, is well realised. This should be a really good movie. But the leaden script, laden with exposition, and some truly bad acting in most of the supporting roles, combine to ruin this film. Claire-Hope Ashitey does well as a terrified young woman carrying the future of the world (literally), but Chiwetel Ejiofor and Peter Mullan, the best of the rest, have such dreadful roles, and everyone else delivers their lumpen lines with such lack of conviction that the whole thing sinks beneath their weight.As an example, a scene in which Theo, played by Clive Owen, realises that the young woman (Ashitey) he has promised to protect is being double-crossed by the people she trusts could have been achieved in about 30 seconds of screen time but instead it goes on for what feels like an eternity, clubbing the viewer over the head with exposition. "We killed ****!" "We're going to kill ******!" "Then we'll take over the world!" All that's missing is a "bwah hah hahhhhh!" and an evil twirl of the moustache from the villain of the piece.Very disappointing and not a little frustrating. In the hands of another director and a writer with less of a tin ear this could have been a gripping vision of a glimmer of hope in a future nightmare world.

I can't recommend this film more, it's probably the best film I've seen all year! It's one of the best sci-fi films ever made. There aren't any flaws at all. The acting is brilliant; Clive Owen gives what I think is his best performance, Michael Caine gives his funniest and most emotional, Chiwetel Ejiofor is amazing as always and Charlie Hunnam does that thing he did in Cold Mountain (but with a Geordie accent) and manages to scare the sh*t out of you. There are some genuine shocks in store. Thanks to Alfonso Cuaran's fantastic naturalistic camera-work, who should be nominated for an Oscar for this (but won't be), the violence becomes more brutal, the acting more powerful and the shocks are so realistic that you frequently feel as though you're watching real footage. Scenes such as the drive through the forest look so real that they are excruciatingly tense and absolutely terrifying to watch. Really, the thing I wanted to address about the film is THAT tracking shot. Totalling something ridiculous like seven minutes long, it is the best scene I have ever seen. It would be really good anyway because of the genius action scene going on. But considering it is a seven minute long uninterrupted tracking shot, it is so much more. So much happens in it, it must have been almost impossible to choreograph. Yet somehow, it looks so natural and fluid, it's almost like it wasn't practised prior to shooting it. I would pay the ticket price just for that scene. Well not really. Five pounds off peak to see a film? Bit steep.In conclusion, go see Children Of Men right now. It is one of the best films I've ever seen and I can't recommend it enough.

There are certain movies that come along every once and a while that you watch and then will almost do anything to get someone else to watch. The Children of Men falls under that category. With a blend of realism and fantasy that touches almost too closely on the "Yeah, that's how it'd be" part in us all. The direction is remarkable, the chase and action, perfect. But most importantly in any film it comes down to the story, and this film, does what any good film should do. It tells a compelling story that has you on the end of your seat with so many twists and turns you aren't sure just what might come around the corner next, but at the same time says something about the world we live in, about the human condition. But what makes this film rise above the rest, is that this story combined with great direction, the magnificent Michael Caine and Clive Owen, blended with great cinematography come together that leave you with the feeling that you have seen a slice of life and as a result, learning something and ultimately come out of the theater with a changed perspective a closer eye on the dirty ways of the world. And that is what a good film should do.

I usually never write reviews but after seeing this movie I felt compelled to do so. I was in the mood for a drama and had been hearing great things about this film since it first debuted. And let me say, this is one of the few films that actually makes you feel as if you are in the movie. The use of the freehand cam added a more realistic touch as well as a unique filming style. No wonder this film won an award for its cinematography. The storyline itself was executed quite well. The battle sequences are very real and at times graphic. The acting was great and the casting likewise. I found myself wanting more by the end of the movie which is usually a sign of a great film. This is definitely worth the price of a ticket. If you enjoy a good story and great acting then this is a must see!
